source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XII "Throw your coat down anywhere, Miss Baldwin," Wingate invited, as he ushered that young lady into his rooms soon after eleven o'clock on the following evening. "Now what can I give you? There are some sandwiches here--ham and pâté-de-foie-gras, I think. Whisky and soda or some hock?" "A pâté sandwich and some plain soda water, please," Sarah replied, taking off the long motoring coat which concealed her evening clothes. "I have been fined for everything except disorderly driving--daren't risk that. Thanks!" she went on. "What ripping sandwiches! And quite a good play, wasn't it?" "I am glad you enjoyed it." "It was a swindle Josephine not turning up," Sarah continued, as she stretched herself out in Wingate's easy-chair. "Domestic ructions again, I suppose. How I do hate that husband of hers!" "It was disappointing," he admitted. There was a brief pause, during which Sarah finished her sandwiches and lit a cigarette. "Wilshaw seems to be having a little trouble with the outside porter," her host remarked presently. "It must cost him at least half a sovereign every time I leave the cab," Sarah sighed. "How much do you make a week out of your driving, if it isn't too personal a question?" he enquired. "It depends upon how much Jimmy's got." "Is he your only client, then?" "He very seldom gives me a chance of another. Once or twice I've refused to be engaged by the day, but he sends his man around to the garage and I find him sitting in the cab when I arrive."


Q: Who did Wingate talk to?

A: Miss Baldwin||"Throw your coat down anywhere, Miss Baldwin," Wingate invited

Q: What is her first name?

A: Sarah||"A pâté sandwich and some plain soda water, please," Sarah replied

Q: Does she smoke?

A: Yes|| There was a brief pause, during which Sarah finished her sandwiches and lit a cigarette.

Q: When did this exchange happen?

A: soon after eleven o'clock||soon after eleven o'clock

Q: On the same evening?

A: No, the following evening. ||the following evening.

Q: Is Sarah old?

A: No, he ushered that young lady into his rooms||he ushered that young lady into his rooms

Q: Who didn't turn up?

A: Josephine||"It was a swindle Josephine not turning up,"

Q: What kind of chair was Sarah sitting on?

A: Wingate's easy-chair||she stretched herself out in Wingate's easy-chair.

Q: Why did Josephine not turn up?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: When did Sarah finish her sandwiches?

A: brief pause||There was a brief pause, during which Sarah finished her sandwiches

Q: Does Sarah like Josephine's husband?

A: No, How I do hate that husband of hers!" ||How I do hate that husband of hers!"

Q: Who is having trouble with the outside porter?

A: Wilshaw||"Wilshaw seems to be having a little trouble with the outside porter,"

Q: How much does it cost him?

A: at least half a sovereign||"It must cost him at least half a sovereign every time I leave the cab,"

Q: When what happens?

A: every time I leave the cab||"It must cost him at least half a sovereign every time I leave the cab,

Q: Does Wingate ask Sarah about money?

A: Yes||"How much do you make a week out of your driving, if it isn't too personal a question?" he enquired.

Q: Who does she mention in her reply?

A: Jimmy||"It depends upon how much Jimmy's got."

Q: Where can Sarah throw her coat?

A: anywhere||"Throw your coat down anywhere

Q: What kind of sandwiches are there?

A: -ham and pâté-de-foie-gras||There are some sandwiches here--ham and pâté-de-foie-gras


Summary: CHAPTER XII "Throw your coat down anywhere, Miss Baldwin," Wingate invited, as he ushered that young lady into his rooms soon after eleven o'clock on the following evening.There are some sandwiches here--ham and pâté-de-foie-gras, I think."A pâté sandwich and some plain soda water, please," Sarah replied, taking off the long motoring coat which concealed her evening clothes."It was a swindle Josephine not turning up," Sarah continued, as she stretched herself out in Wingate's easy-chair.How I do hate that husband of hers!"There was a brief pause, during which Sarah finished her sandwiches and lit a cigarette."Wilshaw seems to be having a little trouble with the outside porter," her host remarked presently."It must cost him at least half a sovereign every time I leave the cab," Sarah sighed."How much do you make a week out of your driving, if it isn't too personal a question?""It depends upon how much Jimmy's got."


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Pope Benedict XVI (; ; ; born Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger; ; born 16 April 1927) served as Pope from 2005 until his resignation in 2013. Benedict's election occurred in the 2005 papal conclave that followed the death of Pope John Paul II. Since his resignation, Benedict holds the title Pope Emeritus. Ordained as a priest in 1951 in his native Bavaria, Ratzinger established himself as a highly regarded university theologian by the late 1950s and was appointed a full professor in 1958. After a long career as an academic and professor of theology at several German universities, he was appointed Archbishop of Munich and Freising and Cardinal by Pope Paul VI in 1977, an unusual promotion for someone with little pastoral experience. In 1981, he was appointed Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, one of the most important dicasteries of the Roman Curia. From 2002 until his election as Pope, he was also Dean of the College of Cardinals. Prior to becoming Pope, he was "a major figure on the Vatican stage for a quarter of a century"; he had an influence "second to none when it came to setting church priorities and directions" as one of John Paul II's closest confidants.


Q: When did he resign?

A: in 2013||until his resignation in 2013

Q: What title does he hold?

A: Pope||Pope Benedict XVI

Q: What day of April was he born on?

A: the 16th||born 16 April

Q: What it his birthgiven middle name?

A: Aloisius||born Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger

Q: Who confided in him?

A: John Paul II||as one of John Paul II's closest confidant

Q: What was his first occupation outside of university?

A: Archbishop of Munich and Freising and Cardinal||After a long career as an academic and professor of theology at several German universities, he was appointed Archbishop of Munich and Freising and Cardinal

Q: Did he have a lot of experience as a pastor?

A: no, an unusual promotion for someone with little pastoral experience||an unusual promotion for someone with little pastoral experience

Q: What was his occupation immediately preceding his papacy?

A: theologian||a highly regarded university theologian

Q: How many years did he serve as pope?

A: Eight||served as Pope from 2005 until his resignation in 2013

Q: What is his native land?

A: Bavaria||in his native Bavaria

Q: Who was the pope prior to his papacy?

A: Pope John Paul II|| that followed the death of Pope John Paul II

Q: What year was he born?

A: 1927||born 16 April 1927

Q: And his last name?

A: Ratzinger||born Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger


Summary: Pope Benedict XVI (; ; ; born Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger; ; born 16 April 1927) served as Pope from 2005 until his resignation in 2013.Benedict's election occurred in the 2005 papal conclave that followed the death of Pope John Paul II.Ordained as a priest in 1951 in his native Bavaria, Ratzinger established himself as a highly regarded university theologian by the late 1950s and was appointed a full professor in 1958.After a long career as an academic and professor of theology at several German universities, he was appointed Archbishop of Munich and Freising and Cardinal by Pope Paul VI in 1977, an unusual promotion for someone with little pastoral experience.Prior to becoming Pope, he was "a major figure on the Vatican stage for a quarter of a century"; he had an influence "second to none when it came to setting church priorities and directions" as one of John Paul II's closest confidants.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER X CAUGHT IN A STORM "Did you ever know this Wilbur Poole, Dad?" questioned Ben. "Yes, I met him years ago at Aaron Poole's home. But of course he was in his right mind then. Poor chap! I pity him very much." "I think we all pity him," answered Dave. "Nobody can be responsible after his mind breaks down." "I feel sorry for Nat Poole and his folks," said Laura. "This will give them a great deal of trouble, not to mention the expense." "If Wilbur Poole was anywhere around Rayville it might pay to start a hunt for him," suggested Roger. "I don't think you'll find him anywhere around here," answered Mr. Basswood. "But it won't hurt to take a look around, if you boys care to take a walk." Ben's father went off to send his telegram to Aaron Poole, and all the boys set off on a hunt for the wild man. They covered the streets of the village and some of the roads on the outskirts, but without success. They met three people who had talked to the strange individual, and from what had passed Dave and his chums were sure that the man must have been Wilbur Poole. "I guess we'll have to give it up," said Phil, when it was getting late. "I'm tired out. And remember, fellows, we have a hard ride before us to-morrow if we expect to reach Carpen Falls in time to hit the trail for Bear Camp before it gets dark."


Q: Where did Ben's father meet Wilbur?

A: at Aaron Poole's home||at Aaron Poole's home

Q: How was Wilbur different at that time?

A: he was in his right mind|| he was in his right mind

Q: How many different Poole family members are mentioned?

A: Three||him years ago at Aaron Poole's home. But of course he was in his right mind then. Poor chap! I pity him very much." "I think we all pity him," answered Dave. "Nobody can be responsible after his mind breaks down." "I feel sorry for Nat Poole

Q: What were their names?

A: Aaron, Wilbur and Nat|| him years ago at Aaron Poole's home. But of course he was in his right mind then. Poor chap! I pity him very much." "I think we all pity him," answered Dave. "Nobody can be responsible after his mind breaks down." "I feel sorry for Nat Poole

Q: Does Mr. Basswood think Wilbur is nearby?

A: no, don't think you'll find him anywhere around here||don't think you'll find him anywhere around here

Q: Does he say they should not search nearby?

A: no, it won't hurt to take a look around|| it won't hurt to take a look around

Q: What does Ben's dad go to send?

A: a telegram|| telegram

Q: To whom?

A: Aaron Poole||Aaron Poole

Q: What do the boys do meanwhile?

A: set off on a hunt||set off on a hunt

Q: For whom?

A: the wild man|| the wild man

Q: Do they find him?

A: no, without success||without success

Q: Do they find any sign that he has been there?

A: yes|| three people who had talked to the strange individua

Q: What sign?

A: three people who had talked to him||three people who had talked to the strange individual

Q: When do they stop the search?

A: when it was getting late||when it was getting late

Q: Whose idea was that?

A: Phil|| Phil

Q: Why does he want to stop?

A: he's tired||"I'm tired out

Q: Do they have plans for the next day?

A: yes|| a hard ride before us to-morrow

Q: What will they do?

A: ride to Carpen Falls|| a hard ride before us to-morrow if we expect to reach Carpen Falls

Q: Will it be a short and easy trip there?

A: no, a hard ride||a hard ride

Q: What do they want to do when they arrive there?

A: hit the trail for Bear Camp||hit the trail for Bear Camp


Summary: "Yes, I met him years ago at Aaron Poole's home.But of course he was in his right mind then."I don't think you'll find him anywhere around here," answered Mr. Basswood."But it won't hurt to take a look around, if you boys care to take a walk."Ben's father went off to send his telegram to Aaron Poole, and all the boys set off on a hunt for the wild man.They covered the streets of the village and some of the roads on the outskirts, but without success.They met three people who had talked to the strange individual, and from what had passed Dave and his chums were sure that the man must have been Wilbur Poole."I guess we'll have to give it up," said Phil, when it was getting late."I'm tired out.And remember, fellows, we have a hard ride before us to-morrow if we expect to reach Carpen Falls in time to hit the trail for Bear Camp before it gets dark."


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

A thorough understanding of adolescence in society depends on information from various perspectives, including psychology, biology, history, sociology, education, and anthropology. Within all of these perspectives, adolescence is viewed as a transitional period between childhood and adulthood, whose cultural purpose is the preparation of children for adult roles. It is a period of multiple transitions involving education, training, employment and unemployment, as well as transitions from one living circumstance to another. Puberty occurs through a long process and begins with a surge in hormone production, which in turn causes a number of physical changes. It is the stage of life characterized by the appearance and development of secondary sex characteristics (for example, a deeper voice and larger adam's apple in boys, and development of breasts and more curved and prominent hips in girls) and a strong shift in hormonal balance towards an adult state. This is triggered by the pituitary gland, which secretes a surge of hormonal agents into the blood stream, initiating a chain reaction to occur. The male and female gonads are subsequently activated, which puts them into a state of rapid growth and development; the triggered gonads now commence the mass production of the necessary chemicals. The testes primarily release testosterone, and the ovaries predominantly dispense estrogen. The production of these hormones increases gradually until sexual maturation is met. Some boys may develop gynecomastia due to an imbalance of sex hormones, tissue responsiveness or obesity.


Q: What connect childhood and adulthood?

A: adolescence||A thorough understanding of adolescence in society depends on information from various perspectives, including psychology, biology, history, sociology, education, and anthropology. Within all of these perspectives, adolescence is viewed as a transitional period between childhood and adulthood, whose cultural purpose is the preparation of children for adult roles. It is a period of multiple transitions involving education, training, employment and unemployment, as well as transitions from one living circumstance to another.

Q: What one word best describes it?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: What non-biological purpose does it have?

A: cultural||Within all of these perspectives, adolescence is viewed as a transitional period between childhood and adulthood, whose cultural purpose is the preparation of children for adult roles.

Q: What's the long biological process that happens during it?

A: puberty||Puberty occurs through a long process and begins with a surge in hormone production,

Q: What develops during this?

A: secondary sex characeristics|| It is the stage of life characterized by the appearance and development of secondary sex characteristics (for example, a deeper voice and larger adam's apple in boys, and development of breasts and more curved and prominent hips in girls)

Q: What's an example?

A: a deeper voice in boys||for example, a deeper voice and larger adam's apple in boys, and development of breasts and more curved and prominent hips in girls)

Q: What causes these developments?

A: the pituitary gland||This is triggered by the pituitary gland,

Q: What does the pituitary gland alter?

A: the male and female gonads||. The male and female gonads are subsequently activated,

Q: What alters those?

A: hormonal agents|| This is triggered by the pituitary gland, which secretes a surge of hormonal agents into the blood stream, initiating a chain reaction to occur

Q: What can happen if the balance of those agents change too much?

A: gynecomastia||Some boys may develop gynecomastia due to an imbalance of sex hormones, tissue responsiveness or obesity.

Q: What else can cause that?

A: tissue responsiveness or obesity||tissue responsiveness or obesity.

Q: What carries the hormones?

A: the testes and the ovaries||The testes primarily release testosterone, and the ovaries predominantly dispense estrogen.


Summary: A thorough understanding of adolescence in society depends on information from various perspectives, including psychology, biology, history, sociology, education, and anthropology.Within all of these perspectives, adolescence is viewed as a transitional period between childhood and adulthood, whose cultural purpose is the preparation of children for adult roles.Puberty occurs through a long process and begins with a surge in hormone production, which in turn causes a number of physical changes.It is the stage of life characterized by the appearance and development of secondary sex characteristics (for example, a deeper voice and larger adam's apple in boys, and development of breasts and more curved and prominent hips in girls) and a strong shift in hormonal balance towards an adult state.This is triggered by the pituitary gland, which secretes a surge of hormonal agents into the blood stream, initiating a chain reaction to occur.The male and female gonads are subsequently activated, which puts them into a state of rapid growth and development; the triggered gonads now commence the mass production of the necessary chemicals.The testes primarily release testosterone, and the ovaries predominantly dispense estrogen.Some boys may develop gynecomastia due to an imbalance of sex hormones, tissue responsiveness or obesity.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XX. Moving against Captain Grady Both Paul and Chet Winthrop were deeply interested in the words uttered by Jeff Jones, the colored member of the horse thieves' gang. "So you know something of Captain Grady and our uncle, Barnaby Winthrop?" cried Chet, excitedly. "What do you know?" "Dat's fer you two fellers ter find out--onless yer let's me go," replied Jeff Jones, suggestively. "You mean you won't speak unless we grant you your liberty?" put in Paul. "Dat's de way to figure it." Paul looked at Chet inquiringly. "We can't promise anything until Mr. Dottery gets back," said Chet. "But if you know anything about our uncle you had better speak out, if you wish us to do anything at all for you." "I won't say a word," growled the colored man. Chet bit his lip in vexation. "Don't you know what it is to have us able to speak a word for you?" said Paul. "Supposing we let Jack Blowfen take you over to the next camp and tell the men that you are a downright horse thief? Would you fancy that?" Jeff Jones began to tremble. He knew what Paul meant--that he would be lynched inside the hour. In that section of the country, at that time, horse stealing was considered almost as bad as murder. "No! no! doan let him take me down ter de Fork!" howled Jeff Jones. "Anyt'ing but dat, boys!" "Well, you, had better talk, then," returned Paul, severely. "I doan know much, but I'll tell yo' all I do know," said the prisoner, after a short pause, "and yo' is ter do de best yo' can fo' me, promise me dat?"


Q: Who is the colored man?

A: Jeff Jones||Jeff Jones

Q: What was he doing?

A: Stealing horses||member of the horse thieves' gang

Q: How many people is he with?

A: two||Paul and Chet Winthrop

Q: Who?

A: Paul and Chet Winthrop||Paul and Chet Winthrop

Q: What were they doing together?

A: interested in him||interested in the words

Q: Why?

A: he knew Captain Grady||know something of Captain Grady

Q: Was he cooperating?

A: no, you won't speak unless we grant you your liberty||you won't speak unless we grant you your liberty

Q: Why not?

A: wnated liberty||onless yer let's me go

Q: Did he get it?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: Was he threatened?

A: yes||let Jack Blowfen take you over to the next camp and tell the men that you are a downright horse thief

Q: In what way?

A: tell the men that he is a downright horse thief||over to the next camp and tell the men that you are a downright horse thief

Q: Did that work?

A: yes||Jeff Jones began to tremble

Q: What did he tell them?

A: told all he knew||but I'll tell yo' all I do know

Q: Did he have any conditions on his cooperation?

A: yes||do de best yo' can fo' me

Q: What's that?

A: best they can do for him||yo' is ter do de best yo' can fo' me


Summary: CHAPTER XX.Moving against Captain Grady Both Paul and Chet Winthrop were deeply interested in the words uttered by Jeff Jones, the colored member of the horse thieves' gang."So you know something of Captain Grady and our uncle, Barnaby Winthrop?""Dat's fer you two fellers ter find out--onless yer let's me go," replied Jeff Jones, suggestively."You mean you won't speak unless we grant you your liberty?""Supposing we let Jack Blowfen take you over to the next camp and tell the men that you are a downright horse thief?He knew what Paul meant--that he would be lynched inside the hour."I doan know much, but I'll tell yo' all I do know," said the prisoner, after a short pause, "and yo' is ter do de best yo' can fo' me, promise me dat?"


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

The Federal City of Bonn () is a city on the banks of the Rhine in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia, with a population of over 300,000. About south-southeast of Cologne, Bonn is in the southernmost part of the Rhine-Ruhr region, Germany's largest metropolitan area, with over 11 million inhabitants. Together with the capital Berlin, the city is the "de facto" joint seat of government of Germany. Bonn is the secondary seat of the President, the Chancellor, the Bundesrat and the primary seat of six federal government ministries and twenty federal authorities. The title of Federal City () reflects its important political status within Germany. Founded in the 1st century BC as a Roman settlement, Bonn is one of Germany's oldest cities. From 1597 to 1794, Bonn was the capital of the Electorate of Cologne, and residence of the Archbishops and Prince-electors of Cologne. Composer Ludwig van Beethoven was born in Bonn in 1770. From 1949 to 1990, Bonn was the provisional capital ("temporary seat of the Federal institutions") of West Germany, and Germany's present constitution, the Basic Law, was declared in the city in 1949. From 1990 to 1999, Bonn served as the seat of government – but no longer capital – of reunited Germany.


Q: What has a population of over 300,000

A: The Federal City of Bonn||The Federal City of Bonn () is a city on the banks of the Rhine in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia

Q: Where is it located?

A: on the banks of the Rhine||on the banks of the Rhine in the German state of North Rhine-

Q: In what land zone?

A: the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia||the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia

Q: Is it in the northernmost zone?

A: no, the southernmost ||the southernmost

Q: What is it, then?

A: southernmost||southernmost

Q: Does it house 10 million people?

A: no, with over 11 million inhabitants||with over 11 million inhabitants

Q: How many?

A: over 11 million||over 11 million inhabitants.

A: Bonn is a city. Do you mean in Germany?||The Federal City of Bonn () is a city

Summary: The Federal City of Bonn () is a city on the banks of the Rhine in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia, with a population of over 300,000.About south-southeast of Cologne, Bonn is in the southernmost part of the Rhine-Ruhr region, Germany's largest metropolitan area, with over 11 million inhabitants.Together with the capital Berlin, the city is the "de facto" joint seat of government of Germany.Bonn is the secondary seat of the President, the Chancellor, the Bundesrat and the primary seat of six federal government ministries and twenty federal authorities.The title of Federal City () reflects its important political status within Germany.Founded in the 1st century BC as a Roman settlement, Bonn is one of Germany's oldest cities.Composer Ludwig van Beethoven was born in Bonn in 1770.From 1949 to 1990, Bonn was the provisional capital ("temporary seat of the Federal institutions") of West Germany, and Germany's present constitution, the Basic Law, was declared in the city in 1949.From 1990 to 1999, Bonn served as the seat of government – but no longer capital – of reunited Germany.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER II. ON A MOUNTAIN PATH "Armed men, my lords!" had been Fanfulla's cry. "We are betrayed!" They looked at one another with stern eyes, and with that grimness that takes the place which fear would hold in meaner souls. Then Aquila rose slowly to his feet, and with him rose the others, looking to their weapons. He softly breathed a name--"Masuccio Torri." "Aye," cried Lodi bitterly, "would that we had heeded your warning! Masuccio it will be, and at his heels his fifty mercenaries." "Not less, I'll swear, by the sound of them," said Ferrabraccio. "And we but six, without our harness." "Seven," the Count laconically amended, resuming his hat and loosening his sword in its scabbard. "Not so, my lord," exclaimed Lodi, laying a hand upon the Count's arm. "You must not stay with us. You are our only hope--the only hope of Babbiano. If we are indeed betrayed--though by what infernal means I know not--and they have knowledge that six traitors met here to-night to conspire against the throne of Gian Maria, at least, I'll swear, it is not known that you were to have met us. His Highness may conjecture, but he cannot know for sure, and if you but escape, all may yet he well--saving with us, who matter not. Go, my lord! Remember your promise to seek at your cousin's hand the gonfalon, and may God and His blessed Saints prosper your Excellency." The old man caught the young man's hand, and bending his head until his face was hidden in his long white hair, he imprinted a kiss of fealty upon it. But Aquila was not so easily to be dismissed.


Q: who rose to his feet?

A: Aquila||Then Aquila rose slowly to his feet,

Q: whose name did he mutter?

A: "Masuccio Torri."|| breathed a name--"Masuccio Torri."

Q: how many men were coming for them?

A: 50.||his fifty mercenaries."

Q: how many were prepared to defend, including the Count?

A: Seven.||Seven," the Count laconically amended

Q: what did Fanfulla cry out?

A: "Armed men, my lords!||"Armed men, my lords!

Q: what else did he say?

A: "We are betrayed!"||"We are betrayed!"

Q: who grabbed the Count's arm?

A: Lodi.||"Not so, my lord," exclaimed Lodi, laying a hand upon the Count's arm.

Q: what did the Count loosen?

A: His sword in its scabbard.||"Seven," the Count laconically amended, resuming his hat and loosening his sword in its scabbard.

Q: did Lodi want him to stay?

A: No.||"You must not stay with us.

Q: why not?

A: He was their only hope.||You are our only hope

Q: what was he the only hope of?

A: Babbiano.||-the only hope of Babbiano.

Q: what were the six men conspiring against?

A: The throne of Gian Maria.||that six traitors met here to-night to conspire against the throne of Gian Maria,

Q: who swore to say that the count hadn't met them?

A: Lodi.||, I'll swear, it is not known that you were to have met us.


Summary: ON A MOUNTAIN PATH "Armed men, my lords!""We are betrayed!"Then Aquila rose slowly to his feet, and with him rose the others, looking to their weapons.He softly breathed a name--"Masuccio Torri."Masuccio it will be, and at his heels his fifty mercenaries.""Seven," the Count laconically amended, resuming his hat and loosening his sword in its scabbard."Not so, my lord," exclaimed Lodi, laying a hand upon the Count's arm."You must not stay with us.You are our only hope--the only hope of Babbiano.If we are indeed betrayed--though by what infernal means I know not--and they have knowledge that six traitors met here to-night to conspire against the throne of Gian Maria, at least, I'll swear, it is not known that you were to have met us.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XVII. DEFEAT. A grey dimness was creeping in upon the schooner when a little bitter breeze sprang up from westwards, and Dampier bade them get the mainsail on to her. "I don't like the look of the weather, and I'm beginning to feel that I'd like to see that boat," he said. "Anyhow, we'll get way on her." It was a relief to hoist the mainsail. The work put a little warmth into them, and the white men, at least, had been conscious of a growing uneasiness about their comrades in the boat. The breeze had, however, freshened before they set it, and there were white caps on the water when the _Selache_ headed for the ice. It had somewhat changed its formation when they approached it, for big masses had become detached from it and were moving out into the open water, while the opening had become perceptibly narrower. The light was now fading rapidly, and Wyllard took the wheel when Dampier sent the man there forward. "Get the cover off the second boat, and see everything clear for hoisting out," he said to him, and then called to Wyllard. "We're close enough. You'd better heave her round." She came round with a thrashing of canvas, stretched out seawards, and came back again with her deck sharply slanted and little puffs of bitter spray blowing over her weather rail, for there was no doubt that the breeze was freshening fast. Then Dampier sent a man up into the foremast shrouds, and looked at Wyllard afterwards.


Q: What was heading towards the boat?

A: a grey dimness||A grey dimness was creeping in upon the schooner

Q: What came from the west?

A: a bitter breeze||a little bitter breeze sprang up from westwards

Q: Who gave some orders?

A: Dampier||Dampier bade them get the mainsail on to her

Q: What did he want done?

A: get the mainsail on||Dampier bade them get the mainsail on to her

Q: Did he feel good about the weather?

A: no, "I don't like the look of the weather||"I don't like the look of the weather

Q: What did he want to see?

A: that boat|| I'd like to see that boat

Q: What did they put up?

A: the mainsail||It was a relief to hoist the mainsail

Q: How did doing this make them feel?

A: a little warm||The work put a little warmth into them

Q: What was on the water?

A: white caps||there were white caps on the water

Q: Where were they headed?

A: for the ice|| when the _Selache_ headed for the ice

Q: What was the name of their vessel?

A: the Selache||the _Selache_

Q: What had happened to the ice?

A: It had changed||It had somewhat changed its formation when they approached it

Q: How had it changed?

A: big masses became detached|| big masses had become detached from it

Q: Where were they headed?

A: open water||were moving out into the open water

Q: Was it getting darker?

A: yes|| The light was now fading rapidly

Q: Who took control of the ship?

A: Wyllard|| Wyllard took the wheel when Dampier

Q: And what did Dampier do?

A: sent the man forward||Dampier sent the man there forward

Q: What did he want them to uncover?

A: the second boat||Get the cover off the second boat

Q: And who did he speak to?

A: Wyllard||then called to Wyllard

Q: What did he order him to do?

A: heave the boat around||You'd better heave her round


Summary: A grey dimness was creeping in upon the schooner when a little bitter breeze sprang up from westwards, and Dampier bade them get the mainsail on to her."I don't like the look of the weather, and I'm beginning to feel that I'd like to see that boat," he said.It was a relief to hoist the mainsail.The work put a little warmth into them, and the white men, at least, had been conscious of a growing uneasiness about their comrades in the boat.The breeze had, however, freshened before they set it, and there were white caps on the water when the _Selache_ headed for the ice.It had somewhat changed its formation when they approached it, for big masses had become detached from it and were moving out into the open water, while the opening had become perceptibly narrower.The light was now fading rapidly, and Wyllard took the wheel when Dampier sent the man there forward."Get the cover off the second boat, and see everything clear for hoisting out," he said to him, and then called to Wyllard.You'd better heave her round."


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Multimedia is content that uses a combination of different content forms such as text, audio, images, animations, video and interactive content. Multimedia contrasts with media that use only rudimentary computer displays such as text-only or traditional forms of printed or hand-produced material. Multimedia can be recorded and played, displayed, interacted with or accessed by information content processing devices, such as computerized and electronic devices, but can also be part of a live performance. Multimedia devices are electronic media devices used to store and experience multimedia content. Multimedia is distinguished from mixed media in fine art; for example, by including audio it has a broader scope. The term "rich media" is synonymous with interactive multimedia. The term "multimedia" was coined by singer and artist Bob Goldstein (later 'Bobb Goldsteinn') to promote the July 1966 opening of his "LightWorks at L'Oursin" show at Southampton, Long Island. Goldstein was perhaps aware of an American artist named Dick Higgins, who had two years previously discussed a new approach to art-making he called "intermedia". On August 10, 1966, Richard Albarino of "Variety" borrowed the terminology, reporting: "Brainchild of songscribe-comic Bob ('Washington Square') Goldstein, the 'Lightworks' is the latest "multi-media" music-cum-visuals to debut as discothèque fare." Two years later, in 1968, the term "multimedia" was re-appropriated to describe the work of a political consultant, David Sawyer, the husband of Iris Sawyer—one of Goldstein's producers at L'Oursin.


Q: What can be recorded and played?

A: Multimedia||Multimedia can be recorded and played

Q: What else can it be

A: interacted with||Multimedia can be recorded and played, displayed, interacted with

Q: Anything else?

A: accessed by information content processing devices||Multimedia can be recorded and played, displayed, interacted with or accessed by information content processing devices

Q: Who coined the term?

A: Bob Goldstein||The term "multimedia" was coined by singer and artist Bob Goldstein

Q: When?

A: July 1966||to promote the July 1966

Q: Who is that?

A: a singer and artist||singer and artist Bob Goldstein

Q: Where was his show?

A: Southampton, Long Island||show at Southampton, Long Island

Q: What was the show called?

A: "LightWorks at L'Oursin"||his "LightWorks at L'Oursin" show

Q: What is Multimedia?

A: content that uses a combination of different content forms||Multimedia is content that uses a combination of different content forms

Q: What kinds of forms?

A: text, audio, images, animations, video and interactive content.||content forms such as text, audio, images, animations, video and interactive content.

Q: What does it contrast with?

A: media that use only rudimentary computer displays||Multimedia contrasts with media that use only rudimentary computer displays

Q: What is used to store multimedia?

A: Multimedia devices||Multimedia devices are electronic media devices used to store and experience multimedia

Q: What is synonymous with interactive multimedia?

A: "rich media"||"rich media" is synonymous with interactive multimedia.

Q: Who was Goldstein aware of

A: Dick Higgins||Goldstein was perhaps aware of an American artist named Dick Higgins

Q: What did he call his approach?

A: "intermedia".||who had two years previously discussed a new approach to art-making he called "intermedia".

Q: Was he American?

A: yes||American artist named Dick Higgins

Q: Who borrowed the term

A: Richard Albarino||Richard Albarino of "Variety" borrowed the terminology

Q: What magazine did he write for?

A: "Variety"||Richard Albarino of "Variety"

Q: When did he write an article about Bob

A: August 10, 1966,||On August 10, 1966,

Q: Who was one of Bob's producers?

A: Iris Sawyer||Iris Sawyer—one of Goldstein's producers


Summary: Multimedia is content that uses a combination of different content forms such as text, audio, images, animations, video and interactive content.Multimedia contrasts with media that use only rudimentary computer displays such as text-only or traditional forms of printed or hand-produced material.Multimedia can be recorded and played, displayed, interacted with or accessed by information content processing devices, such as computerized and electronic devices, but can also be part of a live performance.Multimedia devices are electronic media devices used to store and experience multimedia content.The term "rich media" is synonymous with interactive multimedia.The term "multimedia" was coined by singer and artist Bob Goldstein (later 'Bobb Goldsteinn') to promote the July 1966 opening of his "LightWorks at L'Oursin" show at Southampton, Long Island.Goldstein was perhaps aware of an American artist named Dick Higgins, who had two years previously discussed a new approach to art-making he called "intermedia".On August 10, 1966, Richard Albarino of "Variety" borrowed the terminology, reporting: "Brainchild of songscribe-comic Bob ('Washington Square') Goldstein, the 'Lightworks' is the latest "multi-media" music-cum-visuals to debut as discothèque fare."Two years later, in 1968, the term "multimedia" was re-appropriated to describe the work of a political consultant, David Sawyer, the husband of Iris Sawyer—one of Goldstein's producers at L'Oursin.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXVIII. A MEETING. About a week after the dissolution of the Crooked Creek Company, Harry was riding over from Hetertown, and had nearly reached the creek on his way home, when he met George Purvis. This was their first meeting since their fight, for George had been away on a visit to some relatives in Richmond. When Harry saw George riding slowly toward him, he felt very much embarrassed, and very much annoyed because he was embarrassed. How should he meet George? What should he say; or should he say anything? He did not want to appear anxious to "make up" with him, nor did he want to seem as if he bore malice toward him. If he only knew how George felt about it! As it was, he wished he had stopped somewhere on the road. He had thought of stopping at the mill--why had he not? That would just have given George time to pass. Both boys appeared to be riding as slowly as their horses would consent to go, and yet when they met, Harry had not half made up his mind what he would say, or how he should say it, or whether it would be better or not to say anything. "Hello, George!" said he, quite unpremeditatedly. "Hello!" said George, reining in his horse "Where are you going?" "Going home," said Harry, also stopping in the road. Thus the quarrel came to an end. "So you've sold the telegraph?" said George. "Yes," said Harry. "And I think we made a pretty good bargain. I didn't think we'd do so well when we started."


Q: what company disolved

A: the Crooked Creek Company|| the Crooked Creek Company

Q: who did harry meet

A: George Purvis.||George Purvis.

Q: did they have a fight

A: Yes.|| their fight,

Q: who said hello first

A: Harry||"Hello, George!" said he

Q: was he embarrassed

A: Yes.||he felt very much embarrassed

Q: what town was harry riding from

A: Hetertown||Hetertown

Q: how fast were they riding

A: as slowly as their horses would consent to go||as slowly as their horses would consent to go

Q: how long had it been since the company dissolved

A: About a week||About a week

Q: who was going home

A: harry||on his way home

Q: did the fight end

A: Yes.||the quarrel came to an end.

Q: did george sell the telegraph

A: No.||Yes," said Harry

Q: who did

A: Harry||Harry

Q: did he get a good deal

A: Yes.||we made a pretty good bargain.

Q: who did george visit after the fight

A: relatives in Richmond.||relatives in Richmond.

Q: was harry certain of harrys feelings about the argument

A: No.||If he only knew how George felt about it!

Q: Did Harry stop at the mill

A: No.||why had he not

Q: who stopped first

A: George|| George

Q: who was annoyed

A: Harry||Harry

Q: was harry anxious

A: unknown||unknown

Q: what were they riding

A: horses||horses


Summary: CHAPTER XXVIII.About a week after the dissolution of the Crooked Creek Company, Harry was riding over from Hetertown, and had nearly reached the creek on his way home, when he met George Purvis.This was their first meeting since their fight, for George had been away on a visit to some relatives in Richmond.When Harry saw George riding slowly toward him, he felt very much embarrassed, and very much annoyed because he was embarrassed.If he only knew how George felt about it!That would just have given George time to pass.Both boys appeared to be riding as slowly as their horses would consent to go, and yet when they met, Harry had not half made up his mind what he would say, or how he should say it, or whether it would be better or not to say anything.said he, quite unpremeditatedly.said George, reining in his horse "Where are you going?""So you've sold the telegraph?""And I think we made a pretty good bargain.I didn't think we'd do so well when we started."

source: race

A team of British surgeons has carried out Gaza's first organ transplants for a long-term plan to train local medical staff to perform the operations. Two patients underwent kidney transplants at the Shifa, Gaza's biggest public hospital. The operations were conducted a fortnight ago by a volunteer medical team from the Royal Liverpool hospital. Ziad Matouk, 42, was born with one kidney and was diagnosed with renal failure several years ago. Matouk, whose wife donated one of her kidneys, hopes to return to his job within six months. The couple had sought a transplant in Cairo, but were rejected as unsuitable at a state hospital and could not afford the fee at a private hospital. "We were desperate," said Matouk. The UK-Gaza link-up began about a year ago after Abdelkader Hammad, a doctor at the Royal Liverpool hospital, was contacted by an anaesthetist at the Shifa, who outlined the difficulties the Gaza hospital was facing with dialysis . The Shifa is forced to rely on generators because of power cuts; spare parts for its ageing dialysis machines have been difficult to import; and supplies of consumables are often scarce. After an exploratory trip last April, Hammad---whose family is Palestinian---and three colleagues from Liverpool arrived in Gaza via Egypt last month, bringing specialist equipment. Two patients were selected for surgery. The first, Mohammed Duhair, 42, received a kidney donated by his younger brother in a six-hour operation. Two days later, Matouk received a transplant after his wife, Nadia, 36, was found to be a good match. The surgeon was carried out by the British team, assisted by doctors and nurses from the Shifa. "We are very satisfied with the results," said Sobbi Skaik, head of surgery at the Gaza hospital. Skaik hopes that Gaza medical teams will eventually carry out kidney transplants independently, and that other organ transplants may follow. The Shifa is working with the Gaza ministry of health on a plan to train its doctors, surgeons, nursing staff and laboratory technicians in transplant surgery at the Royal Liverpool. "Funding is a problem," said Hammad. "In the meantime we'll go back as volunteers to Gaza for the next couple of years to do more transplants." The Liverpool team's next visit is scheduled for May.


Q: What is Adbelkader Hammad's job?

A: doctor||doctor

Q: Where does he work?

A: at the Royal Liverpool hospital||at the Royal Liverpool hospital

Q: Where is his family from?

A: Palestine||Palestinian

Q: What did he and other doctors do for the first time?

A: They carried out Gaza's first organ transplants||carried out Gaza's first organ transplants

Q: On how many people?

A: Two||Two patients

Q: What organs did they transplant?

A: kidneys||kidney

Q: Were they donated by strangers or family?

A: family||The first, Mohammed Duhair, 42, received a kidney donated by his younger brother in a six-hour operation. Two days later, Matouk received a transplant after his wife, Nadia

Q: What were the names of the patients?

A: Mohammed Duhair and Ziad Matouk||Mohammed Duhair, 42, received a kidney donated by his younger brother in a six-hour operation. Two days later, Matouk

A: six hours||six-hour operation

A: yes||"We are very satisfied with the results,"

Q: What does Skaik hope?

A: that Gaza medical teams do independent kidney transplants, and possibly other organs||that Gaza medical teams will eventually carry out kidney transplants independently, and that other organ transplants may follow

Q: What is an issue that complicates this?

A: Funding||Funding

A: They will go back as volunteers to Gaza to do more transplants||go back as volunteers to Gaza

A: May||May

A: a fortnight ago||a fortnight ago

A: less than six months||six months

Q: How old is he?

A: 42||42,

Q: What about the other patient?

A: 42||42

A: 36||36

Q: Was she a match?

A: yes||a good match


Summary: A team of British surgeons has carried out Gaza's first organ transplants for a long-term plan to train local medical staff to perform the operations.Two patients underwent kidney transplants at the Shifa, Gaza's biggest public hospital.The operations were conducted a fortnight ago by a volunteer medical team from the Royal Liverpool hospital.Ziad Matouk, 42, was born with one kidney and was diagnosed with renal failure several years ago.Matouk, whose wife donated one of her kidneys, hopes to return to his job within six months.The UK-Gaza link-up began about a year ago after Abdelkader Hammad, a doctor at the Royal Liverpool hospital, was contacted by an anaesthetist at the Shifa, who outlined the difficulties the Gaza hospital was facing with dialysis .After an exploratory trip last April, Hammad---whose family is Palestinian---and three colleagues from Liverpool arrived in Gaza via Egypt last month, bringing specialist equipment.The first, Mohammed Duhair, 42, received a kidney donated by his younger brother in a six-hour operation.Two days later, Matouk received a transplant after his wife, Nadia, 36, was found to be a good match.The surgeon was carried out by the British team, assisted by doctors and nurses from the Shifa."We are very satisfied with the results," said Sobbi Skaik, head of surgery at the Gaza hospital.Skaik hopes that Gaza medical teams will eventually carry out kidney transplants independently, and that other organ transplants may follow."Funding is a problem," said Hammad."In the meantime we'll go back as volunteers to Gaza for the next couple of years to do more transplants."


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: race

While you are in trouble, what are you going to do? What? Cry? Or escape? Those are all the wrong way! Robinson Crusoe can tell you the right answer! It is an exciting story: Robinson Crusoe hated the comfortable life in his home town. So, he want to be a seaman and travelled around the world. But one day, a terrible thing happened. A great storm came and their boat crashed! No one was alive in this accident except Robinson. He was the luckiest man in the world--Because all his friends were dead but he was alive. However, at the same time he was the most _ man of all--He must face the fact .Alone on an island without food, water or gun!But, all roads lead to Rome!He just used his hands to work hard!Then, he made a cave, built a house, grew corn and kept goats. In the end, he could enjoy the life on the island. In his twenty-fourth year on the island, he saved a wild man, and gave him the name of "Friday". With Robinson's teaching, "Friday" became a good servant. Friday, they got a boat and escaped from the island. Surely, the writer of Robinson Crusoe is really a hero! It's too hard to describe Robinson with words. We could say that Robinson was very clever, and also he was brave,...Certainly, too many good words can describe him. But now, I think it isn't important. However, the most important thing is what we have learned from the story. That is, use our own hands to work hard with confidence!

A: Robinson||A great storm came and their boat crashed! No one was alive in this accident except Robinson.

A: A storm||A great storm came and their boat crashed!

Q: Anyone else survive?

A: No, No one was alive in this accident except Robinson.||No one was alive in this accident except Robinson.

A: No, Alone on an island without food, water or gun!||Alone on an island without food, water or gun!

Q: Was he happy?

A: Yes|| In the end, he could enjoy the life on the island

A: A wild man|| In his twenty-fourth year on the island, he saved a wild man,

A: Yes|| they got a boat and escaped from the island.

Q: How?

A: With a boat|| they got a boat and escaped from the island.

A: Use your own hands to work hard|| However, the most important thing is what we have learned from the story. That is, use our own hands to work hard with confidence!

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER VI.—LEO ASSERTS HIS RIGHTS. At once a crowd of performers surrounded the pair. Very few of them liked Jack Snipper, and they wondered what Leo would do should the gymnast attack the boy. “Call me a braggart, will you!” roared Snipper. “Don’t you dare to touch me with that club!” replied Leo calmly. “I’ll teach you a lesson!” And, swinging the Indian club over his head, Jack Snipper made a savage blow at the young gymnast. Had the stick struck Leo the boy’s head would have sustained a severe injury. But as quick as a flash Leo dodged, and the Indian club merely circled through the empty air. “For shame, Snipper!” “Do you want to kill the boy?” “What harm has he done?” And so the cries ran on. “Mind your own affairs!” shouted the maddened gymnast. “I’m going to teach the boy a lesson!” Again he sprang at Leo. But now suddenly the Indian club was caught. A dexterous twist, and it went flying out of reach across the dressing tent. Then, before Snipper could recover, he received a stinging slap full in the face that sent him staggering backward on the grass. A shout of approval went up. “Good for Leo!” “That’s right, boy, stand up for your rights!” The shout brought Adam Lambert, the general manager, to the scene. No sooner had he appeared than all the performers walked away. It was against the rules to fight, and every one present was liable to a heavy fine.


Q: which chapter are we reading?

A: Chapter 6.||CHAPTER VI.—LEO ASSERTS HIS RIGHTS.

A: An Indian club||And, swinging the Indian club over his head,

Q: who ws it aimed at?

A: Leo||And, swinging the Indian club over his head, Jack Snipper made a savage blow at the young gymnast.

Q: how severe a blow was it?

A: a savage blow||And, swinging the Indian club over his head, Jack Snipper made a savage blow at the young gymnast.

Q: if it connected what would have happened?

A: the boy’s head would have sustained a severe injury.||Had the stick struck Leo the boy’s head would have sustained a severe injury.

A: a crowd of performers||At once a crowd of performers surrounded the pair

Summary: CHAPTER VI.—LEO ASSERTS HIS RIGHTS.At once a crowd of performers surrounded the pair.Very few of them liked Jack Snipper, and they wondered what Leo would do should the gymnast attack the boy.“I’ll teach you a lesson!” And, swinging the Indian club over his head, Jack Snipper made a savage blow at the young gymnast.Had the stick struck Leo the boy’s head would have sustained a severe injury.But as quick as a flash Leo dodged, and the Indian club merely circled through the empty air.“For shame, Snipper!” “Do you want to kill the boy?” “What harm has he done?” And so the cries ran on.“Mind your own affairs!” shouted the maddened gymnast.Then, before Snipper could recover, he received a stinging slap full in the face that sent him staggering backward on the grass.“Good for Leo!” “That’s right, boy, stand up for your rights!” The shout brought Adam Lambert, the general manager, to the scene.

source: wikipedia

Discogs, short for discographies, is a website and crowdsourced database of information about audio recordings, including commercial releases, promotional releases, and bootleg or off-label releases. The Discogs servers, currently hosted under the domain name discogs.com, are owned by Zink Media, Inc., and are located in Portland, Oregon, US. While the site lists releases in all genres and on all formats, it is especially known as the largest online database of electronic music releases, and of releases on vinyl media. Discogs currently contains over 8 million releases, by nearly 4.9 million artists, across over 1 million labels, contributed from nearly 346,000 contributor user accounts—with these figures constantly growing as users continually add previously unlisted releases to the site over time. The discogs.com domain name was registered on 30 August 2000, and Discogs itself was launched in November 2000 by programmer, DJ, and music fan Kevin Lewandowski originally as a database of electronic music. He was inspired by the success of community-built sites such as Slashdot, eBay, and Open Directory Project, and decided to use this model for a music discography database. The site's original goal was to build the most comprehensive database of electronic music, organized around the artists, labels, and releases available in that genre. In 2003 the Discogs system was completely rewritten, and in January 2004 it began to support other genres, starting with hip hop. Since then, it has expanded to include rock and jazz in January 2005 and funk/soul, Latin, and reggae in October of the same year. In January 2006 blues and non-music (e.g. comedy records, field recordings, interviews) were added. Classical music started being supported in June 2007, and in October 2007 the "final genres were turned on" – adding support for the Stage & Screen, Brass & Military, Children's, and Folk, World, & Country music genres, allowing capture of virtually every single type of audio recording that has ever been released.


Q: Who owns the websites servers?

A: Zink Media, Inc|| Zink Media, Inc

Q: Where are they located?

A: Portland,||Portland,

Q: When was the website registered?

A: 30 August 2000||30 August 2000

Q: How many different releases are on the site?

A: 8 million releases||8 million releases

Q: artists?

A: 4.9 million|| 4.9 million

Q: labels?

A: 1 million||1 million

Q: Do they continue to catalogue more material?

A: yes||with these figures constantly growing as users continually add previously unlisted releases to the site over time.

Q: Who started the website?

A: Kevin Lewandowski|| Kevin Lewandowski

Q: What were his inspirations?

A: community-built sites||community-built sites

Q: What type of music did the site originally focus on?

A: electronic music||electronic music

Q: Has it since expanded beyond this particular type of music?

A: yes||and in January 2004 it began to support other genres, starting with hip hop.

Q: When did it start branching out into different genres?

A: January 2004||January 2004

Q: What is the ultimate goal of the platform?

A: to build the most comprehensive database of music|| to build the most comprehensive database

Q: Is the information crowd sourced?

A: Yes|| crowdsourced


Summary: Discogs, short for discographies, is a website and crowdsourced database of information about audio recordings, including commercial releases, promotional releases, and bootleg or off-label releases.The Discogs servers, currently hosted under the domain name discogs.com, are owned by Zink Media, Inc., and are located in Portland, Oregon, US.Discogs currently contains over 8 million releases, by nearly 4.9 million artists, across over 1 million labels, contributed from nearly 346,000 contributor user accounts—with these figures constantly growing as users continually add previously unlisted releases to the site over time.The discogs.com domain name was registered on 30 August 2000, and Discogs itself was launched in November 2000 by programmer, DJ, and music fan Kevin Lewandowski originally as a database of electronic music.He was inspired by the success of community-built sites such as Slashdot, eBay, and Open Directory Project, and decided to use this model for a music discography database.The site's original goal was to build the most comprehensive database of electronic music, organized around the artists, labels, and releases available in that genre.In 2003 the Discogs system was completely rewritten, and in January 2004 it began to support other genres, starting with hip hop.

source: wikipedia

Zen () is a school of Mahayana Buddhism that originated in China during the Tang dynasty as Chan Buddhism. Zen school was strongly influenced by Taoism and developed as a distinct school of Chinese Buddhism. From China, Chan Buddhism spread south to Vietnam, northeast to Korea and east to Japan, where it became known as Japanese Zen. The term Zen is derived from the Japanese pronunciation of the Middle Chinese word 禪 (Chan) which traces its roots to the Indian practice of Dhyana ("meditation"). Zen emphasizes rigorous self-control, meditation-practice, insight into Buddha-nature, and the personal expression of this insight in daily life, especially for the benefit of others. As such, it de-emphasizes mere knowledge of sutras and doctrine and favors direct understanding through zazen and interaction with an accomplished teacher. The teachings of Zen include various sources of Mahayana thought, especially Yogachara, the Tathāgatagarbha sūtras and the Huayan school, with their emphasis on Buddha-nature, totality, and the Bodhisattva-ideal. The Prajñāpāramitā literature and, to a lesser extent, Madhyamaka have also been influential in the shaping of the "paradoxical language" of the Zen-tradition. The word "Zen" is derived from the Japanese pronunciation of the Middle Chinese word 禪 () (pinyin: "Chán"), which in turn is derived from the Sanskrit word "dhyāna" (ध्यान ), which can be approximately translated as "absorption" or "meditative state".


Q: Zen is part of which religion?

A: Buddhism||Zen () is a school of Mahayana Buddhism

Q: What is it a school of?

A: Mahayana Buddhism||Mahayana Buddhism

Q: Where did that type come from?

A: China||Mahayana Buddhism that originated in China

Q: When?

A: During the Tang dynasty||during the Tang dynasty

Q: What influenced Zen?

A: Taoism||Zen school was strongly influenced by Taoism

Q: Name a country to which it spread from China.

A: Japan||China, Chan Buddhism spread south to Vietnam, northeast to Korea and east to Japan

Q: Name something the teachings of Zen emphasizes.

A: Meditation-practice|| Zen emphasizes rigorous self-control, meditation-practice

Q: What else?

A: Rigorous self-control||Zen emphasizes rigorous self-control

Q: And what else?

A: Insight into Buddha's nature||Zen emphasizes rigorous self-control, meditation-practice, insight into Buddha-nature

Q: When should that insight be expressed?

A: All the time, especially for the benefit of others.||Zen emphasizes rigorous self-control, meditation-practice, insight into Buddha-nature, and the personal expression of this insight in daily life, especially for the benefit of others.

Q: Does Zen value mere knowledge of doctrine?

A: No, As such, it de-emphasizes mere knowledge of sutras and doctrine and favors direct understanding through zazen and interaction with an accomplished teacher. ||As such, it de-emphasizes mere knowledge of sutras and doctrine and favors direct understanding through zazen and interaction with an accomplished teacher.

Q: What does it value instead?

A: Direct understanding||favors direct understanding through zazen and interaction with an accomplished teacher.

Q: Through what?

A: Through "zazen" and interaction with an accomplished teacher.||through zazen and interaction with an accomplished teacher.

Q: What Chinese word does Zen trace back to?

Q: What Sanskrit word does this come from in turn?

Q: What is a meaning of this word?

A: "absorption" or "meditative state"||turn is derived from the Sanskrit word "dhyāna" (ध्यान ), which can be approximately translated as "absorption" or "meditative state".

A: Indians|| Indian practice of Dhyana (

Summary: Zen () is a school of Mahayana Buddhism that originated in China during the Tang dynasty as Chan Buddhism.Zen school was strongly influenced by Taoism and developed as a distinct school of Chinese Buddhism.From China, Chan Buddhism spread south to Vietnam, northeast to Korea and east to Japan, where it became known as Japanese Zen.The term Zen is derived from the Japanese pronunciation of the Middle Chinese word 禪 (Chan) which traces its roots to the Indian practice of Dhyana ("meditation").Zen emphasizes rigorous self-control, meditation-practice, insight into Buddha-nature, and the personal expression of this insight in daily life, especially for the benefit of others.As such, it de-emphasizes mere knowledge of sutras and doctrine and favors direct understanding through zazen and interaction with an accomplished teacher.The word "Zen" is derived from the Japanese pronunciation of the Middle Chinese word 禪 () (pinyin: "Chán"), which in turn is derived from the Sanskrit word "dhyāna" (ध्यान ), which can be approximately translated as "absorption" or "meditative state".

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER III. THE ROMAN BARONS Having driven Charles VIII out of Italy, it still remained for the allies to remove all traces of his passage from Naples and to restore the rule of the House of Aragon. In this they had the aid of Ferdinand and Isabella, who sent an army under the command of that distinguished soldier Gonzalo de Cordoba, known in his day as the Great Captain. He landed in Calabria in the spring of 1496, and war broke out afresh through that already sorely devastated land. The Spaniards were joined by the allied forces of Venice and the Church under the condotta of the Marquis Gonzaga of Mantua, the leader of the Italians at Fornovo. Lodovico had detached himself from the league, and again made terms with France for his own safety's sake. But his cousin, Giovanni Sforza, Tyrant of Pesaro--the husband of Lucrezia Borgia--continued in the pontifical army at the head of a condotta of 600 lances. Another command in the same ranks was one of 700 lances under the youthful Giuffredo Borgia, now Prince of Squillace and the husband of Doña Sancia of Aragon, a lady of exceedingly loose morals, who had brought to Rome the habits acquired in the most licentious Court of that licentious age. The French lost Naples even more easily than they had conquered it, and by July 7 Ferdinand II was able to reenter his capital and reascend his throne. D'Aubigny, the French general, withdrew to France, whilst Montpensier, the Viceroy, retired to Pozzuoli, where he died in the following year.


Q: who was driven out of Italy?

A: Charles VIII||Having driven Charles VIII out of Italy

Q: what city did the French lose more easily than they got it?

A: Naples||The French lost Naples even more easily than they had conquered it

Q: who was able to enter it?

A: Ferdinand II||by July 7 Ferdinand II was able to reenter his capital

Q: by when?

A: July 7|| by July 7 Ferdinand II was able to reenter

Q: did he get his throne back?

A: yes||and reascend his throne

Q: who withdrew to France?

A: D'Aubigny||D'Aubigny, the French general, withdrew to France

Q: what was he?

A: the French general||D'Aubigny, the French genera

Q: how long after did Montpensier die?

A: the following year|| where he died in the following year

Q: where?

A: Pozzuoli||Montpensier, the Viceroy, retired to Pozzuoli

Q: who was known as the great captain?

A: Gonzalo de Cordoba|| Gonzalo de Cordoba, known in his day as the Great Captain

Q: what was he in command of?

A: an army||an army under the command of that distinguished soldier Gonzalo de Cordoba

Q: whose army was this?

A: Ferdinand's and Isabella's|| Ferdinand and Isabella, who sent an army

Q: who was of lose morals?

A: Doña Sancia|| Doña Sancia of Aragon, a lady of exceedingly loose morals

Q: what did she bring to Rome?

A: the habits acquired in the most licentious Court||had brought to Rome the habits acquired in the most licentious Court of that licentious age

Q: was she married?

A: yes|| the husband of Doña Sancia

Q: to whom?

A: Giuffredo Borgia||Giuffredo Borgia, now Prince of Squillace and the husband of Doña Sancia

Q: what is he now?

A: Prince of Squillace||Giuffredo Borgia, now Prince of Squillace

Q: where did Cordoba land?

A: Calabria||He landed in Calabria

Q: when?

A: 1496||He landed in Calabria in the spring of 1496

Q: who was the italian at Fornovo?

A: Marquis Gonzaga||Marquis Gonzaga of Mantua, the leader of the Italians at Fornovo


Summary: THE ROMAN BARONS Having driven Charles VIII out of Italy, it still remained for the allies to remove all traces of his passage from Naples and to restore the rule of the House of Aragon.In this they had the aid of Ferdinand and Isabella, who sent an army under the command of that distinguished soldier Gonzalo de Cordoba, known in his day as the Great Captain.He landed in Calabria in the spring of 1496, and war broke out afresh through that already sorely devastated land.The Spaniards were joined by the allied forces of Venice and the Church under the condotta of the Marquis Gonzaga of Mantua, the leader of the Italians at Fornovo.Another command in the same ranks was one of 700 lances under the youthful Giuffredo Borgia, now Prince of Squillace and the husband of Doña Sancia of Aragon, a lady of exceedingly loose morals, who had brought to Rome the habits acquired in the most licentious Court of that licentious age.The French lost Naples even more easily than they had conquered it, and by July 7 Ferdinand II was able to reenter his capital and reascend his throne.D'Aubigny, the French general, withdrew to France, whilst Montpensier, the Viceroy, retired to Pozzuoli, where he died in the following year.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- Before she was a princess, she was a child - shy but affectionate, respectful but mischievous. Diana Spencer, shown on her first birthday, grew up at Park House, a country estate leased from the royal family. Ten years after the death of Princess Diana, two women who helped raise the future princess are providing a new, intimate portrait of the girl who would become the "People's Princess." Diana Frances Spencer was born into a life of privilege. She grew up at Park House, a country home leased from the royal family's Sandringham estate in Norfolk, England. Her parents, Johnnie and Frances Spencer, were well-known members of the English aristocracy. Inge Crane came to Park House as an au pair when Diana was just 3 years old. "There's always been something special about Park House. It's difficult to put a finger on what it is," she said in her first interview, given exclusively to CNN. Life at the house wasn't entirely normal -- the queen's estate was about a mile away, and the young Princes Andrew and Edward (Diana's future in-laws) frequently visited to swim in the pool. When the butler would ring the gong for dinner, the children would rush to the stairs, slide down the wooden banister and run into the dining room. Despite growing up in the shadows of royalty, Crane and Mary Clarke, Diana's nanny starting at age 9, describe an "ordinary" childhood for Diana, a tomboy who loved going outdoors, climbing trees and playing with animals.


Q: where did Princess Diana grow up?

A: at Park House|| She grew up at Park House

Q: in what city?

A: in Norfolk|| in Norfolk

Q: did her family own it?

A: no, She grew up at Park House, a country home leased|| She grew up at Park House, a country home leased

Q: whose house was it?

A: the royal family's|| the royal family's

Q: who were Diana's parents?

A: Johnnie and Frances Spencer, were well-known members of the English aristocracy||. Her parents, Johnnie and Frances Spencer, were well-known members of the English aristocracy

Q: did she have an aupair?

A: yes||Inge Crane came to Park House as an au pair w

Q: starting from what age?

A: Three||Inge Crane came to Park House as an au pair when Diana was just 3

Q: who took care of her?

A: a nanny||, Crane and Mary Clarke

Q: how far was the queen's home?

A: about a mile away||about a mile away

Q: who would often come to visit?

A: Princes Andrew and Edward||Princes Andrew and Edward

Q: to do what?

A: to swim in the pool|| to swim in the pool

Q: what did Diana like to do as a kid?

A: going outdoors, climbing trees and playing with animals|| going outdoors, climbing trees and playing with animals

Q: was she a tomboy?

A: yes|| Diana, a tomboy


Summary: She grew up at Park House, a country home leased from the royal family's Sandringham estate in Norfolk, England.Her parents, Johnnie and Frances Spencer, were well-known members of the English aristocracy.Inge Crane came to Park House as an au pair when Diana was just 3 years old.Life at the house wasn't entirely normal -- the queen's estate was about a mile away, and the young Princes Andrew and Edward (Diana's future in-laws) frequently visited to swim in the pool.When the butler would ring the gong for dinner, the children would rush to the stairs, slide down the wooden banister and run into the dining room.Despite growing up in the shadows of royalty, Crane and Mary Clarke, Diana's nanny starting at age 9, describe an "ordinary" childhood for Diana, a tomboy who loved going outdoors, climbing trees and playing with animals.

source: mctest

Janet walked past the barn, the big tree, and through the back yard to reach the chicken pen. Janet gathered the eggs from the chicken pen, so that her father could make scrambled eggs for breakfast. He would need at least 5 eggs for the meal, two for Janet and three for himself. Janet could only find four eggs in the chicken pen. She looked under every chicken, and in every nest, but could not find another egg. She placed the four eggs in her basket, and began to walk toward the house, when she heard a quacking sound. She went toward the sound and found a nest near the pond, with large brown eggs inside. "Quack" said a nearby duck, as Janet took an egg from the nest. Now she had enough for breakfast.


Q: What did Janet walk past first?

A: the barn|| the barn

Q: What was Janet going to?

A: the chicken pen||to reach the chicken pen

Q: Why did she gather eggs?

A: so her father could make scrambled eggs||so that her father could make scrambled eggs for breakfast

Q: How many eggs were needed?

A: Five||need at least 5 eggs

Q: How many did she find?

A: four||only find four eggs

Q: What did she hear?

A: a quacking sound||she heard a quacking sound

Q: What did she discover near the water?

A: a nest||found a nest

Q: What was inside it?

A: eggs|| large brown eggs inside

Q: What color?

A: brown||brown eggs

Q: Were they small?

A: no, large brown eggs||large brown eggs

Q: Did she take anything?

A: an egg||Janet took an egg from the nest

Q: Was she satisfied with the amount needed for the meal?

A: yes||she had enoug


Summary: Janet walked past the barn, the big tree, and through the back yard to reach the chicken pen.Janet gathered the eggs from the chicken pen, so that her father could make scrambled eggs for breakfast.He would need at least 5 eggs for the meal, two for Janet and three for himself.Janet could only find four eggs in the chicken pen.She placed the four eggs in her basket, and began to walk toward the house, when she heard a quacking sound.She went toward the sound and found a nest near the pond, with large brown eggs inside."Quack" said a nearby duck, as Janet took an egg from the nest.Now she had enough for breakfast.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXIX A QUESTION OF TITLE It was as if each person who had doubted Sam's honesty felt it necessary to call at Mrs. Byram's and congratulate him upon what now appeared to be good proof of his innocence. Fred and the miners also came in for their share of attention, and even Bill, whose limb was paining him severely, joined his partners in celebrating their victory, which now seemed certain. Before returning home Mr. Hunter called to consult with his clients relative to making a stock company of the new mine, and, when he left, it was with full authority to do whatever he believed their interests demanded. Among the visitors in the evening was Donovan, and he had no hesitation in calling himself very severe names for having been so stupid as to think it possible his old friends could have been engaged in any questionable transaction. "The cashier is about as sore a man as can be found in town," he said, "an' if I ain't way off in my reckonin' he'll be lookin' for another job mighty soon." "Does he say anything against us?" Bill asked. "He's glum as a fish. Every feller who goes in wants to know where Gus is, an' he keeps out of sight all that's possible." "Have you seen Mr. Wright to-day?" "No; but I heard he an' that lawyer of yours had a long chin about the business. Say, Bill, by the time you get out of this scrape you'll owe a pretty penny for law, I reckon. Why don't you try to make the company pay it?"


Q: Who was a visitor in the evening?

A: Donovan||Donovan

Q: Did he hesitate?

A: no, and he had no hesitation|| and he had no hesitation

Q: What did he call himself?

A: very severe names||himself very severe names

Q: Why?

A: Being stupid||or having been so stupid

Q: What did people doubt about Sam

A: His honesty||Sam's honesty

Q: What did they feel it was necessary to do?

A: call at Mrs. Byram's||call at Mrs. Byram's

Q: Did they then berate him?

A: No, and congratulate him||and congratulate him

Q: What did they do?

A: congratulate him||congratulate him

Q: Who was in pain from his limbs?

A: Bill||Bill

Q: Who came in with Fred?

A: the miners||the miners

Q: Did Mr. Hunter have clients?

A: Yes||called to consult with his clients

Q: What did he call them about?

A: making a stock company of the new mine||making a stock company of the new mine

Q: When did he do this?

A: Before returning home||Before returning home

Q: Did he leave?

A: Yes||when he left

Q: with what?

A: to do whatever he believed their interests demanded||to do whatever he believed their interests demanded

Q: Who is a sore man?

A: The cashier||The cashie

Q: According to who?

A: Donovan||Donovan

Q: What does Donovan compare him to?

A: a fish|| glum as a fish

Q: Had they seen Mr. Wright?

A: No, "Have you seen Mr. Wright to-day?" "No; b||"Have you seen Mr. Wright to-day?" "No; b

A: Yes||it was with full authority

GERALD Christian is in Grade 8 at Ridge Road Middle School in North Carolina, US. She is a member of her school basketball team. Late last month, the 14-year-old faced a big problem. Her mother lost her job. She thought she couldn't pay the $ 50 fee for the city's sports meet this year. Christian was not the only one who had this problem. Some other middle school players in the city had the same problem. That's why famous NBA player Michael Jordan gave $ 250, 000 to the city earlier this month. He wanted to help the poor students. Jordan said: "I know there are kids who get an education by playing sports. We need to keep sports alive for them." Christian was _ . "Really? I can't believe Michael did that for us. These days, I go to bed thinking about it and I wake up thinking about it," she said. "Now the problem is over. " Christian wanted to say "thanks" to Jordan. "Michael, thank you for giving me the chance to show myself. I will do my best at the meet.

A: He wanted to help the poor students||He wanted to help the poor students

Q: Was Christian surprised by this?

A: yes||Really? I can't believe Michael did that for us

Q: did he think about it all the time?

A: yes||I go to bed thinking about it and I wake up thinking about it,

A: Grade 8|| Grade 8

A: yes||She is a member of her school basketball team

Q: what sport?

A: basketball||basketball

Q: did her mother lose her job?

A: yes||Her mother lost her job

Q: how much was the fee for the city's sports meet?

A: $ 50||$ 50

Q: could she afford it?

A: no, she couldn't pay||she couldn't pay

Q: did she face this alone?

A: no, Christian was not the only one ||Christian was not the only one

source: cnn

(Entertainment Weekly) -- How are the elements of the charming, traditional romantic comedy "The Proposal" like the checklist of a charming, traditional bride? Let me count the ways ... Ryan Reynolds wonders if marrying his boss, Sandra Bullock, is a good thing in "The Proposal." Something old: The story of a haughty woman and an exasperated man who hate each other -- until they realize they love each other -- is proudly square, in the tradition of rom-coms from the 1940s and '50s. Or is it straight out of Shakespeare's 1590s? Sandra Bullock is the shrew, Margaret, a pitiless, high-powered New York book editor first seen multitasking in the midst of her aerobic workout (thus you know she needs to get ... loved). Ryan Reynolds is Andrew, her put-upon foil of an executive assistant, a younger man who accepts abuse as a media-industry hazing ritual. And there the two would remain, locked in mutual disdain, except for Margaret's fatal flaw -- she's Canadian. (So is "X-Men's" Wolverine; I thought our neighbors to the north were supposed to be nice.) Margaret, with her visa expired, faces deportation and makes the snap executive decision to marry Andrew in a green-card wedding. It's an offer the underling can't refuse if he wants to keep his job. (A sexual-harassment lawsuit would ruin the movie's mood.) OK, he says. But first comes a visit to the groom-to-be's family in Alaska. Amusing complications ensue. Something new: The chemical energy between Bullock and Reynolds is fresh and irresistible. In her mid-40s, Bullock has finessed her dewy America's Sweetheart comedy skills to a mature, pearly texture; she's lovable both as an uptight careerist in a pencil skirt and stilettos, and as a lonely lady in a flapping plaid bathrobe.

A: The Proposal||The Proposal

A: How the elements of the comedy are like the checklist of a charming, traditional bride?|| How are the elements of the charming, traditional romantic comedy "The Proposal" like the checklist of a charming, traditional bride?
