Ryan Reynolds wonders if marrying his boss, Sandra Bullock, is a good thing in "The Proposal."Something old: The story of a haughty woman and an exasperated man who hate each other -- until they realize they love each other -- is proudly square, in the tradition of rom-coms from the 1940s and '50s.Or is it straight out of Shakespeare's 1590s?Sandra Bullock is the shrew, Margaret, a pitiless, high-powered New York book editor first seen multitasking in the midst of her aerobic workout (thus you know she needs to get ... loved).Ryan Reynolds is Andrew, her put-upon foil of an executive assistant, a younger man who accepts abuse as a media-industry hazing ritual.And there the two would remain, locked in mutual disdain, except for Margaret's fatal flaw -- she's Canadian.Margaret, with her visa expired, faces deportation and makes the snap executive decision to marry Andrew in a green-card wedding.But first comes a visit to the groom-to-be's family in Alaska.Amusing complications ensue.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Height above average terrain (HAAT) (or less popularly, EHAAT, Effective Height Above Average Terrain) is a measure of how high an antenna site is above the surrounding landscape. HAAT is used extensively in FM radio and television, as it is more important than effective radiated power (ERP) in determining the range of broadcasts (VHF and UHF in particular, as they are line of sight transmissions). For international coordination, it is officially measured in meters, even by the Federal Communications Commission in the United States, as Canada and Mexico have extensive border zones where stations can be received on either side of the international boundaries. Stations that want to increase above a certain HAAT must reduce their power accordingly, based on the maximum distance their station class is allowed to cover (see List of North American broadcast station classes for more information on this). The FCC procedure to calculate HAAT is: from the proposed or actual antenna site, either 12 or 16 radials were drawn, and points at 2, 4, 6, 8, and radius along each radial were used. The entire radial graph could be rotated to achieve the best effect for the station. The altitude of the antenna site, minus the average altitude of all the specified points, is the HAAT. This can create some unusual cases, particularly in mountainous regions—it is possible to have a negative number for HAAT (the transmitter would not be located underground, but rather in a valley, with hills on both sides taller than the transmitter itself, for example).


Q: What does HAAT stand for?

A: It stands for Height about average terrain||Height above average terrain

Q: What is a similar acronym that means the same thing?

A: The less popular version, EHAAT, Effective Height Above Average Terrain||EHAAT, Effective Height Above Average Terrain

Q: Can it be a negative number?

A: Yes||it is possible to have a negative number for HAAT (the tra

Q: Where does that happen?

A: Usually in the mountainous regions||his can create some unusual cases, particularly in mountainous regions—

Q: What industries is it used in?

A: More commonly, FM radio and television||extensively in FM radio and television,

Q: What transmission types?

A: Usually VHF and UHF||VHF and UHF in particular,

Q: Is it given in feet?

A: NO||it is officially measured in meters,

Q: What unit is used?

A: Meters|| it is officially measured in meters,

Q: Why?

A: So that stations can be recieved on either side of the international boundaries.|| as Canada and Mexico have extensive border zones where stations can be received on either side of the international boundaries.

Q: What is subtracted from what to find it?

A: average altitude||the average altitude of all the specif


Summary: Height above average terrain (HAAT) (or less popularly, EHAAT, Effective Height Above Average Terrain) is a measure of how high an antenna site is above the surrounding landscape.HAAT is used extensively in FM radio and television, as it is more important than effective radiated power (ERP) in determining the range of broadcasts (VHF and UHF in particular, as they are line of sight transmissions).For international coordination, it is officially measured in meters, even by the Federal Communications Commission in the United States, as Canada and Mexico have extensive border zones where stations can be received on either side of the international boundaries.The altitude of the antenna site, minus the average altitude of all the specified points, is the HAAT.This can create some unusual cases, particularly in mountainous regions—it is possible to have a negative number for HAAT (the transmitter would not be located underground, but rather in a valley, with hills on both sides taller than the transmitter itself, for example).

source: cnn

Fort Lauderdale, Florida (CNN) -- Just taking a sip of water or walking to the bathroom is excruciatingly painful for 15-year-old Michael Brewer, who was burned over 65 percent of his body after being set on fire, allegedly by a group of teenagers. "It hurts my heart to see him in pain, but it enlightens at the same time to know my son is strong enough to make it through on a daily basis," his mother, Valerie Brewer, told CNN on Wednesday. Brewer and her husband, Michael Brewer, Sr., spoke to CNN's Tony Harris, a day after a 13-year-old boy who witnessed last month's attack publicly read a written statement: "I want to express my deepest sympathy to Mikey and his family," Jeremy Jarvis said. "I will pray for Mikey to grow stronger every day and for Mikey's speedy recovery." Jarvis' older brother has been charged in the October 12 attack in Deerfield Beach, Florida. When asked about the teen's statement, Valerie Brewer -- who knows the Jarvis family -- said she "can't focus on that." "I would really like to stay away from that because that brings negative energy to me and I don't need that right now," she said. Her son remains in guarded condition at the University of Miami's Jackson Memorial Hospital Burn Center. He suffered second- and third-degree burns over about two-thirds of his body, according to the hospital's associate director, Dr. Carl Schulman. The teen faces a lifelong recovery from his injuries, Schulman told CNN's Harris.

Summary: Fort Lauderdale, Florida (CNN) -- Just taking a sip of water or walking to the bathroom is excruciatingly painful for 15-year-old Michael Brewer, who was burned over 65 percent of his body after being set on fire, allegedly by a group of teenagers."It hurts my heart to see him in pain, but it enlightens at the same time to know my son is strong enough to make it through on a daily basis," his mother, Valerie Brewer, told CNN on Wednesday.Brewer and her husband, Michael Brewer, Sr., spoke to CNN's Tony Harris, a day after a 13-year-old boy who witnessed last month's attack publicly read a written statement: "I want to express my deepest sympathy to Mikey and his family," Jeremy Jarvis said.When asked about the teen's statement, Valerie Brewer -- who knows the Jarvis family -- said she "can't focus on that.""I would really like to stay away from that because that brings negative energy to me and I don't need that right now," she said.Her son remains in guarded condition at the University of Miami's Jackson Memorial Hospital Burn Center.He suffered second- and third-degree burns over about two-thirds of his body, according to the hospital's associate director, Dr. Carl Schulman.The teen faces a lifelong recovery from his injuries, Schulman told CNN's Harris.

source: cnn

Paris (CNN) -- French officials Tuesday condemned an Israeli airstrike on Gaza that wounded its consul, his wife and their daughter, calling on Israel to avoid civilian casualties. "France strongly deplores the consequences of this air strike," a statement from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Paris announced. "While France is committed to security in Israel, it reaffirms the imperative need to avoid attacks on civilians. This imperative was reaffirmed to the Israeli authorities." The consul, Majdi Shakoura, was at home with his family in the northern end of Gaza when the airstrike hit about 200 meters (650 feet) away, the Foreign Ministry said. The strike blew out their windows, and they were struck by shards of flying glass, the ministry said. Capt. Aryeh Shalikar, an Israeli military spokesman, told CNN the airstrike was aimed at Palestinian militants who fired a rocket into southern Israel late Sunday. Shalikar said the Israel Defense Forces "never received any official statement from any source" regarding injuries to Shakoura or his relatives. "The IDF wishes to convey that missiles are being fired at Israeli civilians from terrorists, and it has no intention of harming civilians when it returns fire at terrorists," he said. Palestinian security and medical officials said one person died and several others were wounded in the airstrike, which they said struck a Hamas naval building in northern Gaza. A Hamas security official said two Israeli rockets struck the building. France has a consulate and a cultural center in Gaza "to support the population," the Foreign Ministry said. France has helped build water and sewer systems and rebuild hospitals in Gaza, which is ruled by the Islamic movement Hamas.


Q: Which official condemned the airstrike?

A: French officials||French officials Tuesday condemned an Israeli airstrike

Q: Which consul was hit?

A: Majdi Shakoura||The consul, Majdi Shakoura

Q: How far away was their home hit?

A: hit about 200 meters (650 feet) away||The consul, Majdi Shakoura, was at home with his family in the northern end of Gaza when the airstrike hit about 200 meters (650 feet) away

Q: Who was the airstrike aimed at?

A: Palestinian militants|| Capt. Aryeh Shalikar, an Israeli military spokesman, told CNN the airstrike was aimed at Palestinian militants

Q: Does IDF say that they're not wishing to harm any civilians?

A: Yes|| Shalikar said the Israel Defense Forces "never received any official statement from any source" regarding injuries to Shakoura or his relatives.

Q: And are they targeting terrorists?

A: Yes||"The IDF wishes to convey that missiles are being fired at Israeli civilians from terrorists

Q: How many people died in the airstrike?

A: one||Palestinian security and medical officials said one person died

Q: Were others wounded?

A: Yes||Palestinian security and medical officials said one person died and several others were wounded in the airstrike

Q: What building was struck?

A: Hamas naval building||Palestinian security and medical officials said one person died and several others were wounded in the airstrike, which they said struck a Hamas naval building in northern Gaza.

Q: Has France helped in building hospitals in Gaza?

A: Yes||France has helped build water and sewer systems and rebuild hospitals in Gaza,


Summary: Paris (CNN) -- French officials Tuesday condemned an Israeli airstrike on Gaza that wounded its consul, his wife and their daughter, calling on Israel to avoid civilian casualties.The consul, Majdi Shakoura, was at home with his family in the northern end of Gaza when the airstrike hit about 200 meters (650 feet) away, the Foreign Ministry said.Aryeh Shalikar, an Israeli military spokesman, told CNN the airstrike was aimed at Palestinian militants who fired a rocket into southern Israel late Sunday.Shalikar said the Israel Defense Forces "never received any official statement from any source" regarding injuries to Shakoura or his relatives."The IDF wishes to convey that missiles are being fired at Israeli civilians from terrorists, and it has no intention of harming civilians when it returns fire at terrorists," he said.Palestinian security and medical officials said one person died and several others were wounded in the airstrike, which they said struck a Hamas naval building in northern Gaza.France has helped build water and sewer systems and rebuild hospitals in Gaza, which is ruled by the Islamic movement Hamas.

source: wikipedia

Windows 8 introduced major changes to the operating system's platform and user interface to improve its user experience on tablets, where Windows was now competing with mobile operating systems, including Android and iOS. In particular, these changes included a touch-optimized Windows shell based on Microsoft's "Metro" design language, the Start screen (which displays programs and dynamically updated content on a grid of tiles), a new platform for developing apps with an emphasis on touchscreen input, integration with online services (including the ability to sync apps and settings between devices), and Windows Store, an online store for downloading and purchasing new software. Windows 8 added support for USB 3.0, Advanced Format hard drives, near field communications, and cloud computing. Additional security features were introduced, such as built-in antivirus software, integration with Microsoft SmartScreen phishing filtering service and support for UEFI Secure Boot on supported devices with UEFI firmware, to prevent malware from infecting the boot process.


Q: what prevents malware for infecting the boot process ?

A: UEFI firmware||with UEFI firmware, to prevent malware from infecting the boot process.

Q: Windows 8 introduced what ?

A: major changes||Windows 8 introduced major changes

Q: to what ?

A: operating system's platform||Windows 8 introduced major changes to the operating system's platform

Q: why ?

A: to improve its user experience on tablets||Windows 8 introduced major changes to the operating system's platform and user interface to improve its user experience on tablets

Q: was this also windows 10 ?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: what does the smart screen do ?

A: phishing filtering service|| integration with Microsoft SmartScreen phishing filtering service

Q: what is the online store for ?

A: downloading and purchasing new software||an online store for downloading and purchasing new software

Q: how many things did windows add support for ?

A: four|| Windows 8 added support for USB 3.0, Advanced Format hard drives, near field communications, and cloud computing

Q: how many Additional security features were introduced ?

A: three||Additional security features were introduced, such as built-in antivirus software, integration with Microsoft SmartScreen phishing filtering service and support for UEFI Secure Boot on supported devices with UEFI firmware, to prevent malware from infecting the boot process.

Q: what harm would malware do ?

A: infecting the boot process||to prevent malware from infecting the boot process.


Summary: Windows 8 introduced major changes to the operating system's platform and user interface to improve its user experience on tablets, where Windows was now competing with mobile operating systems, including Android and iOS.In particular, these changes included a touch-optimized Windows shell based on Microsoft's "Metro" design language, the Start screen (which displays programs and dynamically updated content on a grid of tiles), a new platform for developing apps with an emphasis on touchscreen input, integration with online services (including the ability to sync apps and settings between devices), and Windows Store, an online store for downloading and purchasing new software.Windows 8 added support for USB 3.0, Advanced Format hard drives, near field communications, and cloud computing.Additional security features were introduced, such as built-in antivirus software, integration with Microsoft SmartScreen phishing filtering service and support for UEFI Secure Boot on supported devices with UEFI firmware, to prevent malware from infecting the boot process.

source: cnn

(CNN)The widow of the man whose life was portrayed in the acclaimed film "American Sniper" has penned a heartfelt letter to him on their 13th anniversary. Taya Kyle posted her letter March 16 on the Chris Kyle Facebook page, where she proclaimed, "I miss you and I love you. I feel you in my heart and soul so strongly. I am more blessed to have been your wife than anything else in my life." "Today, I have a choice. I can bury myself under the covers and acknowledge the pain of missing you and mourn the future anniversaries without you," she wrote. "Or, I can celebrate never having a day without you in my heart because you loved me enough to leave me a lifetime of memories and beauty." Kyle, a Navy SEAL, has been credited as the most successful sniper in United States military history. Bradley Cooper was nominated for an Academy Award for his portrayal of Kyle in this winter's film "American Sniper," which was based on Kyle's bestselling autobiography. The film, directed by Clint Eastwood, has become the highest-grossing war movie ever. Why 'American Sniper' is a smash hit Kyle and his friend Chad Littlefield were shot and killed at a gun range in 2013 by Eddie Ray Routh. A Texas jury found Routh guilty of capital murder in February, and he was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole. Jury finds Eddie Ray Routh guilty in 'American Sniper' case


Q: who is a a Navy SEAL?

A: Chris Kyle||Kyle, a Navy SEAL,

Q: was he married?

A: yes||The widow of the man whose life was portrayed in the acclaimed film "American Sniper"

Q: whats her name?

A: Taya Kyle||Taya Kyle posted her letter March 16

Q: when did Kyle die?

A: 2013||Kyle and his friend Chad Littlefield were shot and killed at a gun range in 2013

Q: how?

A: shot||Kyle and his friend Chad Littlefield were shot

Q: by who?

A: Eddie Ray Routh||killed at a gun range in 2013 by Eddie Ray Routh

Q: what title has Kyle been given?

A: most successful sniper in United States military history||most successful sniper in United States military history

Q: was a movie made about him?

A: yes||"American Sniper," which was based on Kyle's bestselling autobiography.

Q: who was the actor that played kyle?

Summary: (CNN)The widow of the man whose life was portrayed in the acclaimed film "American Sniper" has penned a heartfelt letter to him on their 13th anniversary.Taya Kyle posted her letter March 16 on the Chris Kyle Facebook page, where she proclaimed, "I miss you and I love you."Or, I can celebrate never having a day without you in my heart because you loved me enough to leave me a lifetime of memories and beauty."Kyle, a Navy SEAL, has been credited as the most successful sniper in United States military history.Bradley Cooper was nominated for an Academy Award for his portrayal of Kyle in this winter's film "American Sniper," which was based on Kyle's bestselling autobiography.The film, directed by Clint Eastwood, has become the highest-grossing war movie ever.Why 'American Sniper' is a smash hit Kyle and his friend Chad Littlefield were shot and killed at a gun range in 2013 by Eddie Ray Routh.A Texas jury found Routh guilty of capital murder in February, and he was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: cnn

Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo find themselves fighting it out for FIFA's Ballon d'Or award once again -- but the contest between the world's two highest-profile footballers isn't only being played out on the pitch. Bayern Munich's German international goalkeeper Manuel Neuer was the other player on the three-man shortlist revealed Monday, with Ronaldo the overwhelming favorite to take the award. Which means there is no sign of Barcelona's Messi and Real Madrid poster boy Ronaldo's domination of the back pages ending any time soon. Both are so globally known that that their every Facebook posting is worth thousands of dollars for brands associated with the two players, while the allure of their names helps shift any and every product with which they are associated. But who is the most marketable? Is it Messi, the newly-crowned all-time La Liga top scorer? Or is it Ronaldo, the current Ballon d'Or holder and a man seemingly able to score goals at will, no matter what the competition? Sports marketing research company Repucom examined 15 different markets, ranging from Spain to the U.S., and found that Portugal skipper Ronaldo is the better-known of the two: 92% know of him, while 87% have heard of Messi. The figures also show that the same number of men know about Messi as women know about Ronaldo -- 91%. They reveal that Ronaldo sells more effectively, with 86% of those questioned regarding the ex-Manchester United man as "an influential brand spokesman." "Cristiano Ronaldo dominates in terms of his overall marketability -- largely because of the consistently high levels of awareness people have of him around the world, whilst Messi has a greater proportion of people that do know of him saying they like him," said Repucom's global head of research Mike Wragg.


Q: Name the two players who are famous?

A: Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo||Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo

Q: Which one is better known of the two?

A: Ronaldo||Portugal skipper Ronaldo is the better-known

Q: What award are they talking about?

A: FIFA's Ballon d'Or award||FIFA's Ballon d'Or award

Q: Who is the other player who is on the three man shortlist?

A: Manuel Neuer||Manuel Neuer was the other player on the three-man shortlist

Q: Who is more likely to take the award?

A: Ronaldo||Ronaldo the overwhelming favorite to take the award

Q: Are both of them very famously known and globally too?

A: yes||Both are so globally known

Q: What's the worth of their every facebook posting?

A: thousands of dollars|| their every Facebook posting is worth thousands of dollars

Q: Name the research company that examined 15 different markets?

A: Repucom||Repucom examined 15 different markets

Q: What percentage of people know Ronaldo?

A: 92%||Ronaldo is the better-known of the two: 92% know of him

Q: and Messi?

A: 87%||while 87% have heard of Messi.


Summary: Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo find themselves fighting it out for FIFA's Ballon d'Or award once again -- but the contest between the world's two highest-profile footballers isn't only being played out on the pitch.Bayern Munich's German international goalkeeper Manuel Neuer was the other player on the three-man shortlist revealed Monday, with Ronaldo the overwhelming favorite to take the award.Both are so globally known that that their every Facebook posting is worth thousands of dollars for brands associated with the two players, while the allure of their names helps shift any and every product with which they are associated.Sports marketing research company Repucom examined 15 different markets, ranging from Spain to the U.S., and found that Portugal skipper Ronaldo is the better-known of the two: 92% know of him, while 87% have heard of Messi.

source: wikipedia

Anthropology is the study of humans and their societies in the past and present. Its main subdivisions are social anthropology and cultural anthropology, which describes the workings of societies around the world, linguistic anthropology, which investigates the influence of language in social life, and biological or physical anthropology, which concerns long-term development of the human organism. Archaeology, which studies past human cultures through investigation of physical evidence, is thought of as a branch of anthropology in the United States, while in Europe, it is viewed as a discipline in its own right, or grouped under other related disciplines such as history. Similar organizations in other countries followed: The American Anthropological Association in 1902, the Anthropological Society of Madrid (1865), the Anthropological Society of Vienna (1870), the Italian Society of Anthropology and Ethnology (1871), and many others subsequently. The majority of these were evolutionist. One notable exception was the Berlin Society of Anthropology (1869) founded by Rudolph Virchow, known for his vituperative attacks on the evolutionists. Not religious himself, he insisted that Darwin's conclusions lacked empirical foundation.


Q: Who disagreed with Darwin?

A: Rudolph Virchow||Not religious himself, he insisted that Darwin's conclusions lacked empirical foundation

Q: What did he found?

A: the Berlin Society of Anthropology||the Berlin Society of Anthropology (1869) founded by Rudolph Virchow

Q: In what year?

A: 1869||the Berlin Society of Anthropology (1869)

Q: What was founded in 1865?

A: the Anthropological Society of Madrid (1865)|| the Anthropological Society of Madrid (1865)

Q: And in 1870?

A: the Anthropological Society of Vienna|| the Anthropological Society of Vienna (1870)

Q: How much later was the Italian Sociaty of Anthropology and Ethnology founded?

A: one year later|| the Italian Society of Anthropology and Ethnology (1871)

Q: Was the American Anthropological Association founded before or after that?

A: after||The American Anthropological Association in 1902

Q: In what year?

A: 1902||The American Anthropological Association in 1902

Q: Was it an evolutionist organization?

A: yes||The majority of these were evolutionist

Q: What is anthropology?

A: the study of humans and their societies in the past and present||Anthropology is the study of humans and their societies in the past and present

Q: How many main categories does it have?

A: three||Its main subdivisions are social anthropology and cultural anthropology, which describes the workings of societies around the world, linguistic anthropology, which investigates the influence of language in social life, and biological or physical anthropology, which concerns long-term development of the human organism.

Q: What is archaeology?

A: The study of past human cultures through investigation of physical evidence||Archaeology, which studies past human cultures through investigation of physical evidence

Q: Do the US and Europe agree on its categorization?

A: no, is thought of as a branch of anthropology in the United States, while in Europe, it is viewed as a discipline in its own right|| is thought of as a branch of anthropology in the United States, while in Europe, it is viewed as a discipline in its own right

Q: How does the US categorize it?

A: as a branch of anthropology||as a branch of anthropology

Q: And Europe?

A: as a discipline in its own right||as a discipline in its own right

Q: What category of anthropology deals with languages?

A: linguistic anthropology||linguistic anthropology, which investigates the influence of language in social life

Q: What about societies?

A: social anthropology and cultural anthropology||social anthropology and cultural anthropology, which describes the workings of societies around the world

Q: Who did Virchow attack?

A: the evolutionists.|| known for his vituperative attacks on the evolutionists.

Q: Was he religious?

A: no, Not religious himself||Not religious himself


Summary: Anthropology is the study of humans and their societies in the past and present.Its main subdivisions are social anthropology and cultural anthropology, which describes the workings of societies around the world, linguistic anthropology, which investigates the influence of language in social life, and biological or physical anthropology, which concerns long-term development of the human organism.Archaeology, which studies past human cultures through investigation of physical evidence, is thought of as a branch of anthropology in the United States, while in Europe, it is viewed as a discipline in its own right, or grouped under other related disciplines such as history.Similar organizations in other countries followed: The American Anthropological Association in 1902, the Anthropological Society of Madrid (1865), the Anthropological Society of Vienna (1870), the Italian Society of Anthropology and Ethnology (1871), and many others subsequently.The majority of these were evolutionist.One notable exception was the Berlin Society of Anthropology (1869) founded by Rudolph Virchow, known for his vituperative attacks on the evolutionists.Not religious himself, he insisted that Darwin's conclusions lacked empirical foundation.

source: mctest

It's finally the weekend of Halloween and I get to dress up in my lion costume. Halloween is my favorite holiday because I really like candy and love dressing up. Last year I was a ghost, but this year I am a lion. My little brother is dressed like a dinosaur and he keeps chewing on everything. He is only 3 years old so I guess that is okay. His name is Todd and his favorite holiday is his birthday but I don't think he knows much about any of them. My dad loves Christmas and my Mom really likes Thanksgiving. But I love Halloween. We have to wait for my dad to come home from work so we can go out and trick-or-treat. While we are waiting my mommy cooks us dinner. She wants us to eat good food before we spoil our dinner with all the candy we are going to get. I can't wait to go to my friend Kevin's house. His parents give the best candy and give me extra since Kevin is my friend. I think Kevin said he was going to dress up like a pirate but I don't remember. I don't think pirates are very cool, but I didn't tell Kevin that. I think I hear my dad coming up the stairs. Tonight is going to be the best Halloween ever.


Q: How old is my brother?

A: 3 years old||3 years old

Q: What's my favorite holiday?

A: Halloween||Halloween

Q: Was I a vampire last year?

A: no, I was a ghost||I was a ghost

Q: What was I?

A: a ghost||a ghost

Q: What's my little brother's costume?

A: a dinosaur||a dinosaur

Q: Is his name Albert?

A: no, His name is Todd||His name is Todd

Q: What's his name?

A: Todd||Todd

Q: What's his favorite holiday?

A: his birthday||his birthday

Q: Who loves Christmas?

A: My dad||My dad

Q: And who loves Thanksgiving?

A: my Mom|| my Mom

Q: What happens while we're waiting for my dad?

A: my mommy cooks us dinner.||my mommy cooks us dinner.

Q: Where is dad?

A: work||work

Q: Whose house do I really want to go to?

A: Kevin's||Kevin's

Q: Why?

A: His parents give the best candy and give me extra since Kevin is my friend||His parents give the best candy and give me extra since Kevin is my friend

Q: Did I think pirates are cool?

A: no, I don't think pirates are very cool,||I don't think pirates are very cool,

Q: Who might be coming up the stairs?

A: my dad||my dad

Q: What will tonight be?

A: the best Halloween ever||the best Halloween ever

source: mctest

Billy went to the farm to buy some beef for his brother's birthday. When he arrived there he saw that all six of the cows were sad and had brown spots. The cows were all eating their breakfast in a big grassy meadow. He thought that the spots looked very strange so he went closer to the cows to get a better look. When he got closer he also saw that there were five white chickens sitting on the fence. The fence was painted blue and had some dirty black spots on it. Billy wondered where the dirty spots had come. Soon he got close to the chickens and they got scared. All five chickens flew away and went to eat some food. After Billy got a good look at the cows he went to the farmer to buy some beef. The farmer gave him four pounds of beef for ten dollars. Billy thought that it was a good deal so he went home and cooked his brother dinner. His brother was very happy with the dinner. Billy's mom was also very happy.


Q: Who went to the farm?

A: Billy||Billy went to the farm

Q: Why?

A: buy beef||to buy some beef for his brother's birthday

Q: For what?

A: his brother's birthday.|| for his brother's birthday.

Q: How many cows did he see there?

A: six||When he arrived there he saw that all six of the cows were sad and had brown spots.

Q: Did they have spots?

A: yes||and had brown spots.

Q: What color?

A: brown|| cows were sad and had brown spots.

Q: What were they doing?

A: eating breakfast||The cows were all eating their breakfast in a big grassy meadow.

Q: Where?

A: a meadow||reakfast in a big grassy meadow.

Q: How did the spots look to him?

A: strange|| He thought that the spots looked very strange

Q: Did he move closer?

A: yes||so he went closer to the cows to get a better look.


Summary: Billy went to the farm to buy some beef for his brother's birthday.When he arrived there he saw that all six of the cows were sad and had brown spots.The cows were all eating their breakfast in a big grassy meadow.He thought that the spots looked very strange so he went closer to the cows to get a better look.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XX A BLIZZARD A bitter wind searched the poplar bluff where George and his hired man, Grierson, were cutting fuel. Except in the river valleys, trees of any size are scarce on the prairie, but the slender trunks and leafless branches were closely massed and afforded a little shelter. Outside on the open waste, the cold was almost too severe to face, and George once or twice glanced anxiously across the snowy levels, looking for some sign of Edgar, who should have joined them with the team and sledge. It was, however, difficult to see far, because a gray dimness narrowed in the horizon. George stood, dressed in snow-flecked furs, in the center of a little clearing strewn with rows of fallen trunks from which he was hewing off the branches. The work was hard; his whole body strained with each stroke of the heavy ax, but it failed to keep him warm, and the wind was growing more bitter with the approach of night. "I don't know what can be keeping West," he said after a while. "We haven't seen the mail-carrier either, and he's two hours late; but he must have had a heavy trail all the way from the settlement. I expect he'll cut out our place and make straight for Grant's. We'll have snow before long." There was an empty shack not far away where, by George's consent, the mail-carrier left letters when bad weather made it desirable to shorten his round. Grierson nodded as he glanced about. The stretch of desolate white prairie had contracted since he had last noticed it, the surrounding dimness was creeping nearer in, and the ranks of poplar trunks were losing their sharpness of form. Now that the men had ceased chopping, they could hear the eerie moaning of the wind and the sharp patter of icy snow-dust among the withered brush.


Q: Who were they waiting for?

A: Edgar|| looking for some sign of Edgar

Q: Who else?

A: West||I don't know what can be keeping West,

Q: Who was two hours late?

A: the mail-carrier||the mail-carrier either, and he's two hours late

Q: Where would the carrier go after leaving them?

A: Grant's|| I expect he'll cut out our place and make straight for Grant's

Q: How was the weather?

A: very cold|| the cold was almost too severe to face

Q: What was the employee's name?

A: Grierson||his hired man, Grierson

Q: Who was his boss?

A: George||George and his hired man

Q: What were they doing?

A: cutting fuel||George and his hired man, Grierson, were cutting fuel

Q: Are trees bountiful in that region?

A: no, trees of any size are scarce on the prairie||trees of any size are scarce on the prairie

Q: Was this an easy job?

A: no, The work was hard||The work was hard

Q: What would they cut with?

A: an ax||the heavy ax

Q: What was approaching?

A: the surrounding dimness||the surrounding dimness was creeping nearer in

Q: What time of day was it becoming?

A: night||the approach of night

Q: And what had stopped?

A: the men's chopping||the men had ceased chopping


Summary: CHAPTER XX A BLIZZARD A bitter wind searched the poplar bluff where George and his hired man, Grierson, were cutting fuel.Except in the river valleys, trees of any size are scarce on the prairie, but the slender trunks and leafless branches were closely massed and afforded a little shelter.Outside on the open waste, the cold was almost too severe to face, and George once or twice glanced anxiously across the snowy levels, looking for some sign of Edgar, who should have joined them with the team and sledge.The work was hard; his whole body strained with each stroke of the heavy ax, but it failed to keep him warm, and the wind was growing more bitter with the approach of night."I don't know what can be keeping West," he said after a while."We haven't seen the mail-carrier either, and he's two hours late; but he must have had a heavy trail all the way from the settlement.I expect he'll cut out our place and make straight for Grant's.The stretch of desolate white prairie had contracted since he had last noticed it, the surrounding dimness was creeping nearer in, and the ranks of poplar trunks were losing their sharpness of form.Now that the men had ceased chopping, they could hear the eerie moaning of the wind and the sharp patter of icy snow-dust among the withered brush.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER VIII. BRUCE AND THE WAR OF INDEPENDENCE. The position towards France of Edward I. made it really more desirable for him that Scotland should be independent and friendly, than half subdued and hostile to his rule. While she was hostile, England, in attacking France, always left an enemy in her rear. But Edward supposed that by clemency to all the Scottish leaders except Wallace, by giving them great appointments and trusting them fully, and by calling them to his Parliament in London, he could combine England and Scotland in affectionate union. He repaired the ruins of war in Scotland; he began to study her laws and customs; he hastily ran up for her a new constitution, and appointed his nephew, John of Brittany, as governor. But he had overlooked two facts: the Scottish clergy, from the highest to the lowest, were irreconcilably opposed to union with England; and the greatest and most warlike of the Scottish nobles, if not patriotic, were fickle and insatiably ambitious. It is hard to reckon how often Robert Bruce had turned his coat, and how often the Bishop of St Andrews had taken the oath to Edward. Both men were in Edward's favour in June 1304, but in that month they made against him a treasonable secret covenant. Through 1305 Bruce prospered in Edward's service, on February 10, 1306, Edward was conferring on him a new favour, little guessing that Bruce, after some negotiation with his old rival, the Red Comyn, had slain him (an uncle of his was also butchered) before the high altar of the Church of the Franciscans in Dumfries. Apparently Bruce had tried to enlist Comyn in his conspiracy, and had found him recalcitrant, or feared that he would be treacherous (February 10, 1306).


Q: How did Edward I feel that Scotland should act?

A: independent and friendly||independent and friendly

Q: as opposed to what?

A: subdued and hostile||subdued and hostile

Q: towards what?

A: to his rule||to his rule

Q: who always left an enemy?

A: England||England

Q: when?

A: in attacking France||in attacking France

Q: How did Edward think it best to unite England and Scotland?

A: in affectionate union||in affectionate union

Q: how did he attempt this?

A: study her laws and customs||study her laws and customs

Q: what else would he do?

A: ran up for her a new constitution||ran up for her a new constitution

Q: did he also think great appointments and trust would help?

A: yes||appointed his nephew

Q: who did he decide to appoint?

A: his nephew||his nephew

Q: as what?

A: as governor||as governor

Q: what was his name?

A: John||John

Q: where was he from?

A: Brittany||Brittany

Q: what fact had he forgotten?

A: some were opposed to this||opposed

Q: opposed to what?

A: union with England||union with England

Q: who was opposed?

A: Scottish clergy and nobles||Scottish clergy

Q: Who betrayed Edward?

A: Bishop of St Andrews||Bishop of St Andrews

Q: and who else?

A: Robert Bruce||Robert Bruce

Q: what did they do?

A: treasonable secret covenant|| treasonable secret covenant

Q: when?

A: June 1304||June 1304


Summary: The position towards France of Edward I. made it really more desirable for him that Scotland should be independent and friendly, than half subdued and hostile to his rule.While she was hostile, England, in attacking France, always left an enemy in her rear.But Edward supposed that by clemency to all the Scottish leaders except Wallace, by giving them great appointments and trusting them fully, and by calling them to his Parliament in London, he could combine England and Scotland in affectionate union.He repaired the ruins of war in Scotland; he began to study her laws and customs; he hastily ran up for her a new constitution, and appointed his nephew, John of Brittany, as governor.But he had overlooked two facts: the Scottish clergy, from the highest to the lowest, were irreconcilably opposed to union with England; and the greatest and most warlike of the Scottish nobles, if not patriotic, were fickle and insatiably ambitious.It is hard to reckon how often Robert Bruce had turned his coat, and how often the Bishop of St Andrews had taken the oath to Edward.Both men were in Edward's favour in June 1304, but in that month they made against him a treasonable secret covenant.

source: mctest

Luna the hawk wanted some socks. It was the middle of winter and sitting on tree branches made her feet very cold. Luna hoped that her friends could help her find some socks. She flew to the old maple tree where Olive the owl lived. "Olive, may I please borrow a pair of your socks?" she asked. Olive the owl looked surprised. "Luna, I have no use for socks because my legs and toes have thick feathers. Go visit one of the animals that walk on four legs. They might have extra socks you could borrow." Luna flew across the field and landed next to the icy creek. Rose the raccoon was teaching her six babies how to wash their paws. The water was very cold, but the babies were having fun. "Rose, my bare legs and bare toes are so cold, may I please borrow a pair of your socks?" begged Luna. Rose laughed hard. "Silly Luna, I do not have socks. Look at my legs and feet. They are covered with thick, warm fur. I'm sorry I cannot help you. Go visit the humans. Sometimes I tip over their garbage cans at night when I am looking for food. Once I saw a pair of socks." Luna was very afraid of humans. Her grandmother and mother had warned her about them. She was told that some humans are mean and hurt hawks. Her feet were so cold that it was difficult to grip tree branches. She became brave. She flew to the farmhouse on the big hill. When she landed on the roof, she could not believe her eyes. She saw socks! In late autumn, Henrietta the human had put laundry outside to dry and she had forgotten to bring in one tiny pair of socks. The socks were hanging on the clothesline by two wooden pins. Luna used her powerful beak to break the pins. She put on the socks and then flew back to her home in the huge tree. When she landed, her feet were warm and dry. Luna was very happy.


Q: What season was it?

A: winter|| It was the middle of winter

Q: What did Luna need?

A: socks||Luna the hawk wanted some socks

Q: Who did she first ask for socks?

A: Olive the owl||Olive the owl lived. "Olive, may I please borrow a pair of your socks?"

Q: Where does Olive live?

A: in the maple tree||She flew to the old maple tree where Olive the owl lived.

Q: Did she have socks?

A: no, I have no use for socks because my legs and toes have thick feathers. || I have no use for socks because my legs and toes have thick feathers.

Q: Why not?

A: her legs and toes have feathers||I have no use for socks because my legs and toes have thick feathers

Q: Where did Luna fly to next?

A: next to the creek||next to the icy creek

Q: Who was she looking for there?

A: Rose the raccoon||next to the icy creek. Rose the raccoon

Q: How many babies does she have?

A: Six|| Rose the raccoon was teaching her six babies

Q: Why didn't she have socks for Luna?

A: her legs were covered with fur.||hey are covered with thick, warm fur.

Q: Is Luna comfortable around people?

A: no, Luna was very afraid of humans.||Luna was very afraid of humans.

Q: Who warned her about them?

A: Her grandmother and mother||Her grandmother and mother had warned her about them

Q: Where did Luna see socks ?

A: on the clothesline||The socks were hanging on the clothesline

Q: Who put the socks there?

A: Henrietta the human||Henrietta the human had put laundry outside to dry and she had forgotten to bring in one tiny pair of socks.

Q: What did Luna use to break the clothes pins?

A: her beak||Luna used her powerful beak to break the pins.

Q: How did she feel when she returned home?

A: happy.||Luna was very happy.


Summary: Luna the hawk wanted some socks.It was the middle of winter and sitting on tree branches made her feet very cold.She flew to the old maple tree where Olive the owl lived."Luna, I have no use for socks because my legs and toes have thick feathers.Luna flew across the field and landed next to the icy creek.Rose the raccoon was teaching her six babies how to wash their paws.They are covered with thick, warm fur.Her grandmother and mother had warned her about them.In late autumn, Henrietta the human had put laundry outside to dry and she had forgotten to bring in one tiny pair of socks.The socks were hanging on the clothesline by two wooden pins.Luna used her powerful beak to break the pins.

source: race

When my father was dying, I traveled a thousand miles from home to be with him in his last days. It was far more heartbreaking than I'd expected, one of the most difficult and painful times in my life. After he passed away I stayed alone in his apartment. There were so many things to deal with. It all seemed endless. I was lonely. I hated the silence of the apartment. But one evening the silence was broken: I heard crying outside. I opened the door to find a little cat on the steps. He was thin and poor. He looked the way I felt. I brought him inside and gave him a can of fish. He ate it and then almost immediately fell sound asleep. The next morning I checked with neighbors and learned that the cat had been abandoned by his owner who's moved out. So the little cat was there all alone, just like I was. As I walked back to the apartment, I tried to figure out what to do with him. Having something else to take care of seemed _ But as soon as I opened the apartment door he came running and jumped into my arms. It was clear from that moment that he had no intention of going anywhere. I started calling him Willis, in honor of my father's best friend. From then on, things grew easier. With Willis in my lap time seemed to pass much more quickly. When the time finally came for me to return home I had to decide what to do about Willis. There was absolutely no way I would leave without him. It's now been five years since my father died. Over the years, several people have commented on how nice it was of me to rescue the cat. But I know that we rescued each other. I may have given him a home but he gave me something greater.


Q: What was crying?

A: a cat|| I heard crying outside. I opened the door to find a little cat

Q: what did the author feed it?

A: yes||I brought him inside and gave him a can of fish

Q: what did the author feed it?

A: fish|| I brought him inside and gave him a can of fish

Q: then what did the cat do?

A: fell asleep||He ate it and then almost immediately fell sound asleep

A: his father's apartment.||After he passed away I stayed alone in his apartment.

A: no, After he passed away I stayed alone in his apartment.|| After he passed away I stayed alone in his apartment.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Slovenia, officially the Republic of Slovenia (Slovene: , abbr.: "RS"), is a nation state located in the southern Central Europe, variously classified as part of Eastern and Southern Europe. The country is located at the crossroads of main European cultural and trade routes. It is bordered by Italy to the west, Austria to the north, Hungary to the northeast, Croatia to the south and southeast, and the Adriatic Sea to the southwest. It covers and has a population of 2.06 million. It is a parliamentary republic and a member of the United Nations, European Union, and NATO. The capital and largest city is Ljubljana. The territory is mostly mountainous with a mainly continental climate, with the exception of the Slovene Littoral that has a sub-Mediterranean climate and the north-western area that has an Alpine climate. Additionally, the Dinaric Alps and the Pannonian Plain meet on the territory of Slovenia. The country, marked by a significant biological diversity, is one of the most water-rich in Europe, with a dense river network, a rich aquifer system, and significant karst underground watercourses. Over half of the territory is covered by forest. The human settlement of Slovenia is dispersed and uneven. Slovenia has historically been the crossroads of West Slavic, South Slavic, Germanic, Romance, and Hungarian languages and culture. Although the population is not homogeneous, the majority is Slovene. South Slavic language Slovene is the official language throughout the country. Slovenia is a largely secularized country, but its culture and identity have been significantly influenced by Catholicism as well as Lutheranism. The economy of Slovenia is small, open, and export-oriented and has been strongly influenced by international conditions. It has been severely hurt by the Eurozone crisis, started in the late 2000s. The main economic field is services, followed by industry and construction.


Q: what nation has Ljublijana as the capital?

A: Slovenia||The capital and largest city is Ljubljana.

Q: what's the official name?

A: the Republic of Slovenia||Slovenia, officially the Republic of Slovenia (Slovene: , abbr.: "RS"),

Q: what is another name for it?

A: Slovene||Slovene: , abbr.: "RS"

Q: how is it abbreviated?

A: RS||Slovene: , abbr.: "RS"

Q: where is it?

A: in southern Central Europe||is a nation state located in the southern Central Europe

Q: where is it considered to belong?

A: as part of Eastern and Southern Europe||ariously classified as part of Eastern and Southern Europe

Q: which border does it share with Italy?

A: its western border||It is bordered by Italy to the west

Q: who does it border to the north?

A: Austria||Austria to the north

Q: what about northeast?

A: Hungary||Hungary to the northeast,

Q: and where does it border croatiA?

A: to the south and southeast||Croatia to the south and southeast

Q: and does it border a body of water?

A: the Adriatic Sea||and the Adriatic Sea to the southwest.

Q: which border?

A: the southwestern border||the Adriatic Sea to the southwest

Q: what is the population?

A: 2.06 million.|| It covers and has a population of 2.06 million.

Q: which city is the biggest?

A: Ljubljana||he capital and largest city is Ljubljana.

A: yes||It is a parliamentary republic and a member of the United Nations, European Union, and NATO.

A: yes||It is a parliamentary republic and a member of the United Nations, European Union, and NATO.

Q: and what else?

A: the European Union||It is a parliamentary republic and a member of the United Nations, European Union,

A: a parliamentary republic||It is a parliamentary republic and a member of the United Nations


Summary: Slovenia, officially the Republic of Slovenia (Slovene: , abbr.: "RS"), is a nation state located in the southern Central Europe, variously classified as part of Eastern and Southern Europe.It is bordered by Italy to the west, Austria to the north, Hungary to the northeast, Croatia to the south and southeast, and the Adriatic Sea to the southwest.It covers and has a population of 2.06 million.It is a parliamentary republic and a member of the United Nations, European Union, and NATO.The capital and largest city is Ljubljana.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XII. TRANSFORMATION 'Well, now for the second stage of our guardianship!' said Aunt Ada, as the two sisters sat over the fire after Valetta had gone to bed. 'Fergus comes back to-morrow, and Gillian---when?' 'She does not seem quite certain, for there is to be a day or two at Brompton with this delightful Geraldine, so that she may see her grandmother---also Mr. Clement Underwood's church, and the Merchant of Venice---an odd mixture of ecclesiastics and dissipations.' 'I wonder whether she will be set up by it.' 'So do I! They are all remarkably good people; but then good people do sometimes spoil the most of all, for they are too unselfish to snub. And on the other hand, seeing the world sometimes has the wholesome effect of making one feel small---' 'My dear Jenny!' 'Oh! I did not mean you, who are never easily effaced; but I was thinking of youthful bumptiousness, fostered by country life and elder sistership.' 'Certainly, though Valetta is really much improved, Gillian has not been as pleasant as I expected, especially during the latter part of the time.' 'Query, was it her fault or mine, or the worry of the examination, or all three?' 'Perhaps you did superintend a little too much at first. More than modern independence was prepared for, though I should not have expected recalcitration in a young Lily; but I think there was more ruffling of temper and more reserve than I can quite understand.' 'It has not been a success. As dear old Lily would have said, "My dream has vanished," of a friend in the younger generation, and now it remains to do the best I can for her in the few weeks that are left, before we have her dear mother again.'


Q: Who were sitting over the fire?

A: the two sisters|| the two sisters sat over the fire

Q: Who had gone to bed?

A: Valetta||Valetta had gone to bed

Q: Who is coming back tomorrow?

A: Fergus||Fergus comes back to-morrow

Q: Where is Gillian spending a day or two?

A: Brompton|| a day or two at Brompton

Q: who does she want to see there?

A: her grandmother||she may see her grandmother-

Q: Do they think they're bad people?

A: no, They are all remarkably good people||They are all remarkably good people

Q: Has Gillian been pleasant?

A: no, Gillian has not been as pleasant||Gillian has not been as pleasant

Q: especially when?

A: the latter part of the time||especially during the latter part of the time

Q: Is Lily old?

A: no, in a young Lily|| in a young Lily

Q: Is there anger?

A: yes|| but I think there was more ruffling of temper


Summary: said Aunt Ada, as the two sisters sat over the fire after Valetta had gone to bed.'Fergus comes back to-morrow, and Gillian---when?''She does not seem quite certain, for there is to be a day or two at Brompton with this delightful Geraldine, so that she may see her grandmother---also Mr. Clement Underwood's church, and the Merchant of Venice---an odd mixture of ecclesiastics and dissipations.'They are all remarkably good people; but then good people do sometimes spoil the most of all, for they are too unselfish to snub.'Certainly, though Valetta is really much improved, Gillian has not been as pleasant as I expected, especially during the latter part of the time.'More than modern independence was prepared for, though I should not have expected recalcitration in a young Lily; but I think there was more ruffling of temper and more reserve than I can quite understand.'

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER V--CLIPSTONE FRIENDS "What idle progeny succeed To chase the rolling circle's speed, Or urge the flying ball."--GRAY. The afternoon at Clipstone was a success. Gillian was at home, and every one found congeners. Lady Merrifield's sister, Miss Mohun, pounced upon Miss Prescott as a coadjutor in the alphabet of good works needed in the neglected district of Arnscombe, where Mr. Earl was wifeless, and the farm ladies heedless; but they were interrupted by Mysie running up to claim Miss Prescott for a game at croquet. "Uncle Redgie was so glad to see the hoops come into fashion again," and Vera and Paula hardly knew the game, they had always played at lawn tennis; but they were delighted to learn, for Uncle Redgie proved to be a very fine-looking retired General, and there was a lad besides, grown to manly height; and one boy, at home for Easter, who, caring not for croquet, went with Primrose to exhibit to Thekla the tame menagerie, where a mungoose, called of course Raki raki, was the last acquisition. She was also shown the kittens of the beloved Begum, and presented with Phoebus, a tabby with a wise face and a head marked like a Greek lyre, to be transplanted to the Goyle in due time. "If Sister will let me have it," said Thekla. "Of course she will," said Primrose. "Mysie says she is so jolly." "Dear me! all the girls at our school said she was a regular Old Maid." "What shocking bad form!" exclaimed Primrose. "Just like cads of girls," muttered Fergus, unheard; for Thekla continued--"Why, they said she must be our maiden aunt, instead of our sister."

A: Miss Mohun||Lady Merrifield's sister, Miss Mohun

Q: What place needs some attention?

A: Arnscombe||neglected district of Arnscombe

Q: Who want's to take Miss Prescott from the conversation?

A: Mysie|| interrupted by Mysie running up to claim Miss Prescott

Q: To do what?

A: game of croquet||claim Miss Prescott for a game at croquet.

Q: Is Mr. Earl married?

A: no, Mr. Earl was wifeless||Mr. Earl was wifeless

Summary: Lady Merrifield's sister, Miss Mohun, pounced upon Miss Prescott as a coadjutor in the alphabet of good works needed in the neglected district of Arnscombe, where Mr. Earl was wifeless, and the farm ladies heedless; but they were interrupted by Mysie running up to claim Miss Prescott for a game at croquet."Uncle Redgie was so glad to see the hoops come into fashion again," and Vera and Paula hardly knew the game, they had always played at lawn tennis; but they were delighted to learn, for Uncle Redgie proved to be a very fine-looking retired General, and there was a lad besides, grown to manly height; and one boy, at home for Easter, who, caring not for croquet, went with Primrose to exhibit to Thekla the tame menagerie, where a mungoose, called of course Raki raki, was the last acquisition.She was also shown the kittens of the beloved Begum, and presented with Phoebus, a tabby with a wise face and a head marked like a Greek lyre, to be transplanted to the Goyle in due time.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- American journalist Michael Scott Moore, held for more than two years by Somali pirates, has been freed, Moore's family and a Somali official told CNN on Tuesday. "We are just elated," Marlis Saunders, Moore's mother, said in a brief conversation. "It took a lot of work for us to get this point. And to hear he is free -- just joyful, I can't describe it." "All this is just so new," said Saunders, who lives in Redondo Beach, California. "I did not have much time to talk with him. We just have a lot of things to do and I cannot talk anymore. We need a little time to evaluate all this." The governor of Somalia's Mudug region, Ahmed Muse, told CNN that local elders negotiated Moore's release, adding that the journalist is "physically and mentally" worn out. Moore boarded a plane at an airport in Galkayo, in the north-central part of Somalia, Muse said. Muse would not say where the journalist is headed. "I'm absolutely thrilled," said Michel Todd, who was Moore's web editor at Pacific Standard magazine. "It's like seeing somebody come back from the dead. It's a marvelous resurrection." Todd said Moore was a weekly freelance columnist who wrote often about Somalia. He had been researching Somali pirates. "As a news organization, we wanted to write about his capture," Todd said. "But we had been encouraged by the FBI and State Department to (not) write about it because this would hurt his cause. They said, if you really care about the guy, that is not a good idea, raising his profile would make his release more difficult."


Q: Who had 2 years of being held?

A: Michael Scott Moore||Michael Scott Moore

Q: what happened to him?

A: freed||freed

Q: from who?

A: Somali pirates||Somali pirates

Q: after how long?

A: more than two years||more than two years

Q: Did anyone feel about this?

A: Yes||We are just elated

Q: who?

A: Marlis Saunders||Marlis Saunders

Q: who was that?

A: Moore's mother||Moore's mother

Q: how did she feel?

A: elated||elated

Q: why?

A: to hear he is free|| to hear he is free

Q: how does she describe it?

A: She can't.||I can't describe it


Summary: (CNN) -- American journalist Michael Scott Moore, held for more than two years by Somali pirates, has been freed, Moore's family and a Somali official told CNN on Tuesday."We are just elated," Marlis Saunders, Moore's mother, said in a brief conversation.And to hear he is free -- just joyful, I can't describe it."

source: mctest

Once upon a time there was a boy monster named Jerry who lived in a train car at the railroad tracks. He had lived there all his life. Jerry's mother was named Marge, and she was 36. Marge raised Jerry at the railroad tracks because she wanted to keep him safe. She was afraid of the people who lived in the town nearby. The town was named Qarth, and 100 people lived there. Marge believed that the people of Qarth would attack them if they knew they were there. Qarth used to be filled with factories when Jerry was born. By the time Jerry was a teenager, most of the factories had gone away and most of the people worked on special new machines. They ate food from the fields outside of town. Their favorite food to eat was a special kind of corn. They didn't eat meat because nobody raised any farm animals. One day when he was 11, Jerry asked his mother who his father had been. His father's name was George, and he was 2 years older than Marge. Marge looked sad and told Jerry that George had left after he was born because the people in the town didn't like him. This made Jerry very sad. He went off to his corner of the car and didn't talk to Marge again until she went to bed. After she fell asleep he wanted to go out and look for his father. He packed some food and left. When Marge woke up she was upset, but she thought she knew where he had gone.


Q: What was the boy monster's name?

A: Jerry||there was a boy monster named Jerry

Q: Where did he live?

A: in a train car at the railroad tracks||in a train car at the railroad tracks

Q: How long had he lived there?

A: all his life||He had lived there all his life

Q: What was his mom's name?

A: Marge||Jerry's mother was named Marge

Q: how old was she?

A: 36||she was 36

Q: Why did she raise him at the tracks?

A: to keep him safe|| she wanted to keep him safe

Q: from what?

A: the people who lived in the town nearby||the people who lived in the town nearby

Q: What was it called?

A: Qarth||The town was named Qarth

Q: How many people lived there?

A: 100||100 people lived there

Q: What did Marge believe would happen?

A: that the people of Qarth would attack them|| Marge believed that the people of Qarth would attack them if they knew they were there

Q: What was their favorite food?

A: a special kind of corn|| Their favorite food to eat was a special kind of corn

Q: Did they eat meat?

A: They didn't eat meat||They didn't eat meat

Q: What was his father's name?

A: George||His father's name was George

Q: How old was he?

A: 2 years older than his mother||he was 2 years older than Marge

Q: Why did his father leave?

A: the people in the town didn't like him|| because the people in the town didn't like him

Q: Did this make him sad?

A: yes||This made Jerry very sad

Q: Did he go look for his father?

A: yes|| he wanted to go out and look for his father

Q: Was his mother upset?

A: yes||she was upset


Summary: Once upon a time there was a boy monster named Jerry who lived in a train car at the railroad tracks.He had lived there all his life.Jerry's mother was named Marge, and she was 36.Marge raised Jerry at the railroad tracks because she wanted to keep him safe.She was afraid of the people who lived in the town nearby.The town was named Qarth, and 100 people lived there.Marge believed that the people of Qarth would attack them if they knew they were there.Their favorite food to eat was a special kind of corn.They didn't eat meat because nobody raised any farm animals.His father's name was George, and he was 2 years older than Marge.Marge looked sad and told Jerry that George had left after he was born because the people in the town didn't like him.This made Jerry very sad.After she fell asleep he wanted to go out and look for his father.When Marge woke up she was upset, but she thought she knew where he had gone.

source: wikipedia

Endemism is the ecological state of a species being unique to a defined geographic location, such as an island, nation, country or other defined zone, or habitat type; organisms that are indigenous to a place are not endemic to it if they are also found elsewhere. The extreme opposite of endemism is cosmopolitan distribution. An alternative term for a species that is endemic is precinctive, which applies to species (and subspecific categories) that are restricted to a defined geographical area. The word "endemic" is from New Latin "endēmicus", from Greek ενδήμος, "endēmos", "native". "Endēmos" is formed of "en" meaning "in", and "dēmos" meaning "the people". The term "precinctive" has been suggested by some scientists, and was first used in botany by MacCaughey in 1917. It is the equivalent of "endemism". "Precinction" was perhaps first used by Frank and McCoy. "Precinctive" seems to have been coined by David Sharp when describing the Hawaiian fauna in 1900: "I use the word precinctive in the sense of 'confined to the area under discussion' ... 'precinctive forms' means those forms that are confined to the area specified." That definition excludes artificial confinement of examples by humans in far-off botanical gardens or zoological parks. Physical, climatic, and biological factors can contribute to endemism. The orange-breasted sunbird is exclusively found in the fynbos vegetation zone of southwestern South Africa. The glacier bear is found only in limited places in Southeast Alaska. Political factors can play a part if a species is protected, or actively hunted, in one jurisdiction but not another.


Q: How many factors contribute to endemism?

A: Three.||Physical, climatic, and biological factors can contribute to endemism

Q: Is psychological one of those?

A: No.||Physical, climatic, and biological factors can contribute to endemism.

Q: What about biological?

A: Yes.||Physical, climatic, and biological factors can contribute to endemism

Q: What are the other two?

A: Physical and climatic||Physical, climatic, and biological factors can contribute to endemism

Q: In what country is the orange breasted sunbird found?

A: South Africa||The orange-breasted sunbird is exclusively found in the fynbos vegetation zone of southwestern South Africa

Q: Is it found throughout the country?

A: No, The orange-breasted sunbird is exclusively found in the fynbos vegetation zone of southwestern South Africa||The orange-breasted sunbird is exclusively found in the fynbos vegetation zone of southwestern South Africa

Q: Which region of South Africa?

A: southwestern||The orange-breasted sunbird is exclusively found in the fynbos vegetation zone of southwestern South Africa

Q: And what zone?

A: Fynbos vegetation zone.||The orange-breasted sunbird is exclusively found in the fynbos vegetation zone of southwestern South Africa

Q: Does the term endemic have a latin root?

A: Yes||The word "endemic" is from New Latin "endēmicus",

Q: What else?

A: Greek||The word "endemic" is from New Latin "endēmicus", from Greek ενδήμος, "endēmos", "native". "Endēmos" is formed of "en" meaning "in", and "dēmos" meaning "the people

Q: What would "en" translate to?

A: "in"||" is formed of "en" meaning "in"

Q: And "demos"?

A: "the people"||and "dēmos" meaning "the people"

Q: What term means the same thing?

A: Precinctive||The term "precinctive" has been suggested by some scientists, and was first used in botany by MacCaughey in 1917. It is the equivalent of "endemism".

Q: Who first used that?

A: MacCaughey|| The term "precinctive" has been suggested by some scientists, and was first used in botany by MacCaughey

Q: Was he studying animal species?

A: No.||and was first used in botany by MacCaughey in 1917. It is the equivalent of "endemism".

A: Yes.||organisms that are indigenous to a place are not endemic to it if they are also found elsewhere

Q: What would cause that?

A: They are also found elsewhere.||organisms that are indigenous to a place are not endemic to it if they are also found elsewhere.

Q: What is its opposite?

A: Cosmopolitan distribution||The extreme opposite of endemism is cosmopolitan distribution

Q: What is the definition of endemism?

A: The ecological state of a species being unique to a defined geographic location||Endemism is the ecological state of a species being unique to a defined geographic location

Q: Give me one example of a geographic location in this sense.

A: An island|| to a defined geographic location, such as an island, nation,


Summary: Endemism is the ecological state of a species being unique to a defined geographic location, such as an island, nation, country or other defined zone, or habitat type; organisms that are indigenous to a place are not endemic to it if they are also found elsewhere.The extreme opposite of endemism is cosmopolitan distribution.The word "endemic" is from New Latin "endēmicus", from Greek ενδήμος, "endēmos", "native"."Endēmos" is formed of "en" meaning "in", and "dēmos" meaning "the people".The term "precinctive" has been suggested by some scientists, and was first used in botany by MacCaughey in 1917.Physical, climatic, and biological factors can contribute to endemism.The orange-breasted sunbird is exclusively found in the fynbos vegetation zone of southwestern South Africa.

source: mctest

Bob had a son that was named John. John owned the only red dog. There was a blue dog named Jim. The red dog was named Woof. John's mother and Bob's wife was named Gail. They all lived in a tree. There was a family down the street. They were a couple named Frank and Francine. Bob hated his neighbors. One day Bob went to Frank's house and threw toilet paper all over his trees. Frank got back at Bob by stealing his son's dog. This is how the long fight between Frank and Bob began. It lasted for ten years until Bob passed away from a bad heart attack. Frank knew he needed to say sorry to Bob's wife for the years of trouble. So Frank did apologize to Bob's wife. After this everything was great between the two families for the rest of their days on this Earth.


Q: Does Bob have children?

A: yes||Bob had a son that was named John

Q: Which pet is red?

A: Woof.||The red dog was named Woof.

Q: Who is Gail?

A: John's mother and Bob's wife||John's mother and Bob's wife was named Gail.

Q: Does Bob like his neighbors?

A: no, This is how the long fight between Frank and Bob began.||This is how the long fight between Frank and Bob began.

Q: Who is Frank?

A: Francine's husband||They were a couple named Frank and Francine

Q: What lasted for 10 years?

A: 10 years||This is how the long fight between Frank and Bob began. It lasted for ten years

Q: Did Frank apologize to Bob?

A: no, So Frank did apologize to Bob's wife.||So Frank did apologize to Bob's wife.

Q: Who did Frank apologize to?

A: Bob's wife||Frank did apologize to Bob's wife

Q: What happened to Bob?

A: he passed away||Bob passed away from a bad heart attack

Q: From what?

A: a heart attack.||Bob passed away from a bad heart attack.


Summary: Bob had a son that was named John.The red dog was named Woof.John's mother and Bob's wife was named Gail.They were a couple named Frank and Francine.This is how the long fight between Frank and Bob began.It lasted for ten years until Bob passed away from a bad heart attack.So Frank did apologize to Bob's wife.

source: mctest

Jamie and his friends love playing baseball. They play in the park every morning. One summer morning they lost the baseball. Jamie and his friend Joe went to the store. They bought two baseballs. They also bought colas for the other kids. They spent ten dollars. Jamie and Joe went back to the park. His friend Mike drank his cola and went to bat. Mike hit a home run and rounded the bases. All of Jamie's friends cheered very loudly. The sun was very bright and Jamie had an idea. Jamie and his friends went to the pool in town and swam that afternoon. They met Sally and Jessica at the pool. They also met Jenny at the pool. The lifeguard made them put their sandals, watches and hats by the fence. Jamie went home after swimming. He was very tired. He went to sleep but had a lot of fun that day.


Q: where does Jamie play every morning?

A: the park||in the park

Q: is he with anyone?

A: yes||They

Q: what do they like to play?

A: baseball||his friends love playing baseball

Q: where did they go after they lost their ball?

A: the store|| went to the store

Q: what did they buy?

A: baseballs|| two baseballs

Q: how many?

A: two|| two baseballs

Q: did they buy anything else?

A: colas||They also bought colas

Q: how much did they spend?

A: ten dollars||They spent ten dollars

Q: where did they go after they were done at the store?

A: the park||went back to the park

Q: who hit a home run?

A: Mike||Mike hit a home run

Q: Did his friends cheer?

A: yes||Jamie's friends cheered very loudly

Q: Did Jamie go to the pool after?

A: yes|| Jamie and his friends went to the pool in town

Q: who did he meet there?

A: Sally, Jessica, and Jenny||They met Sally and Jessica at the pool. They also met Jenny at the pool.

Q: Was he tired after swimming?

A: yes||Jamie went home after swimming. He was very tired.


Summary: Jamie and his friends love playing baseball.They play in the park every morning.Jamie and his friend Joe went to the store.They bought two baseballs.They also bought colas for the other kids.They spent ten dollars.Jamie and Joe went back to the park.Mike hit a home run and rounded the bases.All of Jamie's friends cheered very loudly.Jamie and his friends went to the pool in town and swam that afternoon.They met Sally and Jessica at the pool.Jamie went home after swimming.
