source: race

Ron Meyer is the president and COO of Universal Studios.As one of the most successful business leaders in Hollywood, he heads up Universal Pictures and Universal Parks & Resorts.He's the guy who oversees the production of Multimillion-dollar extravaganzas likeKing KongandCinderella Man. Meyer's story sounds like the plot of one of his motion pictures.He grew up in a modest home where there was little income.It was a big deal to go to a restaurant.At 15, he quit high school and spent his time hanging out with the neighborhood toughs .He was then a kid quick with his fists who seemed to get into fights somewhat regularly.At one point, he was separated from others with an infectious disease, having no TV and nothing to do.His mother sent him two books.One wasThe Amboy Dukes, a novel about kids in street gangs.The other wasThe Flesh Peddlers, about a guy in the talent agency who lived a successful life."I realized," he says, "that I was no longer that silly kid I had been, and I wanted to change my life." Meyer took any job he could get.He worked as a busboy and short-order cook.He cleaned offices and sold shoes.That attitude made an impression on people.One day he received a call from Paul Kohner, a successful agent who represented stars like John Huston, Charles Bronson and Lana Turner.Their messenger and driver had quit, and they knew Ron was willing to take whatever job they offered. He started the job the next day. Meyer was lucky to work with a good boss--and _ .In nearly six years of driving for Kohner, Meyer became his right-hand man and learned a lot.By the 1970s, Meyer had built many relationships in the business.In 1975, the fate presented an opportunity and he started his own operation Creative Artists Agency, which became a huge success, representing Hollywood legends like Barbra Streisand, Tom Hanks and Tom Cruise. Twenty years later, Meyer was appointed to run Universal Studios, a position far beyond his youthful dream.But once he saw success was possible, he was driven to achieve it.Today, colleagues regularly owe his success--and theirs--to his humility and perseverance.It's a level of success that takes determination, personality and intelligence, whether it comes from a college education or from the street.


Q: Meyer grew up where ?

A: Universal Parks & Resorts.||Universal Parks & Resorts.

Q: where is he the president ?

A: Universal Studios||Universal Studios

Q: hom many multi million dollar productions he did ?

A: Two||King KongandCinderella Man

Q: did he finish school ?

A: no, he quit high schoo||he quit high schoo

Q: how old was he ?

A: 15||15

Q: how did he spend time ?

A: hanging out with the neighborhood toughs||hanging out with the neighborhood toughs

Q: Paul Kohner is who ?

A: successful agen|| successful agen

Q: how many stars sis he repressent ?

A: Three||hn Huston, Charles Bronson and Lana Turner

Q: name 2

A: John Huston, Charles Bronson||John Huston, Charles Bronson

Q: how many years did he drive for someone ?

A: six years||six years

Q: for who ?

A: Kohner||Kohner


Summary: Ron Meyer is the president and COO of Universal Studios.As one of the most successful business leaders in Hollywood, he heads up Universal Pictures and Universal Parks & Resorts.He's the guy who oversees the production of Multimillion-dollar extravaganzas likeKing KongandCinderella Man.Meyer's story sounds like the plot of one of his motion pictures.He grew up in a modest home where there was little income.It was a big deal to go to a restaurant.At 15, he quit high school and spent his time hanging out with the neighborhood toughs .He was then a kid quick with his fists who seemed to get into fights somewhat regularly.At one point, he was separated from others with an infectious disease, having no TV and nothing to do.His mother sent him two books.One wasThe Amboy Dukes, a novel about kids in street gangs.The other wasThe Flesh Peddlers, about a guy in the talent agency who lived a successful life.Meyer took any job he could get.He worked as a busboy and short-order cook.He cleaned offices and sold shoes.That attitude made an impression on people.One day he received a call from Paul Kohner, a successful agent who represented stars like John Huston, Charles Bronson and Lana Turner.Their messenger and driver had quit, and they knew Ron was willing to take whatever job they offered.Meyer was lucky to work with a good boss--and _ .In nearly six years of driving for Kohner, Meyer became his right-hand man and learned a lot.By the 1970s, Meyer had built many relationships in the business.In 1975, the fate presented an opportunity and he started his own operation Creative Artists Agency, which became a huge success, representing Hollywood legends like Barbra Streisand, Tom Hanks and Tom Cruise.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER VIII A SCENE IN THE GYMNASIUM Lew Flapp spoke in such a loud, overbearing voice that a crowd began to collect in the corner where the punching apparatus was located. "What's up?" asked more than one cadet. "Lew Flapp and Dick Rover are going to try to beat each other at punching the bag," was the report. "Rover will have to do his best then. Flapp is a prime one at bag punching. It's about the only thing he can do real well." "This isn't a fair contest," put in another student. "Flapp took lessons from a man who used to do bag-punching on the vaudeville stage." "If that's so I wouldn't try to beat him, if I was Dick Rover." Dick heard some of this talk but said nothing. He was soon ready for the trial, and stepping up to the punching bag he began to undo the top strap. "That bag is all right," blustered Lew Flapp. "Yes--for you," answered Dick. "But you must remember, I am not quite so tall. I must have it an inch lower." "It seems to me you are mighty particular." "I have a right to be. When you do your punching you can raise the bag as high as you please." "That's the talk," came from several standing near. By this time Larry was on the floor again, and he came up to learn what Dick was doing. "Dick, they tell me he is the best bag-puncher here," whispered Larry. "I can't help it."


Q: What is the title?

A: A SCENE IN THE GYMNASIUM|| A SCENE IN THE GYMNASIUM

Q: Who was being overly vocal?

A: Lew Flapp||Lew Flapp spoke in such a loud, overbearing voice

Q: What did it cause to form

A: a crowd||Lew Flapp spoke in such a loud, overbearing voice that a crowd began to collect in the corner where the punching apparatus was located.

Q: What was about to happen?

A: "Lew Flapp and Dick Rover are competing||"Lew Flapp and Dick Rover are going to try to beat each other at punching the bag," was the report.

Q: What was the competition?

A: punching the bag|| going to try to beat each other at punching the bag," was the report.

A: Flapp is|| Flapp is a prime one at bag punching.

A: a vaudeville man||"This isn't a fair contest," put in another student. "Flapp took lessons from a man who used to do bag-punching on the vaudeville stage."

A: he heard them but didn't say anything||Dick heard some of this talk but said nothing. He was soon ready for the trial, and stepping up to the punching bag he began to undo the top strap.

A: un did the top strap||stepping up to the punching bag he began to undo the top strap.

A: he is not so tall|| "But you must remember, I am not quite so tall. I must have it an inch lower."


Summary: CHAPTER VIII A SCENE IN THE GYMNASIUM Lew Flapp spoke in such a loud, overbearing voice that a crowd began to collect in the corner where the punching apparatus was located."Lew Flapp and Dick Rover are going to try to beat each other at punching the bag," was the report.Flapp is a prime one at bag punching."This isn't a fair contest," put in another student.Dick heard some of this talk but said nothing.He was soon ready for the trial, and stepping up to the punching bag he began to undo the top strap."That bag is all right," blustered Lew Flapp."But you must remember, I am not quite so tall.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Ordination is the process by which individuals are consecrated, that is, set apart as clergy to perform various religious rites and ceremonies. The process and ceremonies of ordination vary by religion and denomination. One who is in preparation for, or who is undergoing the process of ordination is sometimes called an ordinand. The liturgy used at an ordination is sometimes referred to as an ordination. The tradition of the ordained monastic community ("sangha") began with the Buddha, who established orders of monks and later of nuns. The procedure of ordination in Buddhism is laid down in the Vinaya and Patimokkha or Pratimoksha scriptures. There exist three intact ordination lineages nowadays in which one can receive an ordination according to the Buddha's teachings: Saicho repeatedly requested that the Japanese government allow the construction of a Mahayana ordination platform. Permission was granted in 822 CE, seven days after Saicho died. The platform was finished in 827 CE at Enryaku-ji temple on Mount Hiei, and was the first in Japan. Prior to this, those wishing to become monks/nuns were ordained using the Hinayana precepts, whereas after the Mahayana ordination platform, people were ordained with the Bodhisattva precepts as listed in the Brahma Net Sutra.


Q: What is the article about?

A: Ordination||Ordination

Q: What is the meaning of it?

A: process by which individuals are consecrated||Ordination is the process by which individuals are consecrated

Q: Who did it begin with?

A: Buddha||The tradition of the ordained monastic community ("sangha") began with the Buddha

Q: What else is Buddha responsible for?

A: established orders of monks||Buddha, who established orders of monks

Q: Where can you find the procedure outlinw?

A: Pratimoksha scriptures|| The procedure of ordination in Buddhism is laid down in the Vinaya and Patimokkha or Pratimoksha scriptures.

Q: How many lineages are there?

A: three||There exist three intact ordination lineages nowadays

Q: What is one called that is pursuing the certification?

A: ordinand||One who is in preparation for, or who is undergoing the process of ordination is sometimes called an ordinand.

Q: Who requested of the ordination platform for Japan?

A: Saicho||Saicho repeatedly requested that the Japanese government

A: Mahayana ordination platform||Saicho repeatedly requested that the Japanese government allow the construction of a Mahayana ordination platform

Q: Was it granted?

A: Yes||Permission was granted

Q: When?

A: 822 CE||Permission was granted in 822 CE


Summary: Ordination is the process by which individuals are consecrated, that is, set apart as clergy to perform various religious rites and ceremonies.One who is in preparation for, or who is undergoing the process of ordination is sometimes called an ordinand.The tradition of the ordained monastic community ("sangha") began with the Buddha, who established orders of monks and later of nuns.The procedure of ordination in Buddhism is laid down in the Vinaya and Patimokkha or Pratimoksha scriptures.There exist three intact ordination lineages nowadays in which one can receive an ordination according to the Buddha's teachings: Saicho repeatedly requested that the Japanese government allow the construction of a Mahayana ordination platform.Permission was granted in 822 CE, seven days after Saicho died.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Weimar Republic was an unofficial, historical designation for the German state between 1919 and 1933. The name derives from the city of Weimar, where its constitutional assembly first took place. The official name of the state was "Deutsches Reich"; it had remained unchanged since 1871. In English the country was usually known simply as Germany. A national assembly was convened in Weimar, where a new constitution for the "Deutsches Reich" was written, and adopted on 11 August 1919. In its fourteen years, the Weimar Republic faced numerous problems, including hyperinflation, political extremism (with paramilitaries – both left- and right-wing), as well as contentious relationships with the victors of the First World War. The people of Germany blamed the Weimar Republic rather than their wartime leaders for the country's defeat and for the humiliating terms of the Treaty of Versailles. Weimar Germany fulfilled most of the requirements of the Treaty of Versailles although it never completely met its disarmament requirements, and eventually paid only a small portion of the war reparations (by twice restructuring its debt through the Dawes Plan and the Young Plan). Under the Locarno Treaties, Germany accepted the western borders of the republic, but continued to dispute the Eastern border.


Q: What was an unofficial designation

A: the Weimar Republic||Weimar Republic was an unofficial, historical designation

Q: For what?

A: the German state||Weimar Republic was an unofficial, historical designation for the German state

Q: During what year?

A: between 1919 and 1933||historical designation for the German state between 1919 and 1933

Q: Was Weimar a city?

A: Yes||he name derives from the city of Weimar

Q: What took place there?

A: its constitutional assembly|| Weimar, where its constitutional assembly

Q: What was the official name?

A: Deutsches Reich||The official name of the state was "Deutsches Reich

Q: When did that begin?

A: 1871||"Deutsches Reich"; it had remained unchanged since 1871

Q: What was adopted in 1919

A: a new constitution||new constitution for the "Deutsches Reich" was written, and adopted on 11 August 1919.

Q: What month?

A: August||adopted on 11 August

Q: What day?

A: the 11th||adopted on 11 Augus

Q: What happened in the 14th year

A: unknown||unknown


Summary: Weimar Republic was an unofficial, historical designation for the German state between 1919 and 1933.The name derives from the city of Weimar, where its constitutional assembly first took place.The official name of the state was "Deutsches Reich"; it had remained unchanged since 1871.A national assembly was convened in Weimar, where a new constitution for the "Deutsches Reich" was written, and adopted on 11 August 1919.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER 6 Can piety the discord heal, Or stanch the death-feud's enmity? --Scott It must not be supposed that such a history of Guy's mind was expressed by himself, or understood by Mrs. Edmonstone; but she saw enough to guess at his character, perceive the sort of guidance he needed, and be doubly interested in him. Much did she wish he could have such a friend as her brother would have been, and hope that nothing would prevent a friendship with her nephew. The present question about the horse was, she thought, unfortunate, since, though Guy had exercised great self-denial, it was no wonder Philip was annoyed. Mr. Edmonstone's vexation was soon over. As soon as she had persuaded him that there had been no offence, he strove to say with a good grace, that it was very proper, and told Guy he would be a thorough book-worm and tremendous scholar, which Guy took as an excellent joke. Philip had made up his mind to be forbearing, and to say no more about it. Laura thought this a pity, as they could thus never come to an understanding; but when she hinted it, he wore such a dignified air of not being offended, that she was much ashamed of having tried to direct one so much better able to judge. On his side Guy had no idea the trouble he had caused; so, after bestowing his thanks in a gay, off-hand way, which Philip thought the worst feature of the case, he did his best to bring Hecuba back into his mind, drive the hunters out of it, and appease the much-aggrieved William of Deloraine.


Q: Who wanted a friend like her brother?

A: Mrs. Edmonstone||Much did she wish he could have such a friend as her brother

Q: Who was annoyed?

A: Philip||it was no wonder Philip was annoyed

Q: Was Guy annoyed about the idea of being a bookworm?

A: No, told Guy he would be a thorough book-worm and tremendous scholar, which Guy took as an excellent joke||told Guy he would be a thorough book-worm and tremendous scholar, which Guy took as an excellent joke

Q: What did he think of it?

A: Hecuba||he did his best to bring Hecuba back into his mind

Q: Did Philip decide to keep talking about the issue?

A: No, Philip had made up his mind to be forbearing, and to say no more about it.||Philip had made up his mind to be forbearing, and to say no more about it.

A: to be forbearing||Philip had made up his mind to be forbearing

A: Laura||Laura thought this a pity, as they could thus never come to an understanding

Q: What gave thanks in a careless manner?

A: Guy|| so, after bestowing his thanks in a gay, off-hand way

Q: Who was from Deloraine?

A: William||much-aggrieved William of Deloraine

Q: Did Guy understand the trouble he made?

A: No, On his side Guy had no idea the trouble he had caused||On his side Guy had no idea the trouble he had caused

source: wikipedia

The Arena Football League (AFL) is the highest level of professional indoor American football in the United States. It was founded in 1987 by Jim Foster, making it the third longest-running professional football league in North America, after the Canadian Football League and the National Football League. It is played indoors on a 68-yard field (about half the distance of an NFL field), resulting in a faster-paced and higher-scoring game. The sport was invented in the early 1980s and patented by Foster, a former executive of the United States Football League and the National Football League. For its 2015 season, the league consisted of 12 teams, all from the United States; however, upon the completion of the regular season, the league announced that the two teams it had assumed operation of during the season would cease all operations effective immediately; a regular season game slated between the two had previously been canceled and declared a tie. Subsequently, one of the remaining teams, the Spokane Shock, severed its ties with the league to join the competing IFL. The AFL is divided into two conferences – the American Conference and National Conference. Starting 2016, each conference will have only four teams as the champion San Jose SaberCats announced in November 2015 that they were ceasing activity for "reasons not associated with League operations."


Q: What AFL stands for?

A: Arena Football League||The Arena Football League

Q: Is it played outside?

A: No, rofessional indoor American football in t||rofessional indoor American football in t

Q: When was it founded?

A: 1987|| It was founded in 1987

Q: By whom?

A: Jim Foster||It was founded in 1987 by Jim Foster

Q: How is it ranked by longest-running?

A: third||making it the third longest-runn

A: 68-yards|| 68-yard field

A: about half the distance of an NFL field||about half the distance of an NFL field

A: higher-scoring||higher-scoring

Summary: The Arena Football League (AFL) is the highest level of professional indoor American football in the United States.It was founded in 1987 by Jim Foster, making it the third longest-running professional football league in North America, after the Canadian Football League and the National Football League.It is played indoors on a 68-yard field (about half the distance of an NFL field), resulting in a faster-paced and higher-scoring game.The sport was invented in the early 1980s and patented by Foster, a former executive of the United States Football League and the National Football League.For its 2015 season, the league consisted of 12 teams, all from the United States; however, upon the completion of the regular season, the league announced that the two teams it had assumed operation of during the season would cease all operations effective immediately; a regular season game slated between the two had previously been canceled and declared a tie.Subsequently, one of the remaining teams, the Spokane Shock, severed its ties with the league to join the competing IFL.The AFL is divided into two conferences – the American Conference and National Conference.Starting 2016, each conference will have only four teams as the champion San Jose SaberCats announced in November 2015 that they were ceasing activity for "reasons not associated with League operations."


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Germany, officially the Federal Republic of Germany, is a federal parliamentary republic in central-western Europe. It includes 16 constituent states, covers an area of , and has a largely temperate seasonal climate. With about 82 million inhabitants, Germany is the most populous member state of the European Union. After the United States, it is the second most popular immigration destination in the world. Germany's capital and largest metropolis is Berlin, while its largest conurbation is the Ruhr, with its main centres of Dortmund and Essen. The country's other major cities are Hamburg, Munich, Cologne, Frankfurt, Stuttgart, Düsseldorf, Leipzig, Bremen, Dresden, Hannover and Nuremberg. Various Germanic tribes have inhabited the northern parts of modern Germany since classical antiquity. A region named Germania was documented before 100 AD. During the Migration Period, the Germanic tribes expanded southward. Beginning in the 10th century, German territories formed a central part of the Holy Roman Empire. During the 16th century, northern German regions became the centre of the Protestant Reformation. After the collapse of the Holy Roman Empire, the German Confederation was formed in 1815. The German revolutions of 1848–49 resulted in the Frankfurt Parliament establishing major democratic rights. In 1871, Germany became a nation state when most of the German states unified into the Prussian-dominated German Empire. After World War I and the German Revolution of 1918–19, the Empire was replaced by the parliamentary Weimar Republic. In 1933 the Nazi seizure of power quickly led to the establishment of Nazi Germany which was built upon a dictatorship and consequently led to World War II and the Holocaust. After the end of World War II in Europe and a period of Allied occupation, two German states were founded: the democratic West Germany and the socialist East Germany. Following the Revolutions of 1989 that ended communist rule in Central and Eastern Europe, the country was reunified on 3 October 1990.


Q: When did Germany become a nation state?

A: In 1871||In 1871, Germany became a nation state

Q: What years were the German Revolution?

A: 1918–19.||German Revolution of 1918–19,

Q: After that event, What was the Empire replaced by?

A: Weimar Republic.|| Empire was replaced by the parliamentary Weimar Republic.

Q: When did the Nazi seizure of power happen?

A: In 1933|| In 1933 the Nazi seizure of power

Q: Did this lead to the establishment of Nazi Germany?

A: Yes||led to the establishment of Nazi Germany

Q: What was that built upon?

A: A dictatorship||Nazi Germany which was built upon a dictatorship

Q: How many events did that cause?

A: Two.||a dictatorship and consequently led to World War II and the Holocaust.

A: World War II||led to World War II

A: The Holocaust.|| led to World War II and the Holocaust.

A: Berlin||Germany's capital and largest metropolis is Berlin,


Summary: Germany, officially the Federal Republic of Germany, is a federal parliamentary republic in central-western Europe.Germany's capital and largest metropolis is Berlin, while its largest conurbation is the Ruhr, with its main centres of Dortmund and Essen.Various Germanic tribes have inhabited the northern parts of modern Germany since classical antiquity.A region named Germania was documented before 100 AD.During the Migration Period, the Germanic tribes expanded southward.In 1871, Germany became a nation state when most of the German states unified into the Prussian-dominated German Empire.After World War I and the German Revolution of 1918–19, the Empire was replaced by the parliamentary Weimar Republic.In 1933 the Nazi seizure of power quickly led to the establishment of Nazi Germany which was built upon a dictatorship and consequently led to World War II and the Holocaust.After the end of World War II in Europe and a period of Allied occupation, two German states were founded: the democratic West Germany and the socialist East Germany.Following the Revolutions of 1989 that ended communist rule in Central and Eastern Europe, the country was reunified on 3 October 1990.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Spain and its autonomous communities are divided into fifty provinces (, ; sing. "provincia"). Ceuta, Melilla and the Plazas de soberanía are not part of any provinces. The layout of Spain's provinces closely follows the pattern of the territorial division of the country carried out in 1833. The only major change of provincial borders since that time has been the sub-division of the Canary Islands into two provinces rather than one. Historically, the provinces served mainly as transmission belts for policies enacted in Madrid, as Spain was a highly centralised state for most of its history. The importance of the provinces has declined since the adoption of the system of autonomous communities in the period of the Spanish transition to democracy. They nevertheless remain electoral districts for national elections and as geographical references: for instance in postal addresses and telephone codes. A small town would normally be identified as being in, say, Valladolid province rather than the autonomous community of Castile and León. The provinces were the "building-blocks" from which the autonomous communities were created. Consequently, no province is divided between more than one of these communities. Most of the provinces—with the exception of Álava/Araba, Asturias/Asturies, Bizkaia/Vizcaya, Cantabria, Gipuzkoa/Gipúzcoa, Illes Balears/Islas Baleares, La Rioja, and Nafarroa/Navarra—are named after their principal town. Only two capitals of autonomous communities—Mérida in Extremadura and Santiago de Compostela in Galicia—are not also the capitals of provinces.


Q: What were provinces historically for?

A: transmission belts for policies enacted||the provinces served mainly as transmission belts for policies enacted

Q: Where are they enacted?

A: in Madrid||enacted in Madrid

Q: What location is divided into fifty provinces?

A: Spain||Spain and its autonomous communities are divided into fifty provinces

Q: and?

A: its autonomous communities||Spain and its autonomous communities

Q: What are most provinces named after?

A: their principal town||are named after their principal town

Q: How many aren't?

Q: How many are not the provinces' capital?

A: Two||Only two capitals of autonomous communities—Mérida in Extremadura and Santiago de Compostela in Galicia—are not also the capitals of provinces.

Q: Which are they?

A: Mérida and Santiago de Compostela||Mérida in Extremadura and Santiago de Compostela in Galicia

Q: What made the province more unimportant?

A: the adoption of the system of autonomous communities||has declined since the adoption of the system of autonomous communities

A: Three||Ceuta, Melilla and the Plazas de soberanía are not part of any provinces

A: Ceuta, Melilla and the Plazas de soberanía||Ceuta, Melilla and the Plazas de soberanía


Summary: Spain and its autonomous communities are divided into fifty provinces (, ; sing.Ceuta, Melilla and the Plazas de soberanía are not part of any provinces.Historically, the provinces served mainly as transmission belts for policies enacted in Madrid, as Spain was a highly centralised state for most of its history.The importance of the provinces has declined since the adoption of the system of autonomous communities in the period of the Spanish transition to democracy.Most of the provinces—with the exception of Álava/Araba, Asturias/Asturies, Bizkaia/Vizcaya, Cantabria, Gipuzkoa/Gipúzcoa, Illes Balears/Islas Baleares, La Rioja, and Nafarroa/Navarra—are named after their principal town.Only two capitals of autonomous communities—Mérida in Extremadura and Santiago de Compostela in Galicia—are not also the capitals of provinces.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Since the Protestant Reformation, the most prominent Christian denomination in Thuringia has been Lutheranism. During the GDR period, church membership was discouraged and has continued shrinking since the reunification in 1990. Today over two thirds of the population is non-religious. The Protestant Evangelical Church in Germany has had the largest number of members in the state, adhered to by 24.0% of the population in 2009. Members of the Catholic Church formed 7.8% of the population, while 68.2% of Thuringians were non-religious or adhere to other faiths. The highest Protestant concentrations are in the small villages of southern and western Thuringia, whereas the bigger cities are even more non-religious (up to 88% in Gera). Catholic regions are the Eichsfeld in the northwest and parts of the Rhön Mountains around Geisa in the southwest. Protestant church membership is shrinking rapidly, whereas the Catholic Church is somewhat more stable because of Catholic migration from Poland, Southern Europe and West Germany. Other religions play no significant role in Thuringia. There are only a few thousand Muslims (largely migrants) and about 750 Jews (mostly migrants from Russia) living in Thuringia. Furthermore, there are some Orthodox communities of Eastern European migrants and some traditional Protestant Free churches in Thuringia without any societal influence.


Q: what is the biggest church in Germany?

A: The Protestant Evangelical Church||The Protestant Evangelical Church in Germany has had the largest number of members in the state

Q: what percent of the local people are in that church?

A: 24.0% of the population in 2009||adhered to by 24.0% of the population in 2009

Q: what other group has a large percentage of people in it?

A: the Catholic Church||Members of the Catholic Church formed 7.8% of the population

Q: are most people a part of one of these groups?

A: no, while 68.2% of Thuringians were non-religious||while 68.2% of Thuringians were non-religious

Q: what other ethnic groups are there in this area?

A: Muslims, Jews||There are only a few thousand Muslims (largely migrants) and about 750 Jews

Q: where are they originally from?

A: migrants from Russia||Jews (mostly migrants from Russia)

Q: how many are there?

A: about 750 Jews|| about 750 Jews

Q: when did church-going really start decreasing in the area?

A: During the GDR period||During the GDR period, church membership was discouraged

Q: why did it decrease?

A: church membership was discouraged||church membership was discouraged

Q: is catholicism decreasing as quickly?

A: no, Catholic Church is somewhat more stable||Catholic Church is somewhat more stable

Q: why not?

A: Catholic migration from Poland||Catholic migration from Poland

Q: and from what other areas?

A: Southern Europe and West Germany||Southern Europe and West Germany


Summary: During the GDR period, church membership was discouraged and has continued shrinking since the reunification in 1990.The Protestant Evangelical Church in Germany has had the largest number of members in the state, adhered to by 24.0% of the population in 2009.Members of the Catholic Church formed 7.8% of the population, while 68.2% of Thuringians were non-religious or adhere to other faiths.Protestant church membership is shrinking rapidly, whereas the Catholic Church is somewhat more stable because of Catholic migration from Poland, Southern Europe and West Germany.There are only a few thousand Muslims (largely migrants) and about 750 Jews (mostly migrants from Russia) living in Thuringia.

source: race

If you were a pilot flying a plane, and suddenly the engine failed, would you eject , or stay in? For a pilot, the choice is very difficult. If he ejects, he is wise, but the plane crashes. If he stays in the plane, he risks his life. Recently, Chinese Air Force pilot Li Feng, 38, faced this choice during a training exercise. It was March 7 and he was flying a Jian-10 (Flghter-10) at 4,500 meters. A warning appeared on the plane's computer screen. He realized the plane might fail at any moment. Li Feng did a quick check of the engine and asked the base if he could return. When the fighter was 7km away from the airport, however, the engine stopped working. The plane began to fall at a speed of 25 meters a second from an altitude of 1,160 meters. Under Air Force rules fighter pilots may eject if their aircraft loses engine power below 2,000 meters and can't be restarted. Before Li lost contact with the control tower, the commander in the air base asked him to eject. But Li Feng insisted on having another try. "I knew where the deadline (to abandon the aircraft) was and was prepared for the ejection, but I decided not to give up unless the fighter was totally out of control," Li recalled during a recent television interview. After 104 seconds, Li was able to bring the fighter to a safe landing. The plane only suffered slight damage. "You are a hero! Congratulations!" Li's teacher, Xu yongling wrote in a text message to him after the landing. He said Li was a cool-headed pilot and very professional. Li's brave and calm act not only saved the 200 million yuan aircraft but also gave him invaluable first-hand experience of dealing with an engine emergency. For his outstanding performance, the Air Force recently awarded him a gold medal.


Q: who was flying the plane?

A: Li Feng||Li Feng

Q: from what country?

A: China||Chinese

Q: his age?

A: 38||38

Q: his profession?

A: pilot||pilot

Q: what kind of aircraft was he flying?

A: Jian-10||Jian-10

Q: is that a passenger plane?

A: No, Jian-10 (Flghter-10)||Jian-10 (Flghter-10)

A: Yes|| Chinese Air Force

Q: what branch?

A: Air Force|| Air Force

Q: what?

A: the engine stopped working||the engine stopped working

A: No, After 104 seconds, Li was able to bring the fighter to a safe landing. ||After 104 seconds, Li was able to bring the fighter to a safe landing.

A: bring the fighter to a safe landing|| Li was able to bring the fighter to a safe landing

A: No, The plane only suffered slight damage||The plane only suffered slight damage

A: Xu yongling|| Li's teacher, Xu yongling

Q: was he recognized for this?

A: Yes||For his outstanding performance, the Air Force recently awarded him a gold medal.


Summary: Recently, Chinese Air Force pilot Li Feng, 38, faced this choice during a training exercise.It was March 7 and he was flying a Jian-10 (Flghter-10) at 4,500 meters.A warning appeared on the plane's computer screen.Li Feng did a quick check of the engine and asked the base if he could return.When the fighter was 7km away from the airport, however, the engine stopped working.After 104 seconds, Li was able to bring the fighter to a safe landing.The plane only suffered slight damage.Congratulations!"Li's teacher, Xu yongling wrote in a text message to him after the landing.Li's brave and calm act not only saved the 200 million yuan aircraft but also gave him invaluable first-hand experience of dealing with an engine emergency.For his outstanding performance, the Air Force recently awarded him a gold medal.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System. It is a giant planet with a mass one-thousandth that of the Sun, but two and a half times that of all the other planets in the Solar System combined. Jupiter and Saturn are gas giants; the other two giant planets, Uranus and Neptune are ice giants. Jupiter has been known to astronomers since antiquity. The Romans named it after their god Jupiter. When viewed from Earth, Jupiter can reach an apparent magnitude of −2.94, bright enough for its reflected light to cast shadows, and making it on average the third-brightest object in the night sky after the Moon and Venus. Jupiter is primarily composed of hydrogen with a quarter of its mass being helium, though helium comprises only about a tenth of the number of molecules. It may also have a rocky core of heavier elements, but like the other giant planets, Jupiter lacks a well-defined solid surface. Because of its rapid rotation, the planet's shape is that of an oblate spheroid (it has a slight but noticeable bulge around the equator). The outer atmosphere is visibly segregated into several bands at different latitudes, resulting in turbulence and storms along their interacting boundaries. A prominent result is the Great Red Spot, a giant storm that is known to have existed since at least the 17th century when it was first seen by telescope. Surrounding Jupiter is a faint planetary ring system and a powerful magnetosphere. Jupiter has at least 69 moons, including the four large Galilean moons discovered by Galileo Galilei in 1610. Ganymede, the largest of these, has a diameter greater than that of the planet Mercury.


Q: What is the largest planet in the solar system?

A: Jupiter||Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System

Q: What is it mostly made of?

A: gas||Jupiter and Saturn are gas giants;

Q: And what element?

A: hydrogen||Jupiter is primarily composed of hydrogen

Q: What is most of the weight from?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: How much bigger is it than all the other planets together?

A: two and a half times|| but two and a half times that of all the other planets in the Solar System combined

Q: How long have people known about it?

A: since antiquity||Jupiter has been known to astronomers since antiquity.

Q: Who gave it its name?

A: The Romans||The Romans named it after their god Jupiter

Q: How many planets is it away from the Sun?

A: it is the fifth planet from the Sun||Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun

Q: Is it the most bright object at night?

A: no, and making it on average the third-brightest object in the night sky after the Moon and Venus. ||and making it on average the third-brightest object in the night sky after the Moon and Venus.

Q: How many things are brighter?

A: two||, and making it on average the third-brightest object in the night sky after the Moon and Venus.

Q: What is its shape?

A: that of an oblate spheroid|| the planet's shape is that of an oblate spheroid

Q: Why?

A: Because of its rapid rotation||Because of its rapid rotation, the planet's shape is that of an oblate spheroid

Q: Is it more similar to Uranus or Saturn?

A: Saturn|| Jupiter and Saturn are gas giants;

Q: Is its atmosphere calm?

A: no, resulting in turbulence and storms along their interacting boundaries.||resulting in turbulence and storms along their interacting boundaries.

Q: Are there a lot of storms?

A: yes||resulting in turbulence and storms along their interacting boundaries

Q: What is a famous one?

A: the Great Red Spot||A prominent result is the Great Red Spot, a giant storm

A: the 17th century||since at least the 17th century

A: yes||Ganymede, the largest of these, has a diameter greater than that of the planet Mercury.

A: Ganymede||Ganymede, the largest of these, has a diameter greater than that of the planet Mercury.

Q: How many moons total does the planet have?

A: at least 69 moons||Jupiter has at least 69 moons


Summary: Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System.It is a giant planet with a mass one-thousandth that of the Sun, but two and a half times that of all the other planets in the Solar System combined.Jupiter and Saturn are gas giants; the other two giant planets, Uranus and Neptune are ice giants.Jupiter has been known to astronomers since antiquity.The Romans named it after their god Jupiter.When viewed from Earth, Jupiter can reach an apparent magnitude of −2.94, bright enough for its reflected light to cast shadows, and making it on average the third-brightest object in the night sky after the Moon and Venus.Jupiter is primarily composed of hydrogen with a quarter of its mass being helium, though helium comprises only about a tenth of the number of molecules.Because of its rapid rotation, the planet's shape is that of an oblate spheroid (it has a slight but noticeable bulge around the equator).The outer atmosphere is visibly segregated into several bands at different latitudes, resulting in turbulence and storms along their interacting boundaries.A prominent result is the Great Red Spot, a giant storm that is known to have existed since at least the 17th century when it was first seen by telescope.Jupiter has at least 69 moons, including the four large Galilean moons discovered by Galileo Galilei in 1610.Ganymede, the largest of these, has a diameter greater than that of the planet Mercury.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

The Canada 2006 Census was a detailed enumeration of the Canadian population. Census day was May 16, 2006. The following census was the 2011 Census. Canada's total population enumerated by the 2006 census was 31,612,897. This count was lower than the official July 1, 2006 population estimate of 32,623,490 people. Over 12.7 million households, 32.5 million people were expected to be counted. Canada Post delivered census forms by mail to 70% of the country, primarily residents in urban areas. Census enumerators delivered to the remaining 30% of households. Every fifth home received the long questionnaire (53 questions versus 8 questions on the short form). For the first time, Canadian residents were able to go online to fill in their forms. Statistics Canada expected approximately 20% of households to file their surveys electronically. Persistent census staff are contacting tardy households. The total estimated cost of the 2006 census is $567 million spread over seven years, employing more than 25,000 full and part-time census workers. New in the 2006 Census Questionnaire: Questions not asked in the 2006 Census: Modified questions: As the data were compiled, Statistics Canada released various census data products. The first set of data products was released on March 13, 2007, originally scheduled for release on February 13, 2007, covering population and dwelling counts by geographical unit. This was followed by other census data products.


Q: Can Canadians now fill out the census online?

A: Yes||For the first time, Canadian residents were able to go online to fill in their forms.

Q: What day was the census in 2006?

A: May 16|| Census day was May 16, 2006.

Q: What year was its next census?

A: 2011||. The following census was the 2011 Census.

Q: What was the population in 2006?

A: 31,612,897||Canada's total population enumerated by the 2006 census was 31,612,897.

Q: Which homes received the long questionnaire?

A: Every fifth home|| Every fifth home received the long questionnaire

Q: What percentage of forms were mailed?

A: 70%||Canada Post delivered census forms by mail to 70% of the country, primarily residents in urban areas

Q: How many houses were expected to file electronically?

A: 20%|| Statistics Canada expected approximately 20% of households to file their surveys electronically

Q: How much was the 2006 census (in dollars)?

A: $567 million|| The total estimated cost of the 2006 census is $567 million spread over seven years

Q: How many workers were there?

A: 25,000||employing more than 25,000 full and part-time census workers.

Q: When did the first set of data come out?

A: March 13, 2007||The first set of data products was released on March 13, 2007

Q: When was it supposed to come out?

A: February 13, 2007||originally scheduled for release on February 13, 200

Q: How many questions were on the long census form?

A: 53 questions||long questionnaire (53 questions

Q: And how many on the short?

A: 8 questions|| 8 questions on the short form

Q: Did workers go to houses that were late?

A: Yes||Persistent census staff are contacting tardy households.

Q: How many years was counting the 2006 census spread over?

A: seven years||The total estimated cost of the 2006 census is $567 million spread over seven years


Summary: Census day was May 16, 2006.The following census was the 2011 Census.Canada's total population enumerated by the 2006 census was 31,612,897.Canada Post delivered census forms by mail to 70% of the country, primarily residents in urban areas.Every fifth home received the long questionnaire (53 questions versus 8 questions on the short form).For the first time, Canadian residents were able to go online to fill in their forms.Statistics Canada expected approximately 20% of households to file their surveys electronically.Persistent census staff are contacting tardy households.The total estimated cost of the 2006 census is $567 million spread over seven years, employing more than 25,000 full and part-time census workers.The first set of data products was released on March 13, 2007, originally scheduled for release on February 13, 2007, covering population and dwelling counts by geographical unit.

source: mctest

Sometimes Karen likes to go to the library. Her friend Michael also likes the library, but her other friend James does not like the library. Karen and Michael like to read about different things. They can learn about things that they don't know much about. They also like to read fun and exciting stories. The librarian, Mr. Hernandez, knows Michael and Karen, because they are in the library a lot. He knows what kind of books they like. When the library gets new books, he tells Karen and Michael about any books that he thinks they would like. James only goes to the library when he has to read a book for class. Mr. Hernandez does not know very much about James, because James does not go to the library often. Karen's favorite books are about airplanes, cars, and trains. She like reading about how fast they can go, and about the workers who build them. When she grows up, she is going to buy a fast car and travel to different states. Michael likes books about dinosaurs, cowboys, and fireworks. When he grows up, he is going to buy a costume and dress up like a cowboy.


Q: who likes the library?

A: Karen||Karen

Q: who else

A: Michael||Michael

Q: who doesnt like it

A: James||James

Q: why do micheal and karen like it?

A: They like to read||Karen and Michael like to read about different things

Q: how does mr hernandez know them?

A: they are in the library a lot|| they are in the library a lot

Q: what does he do for them?

A: he tells them about new books they might like||he tells Karen and Michael about any books that he thinks they would like

Q: what is the reason james goes to the library?

A: he has to read a book for class||when he has to read a book for class

Q: what does karen like to read about?

A: airplanes, cars, and trains||airplanes, cars, and trains

Q: what does she want to know about them?

A: how fast they can go, and about the workers who build them||how fast they can go, and about the workers who build them

Q: what does she want to do when she's older?

A: buy a fast car and travel||buy a fast car and travel

Q: does micheal like the same books?

A: no, Michael likes books about dinosaurs, cowboys, and fireworks.||Michael likes books about dinosaurs, cowboys, and fireworks.

Q: what does he like?

A: dinosaurs, cowboys, and fireworks||dinosaurs, cowboys, and fireworks

Q: what is he going to do as an adult?

A: buy a costume and dress up like a cowboy||buy a costume and dress up like a cowboy


Summary: Sometimes Karen likes to go to the library.Her friend Michael also likes the library, but her other friend James does not like the library.Karen and Michael like to read about different things.The librarian, Mr. Hernandez, knows Michael and Karen, because they are in the library a lot.When the library gets new books, he tells Karen and Michael about any books that he thinks they would like.James only goes to the library when he has to read a book for class.Karen's favorite books are about airplanes, cars, and trains.She like reading about how fast they can go, and about the workers who build them.When she grows up, she is going to buy a fast car and travel to different states.Michael likes books about dinosaurs, cowboys, and fireworks.When he grows up, he is going to buy a costume and dress up like a cowboy.

source: race

Characters: Sandy, Rose, Jane, Justin, Mrs. Lin Setting: A middle school Rose: Sandy, follow me after class. (They go to the office together.) Rose: You are often absent and your grades are not as good as before. What's happened to you? Sandy: No, it's nothing. Thanks for your care. Rose: Are you sure? Anyway, if you have any problem, tell me. (After school, Sandy and Jane are on the way home .) Jane: Sandy, I called you yesterday. Your mother told me that you had a part-time job. What's the matter with you?We have to study hard during this year before we take the entrance examination. This year is very important to us. Sandy: (Crying) My father has lost his job, and we have no money to pay all the spending. Jane: Oh, Sandy, Don't worry. I will help you. (After the day, Jane decides to tell Rose about Sandy's problem.) Jane: Rose, I have to tell you something about Sandy. Rose: Jane, you are Sandy's good friend. Do you know what's wrong with Sandy? Jane: Eh...I hear that Sandy's father has lost his job, and Sandy has a part-time job... Rose: OK, I understand. (Rose is in the social worker's office) Rose: ...I've told you everything about Sandy. Justin: I see. I'll manage it as soon as I can. (In Sandy's home, Mrs. Lin is ill in bed) Justin: Mrs. Lin, I understand your feeling, but it's her time to study hard to enter a good senior high school, she can't do a part-time job after class. Mrs. Lin: I know what you want to tell me. But, in fact, her father hasn't found a job and I ...(Crying) I've been ill in bed several years! Justin: Don't worry. I can introduce some work I know to her father. Mrs. Lin: Thank you very much.


Q: Who is unemployed?

A: Sandy's father|| Sandy: (Crying) My father has lost his job

Q: What is Sandy's last name

A: Lin||In Sandy's home, Mrs. Lin

Q: what is wrong with her mother?

A: she's ill|| Mrs. Lin is ill in bed

Q: can she work?

A: no, I've been ill in bed several years||I've been ill in bed several years

Q: Who was the first to find out about Sandy's job?

A: Jane||Jane: Sandy, I called you yesterday. Your mother told me that you had a part-time job.

Q: Who told her?

A: Sandy's mother||Your mother told me that you had a part-time job

Q: who did Jane tell?

A: Rose||Jane decides to tell Rose about Sandy's problem

Q: Had Rose already noticed anything?

A: yes||Rose: Jane, you are Sandy's good friend. Do you know what's wrong with Sandy?

Q: Who did Rose talk to ?

A: Justin||Rose: ...I've told you everything about Sandy. Justin: I see

Q: what is his occupation?

A: social worker||Rose is in the social worker's office) Rose: ...I've told you everything about Sandy. Justin: I see.

Q: does her friends think Sandy can handle her job and school?

A: no, but it's her time to study hard to enter a good senior high school, she can't do a part-time job after class|| but it's her time to study hard to enter a good senior high school, she can't do a part-time job after class

Q: Does Justin have a solution?

A: yes||Justin: Don't worry. I can introduce some work I know to her father

Q: what does he offer to do?

A: to find work for the father||Justin: Don't worry. I can introduce some work I know to her father.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XIII. THE LETTER. There could be no question but that Ninety-four's company were highly delighted with the news brought by Seth regarding his progress. It was as if each man felt personally complimented by Mr. Fernald when he advanced the amateur so rapidly, and all united in declaring that "Josh was a right good fellow." Seth was in the highest degree excited. He had expected that his friends of Ninety-four would be pleased at learning of his good fortune, but never fancied they could be so deeply interested, and now he began to understand what a gloom might be cast over the company if he should fail in this attempt to gain a foothold in the Department. 'Lish Davis would not be content until the boy gave an exhibition of what he had learned in the way of gymnastic exercises during the morning, and when this had been brought to a close amid the applause of all present, the driver said in a tone of satisfaction: "You're getting on in great shape, Amateur, and if nothing happens to give you a pull-back, ought'er be well up in the drill 'twixt now and a year from to-day. Josh Fernald has the name of being precious hard on them as comes under him for instruction; but I've always allowed he'd boost along mighty fast any one who struck his fancy. He must have seen that you were in earnest, young fellow, for when I talked with him the best promise I could get was that he'd look you over in the course of a month or two."


Q: how excited was Seth?

A: In the highest degree||Seth was in the highest degree excited.

Q: when would Lish be content?

A: When the boy gave an exhibition of what he learned.||Lish Davis would not be content until the boy gave an exhibition of what he had learned

Q: who was delighted with Seths news?

A: Ninety-four's company||There could be no question but that Ninety-four's company were highly delighted with the news brought by Seth regarding his progress.

Q: what did they all think about Josh?

A: That he is hard on people under him for instruction||Josh Fernald has the name of being precious hard on them as comes under him for instruction

Q: what was seth trying to gain?

A: a foothold in the Department.||if he should fail in this attempt to gain a foothold in the Department.

Q: what promise was the driver given?

A: he'd look you over in the course of a month or two||best promise I could get was that he'd look you over in the course of a month or two."

Q: who did he think Josh would boost along?

A: Any one who struck his fancy|| he'd boost along mighty fast any one who struck his fancy

Q: what was seth surprised by?

A: That his friends were so deeply interested.||He had expected that his friends of Ninety-four would be pleased at learning of his good fortune, but never fancied they could be so deeply interested

Q: what might happen if he fails?

A: A gloom might be cast over the company.|| and now he began to understand what a gloom might be cast over the company if he should fail

Q: what did all unite in calling josh?

A: A right good fellow.|| and all united in declaring that "Josh was a right good fellow."


Summary: There could be no question but that Ninety-four's company were highly delighted with the news brought by Seth regarding his progress.It was as if each man felt personally complimented by Mr. Fernald when he advanced the amateur so rapidly, and all united in declaring that "Josh was a right good fellow."Seth was in the highest degree excited.He had expected that his friends of Ninety-four would be pleased at learning of his good fortune, but never fancied they could be so deeply interested, and now he began to understand what a gloom might be cast over the company if he should fail in this attempt to gain a foothold in the Department.'Lish Davis would not be content until the boy gave an exhibition of what he had learned in the way of gymnastic exercises during the morning, and when this had been brought to a close amid the applause of all present, the driver said in a tone of satisfaction: "You're getting on in great shape, Amateur, and if nothing happens to give you a pull-back, ought'er be well up in the drill 'twixt now and a year from to-day.Josh Fernald has the name of being precious hard on them as comes under him for instruction; but I've always allowed he'd boost along mighty fast any one who struck his fancy.He must have seen that you were in earnest, young fellow, for when I talked with him the best promise I could get was that he'd look you over in the course of a month or two."

source: cnn

(CNN) -- Major League Baseball on Monday suspended 13 players, including New York Yankees star Alex Rodriguez, after an investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs. The league suspended Rodriguez for 211 regular-season games through the 2014 season, but the 38-year-old slugger said he planned to appeal. Twelve other players have accepted 50-game suspensions without pay. A-Rod and the other players are accused of having ties to the now-shuttered Biogenesis anti-aging clinic in south Florida and taking performance-enhancing drugs. Rodriguez has denied the accusation. "I'm fighting for my life. I have to defend myself. If I don't defend myself, no one else will," he told reporters after the league announced its decision. Twitter reaction to A-Rod ban The last seven months have been a "nightmare," he said. It "has been probably the worst time of my life for sure," said Rodriguez, "obviously for the circumstances that are at hand and also dealing with a very tough surgery and a rehab program, and being 38." Asked directly whether he had used performance-enhancing drugs, he declined -- repeatedly -- to comment. "I think we'll have a forum to discuss all of that, and we'll talk about it then," Rodriguez said. Earlier in a written statement, he said that he was disappointed with the penalty and intends to appeal. He thanked family, friends and fans for their support and stressed that he was eager to get back on the field with his teammates. Timeline of Alex Rodriguez's rise and fall His suspension is set to go into effect on Thursday, the league said. But officials also said that Rodriguez could keep playing if he appeals.


Q: what question did Alex Rodreguez refuse to answer

A: whether he had used performance-enhancing drugs||Asked directly whether he had used performance-enhancing drugs, he declined

Q: was he asked just a single time?

A: no, Asked directly whether he had used performance-enhancing drugs, he declined -- repeatedly -- to comment. ||Asked directly whether he had used performance-enhancing drugs, he declined -- repeatedly -- to comment.

Q: when does the temporary ban start?

A: Thursday,||His suspension is set to go into effect on Thursday,

Q: how many players are suspended?

A: 13||Major League Baseball on Monday suspended 13 players

Q: what organization banned them?

A: Major League Baseball||Major League Baseball on Monday suspended 13 players,

Q: which team is Rodreguez with?

A: Yankees||ew York Yankees star Alex Rodriguez,

Q: where are they based?

A: New York||New York Yankee

Q: what were the league looking into?

A: use of performance-enhancing drugs.||an investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

Q: What's his nickname?

A: A-Rod||A-Rod

Q: how long had been bad for him?

A: seven months||The last seven months have been a "nightmare," he said.

Q: how many games was he banned for?

A: 211||suspended Rodriguez for 211 regular-season games

Q: how old is he?

A: 38||but the 38-year-old slugge

Q: anyone else appealing?

A: yes|| accepted 50-game suspensions without pay.


Summary: (CNN) -- Major League Baseball on Monday suspended 13 players, including New York Yankees star Alex Rodriguez, after an investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs.The league suspended Rodriguez for 211 regular-season games through the 2014 season, but the 38-year-old slugger said he planned to appeal.Twelve other players have accepted 50-game suspensions without pay.A-Rod and the other players are accused of having ties to the now-shuttered Biogenesis anti-aging clinic in south Florida and taking performance-enhancing drugs.Twitter reaction to A-Rod ban The last seven months have been a "nightmare," he said.Asked directly whether he had used performance-enhancing drugs, he declined -- repeatedly -- to comment.Timeline of Alex Rodriguez's rise and fall His suspension is set to go into effect on Thursday, the league said.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: race

"If I rest, I _ "----would be an excellent motto for those who are troubled by the slightest bit of idleness.Even the most hard-working person might adopt it with advantage to serve as a reminder that, if one allows his abilities to rest, like the iron in the unused key, they will soon show signs of rust and, eventually, cannot do the work required of them. Those who would attain the heights reached and kept by great men must- keep their ability polished by constant use, so that they may unlock the doors of knowledge, the gate that guard the entrances to the professions, to science, art, literature, agriculture--every department of human endeavor. Industry keeps the key bright that opens the treasury of achievement.If Hugh Miller, after toiling all day in a quarry, had devoted his evenings to rest and recreation, he would never have become a famous geologist.The celebrated mathematician, Edmund Stone, would never have published a mathematical dictionary, never have found the key to science of mathematics, if he had given his spare moments to idleness, had the little Scotch lad, Ferguson, allowed the busy brain to go to sleep while he tended sheep on the hillside instead of calculating the position of the stars by a string of beads, he would never have become a famous astronomer. Labor defeats all--not inconstant, or ill-directed labor; but faithful, persistent, daily effort toward a well-directed purpose.So industry is the price of noble and enduring success.


Q: What defeats all?

A: Labor||Labor defeats

Q: What kind of labor?

A: faithful, persistent labor||faithful, persistent, daily effort toward a well-directed purpose

Q: Towards what?

A: a well-directed purpose||a well-directed purpose

Q: What's the cost of this royal and long lasting win?

A: industry||industry is the price of noble and enduring success

Q: How do men keep their skills shiny?

A: by constant use||by constant use

Q: For what?

A: so that they may unlock the doors of knowledge||so that they may unlock the doors of knowledge

Q: What's one thing locked in there?

A: the professions||the professions

Q: Like what?

A: science||o science

Q: And?

A: literature||literature

Q: Not math?

A: every department of human endeavor|| that guard the entrances to the professions, to science, art, literature, agriculture--every department of human endeavor

Q: What happens to a key you never use?

A: it will show signs of rust||show signs of rust

Q: Will it continue to work?

A: no, key, they will soon show signs of rust and, eventually, cannot do the work required of them||key, they will soon show signs of rust and, eventually, cannot do the work required of them

Q: Who worked all day in a rock pit?

A: Hugh Miller||Hugh Miller

Q: What did he publish?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: Who was small Scottish boy?

A: Ferguson||Ferguson

Q: What was he doing on side of a hill?

A: tended sheep||tended sheep

Q: Did he also do something sky related?

A: calculated the position of the stars by a string of beads||calculating the position of the stars by a string of beads

Q: Did he become well known for something?

A: astronomer||astronomer

Q: What do you think the last word of the motto is at the beginning?

A: die||"If I rest, I _ "

Q: Is it a good motto for lazy folks?

A: no, "If I rest, I _ "----would be an excellent motto for those who are troubled by the slightest bit of idleness||"If I rest, I _ "----would be an excellent motto for those who are troubled by the slightest bit of idleness


Summary: "If I rest, I _ "----would be an excellent motto for those who are troubled by the slightest bit of idleness.Even the most hard-working person might adopt it with advantage to serve as a reminder that, if one allows his abilities to rest, like the iron in the unused key, they will soon show signs of rust and, eventually, cannot do the work required of them.Those who would attain the heights reached and kept by great men must- keep their ability polished by constant use, so that they may unlock the doors of knowledge, the gate that guard the entrances to the professions, to science, art, literature, agriculture--every department of human endeavor.Industry keeps the key bright that opens the treasury of achievement.If Hugh Miller, after toiling all day in a quarry, had devoted his evenings to rest and recreation, he would never have become a famous geologist.The celebrated mathematician, Edmund Stone, would never have published a mathematical dictionary, never have found the key to science of mathematics, if he had given his spare moments to idleness, had the little Scotch lad, Ferguson, allowed the busy brain to go to sleep while he tended sheep on the hillside instead of calculating the position of the stars by a string of beads, he would never have become a famous astronomer.Labor defeats all--not inconstant, or ill-directed labor; but faithful, persistent, daily effort toward a well-directed purpose.So industry is the price of noble and enduring success.

source: mctest

On a snowy winter morning, the brown-haired lady saw a squirrel that was hurt. It only had three legs, and it looked hungry. She put some corn out for the squirrel to eat, but other bully squirrels came, too. The brown-haired lady started giving the little squirrel peanuts to eat. She gave some to the bully squirrels, too, so they would leave the three-legged squirrel alone. The winter snow melted and then it was spring. The grass turned green and the air was warm. Now, when the little squirrel with three legs would come to see the brown-haired lady with the peanuts, it would take the peanuts and dig a little hole and hide the peanuts for later. The squirrel would hold the peanut in its mouth and dig and dig and dig, and then it would put the peanut in the hole and pat it down with its little front paw. Then it would run back over to the brown-haired lady and get some more peanuts to eat.


Q: Who seen a squirrel?

A: the lady||the brown-haired lady

Q: Was it snowing?

A: yes|| a snowy winter morning

Q: Did the squirrel have legs?

A: yes||It only had three legs

Q: How many?

A: three|| It only had three

Q: Was he hungry?

A: yes||it looked hungry

Q: what did the lady put out for the squirrel?

A: corn||She put some corn out

Q: What color hair did the lady have?

A: brown||brown-haired lady

Q: Did She feed other squirrels?

A: yes||ther bully squirrels came, too

Q: What did she feed them?

A: peanuts||peanuts to ea

Q: When did the snow melt?

A: spring||snow melted and then it was spring

Q: Was the air warm?

A: yes||the air was warm

Q: What would the squirrel do with the peanuts?

A: hide them||dig a little hole and hide the peanuts

Q: Where?

A: a hole||a little hole

Q: Was the grass green?

A: yes||The grass turned green

Q: How did the squirrel hold the peanuts?

A: in its mouth||in its mouth


Summary: On a snowy winter morning, the brown-haired lady saw a squirrel that was hurt.It only had three legs, and it looked hungry.She put some corn out for the squirrel to eat, but other bully squirrels came, too.The brown-haired lady started giving the little squirrel peanuts to eat.The winter snow melted and then it was spring.The grass turned green and the air was warm.Now, when the little squirrel with three legs would come to see the brown-haired lady with the peanuts, it would take the peanuts and dig a little hole and hide the peanuts for later.The squirrel would hold the peanut in its mouth and dig and dig and dig, and then it would put the peanut in the hole and pat it down with its little front paw.

source: mctest

Bill and Sarah chose to meet at the park on Saturday to play ball and have a picnic. They went to the same grade school together and lived on the same street down from the park. Sarah does not often like boys, but for a boy, Bill was alright. Most boys like Tom and Mark are stupid and a real pain, but Bill was a lot of fun to play with and didn't do dumb things like putting a booger on her back during recess. When Bill and Sarah arrived at the park, they first played ball in the grass near the playground. Then they chose to pretend that Bill was a monster and Sarah was the monster hunter. Sarah chased Bill all over the playground. They went in and out and up and down. Bill ran under the slide and stepped in a puddle. He didn't get hurt but he sure got plenty wet. Playing the monster game was the most fun that they had at the park that day. Later they sat in the grass for a picnic. They both took off their shoes so that Bill's feet could dry off and so that he wouldn't feel silly without shoes. Sarah took out her lunch and laid it out next to her. She had dried fruit and cheese and a peanut butter sandwich. Bill opened his lunch bag and found a coke, a bag of chips, and a ham salad sandwich. Sarah wanted to trade Bill his bag of chips for her fruit. He said that would be a fair trade and they enjoyed their lunch together. After they had their lunch, they lay back in the grass and watched the clouds. Some clouds looked like animals or shapes. Bill spotted one that looked like a reindeer. Sarah pointed to one that looked like a drum. Finally Bill and Sarah got up and brushed off the grass and headed for home.


Q: Where did Bill and Sarah meet?

A: the park||the park

Q: On what day?

A: Saturday||Saturday

Q: What did they play?

A: ball||ball

Q: Did they live across town from eachother?

A: No, on t|| on t

A: No, oked like a rein||oked like a rein

A: puddle||puddle

A: so that Bill's feet could dry||so that Bill's feet could dry

Summary: Bill and Sarah chose to meet at the park on Saturday to play ball and have a picnic.They went to the same grade school together and lived on the same street down from the park.Most boys like Tom and Mark are stupid and a real pain, but Bill was a lot of fun to play with and didn't do dumb things like putting a booger on her back during recess.When Bill and Sarah arrived at the park, they first played ball in the grass near the playground.Then they chose to pretend that Bill was a monster and Sarah was the monster hunter.Sarah chased Bill all over the playground.He didn't get hurt but he sure got plenty wet.They both took off their shoes so that Bill's feet could dry off and so that he wouldn't feel silly without shoes.She had dried fruit and cheese and a peanut butter sandwich.Sarah wanted to trade Bill his bag of chips for her fruit.He said that would be a fair trade and they enjoyed their lunch together.After they had their lunch, they lay back in the grass and watched the clouds.Bill spotted one that looked like a reindeer.

source: mctest

Maxine was a happy frog that lived in a beautiful pond by the river. She loved to play in the water and take a bath every day. But her friends, Martin, Edgar, and Cindy didn't like to take baths. So one day when she was swimming alone, she met a new friend names Thomas. Thomas loved to take lots of baths, so he became friends with Maxine. But Martin, Edgar, and Cindy didn't like Thomas. So one day when Maxine and Thomas were swimming, Cindy did something mean. She threw rocks and Maxine and Thomas. Maxine's dad saw what happened and he was very mad. He went over and yelled at Cindy for what she did. After that Cindy didn't throw any rocks, and Maxine and Thomas could swim together and take lots of baths. They were very happy since they could play in the water as much as they wanted without other frogs being mean to them.


Q: Which of the four friends enjoyed bathing?

A: Maxine||She loved to play in the water and take a bath every day.

Q: Which female didn't?

A: Cindy||Cindy didn't like to take baths.

Q: Who was mean?

A: Cindy||Cindy did something mean

Q: What mean thing did she do?

A: She threw rocks||She threw rocks and Maxine and Thomas.

Q: Who yelled?

A: MAxine's dad||He went over and yelled at Cindy

Q: At whom?

A: Cindy||yelled at Cindy

Q: Which male enjoyed the water?

A: Thomas||homas loved to take lots of baths,

Q: Who had a parent intervene?

A: Maxine||Maxine's dad saw what happened

Q: What gender was the parent?

A: male||Maxine's dad

Q: Did The mean behavior continue?

A: no, After that Cindy didn't throw any rocks, ||After that Cindy didn't throw any rocks,


Summary: She loved to play in the water and take a bath every day.But her friends, Martin, Edgar, and Cindy didn't like to take baths.Thomas loved to take lots of baths, so he became friends with Maxine.So one day when Maxine and Thomas were swimming, Cindy did something mean.She threw rocks and Maxine and Thomas.Maxine's dad saw what happened and he was very mad.He went over and yelled at Cindy for what she did.After that Cindy didn't throw any rocks, and Maxine and Thomas could swim together and take lots of baths.

source: cnn

London, England (CNN) -- TV talent show star Susan Boyle will sing for Pope Benedict XVI during his visit to Scotland next month, the Catholic Church in Scotland said Wednesday. A church spokesman said in June they were negotiating with the singing phenomenon to perform. Benedict is due to visit England and Scotland from September 16-19. Boyle will perform three times at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on Thursday, Sept. 16, the Scottish Catholic Media Office said. She will also sing with the 800-strong choir at the open-air Mass there. In the pre-Mass program, Boyle plans to sing the hymn "How Great Thou Art" as well as her signature song, "I Dreamed a Dream," the tune from the musical "Les Miserables" that shot her to fame in April 2009. "To be able to sing for the pope is a great honor and something I've always dreamed of -- it's indescribable," Boyle, a Catholic, said in a statement. "I think the 16th of September will stand out in my memory as something I've always wanted to do. I've always wanted to sing for His Holiness and I can't really put into words my happiness that this wish has come true at last." Boyle said her late mother was at the same Glasgow park when Pope John Paul II visited in 1982. After the final hymn at the end of the Mass, Boyle will sing a farewell song to the pope as he leaves to go to the airport for his flight to London, the church said.


Q: who is Susan Boyle ?

A: TV talent show star||TV talent show star

Q: who will she sing for ?

A: Pope Benedict XVI||Pope Benedict XVI

Q: who said this ?

A: the Catholic Church||the Catholic Church

Q: where ?

A: in Scotland||in Scotland

Q: is he due to visit china ?

A: no, Benedict is due to visit England||Benedict is due to visit England

Q: where will he visit ?

A: England and Scotland||England and Scotland

Q: when ?

A: September 16-19||September 16-19

Q: how many times will she perform ?

A: three||three

Q: at what park ?

A: Bellahouston Park||Bellahouston Park

Q: in chicago ?

A: no, n Glasgow ||n Glasgow

Q: where ?

A: Glasgow||Glasgow

Q: when did Pope John Paul II visit ?

A: 1982||1982

Q: where is the pope flying to ?

A: London||London

Q: what will boyle sing ?

A: farewell song||farewell song

Q: the 16th of September will stand out in my memory in what way ?

A: as something I've always wanted to do||as something I've always wanted to do


Summary: London, England (CNN) -- TV talent show star Susan Boyle will sing for Pope Benedict XVI during his visit to Scotland next month, the Catholic Church in Scotland said Wednesday.Benedict is due to visit England and Scotland from September 16-19.Boyle will perform three times at Bellahouston Park in Glasgow on Thursday, Sept. 16, the Scottish Catholic Media Office said."I think the 16th of September will stand out in my memory as something I've always wanted to do.After the final hymn at the end of the Mass, Boyle will sing a farewell song to the pope as he leaves to go to the airport for his flight to London, the church said.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXVI THE JUDGMENT OF DOMITIAN Two hours had gone by and Caleb, with fury in his heart, sat brooding in the office attached to the warehouse that he had hired. At that moment he had but one desire--to kill his successful rival, Marcus. Marcus had escaped and returned to Rome; of that there could be no doubt. He, one of the wealthiest of its patricians, had furnished the vast sum which enabled old Nehushta to buy the coveted Pearl-Maiden in the slave-ring. Then his newly acquired property had been taken to this house, where he awaited her. This then was the end of their long rivalry; for this he, Caleb, had fought, toiled, schemed and suffered. Oh! rather than such a thing should be, in that dark hour of his soul, he would have seen her cast to the foul Domitian, for Domitian, at least, she would have hated, whereas Marcus, he knew, she loved. Now there remained nothing but revenge. Revenged he must be, but how? He might dog Marcus and murder him, only then his own life would be hazarded, since he knew well the fate that awaited the foreigner, and most of all the Jew, who dared to lift his hand against a Roman noble, and if he hired others to do the work they might bear evidence against him. Now Caleb did not wish to die; life seemed the only good that he had left. Also, while he lived he might still win Miriam--after his rival had ceased to live. Doubtless, then she would be sold with his other slaves, and he could buy her at the rate such tarnished goods command. No, he would do nothing to run himself into danger. He would wait, wait and watch his opportunity.


Q: What was now left?

A: revenge||Now there remained nothing but revenge

Q: Against who?

A: Marcus||He might dog Marcus

Q: What was in the angered man's heart?

A: fury||with fury in his heart

Q: What was one option to get back at the man?

A: dog and murder him||He might dog Marcus and murder him

Q: What was a drawback to that plan?

A: his own life would be hazarded||only then his own life would be hazarded

Q: What was the subject of their rivalry?

A: the coveted Pearl-Maiden||the coveted Pearl-Maiden

Q: Where had Marcus gotten away from?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: What was the maiden's occupation?

A: a slave||the coveted Pearl-Maiden in the slave-ring

Q: And her name?

A: Miriam||he might still win Miriam

Q: What might he be able to do if his rival were dead?

A: win Miriam||he might still win Miriam--after his rival had ceased to live


Summary: CHAPTER XXVI THE JUDGMENT OF DOMITIAN Two hours had gone by and Caleb, with fury in his heart, sat brooding in the office attached to the warehouse that he had hired.He, one of the wealthiest of its patricians, had furnished the vast sum which enabled old Nehushta to buy the coveted Pearl-Maiden in the slave-ring.Now there remained nothing but revenge.He might dog Marcus and murder him, only then his own life would be hazarded, since he knew well the fate that awaited the foreigner, and most of all the Jew, who dared to lift his hand against a Roman noble, and if he hired others to do the work they might bear evidence against him.Also, while he lived he might still win Miriam--after his rival had ceased to live.
