source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XV. A DISOBEDIENT BROTHER Dan was his own man again in the morning, though rather pale and weak; he wanted to get up, but Cecily ordered him to stay in bed. Fortunately Felicity forgot to repeat the command, so Dan did stay in bed. Cecily carried his meals to him, and read a Henty book to him all her spare time. The Story Girl went up and told him wondrous tales; and Sara Ray brought him a pudding she had made herself. Sara's intentions were good, but the pudding-- well, Dan fed most of it to Paddy, who had curled himself up at the foot of the bed, giving the world assurance of a cat by his mellifluous purring. "Ain't he just a great old fellow?" said Dan. "He knows I'm kind of sick, just as well as a human. He never pays no attention to me when I'm well." Felix and Peter and I were required to help Uncle Roger in some carpentering work that day, and Felicity indulged in one of the house-cleaning orgies so dear to her soul; so that it was evening before we were all free to meet in the orchard and loll on the grasses of Uncle Stephen's Walk. In August it was a place of shady sweetness, fragrant with the odour of ripening apples, full of dear, delicate shadows. Through its openings we looked afar to the blue rims of the hills and over green, old, tranquil fields, lying the sunset glow. Overhead the lacing leaves made a green, murmurous roof. There was no such thing as hurry in the world, while we lingered there and talked of "cabbages and kings." A tale of the Story Girl's, wherein princes were thicker than blackberries, and queens as common as buttercups, led to our discussion of kings. We wondered what it would be like to be a king. Peter thought it would be fine, only kind of inconvenient, wearing a crown all the time.


Q: What did Sara Ray bring Dan?

A: a pudding||Sara Ray brought him a pudding

Q: Were her intentions good?

A: Yes||Sara's intentions were good

Q: How about the pudding?

A: No, but the pudding-- well, Dan fed most of it to Paddy|| but the pudding-- well, Dan fed most of it to Paddy

Q: Who got most of the pudding?

A: Paddy||Dan fed most of it to Paddy

Q: What was Paddy?

A: cat||Paddy, who had curled himself up at the foot of the bed, giving the world assurance of a cat by his mellifluous purring.

Q: Where was he sitting?

A: foot of the bed||Paddy, who had curled himself up at the foot of the bed

Q: When does he not pay attention to Dan?

A: when he's well||He never pays no attention to me when I'm well."

Q: What did Cecily order Dan to do?

A: stay in bed|| Cecily ordered him to stay in bed

Q: Name something that Cecily did for Dan?

A: carried his meals to him||Cecily carried his meals to him

Q: Anything else?

A: read a Henty book to him|| and read a Henty book to him all her spare time

Q: What kinid of work did Uncle Roger need help with?

A: carpentering||required to help Uncle Roger in some carpentering work that da

Q: How many people were required to help him?

A: three||Felix and Peter and I were required to help Uncle Roger in some carpentering work that day,

Q: Can you name one of them?\

A: Felix||Felix and Peter and I were required to help Uncle Roger in some carpentering work that day

Q: Can you name another?

A: Peter||Felix and Peter and I were required to help Uncle Roger in some carpentering work


Summary: A DISOBEDIENT BROTHER Dan was his own man again in the morning, though rather pale and weak; he wanted to get up, but Cecily ordered him to stay in bed.Cecily carried his meals to him, and read a Henty book to him all her spare time.The Story Girl went up and told him wondrous tales; and Sara Ray brought him a pudding she had made herself.Sara's intentions were good, but the pudding-- well, Dan fed most of it to Paddy, who had curled himself up at the foot of the bed, giving the world assurance of a cat by his mellifluous purring.He never pays no attention to me when I'm well."Felix and Peter and I were required to help Uncle Roger in some carpentering work that day, and Felicity indulged in one of the house-cleaning orgies so dear to her soul; so that it was evening before we were all free to meet in the orchard and loll on the grasses of Uncle Stephen's Walk.

source: race

I'm Leo. There is a great artist in my family. She is Lisa. Lisa likes drawing a lot. Here are her three drawings. There is an animal in the first drawing. It has two big eyes, a big mouth and two small ears. It has long arms and long legs. It is black and white. There are some apples in its hands. It looks very happy. What is it? I don't know, but Lisa says it is a panda. There is a woman in the second drawing. She is thin. She has straight blonde hair, a small mouth, a big nose and two big eyes. She looks angry. Who is she? Lisa says she is our mom. But Mom has curly blonde hair, small eyes and a small nose. There is an animal in the third drawing, too. Its head is an apple. Its hair and tail are leaves. It has a long mouth, and _ is a banana. Its two legs are carrots. What is it? Lisa says it is a horse, but it doesn't look like a horse. Lisa is really a great artist, isn't she? .


Q: What is in the second drawing?

A: a woman||. There is a woman in the second drawing.

Q: Who is the artist in the family?

A: Lisa||There is a great artist in my family. She is Lisa.

Q: What is in the third drawing?

A: an animal||There is an animal in the third drawing,

Q: What is it's head made out of?

A: apple|| Its head is an apple

Q: And what about it's hair and tail?

A: leaves|| Its hair and tail are leaves.

Q: What are its legs made out of?

A: carrots||Its two legs are carrots.

Q: Did Lisa say it was a zebra?

A: no, Lisa says it is a horse|| Lisa says it is a horse

Q: What is in the first drawing?

A: an animal||There is an animal in the first drawing.

Q: What's in it's hands?

A: apples||There are some apples in its hands.

Q: Does the woman in the second picture have brown hair?

A: no, She has straight blonde hair||She has straight blonde hair


Summary: There is a great artist in my family.There is an animal in the first drawing.There are some apples in its hands.There is a woman in the second drawing.She has straight blonde hair, a small mouth, a big nose and two big eyes.There is an animal in the third drawing, too.Its head is an apple.Its hair and tail are leaves.Its two legs are carrots.Lisa says it is a horse, but it doesn't look like a horse.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- A body discovered at Churchill Downs on Sunday, a day after the storied Louisville racetrack hosted the Kentucky Derby, may have been the victim of a homicide, police said. Workers in the barn area discovered the body early in the morning and notified track security, which called police, said Robert Biven, a spokesman for the Louisville Metropolitan Police Department. "We just got the call just prior to 5 a.m. to respond to the backside" of the racetrack, Biven told CNN. Police spokeswoman Alicia Smiley said police suspect foul play. The body, which has not been identified, appears to be a Latino man in his 30s or 40s, Biven said. About 400 people were located Saturday night in the rear of the racetrack, he said. "So we are trying to speak with as many people as we possibly can," he said. "We do have a few leads coming in." An autopsy is to be carried out Monday morning. Biven described the track's backside as "like a mini city," with 48 barns, workers' dormitories and areas where trainers live. "It's a 24-hour operation," he said. I'll Have Another wins Kentucky Derby Operations at the racetrack were to continue normally on Sunday, Churchill Downs spokesman John Asher said. No races are scheduled at the track for three days, but cleanup from Saturday's race was to continue and the racetrack museum was to be open, he said. CNN's Kara Devlin and Christine Sever contributed to this report

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

The National Assembly for Wales (; commonly known as the Welsh Assembly) is a devolved assembly with power to make legislation in Wales. The Assembly comprises 60 members, who are known as Assembly Members, or AMs ("Aelodau y Cynulliad"). Since 2011, Members are elected for five-year terms under an additional members system, in which 40 AMs represent geographical constituencies elected by the plurality system, and 20 AMs represent five electoral regions using the d'Hondt method of proportional representation. The Assembly was created by the Government of Wales Act 1998, which followed a referendum in 1997. The Assembly had no powers to initiate primary legislation until limited law-making powers were gained through the Government of Wales Act 2006. Its primary law-making powers were enhanced following a Yes vote in the referendum on 3 March 2011, making it possible for it to legislate without having to consult the UK parliament or the Secretary of State for Wales in the 20 areas that are devolved. An appointed Council for Wales and Monmouthshire was established in 1949 to "ensure the government is adequately informed of the impact of government activities on the general life of the people of Wales". The council had 27 members nominated by local authorities in Wales, the University of Wales, National Eisteddfod Council and the Welsh Tourist Board. A post of Minister of Welsh Affairs was created in 1951 and the post of Secretary of State for Wales and the Welsh Office were established in 1964 leading to the abolition of the Council for Wales. The establishment of the Welsh Office effectively created the basis for the territorial governance of Wales. The Royal Commission on the Constitution (the Kilbrandon Commission) was set up in 1969 by Harold Wilson's Labour Government to investigate the possibility of devolution for Scotland and Wales. Its recommendations formed the basis of the 1974 White Paper "Democracy and Devolution: proposals for Scotland and Wales", which proposed the creation of a Welsh Assembly. However, voters rejected the proposals by a majority of four to one in a referendum held in 1979.


Q: what is it commonly known as

A: the Welsh Assembly||The National Assembly for Wales (; commonly known as the Welsh Assembly

Q: what does the assembly do

A: legislates||Welsh Assembly) is a devolved assembly with power to make legislation in Wales

Q: how many people are in it

A: 60||The Assembly comprises 60 members

Q: for how long

A: five-years||Since 2011, Members are elected for five-year terms

Q: what do 40 of them represent

A: geographical constituencies||40 AMs represent geographical constituencies elected by the plurality system

Q: and the other 20?

A: five electoral regions||20 AMs represent five electoral regions

Q: using what

A: the d'Hondt method of proportional representation.||20 AMs represent five electoral regions using the d'Hondt method of proportional representation.

Q: who created the assembly

A: The Assembly was created by the Government of Wales Act 1998||The Assembly was created by the Government of Wales Act 1998

Q: following what

A: a referendum||Act 1998, which followed a referendum

A: 2006||limited law-making powers were gained through the Government of Wales Act 2006

Q: are they now able to make laws without having to consult UK

A: Yes||making it possible for it to legislate without having to consult the UK parliamen

A: 1949|| Council for Wales and Monmouthshire was established in 1949

A: 27|| The council had 27 members

Summary: The National Assembly for Wales (; commonly known as the Welsh Assembly) is a devolved assembly with power to make legislation in Wales.The Assembly comprises 60 members, who are known as Assembly Members, or AMs ("Aelodau y Cynulliad").Since 2011, Members are elected for five-year terms under an additional members system, in which 40 AMs represent geographical constituencies elected by the plurality system, and 20 AMs represent five electoral regions using the d'Hondt method of proportional representation.The Assembly was created by the Government of Wales Act 1998, which followed a referendum in 1997.The Assembly had no powers to initiate primary legislation until limited law-making powers were gained through the Government of Wales Act 2006.Its primary law-making powers were enhanced following a Yes vote in the referendum on 3 March 2011, making it possible for it to legislate without having to consult the UK parliament or the Secretary of State for Wales in the 20 areas that are devolved.An appointed Council for Wales and Monmouthshire was established in 1949 to "ensure the government is adequately informed of the impact of government activities on the general life of the people of Wales".The council had 27 members nominated by local authorities in Wales, the University of Wales, National Eisteddfod Council and the Welsh Tourist Board.A post of Minister of Welsh Affairs was created in 1951 and the post of Secretary of State for Wales and the Welsh Office were established in 1964 leading to the abolition of the Council for Wales.The Royal Commission on the Constitution (the Kilbrandon Commission) was set up in 1969 by Harold Wilson's Labour Government to investigate the possibility of devolution for Scotland and Wales.Its recommendations formed the basis of the 1974 White Paper "Democracy and Devolution: proposals for Scotland and Wales", which proposed the creation of a Welsh Assembly.

source: race

HAVE you noticed that the moon is becoming rounder and brighter day after day? That's because Sept 8 is the Mid-Autumn Festival. For Chinese people, a full moon means that family members can get together on that day. On the Mid-Autumn Festival, people get together and enjoy the round moon . They also send wishes for family members not with them. There are many stories about the moon to make the tradition more interesting. In China, Chang'e flying to the moon is a well-known legend . Hou Yi and Chang'e were husband and wife in old times. At the time, there were 10 suns in the sky. Hou yi, a brave man, shot down nine suns. People see Hou Yi as a great hero. Besides China, many other countries have beautiful stories about the moon. In Greek legend , Artemis is the goddess of the moon. She takes care of the hunt and wild animals. Artemis also looks after young children and women in childbirth . In India, the god of the moon is Soma. He has four hands and rides through the sky in a chariot . If a baby is born on a full moon day, Indian people believe he or she is lucky.


Q: What's the date of the Mid-Autumn festival?

A: Sept 8|| Sept 8

Q: Does the moon wax or wane during this time?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: Is the holiday based around the moon?

A: Yes||On the Mid-Autumn Festival, people get together and enjoy the round moon

Q: Which legendary figure flew to the moon?

A: Chang'e||Chang'e

Q: Who was her spouse?

A: Hou Yi||Hou Yi

Q: What is he famous for?

A: Hou Yi shot down nine suns||shot down nine suns

Q: How many suns were there before then?

A: 10|| there were 10 suns in the sky

Q: How many mentions of a full moon being representing good fortune are there in the story?

A: One||If a baby is born on a full moon day, Indian people believe he or she is lucky.

Q: What specific event is said to be lucky?

A: If a baby is born on a full moon day|| If a baby is born on a full moon day

Q: Which deity is responsible for this?

A: Soma.||Soma.

Q: What country is he associated with?

A: India||India

Q: Which deity is famous as a hunter?

A: Artemis||Artemis

Q: Which country is she associated with?

A: Greece||Greek

Q: Which figure uses a chariot?

A: Soma|| Soma


Summary: HAVE you noticed that the moon is becoming rounder and brighter day after day?That's because Sept 8 is the Mid-Autumn Festival.On the Mid-Autumn Festival, people get together and enjoy the round moon .In China, Chang'e flying to the moon is a well-known legend .Hou Yi and Chang'e were husband and wife in old times.At the time, there were 10 suns in the sky.Hou yi, a brave man, shot down nine suns.In Greek legend , Artemis is the goddess of the moon.In India, the god of the moon is Soma.He has four hands and rides through the sky in a chariot .If a baby is born on a full moon day, Indian people believe he or she is lucky.

source: wikipedia

The Kingdom of Yugoslavia (, , "Kingdom of South Slavia") was a state in Southeast Europe and Central Europe, that existed during the interwar period (1918–1939) and first half of World War II (1939–1943). It was formed in 1918 by the merger of the provisional State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs (itself formed from territories of the former Austro-Hungarian Empire) with the formerly independent Kingdom of Serbia. The Kingdom of Montenegro had united with Serbia five days previously, while the regions of Kosovo, Vojvodina and Vardar Macedonia were parts of Serbia prior to the unification. For its first eleven years of existence, the Kingdom was officially called the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, but the term "Yugoslavia" was its colloquial name from its origins. The official name of the state was changed to "Kingdom of Yugoslavia" by King Alexander I on 3 October 1929. The state was ruled by the Serbian dynasty of Karađorđević, which previously ruled the Kingdom of Serbia under Peter I from 1903 (after the May Overthrow) onwards. Peter I became the first king of Yugoslavia until his death in 1921. He was succeeded by his son Alexander I, who had been regent for his father. He was known as "Alexander the Unifier" and he renamed the kingdom "Yugoslavia" in 1929. He was assassinated in Marseille by Vlado Chernozemski, a member of the Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization (IMRO), during his visit to France in 1934. The crown passed to his then-still under-aged son Peter. His cousin Paul ruled as Prince regent until 1941, when Peter II would come of age. The royal family flew to London the same year, prior to the country being invaded by the Axis powers.


Q: What is this about?

A: Yugoslavia||Yugoslavia

Q: During which time period?

A: 1918–1943||The Kingdom of Yugoslavia (, , "Kingdom of South Slavia") was a state in Southeast Europe and Central Europe, that existed during the interwar period (1918–1939) and first half of World War II (1939–1943).

Q: Was this a peaceful time?

A: No, The Kingdom of Yugoslavia (, , "Kingdom of South Slavia") was a state in Southeast Europe and Central Europe, that existed during the interwar period (1918–1939) and first half of World War II (1939–1943). ||The Kingdom of Yugoslavia (, , "Kingdom of South Slavia") was a state in Southeast Europe and Central Europe, that existed during the interwar period (1918–1939) and first half of World War II (1939–1943).

Q: Where was this located?

A: Southeast Europe and Central Europe||Southeast Europe and Central Europe

Q: When was it started?

A: 1918||1918

Q: By which groups?

A: the merger of the provisional State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs||the merger of the provisional State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs

Q: What was it called at first?

A: Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes||Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes

Q: For how long?

A: eleven years||eleven years

Q: What year was it changed?

A: 1929||1929

Q: Which date?

A: 3 October 1929||3 October 1929

Q: By who?

A: King Alexander I||King Alexander I

Q: To what?

A: Kingdom of Yugoslavia||Kingdom of Yugoslavia


Summary: The Kingdom of Yugoslavia (, , "Kingdom of South Slavia") was a state in Southeast Europe and Central Europe, that existed during the interwar period (1918–1939) and first half of World War II (1939–1943).It was formed in 1918 by the merger of the provisional State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs (itself formed from territories of the former Austro-Hungarian Empire) with the formerly independent Kingdom of Serbia.For its first eleven years of existence, the Kingdom was officially called the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, but the term "Yugoslavia" was its colloquial name from its origins.The official name of the state was changed to "Kingdom of Yugoslavia" by King Alexander I on 3 October 1929.The state was ruled by the Serbian dynasty of Karađorđević, which previously ruled the Kingdom of Serbia under Peter I from 1903 (after the May Overthrow) onwards.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXVII WAITING Ingleside, 1st November 1917 "It is November--and the Glen is all grey and brown, except where the Lombardy poplars stand up here and there like great golden torches in the sombre landscape, although every other tree has shed its leaves. It has been very hard to keep our courage alight of late. The Caporetto disaster is a dreadful thing and not even Susan can extract much consolation out of the present state of affairs. The rest of us don't try. Gertrude keeps saying desperately, 'They must not get Venice--they must not get Venice,' as if by saying it often enough she can prevent them. But what is to prevent them from getting Venice I cannot see. Yet, as Susan fails not to point out, there was seemingly nothing to prevent them from getting to Paris in 1914, yet they did not get it, and she affirms they shall not get Venice either. Oh, how I hope and pray they will not--Venice the beautiful Queen of the Adriatic. Although I've never seen it I feel about it just as Byron did--I've always loved it--it has always been to me 'a fairy city of the heart.' Perhaps I caught my love of it from Walter, who worshipped it. It was always one of his dreams to see Venice. I remember we planned once--down in Rainbow Valley one evening just before the war broke out--that some time we would go together to see it and float in a gondola through its moonlit streets.


Q: Which literary giant wrote about Venice?

A: Byron|| Although I've never seen it I feel about it just as Byron did

Q: Did the the narrator ever visit the city?

A: no, Although I've never seen it I|| Although I've never seen it I

Q: But did he feel close to it?

A: yes||Although I've never seen it I feel about it just as Byron did--I've always loved it--it has always been to me 'a fairy city of the heart.'

Q: How did he describe it in his own words?

A: "a fairy city of the heart"|| 'a fairy city of the heart.'

Q: Who else was in love with the city?

A: Walter|| Perhaps I caught my love of it from Walter, who worshipped it.

A: yes||that some time we would go together to see it and float in a gondola through its moonlit streets.

Q: With whom?

A: the author||. I remember we planned once--down in Rainbow Valley one evening just before the war broke out--that some time we would go together to see it and float in a gondola through its moonlit streets.

A: yes||down in Rainbow Valley

A: just before the war broke out|| just before the war broke out

Summary: The Caporetto disaster is a dreadful thing and not even Susan can extract much consolation out of the present state of affairs.Gertrude keeps saying desperately, 'They must not get Venice--they must not get Venice,' as if by saying it often enough she can prevent them.Yet, as Susan fails not to point out, there was seemingly nothing to prevent them from getting to Paris in 1914, yet they did not get it, and she affirms they shall not get Venice either.Oh, how I hope and pray they will not--Venice the beautiful Queen of the Adriatic.Although I've never seen it I feel about it just as Byron did--I've always loved it--it has always been to me 'a fairy city of the heart.'Perhaps I caught my love of it from Walter, who worshipped it.It was always one of his dreams to see Venice.I remember we planned once--down in Rainbow Valley one evening just before the war broke out--that some time we would go together to see it and float in a gondola through its moonlit streets.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER II Serge went to Moscow. He entered the Teknik. He became a student. He learned geography from Stoj, the professor, astrography from Fudj, the assistant, together with giliodesy, orgastrophy and other native Russian studies. All day he worked. His industry was unflagging. His instructors were enthusiastic. "If he goes on like this," they said, "he will some day know something." "It is marvellous," said one. "If he continues thus, he will be a professor." "He is too young," said Stoj, shaking his head. "He has too much hair." "He sees too well," said Fudj. "Let him wait till his eyes are weaker." But all day as Serge worked he thought. And his thoughts were of Olga Ileyitch, the girl that he had seen with Kwartz, inspector of police. He wondered why she had killed Popoff, the inspector. He wondered if she was dead. There seemed no justice in it. One day he questioned his professor. "Is the law just?" he said. "Is it right to kill?" But Stoj shook his head, and would not answer. "Let us go on with our orgastrophy," he said. And he trembled so that the chalk shook in his hand. So Serge questioned no further, but he thought more deeply still. All the way from the Teknik to the house where he lodged he was thinking. As he climbed the stair to his attic room he was still thinking. The house in which Serge lived was the house of Madame Vasselitch. It was a tall dark house in a sombre street. There were no trees upon the street and no children played there. And opposite to the house of Madame Vasselitch was a building of stone, with windows barred, that was always silent. In it were no lights, and no one went in or out.


Q: How long did Sarge work?

A: all day||all day

Q: Were his teachers boring?

A: no, enthusiastic||enthusiastic

Q: Were they hopeful for him?

A: yes||"It is marvellous," said one. "If he continues thus, he will be a professor."

Q: Where did Serge go?

A: Moscow||Moscow

Q: What did he go into?

A: Teknik||Teknik

Q: What was he?

A: a student||a student

Q: Who was Stoj?

A: the professor||the professor

Q: What did he learn from him?

A: geography||geography

Q: What did he learn from Fudj?

A: astrography||astrography

Q: Did one teacher think he would become a professor?

A: yes||"It is marvellous," said one. "If he continues thus, he will be a professor."

Q: Did Stoj think he was too old?

A: no, "He is too young," said Stoj, shaking his head. "He has too much hair." ||"He is too young," said Stoj, shaking his head. "He has too much hair."

Q: What did Stoj say about his hair?

A: he has too much hair||He has too much hair."

Q: What did Fudj say aout his vision?

A: that he sees too well||"He sees too well," said Fudj. "Let him wait till his eyes are weaker."

Q: what did Serge do all day?

A: he thought|| he thought

Q: about whom?

A: Olga Ileyitch||Olga Ileyitch

Q: who had she been with?

A: Kwartz||Kwartz

Q: What is his job?

A: he was the inspector of police||, inspector of police

Q: Did she kill someone?

A: yes|| He wondered why she had killed Popoff

Q: who?

A: Popoff||Popoff

Q: What is his job?

A: an inspector||the inspector.


Summary: CHAPTER II Serge went to Moscow.He entered the Teknik.He became a student.He learned geography from Stoj, the professor, astrography from Fudj, the assistant, together with giliodesy, orgastrophy and other native Russian studies.His instructors were enthusiastic."It is marvellous," said one."He is too young," said Stoj, shaking his head."He has too much hair.""He sees too well," said Fudj.But all day as Serge worked he thought.And his thoughts were of Olga Ileyitch, the girl that he had seen with Kwartz, inspector of police.He wondered why she had killed Popoff, the inspector.He wondered if she was dead.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: cnn

(CNN) -- Kenyan actress Lupita Nyong'o has become a new critics' darling after her breakout role in last year's hit movie "12 Years A Slave." Since then, the award ceremonies and opportunities to dazzle photographers have been plentiful for Nyong'o, whose mesmerizing performance as Patsey earned her numerous accolades and recognition, including an Oscar nomination for Best Actress in a Supporting Role. Though all this attention is new to Nyong'o, who was born in Mexico to Kenyan parents, the young actress seems to enjoy all the hype around her. But there is much more to her story than how she captivates the cameras on the red carpet. CNN's Stephanie Elam caught up with Nyong'o to speak about her journey from Kenya to Hollywood. An edited version of the interview follows. CNN: How did you end up being born in Mexico? Lupita Nyong'o: My father is a politician. At the time he was also a professor of political science and he was organizing for democracy in Kenya. We were under an autocratic regime and after a series of unfortunate events, including the disappearance of his brother, he went into political exile in Mexico. I was born in his last year there. Read more: 10 things to know about Lupita Nyong'o CNN: So you were born in Mexico but grew up in Kenya. LN: Yes, all my conscious memories are in Kenya until when I was 16 my parents sent me back to Mexico to learn Spanish. I grew up in Nairobi, which is the capital of Kenya, so it's hustle and bustle and there's always something going on. I come from a very big family and we're very close knit so I had lots of time with me family.


Q: Who was born in Mexico but not raised there?

A: Lupita Nyong'o||CNN: So you were born in Mexico but grew up in Kenya. LN: Yes, all my conscious memories are in Kenya until when I was 16 my parents sent me back to Mexico to learn Spanish.

Q: What movie was her breakout role in?

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

The main passenger airport serving the metropolis and the state is Melbourne Airport (also called Tullamarine Airport), which is the second busiest in Australia, and the Port of Melbourne is Australia's busiest seaport for containerised and general cargo. Melbourne has an extensive transport network. The main metropolitan train terminus is Flinders Street Station, and the main regional train and coach terminus is Southern Cross Station. Melbourne is also home to Australia's most extensive freeway network and has the world's largest urban tram network. Between 1836 and 1842 Victorian Aboriginal groups were largely dispossessed[by whom?] of their land. By January 1844, there were said to be 675 Aborigines resident in squalid camps in Melbourne. The British Colonial Office appointed five Aboriginal Protectors for the Aborigines of Victoria, in 1839, however their work was nullified by a land policy that favoured squatters to take possession of Aboriginal lands. By 1845, fewer than 240 wealthy Europeans held all the pastoral licences then issued in Victoria and became a powerful political and economic force in Victoria for generations to come.


Q: Which is the busiest seaport?

A: Port of Melbourne||Port of Melbourne

Q: How would you describe their transportation options?

A: extensive transport network||extensive transport network

Q: What happens at the Flinders Street Station?

A: The main metropolitan train terminus||The main metropolitan train terminus

Q: What is the name of the airport for passengers?

A: Melbourne Airport||Melbourne Airpor

Q: Where do the coach trains arrive to?

A: Southern Cross Station||Southern Cross Station

Q: What happened in 1836?

A: Victorian Aboriginal groups were largely dispossessed||Victorian Aboriginal groups were largely dispossessed

Q: until when?

A: 1842||1842

Q: Where did they go?

A: Melbourne||Melbourne

Q: How many were there?

A: 675 Aborigines||675 Aborigines

Q: What was done to help them?

A: The British Colonial Office appointed five Aboriginal Protectors||The British Colonial Office appointed five Aboriginal Protectors

Q: Did it work?

A: their work was nullified by a land policy that favoured squatters||their work was nullified by a land policy that favoured squatters


Summary: The main passenger airport serving the metropolis and the state is Melbourne Airport (also called Tullamarine Airport), which is the second busiest in Australia, and the Port of Melbourne is Australia's busiest seaport for containerised and general cargo.Melbourne has an extensive transport network.The main metropolitan train terminus is Flinders Street Station, and the main regional train and coach terminus is Southern Cross Station.Between 1836 and 1842 Victorian Aboriginal groups were largely dispossessed[by whom?]By January 1844, there were said to be 675 Aborigines resident in squalid camps in Melbourne.The British Colonial Office appointed five Aboriginal Protectors for the Aborigines of Victoria, in 1839, however their work was nullified by a land policy that favoured squatters to take possession of Aboriginal lands.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- A Florida corrections officer assisting in a manhunt died Wednesday in an exchange of gunfire with a murder suspect, who also died, authorities said. Col. Greg Malloy, 44, was mortally wounded, the Florida Department of Corrections said in a statement. Malloy was working as part of the Holmes Correctional Institution's K-9 tracking team, which was assisting the Holmes County Sheriff's Office in the search for Wade Williams. Williams, wanted in the double homicide of his parents, was also killed during the exchange, according to the statement. The incident occurred about 13 miles from Bonifay in the Florida Panhandle. "Words can never express our emotions when an officer falls in the line of duty," said Department of Corrections Secretary Walt McNeil. "Tragedies such as today's underscore the dangers inherent in our profession, both inside and outside the prison walls. We extend our condolences to Greg's family and his co-workers." Malloy began his career with the Department of Corrections in 1988. The Florida Department of Law Enforcement is conducting the shooting investigation. The Holmes County sheriff had not yet responded to a message left by CNN Wednesday afternoon.

A: Greg Malloy||Greg Malloy, 44, was mortally wounded

Q: How old was he?

A: 44|| Greg Malloy, 44

Q: What was his job?

A: corrections officer|| A Florida corrections officer assisting in a manhunt died

Q: Who was he assisting that day?

A: the Holmes County Sheriff's Office|| which was assisting the Holmes County Sheriff's Office

Q: Was he part of a particular team?

A: yes||Malloy was working as part of the Holmes Correctional Institution's K-9 tracking team

Q: Which one?

A: the Holmes Correctional Institution's K-9 tracking team,||part of the Holmes Correctional Institution's K-9 tracking team,

A: in the Florida Panhandle||Bonifay in the Florida Panhandle

A: Walt McNeil||said Department of Corrections Secretary Walt McNeil

A: yes||the dangers inherent in our profession

Q: Just in the prisons?

A: no, dangers inherent in our profession, both inside and outside the prison walls||dangers inherent in our profession, both inside and outside the prison walls

Summary: (CNN) -- A Florida corrections officer assisting in a manhunt died Wednesday in an exchange of gunfire with a murder suspect, who also died, authorities said.Col. Greg Malloy, 44, was mortally wounded, the Florida Department of Corrections said in a statement.Malloy was working as part of the Holmes Correctional Institution's K-9 tracking team, which was assisting the Holmes County Sheriff's Office in the search for Wade Williams.Williams, wanted in the double homicide of his parents, was also killed during the exchange, according to the statement.The incident occurred about 13 miles from Bonifay in the Florida Panhandle."Words can never express our emotions when an officer falls in the line of duty," said Department of Corrections Secretary Walt McNeil."Tragedies such as today's underscore the dangers inherent in our profession, both inside and outside the prison walls.Malloy began his career with the Department of Corrections in 1988.The Florida Department of Law Enforcement is conducting the shooting investigation.The Holmes County sheriff had not yet responded to a message left by CNN Wednesday afternoon.

source: wikipedia

Aragon ( or , Spanish and , or ) is an autonomous community in Spain, coextensive with the medieval Kingdom of Aragon. Located in northeastern Spain, the Aragonese autonomous community comprises three provinces (from north to south): Huesca, Zaragoza, and Teruel. Its capital is Zaragoza (also called "Saragossa" in English). The current Statute of Autonomy declares Aragon a "nationality" of Spain. Aragon's northern province of Huesca borders France and is positioned in the middle of the Pyrenees. Within Spain, the community is flanked by Catalonia to the east, Valencian Community and Castilla–La Mancha to the south, and Castile and León, La Rioja, and Navarre to the west. Covering an area of , the region's terrain ranges diversely from permanent glaciers to verdant valleys, rich pasture lands and orchards, through to the arid steppe plains of the central lowlands. Aragon is home to many rivers—most notably, the river Ebro, Spain's largest river in volume, which runs west-east across the entire region through the province of Zaragoza. It is also home to the Aneto, the highest mountain in the Pyrenees. , the population of Aragon was 1,317,847, with slightly more than half of it living in Zaragoza, its capital city. The economy of Aragon generates () a GDP of €33,162 million which represents 3.13% of Spain's national GDP, and is currently 6th in per capita production behind Madrid, Basque Country, Navarre, Catalonia and La Rioja.


Q: Where is Aragon located?

A: in northeastern Spain|| Located in northeastern Spain

Q: What are the people of the community referred to as?

A: the Aragonese||the Aragonese

Q: Does it have a diverse terrain?

A: yes||region's terrain ranges diversely from permanent glaciers to verdant valleys

Q: What is its most notable body of water called?

A: the river Ebro||river Ebro, Spain's largest river in volume

Q: Does it run North and South?

A: no, west-east across||west-east across

Q: Are there any mountains?

A: yes||Aneto, the highest mountain in the Pyrenees

Q: What is the name of one of them?

A: Aneto||Aneto, the highest mountain in the Pyrenees.

A: three||three provinces

A: The current Statute of Autonomy||The current Statute of Autonomy

A: "Saragossa"||also called "Saragossa" in English


Summary: Located in northeastern Spain, the Aragonese autonomous community comprises three provinces (from north to south): Huesca, Zaragoza, and Teruel.Its capital is Zaragoza (also called "Saragossa" in English).The current Statute of Autonomy declares Aragon a "nationality" of Spain.Aragon's northern province of Huesca borders France and is positioned in the middle of the Pyrenees.Covering an area of , the region's terrain ranges diversely from permanent glaciers to verdant valleys, rich pasture lands and orchards, through to the arid steppe plains of the central lowlands.Aragon is home to many rivers—most notably, the river Ebro, Spain's largest river in volume, which runs west-east across the entire region through the province of Zaragoza.It is also home to the Aneto, the highest mountain in the Pyrenees., the population of Aragon was 1,317,847, with slightly more than half of it living in Zaragoza, its capital city.The economy of Aragon generates () a GDP of €33,162 million which represents 3.13% of Spain's national GDP, and is currently 6th in per capita production behind Madrid, Basque Country, Navarre, Catalonia and La Rioja.

source: race

It was a cold winter day. A woman drove up to the Rainbow Bridge tollbooth . "I'm paying for myself, and for the six cars behind me," she said with a smile, handing over seven tickets. One after another, the next six drivers arriving at the tollbooth were informed, "Some lady up ahead already paid your fare." It turned out that the woman, Natalie Smith, had read something on a friend's refrigerator: "Practice random kindness and senseless acts of beauty." The phrase impressed her so much that she copied it down. Judy Foreman spotted the same phrase on a warehouse wall far away from home. When it stayed on her mind for days, she gave up and drove all the way back to copy it down. "I thought it was beautiful," she said, explaining why she'd taken to writing it at the bottom of all her letters, "like a message from above." Her husband, Frank, liked the phrase so much that he put it up on the classroom wall for his students, one of whom was the daughter of Alice Johnson, a local news reporter. Alice put it in the newspaper, admitting that though she liked it, she didn't know where it came from or what it really meant. Two days later, Alice got a call from Anne Herbert, a woman living in Marin. It was in a restaurant that Anne wrote the phrase down on a piece of paper, after turning it around in her mind for days. "Here's the idea," Anne says. "Anything you think there should be more of, do it randomly." Her fantasies include painting the classrooms of shabby schools, leaving hot meals on kitchen tables in the poor part of town, and giving money secretly to a proud old lady. Anne says, " _ ." The acts of random kindness spread. If you were one of those drivers who found your fare paid, who knows what you might have been inspired to do for someone else later. Like all great events, kindness begins slowly, with every single act. Let it be yours!


Q: How many cars did the woman pay for?

A: Seven||"I'm paying for myself, and for the six cars behind me

Q: where at?

A: Rainbow Bridge tollbooth|| A woman drove up to the Rainbow Bridge tollbooth

Q: what were the other drivers told?

A: Some lady up ahead already paid your fare||Some lady up ahead already paid your fare

Q: who was the lady?

A: Natalie Smith||It turned out that the woman, Natalie Smith

A: no, It turned out that the woman, Natalie Smith, had read something on a friend's refrigerator:||It turned out that the woman, Natalie Smith, had read something on a friend's refrigerator:

Q: who did?

A: Judy Foreman||Judy Foreman

A: no, When it stayed on her mind for days, she gave up and drove all the way back to copy it down||When it stayed on her mind for days, she gave up and drove all the way back to copy it down

A: later|| Judy Foreman spotted the same phrase on a warehouse wall far away from home. When it stayed on her mind for days, she gave up and drove all the way back to copy it down. "I thought it was beautiful," she said, explaining why she'd taken to writing it at the bottom of all her letters, "like a message from above." Alice put it in the newspaper, admitting that though she liked it, she didn't know where it came from or what it really meant.

Summary: A woman drove up to the Rainbow Bridge tollbooth ."I'm paying for myself, and for the six cars behind me," she said with a smile, handing over seven tickets.One after another, the next six drivers arriving at the tollbooth were informed, "Some lady up ahead already paid your fare."It turned out that the woman, Natalie Smith, had read something on a friend's refrigerator: "Practice random kindness and senseless acts of beauty."Judy Foreman spotted the same phrase on a warehouse wall far away from home.When it stayed on her mind for days, she gave up and drove all the way back to copy it down."I thought it was beautiful," she said, explaining why she'd taken to writing it at the bottom of all her letters, "like a message from above."Her husband, Frank, liked the phrase so much that he put it up on the classroom wall for his students, one of whom was the daughter of Alice Johnson, a local news reporter.Alice put it in the newspaper, admitting that though she liked it, she didn't know where it came from or what it really meant.Two days later, Alice got a call from Anne Herbert, a woman living in Marin.It was in a restaurant that Anne wrote the phrase down on a piece of paper, after turning it around in her mind for days."Anything you think there should be more of, do it randomly."

source: wikipedia

Mao Zedong or Mao Tse-tung (; December 26, 1893September 9, 1976), also known as Chairman Mao, was a Chinese communist revolutionary, poet, political theorist and founding father of the People's Republic of China, which he governed as the Chairman of the Communist Party of China from its establishment in 1949 until his death in 1976. His Marxist–Leninist theories, military strategies and political policies are collectively known as Maoism or Marxism–Leninism–Maoism. Born the son of a wealthy farmer in Shaoshan, Hunan, Mao adopted a Chinese nationalist and anti-imperialist outlook in early life, particularly influenced by the events of the Xinhai Revolution of 1911 and May Fourth Movement of 1919. Mao adopted Marxism–Leninism while working at Peking University and became a founding member of the Communist Party of China (CPC), leading the Autumn Harvest Uprising in 1927. During the Chinese Civil War between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the CPC, Mao helped to found the Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army, led the Jiangxi Soviet's radical land policies and ultimately became head of the CPC during the Long March. Although the CPC temporarily allied with the KMT under the United Front during the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937–1945), after Japan's defeat China's civil war resumed and in 1949 Mao's forces defeated the Nationalists who withdrew to Taiwan.


Q: Who was the founder of Communist China?

A: Mao Zedong||Mao Zedong or Mao Tse-tung (; December 26, 1893September 9, 1976), also known as Chairman Mao, was a Chinese communist revolutionary, poet, political theorist and founding father of the People's Republic of C

Q: By what other title was he referred to?

A: Chairman Mao||Mao Zedong or Mao Tse-tung (; December 26, 1893September 9, 1976), also known as Chairman Mao, was a Chinese communist revolutionary

Q: Where was he born?

A: China||Mao Zedong or Mao Tse-tung (; December 26, 1893September 9, 1976), also known as Chairman Mao, was a Chinese communist revolutionary, poet, political theorist and founding father of the People's Republic of China,

Q: In what region?

A: Shaoshan||Born the son of a wealthy farmer in Shaoshan, Hunan

A: farmer||on of a wealthy farmer in Shaoshan, Hunan

Q: Was his family poor?

A: No, Born the son of a wealthy farmer in Shaosha||Born the son of a wealthy farmer in Shaosha

A: one was the Xinhai Revolution||nfluenced by the events of the Xinhai Revolution of 1911 and May Fourth Movement of 1919. Mao adopted Marxism–Lenin

Q: And the other?

A: May Fourth Movement||particularly influenced by the events of the Xinhai Revolution of 1911 and May Fourth Movement of 1919.

Q: When did he finally beat the Nationalist army?

A: in 1949||in 1949 Mao's forces defeated the Nationalists who withdrew to Taiwan.

A: Taiwan||defeated the Nationalists who withdrew to Taiwan.


Summary: Mao Zedong or Mao Tse-tung (; December 26, 1893September 9, 1976), also known as Chairman Mao, was a Chinese communist revolutionary, poet, political theorist and founding father of the People's Republic of China, which he governed as the Chairman of the Communist Party of China from its establishment in 1949 until his death in 1976.Born the son of a wealthy farmer in Shaoshan, Hunan, Mao adopted a Chinese nationalist and anti-imperialist outlook in early life, particularly influenced by the events of the Xinhai Revolution of 1911 and May Fourth Movement of 1919.Mao adopted Marxism–Leninism while working at Peking University and became a founding member of the Communist Party of China (CPC), leading the Autumn Harvest Uprising in 1927.During the Chinese Civil War between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the CPC, Mao helped to found the Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army, led the Jiangxi Soviet's radical land policies and ultimately became head of the CPC during the Long March.Although the CPC temporarily allied with the KMT under the United Front during the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937–1945), after Japan's defeat China's civil war resumed and in 1949 Mao's forces defeated the Nationalists who withdrew to Taiwan.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: cnn

(CNN) -- The Supreme Court has just agreed to take on the case of Fisher v. University of Texas. Abigail Fisher, a white woman, argues that she has been a victim of the university's race-conscious admission policies; the university contends that its drive for racial and ethnic diversity is educationally enriching -- a benefit to all students. Will the ugly discourse that generally characterizes debate over racially preferential policies disappear with the wave of a magic Supreme Court wand? It seems unlikely. The issue is a cat with many more than nine lives. It arrived in the early 1970s and, despite many attacks, some of which have taken the form of amendments to state constitutions, it has survived in pretty fine fettle. The court will have only eight justices to hear the arguments. Elena Kagan, having been involved in the case as solicitor general in the Obama administration, has bowed out of participation. Her absence, however, leaves five justices likely to express at least some degree of skepticism about the racial preferences given to non-Asian minorities in the admissions process. Has the University of Texas been enriched by academic diversity? Maybe. But equally likely is the possibility that racial double standards reinforce stereotypes about smart whites and even smarter Asians. There are certainly wide gaps in the average SAT scores between blacks and Hispanics, on the one hand, and whites and Asians, on the other hand. Among freshmen entering the University of Texas in 2009 who did not fall into the top 10% of their high school class (automatic admission at the university), Asians scored at the 93rd percentile of 2009 SAT takers nationwide, whites at the 89th percentile, Hispanics at the 80th percentile and blacks at the 52nd percentile. Startling? No. This picture has been well known for a long time. Heartbreaking, yes, because the numbers mean the underperforming minority students are being woefully ill served by the K-12 school system. Moreover, arriving at institutions of higher education with an academic disadvantage, they do not catch up, as it has become clear.


Q: What does being in the top 10% of your high school class get you?

A: automatic admission||automatic admission

Q: To where?

A: at the university||at the university

Q: Which one?

A: University of Texas||University of Texas

Q: Where do whites rank on the SAT?

A: 89th percentile|| 89th percentile

Q: Asians?

A: 93rd percentile||93rd percentile

Q: Hispanics

A: 80th percentile||80th percentile

Q: Blacks?

A: 52nd percentile|| 52nd percentile

Q: What system is to blame for this difference?

A: K-12 school system.||K-12 school system.

Q: Who is taking their case to The Supreme Court?

A: Abigail Fisher||Abigail Fisher

Q: Who is she suing?

A: University of Texas||University of Texas

Q: What does she feel made her a victim?

A: race-conscious admission policies||race-conscious admission policies

Q: What race is she?

A: white||white

Q: How does the university feel about their policy?

A: is educationally enriching||is educationally enriching

Q: How many justices will participate in this case?

A: eight||eight

Q: Who's they ninth judge?

A: Elena Kagan||Elena Kagan

Q: What happened to her?

A: bowed out||bowed out

Q: Was she previously involved in this case?

A: yes||having been involved

Q: During what?

A: during Obama administration||Obama administration

Q: What was her job?

A: solicitor general||solicitor general

Q: Without her how many will doubt the policy?

A: five|| five


Summary: (CNN) -- The Supreme Court has just agreed to take on the case of Fisher v. University of Texas.Abigail Fisher, a white woman, argues that she has been a victim of the university's race-conscious admission policies; the university contends that its drive for racial and ethnic diversity is educationally enriching -- a benefit to all students.The court will have only eight justices to hear the arguments.Elena Kagan, having been involved in the case as solicitor general in the Obama administration, has bowed out of participation.Her absence, however, leaves five justices likely to express at least some degree of skepticism about the racial preferences given to non-Asian minorities in the admissions process.Among freshmen entering the University of Texas in 2009 who did not fall into the top 10% of their high school class (automatic admission at the university), Asians scored at the 93rd percentile of 2009 SAT takers nationwide, whites at the 89th percentile, Hispanics at the 80th percentile and blacks at the 52nd percentile.Startling?Moreover, arriving at institutions of higher education with an academic disadvantage, they do not catch up, as it has become clear.

source: mctest

Anna loved the beach and went as often as she could. She liked the birds and the waves. Jason did not like the beach. He did not like how warm the sand was. He didn't like the salt in the water. Jason wanted to stay home. Jason went to the beach with his mother and father and met Anna. She had a red kite that Jason liked very much. Anna was having trouble getting the kite in the air and was sad. Jason went over to help her and together they got the kite into the air and watched it go higher and higher. Anna let Jason fly the kite for a little bit. After that Jason was hungry. Anna showed him that she had brought a green Picnic basket from her house. Inside the picnic basket there were cakes and sandwiches and salad and some fruit. Jason had brought lemonade in a blue bottle and shared it with Anna. It was the most fun Jason had at the beach.


Q: Who loved to ocean?

A: Anna||Anna

Q: what did she like about it?

A: birds and the waves||birds and the waves

Q: Did Jason like it?

A: Jason did not like the beach.||Jason did not like the beach.

Q: what was his problem with the sand?

A: warm||warm t

Q: What about the water?

A: salt||salt

Q: what did he want to do instead?

A: stay home||stay home

Q: Who did he accompany to the ocean?

A: mother and father||mother and father

Q: Who did they meet there?

A: Anna||Anna

Q: what did Anna have that Jason admired?

A: red kite||red kite

Q: how did Anna feel about being unable to use it properly?

A: sad.|| sad.

Q: Who assisted her to get it up?

A: Jason|| Jason

Q: why did Anna show him her picnic basket?

A: Jason was hungry.||Jason was hungry.

Q: What was inside?

A: cakes and sandwiches and salad and some fruit|| cakes and sandwiches and salad and some fruit

A: lemonade||lemonade

Q: what was it in?

A: blue bottle||blue bottle

Q: did he share it?

A: shared it with Anna||shared it with Anna

A: green||green

Q: How did Jason feel about his trip to the ocean?

A: fun||fun


Summary: Anna loved the beach and went as often as she could.She liked the birds and the waves.Jason did not like the beach.He did not like how warm the sand was.He didn't like the salt in the water.Jason wanted to stay home.Jason went to the beach with his mother and father and met Anna.She had a red kite that Jason liked very much.Jason went over to help her and together they got the kite into the air and watched it go higher and higher.After that Jason was hungry.Anna showed him that she had brought a green Picnic basket from her house.Inside the picnic basket there were cakes and sandwiches and salad and some fruit.Jason had brought lemonade in a blue bottle and shared it with Anna.It was the most fun Jason had at the beach.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXIII LOVERS Bernard Maddison kept his engagement that evening, and dined alone with Lady Thurwell and Helen. There had been some talk of going to the opera afterwards, but no one seemed to care about it, and so it dropped through. "For my part," Lady Thurwell said, as they sat lingering over their dessert, "I shall quite enjoy an evening's rest. You literary men, Mr. Maddison, talk a good deal about being overworked, but you know nothing of the life of a chaperon in the season. I tell Helen that she is sadly wanting in gratitude. We do everything worth doing--picture galleries, matinées, shopping, afternoon calls, dinners, dances, receptions--why, there's no slavery like it." Helen laughed softly. "We do a great deal too much, aunt," she said. "I am almost coming round to my father's opinion. You know, Mr. Maddison, he very seldom comes to London, and then only when he wants to pay a visit to his gunmaker, or to renew his hunting kit, or something of that sort. London life does not suit him at all." "I think your father a very wise man," he answered. "He seeks his pleasures in a more wholesome manner." She looked thoughtful. "Yes, I suppose, ethically, the life of a man about town is on a very low level. That is why one meets so few who interest one, as a rule. Don't you think all this society life very frivolous, Mr. Maddison?" "I am not willing to be its judge," he answered. "Yet it is a moral axiom that the higher we seek for our pleasures the greater happiness we attain to. I am an uncompromising enemy to what is known as fashionable society, so I will draw no conclusions."


Q: Who does city life not favor?

A: Helen's father|| London life does not suit him

Q: Does he visit there often?

A: no, he very seldom comes to London||he very seldom comes to London

Q: Why does he come then?

A: when he wants to pay a visit to his gunmaker||only when he wants to pay a visit to his gunmaker

Q: Any other reason?

A: or to renew his hunting kit||or to renew his hunting ki

Q: Who thinks that's a smart move?

A: Mr. Maddison||Mr. Maddison

Q: Why's that?

A: He seeks his pleasures in a more wholesome manner||He seeks his pleasures in a more wholesome manner

Q: Did she immediately dismiss the thought?

A: no, She looked thoughtful||She looked thoughtful

Q: How many interesting people does she feel one tends to meet?

A: few||few

Q: Does Maddison find it all shallow?

A: he draws no conclusions||I will draw no conclusions

Q: Is he a fan then?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: How many people are eating together?

A: Three|| dined alone with Lady Thurwell and Helen

Q: What are their names?

A: Bernard Maddison, Lady Thurwell, and Helen||Bernard Maddison kept his engagement that evening, and dined alone with Lady Thurwell and Helen

Q: Are they heading out to a performance soon?

A: no, but no one seemed to care about it, and so it dropped through||but no one seemed to care about it, and so it dropped through

Q: What part of the meal are they on?

A: dessert||dessert

Q: What kind of a man is he?

A: a literary man|| literary men

Q: Is Thurwell looking forward to an active night?

A: no, I shall quite enjoy an evening's rest||I shall quite enjoy an evening's rest

Q: In what capacity is she acting for the dinner?

A: chaperon||chaperon

Q: For whom?

A: Helen||Helen

Q: Is Helen grateful?

A: no, sadly wanting in gratitude|| sadly wanting in gratitude

Q: What kind of things do they do together?

A: picture galleries, matinées, shopping||picture galleries, matinées, shopping


Summary: CHAPTER XXIII LOVERS Bernard Maddison kept his engagement that evening, and dined alone with Lady Thurwell and Helen.There had been some talk of going to the opera afterwards, but no one seemed to care about it, and so it dropped through."For my part," Lady Thurwell said, as they sat lingering over their dessert, "I shall quite enjoy an evening's rest.You literary men, Mr. Maddison, talk a good deal about being overworked, but you know nothing of the life of a chaperon in the season.I tell Helen that she is sadly wanting in gratitude.We do everything worth doing--picture galleries, matinées, shopping, afternoon calls, dinners, dances, receptions--why, there's no slavery like it."Helen laughed softly.You know, Mr. Maddison, he very seldom comes to London, and then only when he wants to pay a visit to his gunmaker, or to renew his hunting kit, or something of that sort.London life does not suit him at all.""He seeks his pleasures in a more wholesome manner.""Yes, I suppose, ethically, the life of a man about town is on a very low level.That is why one meets so few who interest one, as a rule.

source: mctest

A little boy named Jimmy and his best friend Jeremy are walking home from school one day in the cold. They walk and talk about how different kindergarten is from the first grade. Jimmy and Jeremy are in different classes and they do different things. Jimmy's teacher has the kids do lots of arts and crafts making sock puppets, pasting pictures and many other things. Jeremy wishes he was in the same class as Jimmy because they are best friends and he likes doing arts and crafts. Jimmy tells Jeremy that they are going to be best friends even if they are in different classes, this makes Jeremy feel better. Jimmy remembers that Jeremy's birthday party is next week and he gets excited. Jimmy has the idea to make Jeremy a birthday cake with the help of his mother. They finally arrive at the corner where Jimmy lives and they promise to meet up the next morning for the walk to school. Jeremy lives three houses down and he races home.


Q: Who is Jimmy's best friend?

A: Jeremy||Jeremy

Q: Where are they walking home from?

A: school||school

Q: Who's leader has them do crafty things?

A: Jimmy's|| Jimmy's

Q: What does Jeremy wish?

A: That he was in the same class||he was in the same class

Q: Whose birthday is it going to be?

A: Jeremy's||Jeremy's

Q: When?

A: Next week||next week

Q: What will Jimmy bake for it?

A: A birthday cake||birthday cake

Q: With whose help?

A: His mother||mother

Q: Where do they finally arrive?

A: At the corner where Jimmy lives||corner where Jimmy lives

Q: What do they promise?

A: To meet up the next morning||meet up

Q: Where does Jeremy live?

A: Three houses down||three houses down

Q: Does he walk home slowly?

A: No, races||races

Q: How does he go home?

A: By walking||walking


Summary: A little boy named Jimmy and his best friend Jeremy are walking home from school one day in the cold.Jimmy's teacher has the kids do lots of arts and crafts making sock puppets, pasting pictures and many other things.Jeremy wishes he was in the same class as Jimmy because they are best friends and he likes doing arts and crafts.Jimmy remembers that Jeremy's birthday party is next week and he gets excited.Jimmy has the idea to make Jeremy a birthday cake with the help of his mother.They finally arrive at the corner where Jimmy lives and they promise to meet up the next morning for the walk to school.Jeremy lives three houses down and he races home.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- With a fourth video released, Gruber-gate is now in full swing. The latest caught-on-tape remarks from economist Jonathan Gruber, one of the architects of the Affordable Care Act, has him asserting back in 2010 that the "American public" -- that's you and me -- "doesn't actually care that much about the uninsured." He thinks he knows us so well. In another video released earlier, he said that to pass new health care legislation, the Obama administration successfully relied on an electorate -- again, you and me -- that didn't really understand it. "It's a very clever, you know, basic exploitation of the lack of economic understanding of the American voter," he tells the Honors Colloquium 2012 at the University of Rhode Island. There appears to be a bottomless well of Gruber's greatest hits. In yet another, from a speech at the University of Pennsylvania in 2013, he explains that the very function of the law -- doing what it was designed to do -- was totally unpalatable to voters (that is, if only we'd turned away from our Cheetos bags and NASCAR races long enough to catch it). "If you had a law which said healthy people are going to pay in -- if you made it explicit that healthy people pay in and sick people get money, it would not have passed." To hammer the point home, he admits that the sales pitch was one big cover-up operation: "Lack of transparency is a huge advantage. And basically, you know, call it the stupidity of the American voter or whatever. But basically that was really, really critical to getting the thing to pass."


Q: what happened in 2013 ?

A: a speech||a speech

Q: where ?

A: University of Pennsylvania||University of Pennsylvania

Q: what was unacceptable ?

A: he very function of the law||he very function of the law

Q: doing what ?

A: it was designed to do||it was designed to do

Q: who is now in full swing ?

A: Gruber-gate||Gruber-gate

Q: did he release 20 videos ?

A: no, With a fourth video||With a fourth video

Q: what video was this ?

A: fourth||fourth

Q: who had rekarks caught ?

A: Jonathan Gruber,||Jonathan Gruber,

Q: what did he srtat ?

A: Affordable Care Ac||Affordable Care Ac

Q: the american public is who ?

A: you and me||you and me

Q: what year was all this in ?

A: 2010||2010

Q: Obama group relied on what ?

A: electorate||electorate

Q: did it fail ?

A: no, successfully||successfully

Q: its clever" who did he tell that to ?

A: Honors Colloquium||Honors Colloquium

Q: in 2013 ?

A: 2012||2012

Q: what appears to be a bottomless well ?

A: Gruber's greatest hits.||Gruber's greatest hits.

Q: what did he say the sales pitch was ?

A: one big cover-up||one big cover-up

Q: Lack of transparency is what ?

A: huge advantage||huge advantage

Q: only we'd turned away from what ?

A: Cheetos bags||Cheetos bags

Q: and what else ?

A: NASCAR races||NASCAR races


Summary: (CNN) -- With a fourth video released, Gruber-gate is now in full swing.The latest caught-on-tape remarks from economist Jonathan Gruber, one of the architects of the Affordable Care Act, has him asserting back in 2010 that the "American public" -- that's you and me -- "doesn't actually care that much about the uninsured."In another video released earlier, he said that to pass new health care legislation, the Obama administration successfully relied on an electorate -- again, you and me -- that didn't really understand it."It's a very clever, you know, basic exploitation of the lack of economic understanding of the American voter," he tells the Honors Colloquium 2012 at the University of Rhode Island.There appears to be a bottomless well of Gruber's greatest hits.In yet another, from a speech at the University of Pennsylvania in 2013, he explains that the very function of the law -- doing what it was designed to do -- was totally unpalatable to voters (that is, if only we'd turned away from our Cheetos bags and NASCAR races long enough to catch it).To hammer the point home, he admits that the sales pitch was one big cover-up operation: "Lack of transparency is a huge advantage.And basically, you know, call it the stupidity of the American voter or whatever.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER IV. Lady Wallinger and Edith were together in the morning room of Hellingsley, the morrow after the arrival of Oswald. Edith was arranging flowers in a vase, while her aunt was embroidering a Spanish peasant in correct costume. The daughter of Millbank looked as bright and fragrant as the fair creations that surrounded her. Beautiful to watch her as she arranged their forms and composed their groups; to mark her eye glance with gratification at some happy combination of colour, or to listen to her delight as they wafted to her in gratitude their perfume. Oswald and Sir Joseph were surveying the stables; Mr. Millbank, who had been daily expected for the last week from the factories, had not yet arrived. 'I must say he gained my heart from the first,' said Lady Wallinger. 'I wish the gardener would send us more roses,' said Edith. 'He is so very superior to any young man I ever met,' continued Lady Wallinger. 'I think we must have this vase entirely of roses; don't you think so, aunt?' inquired her niece. 'I am fond of roses,' said Lady Wallinger. 'What beautiful bouquets Mr. Coningsby gave us at Paris, Edith!' 'Beautiful!' 'I must say, I was very happy when I met Mr. Coningsby again at Cambridge,' said Lady Wallinger. 'It gave me much greater pleasure than seeing any of the colleges.' 'How delighted Oswald seems at having Mr. Coningsby for a companion again!' said Edith. 'And very naturally,' said Lady Wallinger. 'Oswald ought to deem himself fortunate in having such a friend. I am sure the kindness of Mr. Coningsby when we met him at Cambridge is what I never shall forget. But he always was my favourite from the first time I saw him at Paris. Do you know, Edith, I liked him best of all your admirers.'


Q: Was someone in the morning room alone?

A: no, Lady Wallinger and Edith were together in the morning room||Lady Wallinger and Edith were together in the morning room

Q: Who was there?

A: Lady Wallinger and Edith||Lady Wallinger and Edith were together in the morning room

Q: When?

A: the morrow after the arrival of Oswald||the morrow after the arrival of Oswald

Q: What was Edith doing?

A: arranging flowers||Edith was arranging flowers

Q: And the other woman?

A: embroidering||her aunt was embroidering a Spanish peasant

Q: What was she embroidering?

A: a Spanish peasant in correct costume||embroidering a Spanish peasant in correct costume

Q: Where was Oswald?

A: the stables||Oswald and Sir Joseph were surveying the stables

Q: Was he alone?

A: no, Oswald and Sir Joseph were surveying the stables||Oswald and Sir Joseph were surveying the stables

Q: Who was with him?

A: Sir Joseph||Oswald and Sir Joseph

Q: What were the two doing?

A: surveying the stables||Oswald and Sir Joseph were surveying the stables

A: Mr. Millbank||Mr. Millbank, who had been daily expected for the last week from the factories, had not yet arrived

A: the factories||Mr. Millbank, who had been daily expected for the last week from the factories

A: no, He is so very superior||He is so very superior

A: no, 'I think we must have this vase entirely of roses||'I think we must have this vase entirely of roses

A: Paris||What beautiful bouquets Mr. Coningsby gave us at Paris, Edith!'

Q: Who gave them?

Summary: Lady Wallinger and Edith were together in the morning room of Hellingsley, the morrow after the arrival of Oswald.Edith was arranging flowers in a vase, while her aunt was embroidering a Spanish peasant in correct costume.Oswald and Sir Joseph were surveying the stables; Mr. Millbank, who had been daily expected for the last week from the factories, had not yet arrived.'I wish the gardener would send us more roses,' said Edith.'He is so very superior to any young man I ever met,' continued Lady Wallinger.'I think we must have this vase entirely of roses; don't you think so, aunt?''What beautiful bouquets Mr. Coningsby gave us at Paris, Edith!''I must say, I was very happy when I met Mr. Coningsby again at Cambridge,' said Lady Wallinger.'How delighted Oswald seems at having Mr. Coningsby for a companion again!'

source: race

PITTSBURGH - For most people, snakes seem unpleasant or even threatening. But Howie Choset sees in their delicate movements a way to save lives. The 37-year-old Carnegie Mellon University professor has spent years developing snake-like robots he hopes will eventually slide through fallen buildings in search of victims trapped after natural disasters or other emergencies. Dan Kara is president of Robotics Trends, a Northboro, Mass.-based company that publishes an online industry magazine and runs robotics trade shows. He said there are other snake-like robots being developed, mainly at universities, but didn't know of one that could climb pipes. The Carnegie Mellon machines are designed to carry cameras and electronic sensors and can be controlled with a joystick . They move smoothly with the help of small electric motors, or servos, commonly used by hobbyists in model airplanes. Built from lightweight materials, the robots are about the size of a human arm or smaller. They can sense which way is up, but are only as good as their human operators, Choset added. Sam Stover, a search term manager with the Federal Emergency Management Agency based in Indiana, said snake-type robots would offer greater mobility than equipment currently available, such as cameras attached to extendable roles. "It just allows us to do something we've not been able to do before," Stover said, "We needed them yesterday." He said snifter dogs are still the best search tool for rescue workers, but that they can only be used effectively when workers have access to damaged building. Stover, among the rescue workers who handled the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, said snake robots would have helped rescuers search flooded houses in that disaster. Choset said the robots may not be ready for use for another five to ten years, depending on funding.


Q: Who uses snakes to save lives?

A: Howie Choset||But Howie Choset sees in their delicate movements a way to save lives.

Q: How old is he?

A: 37||The 37-year-old Carnegie Mellon University professor has spent years developing snake-like robots he hopes will eventually slide throu

Q: Does he teach?

A: Yes||The 37-year-old Carnegie Mellon University professor has spent years developing snake-like robots he hopes will eventually slide through fallen buildings in search of victims trapped after natural disasters or other emergencies.

Q: Where?

A: Carnegie Mellon||The 37-year-old Carnegie Mellon University professor

Q: What does he make?

A: robots||The 37-year-old Carnegie Mellon University professor has spent years developing snake-like robots he hopes will eventually slide through fallen buildings in search of victims trapped after natural disasters or other emergencies.

Q: Why?

A: To help victims||g snake-like robots he hopes will eventually slide through fallen buildings in search of victims trapped after natural disasters or other emergencies.

Q: What is Robotics Trends?/

A: a company||Dan Kara is president of Robotics Trends, a Northboro, Mass.-based company th

Q: What does it do?

A: publishes an online industry magazine||publishes an online industry magazine

A: Massachusetts||Dan Kara is president of Robotics Trends, a Northboro, Mass.-based company that publishes an online industry magazine and runs robotics trade shows.

A: Yes||Dan Kara is president of Robotics Trends, a Northboro, Mass.-based company that publishes an online industry magazine and runs robotics trade shows.

Summary: But Howie Choset sees in their delicate movements a way to save lives.The 37-year-old Carnegie Mellon University professor has spent years developing snake-like robots he hopes will eventually slide through fallen buildings in search of victims trapped after natural disasters or other emergencies.Dan Kara is president of Robotics Trends, a Northboro, Mass.-based company that publishes an online industry magazine and runs robotics trade shows.The Carnegie Mellon machines are designed to carry cameras and electronic sensors and can be controlled with a joystick .They move smoothly with the help of small electric motors, or servos, commonly used by hobbyists in model airplanes.Built from lightweight materials, the robots are about the size of a human arm or smaller.They can sense which way is up, but are only as good as their human operators, Choset added.

source: mctest

There once was a boy named John who was a good superhero. He thought he was a superhero, at least. His mommy made him eat his cereal with yoghurt every morning so he could stay strong. Today he had to go to school and he wasn't very happy about that. After breakfast he walked to the bus stop. There he found his neighbor Ashley, who was also an evil superhero. John thought she was an evil superhero at least. When John got to the bus stop, Ashley made a silly face at him. Then she dared him to lick a worm she found on the sidewalk. John had super powers, so he said yes to the dare. He picked up the worm. It was slimy and gross. It wiggled around between his fingers. John closed his eyes and licked it. Ashley laughed so hard, she fell to the ground. But John felt like a real superhero who had won the day for good kids everywhere. First thing tomorrow, John would start wearing a cape to school. He hoped his mommy would let him wear it. The bus came and Ashley was still sitting on the ground laughing. John had a great, superhero kind of thought. He put the worm in her hair. Now Ashley was screaming! John the superhero got in trouble for that.


Q: What was the child's name?

A: John||John

Q: WHat was he?

A: a good superhero||a good superhero

Q: WHat did he eat for breakfast?

A: cereal with yoghurt||cereal with yoghurt

Q: Why was he unhappy?

A: he had to go to school||he had to go to school

Q: Who did he see at the bus stop?

A: his neighbor Ashley||his neighbor Ashley

Q: WHat did she do first?

A: made a silly face at him||made a silly face at him

Q: And then?

A: she dared him to lick a worm she found on the sidewalk||she dared him to lick a worm she found on the sidewalk

Q: Did he do it?

A: yes||licked it

Q: Why?

A: because he had super powers||John had super powers, so he said yes to the dare

Q: What did he decide to do on the next day?

A: wear a cape||start wearing a cape

Q: Whose permission did he need?

A: his mommy||his mommy

Q: WHat did John do to Ashley?

A: put the worm in her hair||He put the worm in her hair

Q: WHat did she do then?

A: scream||Ashley was screaming

Q: How often did he have breakfast?

A: every morning||every morning


Summary: There once was a boy named John who was a good superhero.His mommy made him eat his cereal with yoghurt every morning so he could stay strong.Today he had to go to school and he wasn't very happy about that.There he found his neighbor Ashley, who was also an evil superhero.When John got to the bus stop, Ashley made a silly face at him.Then she dared him to lick a worm she found on the sidewalk.John had super powers, so he said yes to the dare.Ashley laughed so hard, she fell to the ground.First thing tomorrow, John would start wearing a cape to school.He hoped his mommy would let him wear it.He put the worm in her hair.John the superhero got in trouble for that.
