source: race

Tom goes everywhere with Catherine Green, a 54-year-old secretary. He moves around her office at work and goes shopping with her. "Most people don't seem to mind Tom," says Catherine, who thinks he is wonderful. "He's my fourth child," she says. She may think of him and treat him that way as her son. He moves around buying his food, paying his health bills and his taxes, but in fact Tom is a dog. Catherine and Tom live in Sweden, a country where everyone is expected to lead an orderly life according to rules laid down by the government, which also provides a high level of care for its people. This level of care costs money. People in Sweden pay taxes on everything, so aren't surprised to find that owning a dog means more taxes. Some people are paying as much as 500 Swedish kronor in taxes a year for the right to keep their dog, which is spent by the government on dog hospitals and sometimes medical treatment for a dog that falls ill. However, most such treatment is expensive, so owners often decide to offer health and even life _ for their dog. In Sweden dog owners must pay for any damage their dog does. A Swedish Kennel Club official explains what this means: if your dog runs out on the road and gets hit by a passing car, you, as the owner, have to pay for any damage done to the car, even if your dog has been killed in the accident.


Q: How old is Catherine?

A: 54|| 54

Q: where does she live?

A: Sweden||Sweden

Q: Who is Tom?

A: a dog||a dog

Q: Who provides care for its people?

A: the government||the government

Q: is it expensive?

A: Yes||This level of care costs money.

Q: How do they afford it?

A: owners offer health and even life _ for their dog.||owners often decide to offer health and even life _ for their dog.

Q: Are there taxes on most things in Sweden?

A: Yes||People in Sweden pay taxes on everything,

Q: even dogs?

A: Yes||owning a dog means more taxes.

Q: how much?

A: 500 Swedish kronor||500 Swedish kronor

Q: what is that money used for?

A: dog hospitals and sometimes medical treatment||dog hospitals and sometimes medical treatment

Q: What happens if a dog is hit by a car?

A: the owner, has to pay for any damage done to the car,||the owner, have to pay for any damage done to the car,

Q: but what if the dog is killed?

A: even if your dog has been killed in the accident.||even if your dog has been killed in the accident.

Q: What does Catherine do for work?

A: secretary||secretary

Q: Does Tom bother most people?

A: No, Most people don't seem to mind Tom||Most people don't seem to mind Tom

Q: What does she consider Tom as?

A: fourth child||fourth child

Q: is treatment for a dog expensive?

A: Yes||most such treatment is expensive

Q: Does Tom buy his own food?

A: No, He moves around buying his food, paying his health bills and his taxes||He moves around buying his food, paying his health bills and his taxes

Q: HOw many children does she have besides tom?

A: Three||He's my fourth child,

Q: Does he go to the office with her?

A: Yes||He moves around her office at work

Q: how about shopping?

A: Yes||and goes shopping with her.


Summary: Tom goes everywhere with Catherine Green, a 54-year-old secretary.He moves around her office at work and goes shopping with her."Most people don't seem to mind Tom," says Catherine, who thinks he is wonderful."He's my fourth child," she says.He moves around buying his food, paying his health bills and his taxes, but in fact Tom is a dog.Catherine and Tom live in Sweden, a country where everyone is expected to lead an orderly life according to rules laid down by the government, which also provides a high level of care for its people.This level of care costs money.People in Sweden pay taxes on everything, so aren't surprised to find that owning a dog means more taxes.Some people are paying as much as 500 Swedish kronor in taxes a year for the right to keep their dog, which is spent by the government on dog hospitals and sometimes medical treatment for a dog that falls ill.However, most such treatment is expensive, so owners often decide to offer health and even life _ for their dog.A Swedish Kennel Club official explains what this means: if your dog runs out on the road and gets hit by a passing car, you, as the owner, have to pay for any damage done to the car, even if your dog has been killed in the accident.

source: mctest

A day at the beach. When Sam woke in the morning, he was super excited! Today was the day! It was Sunday, the day that Sam's mom and dad had promised to take Sam to the beach. Sam's grandma had given a pail and shovel to Sam to use in the sand. At breakfast Sam was so excited he was wiggling in his seat! Mom told Sam that they would leave when the big hand on the clock was pointing to the 10, and the little had was pointing to the 12. Mom asked Sam if he would like to help make sandwiches for the trip, and Sam said that he wanted to help. Dad said, "let's make a game of it, we need to make a sandwich for each of us. There are three of us, so we need three sandwiches. Let's count as we make the sandwiches!" Sam counted as mom made the sandwiches, one for dad, one for mom and one for Sam. Then mom started to make another sandwich! "Mom!" said Sam, "we have three sandwiches and that makes one sandwich for each of us." Sam's mom laughed, "You're right Sam!" Sam's mom said she was being silly.


Q: Why were they making sandwiches?

A: for the trip||Mom asked Sam if he would like to help make sandwiches for the trip

Q: How many did they make?

A: Three||There are three of us, so we need three sandwiches.

Q: Why so many?

A: There were three people||There are three of us

Q: Where are they going?

A: beach||Sam's mom and dad had promised to take Sam to the beach

Q: Who all is going along?

A: Sam, mom, dad||the day that Sam's mom and dad had promised to take Sam to the beach

Q: Is it the weekend?

A: yes||It was Sunday

Q: What day is it?

A: Sunday||It was Sunday

Q: Why is he struggling to sit still?

A: he was excited||Sam was so excited he was wiggling in his seat

Q: What time will the leave?

A: 12:00||they would leave when the big hand on the clock was pointing to the 10, and the little had was pointing to the 12.

Q: What was given to Sam?

A: a pail and shovel||Sam's grandma had given a pail and shovel to Sam to use in the sand.

Q: what for?

A: to use in the sand||to Sam to use in the sand.

Q: Who gave them to him?

A: his grandma||Sam's grandma had given a pail and shovel to Sam to use in the sand.

Q: Is she going?

A: no, we need to make a sandwich for each of us. There are three of us,||we need to make a sandwich for each of us. There are three of us,

Q: Who told Sam they would go?

A: his mom and dad||the day that Sam's mom and dad had promised to take Sam to the beach.

Q: How will they know it's time to leave?

A: the clock||when the big hand on the clock was pointing to the 10, and the little had was pointing to the 12.

Q: how will the clock tell them?

A: big hand on 10, little hand on 12||Mom told Sam that they would leave when the big hand on the clock was pointing to the 10, and the little had was pointing to the 12.

Q: Who counted the sandwiches?

A: Sam||Sam counted as mom made the sandwiches, one for dad, one for mom and one for Sam

Q: why did he stop his mom?

A: there was one sandwich each||we have three sandwiches and that makes one sandwich for each of us

Q: why did she laugh?

A: she was being silly.||Sam's mom said she was being silly.

Q: What did dad make into a game?

A: counting the sandwiches||Dad said, "let's make a game of it, we need to make a sandwich for each of us.

source: cnn

ATLANTA, Georgia (CNN) -- In 1989, the warnings were dire. The Spike Lee film "Do the Right Thing," critics and columnists said, would provoke violence and disrupt race relations. Spike Lee: "I wanted to do a film that would try to show what was happening at the time." "This movie is dynamite under every seat," wrote Newsweek's Jack Kroll. Other commentators believed the film would harm the candidacy of David Dinkins, an African-American who was running for mayor of New York. It might even spark riots at movie theaters, they thought. Instead, what the film provoked was ... talk. There were no riots. Dinkins was elected. "Do the Right Thing" had a successful run at the box office -- if not as successful as Lee and his supporters hoped -- and was nominated for two Academy Awards. Twenty years later, the film still maintains a hold on the imagination. In 2007, the American Film Institute ranked it as one of the 100 best American films. Roger Ebert, who has written he cried when he first saw the film at the Cannes Film Festival, still considers the film a wonder: "Spike Lee had done an almost impossible thing. He'd made a movie about race in America that empathized with all the participants," he wrote in 2001. So what is the thing about "Do the Right Thing?" Watch Spike Lee describe things in his own words » Part of its staying power is in its boldness, both in look and action. Lee's first two films, "She's Gotta Have It" (1986) and "School Daze" (1988), had marked him as a rising young filmmaker. But it was "Do the Right Thing," made when Lee was just 32, that showcased his confidence, from the deliberately striking color scheme (bright reds and oranges that make a hot day seem even hotter) to its heightened -- sometimes stagy -- atmosphere, to its grim, documentary-style riot climax.


Q: Who created Do the Right Thing?

A: Spike Lee||The Spike Lee film "Do the Right Thing

Q: When?

A: 1989|| In 1989

Q: Why were newspaper writers concerned?

A: they said it would provoke violence and disrupt race relations||critics and columnists said, would provoke violence and disrupt race relations

Q: Were they right?

A: no, Instead, what the film provoked was ... talk||Instead, what the film provoked was ... talk

Q: Was the movie successful?

A: yes||Do the Right Thing" had a successful run at the box office

Q: Was it nominated for any awards?

A: yes||and was nominated for two Academy Awards.

Q: Which one?

A: two Academy Awards.||and was nominated for two Academy Awards.

Q: Who called the film a wonder?

A: Roger Ebert||Roger Ebert, who has written he cried when he first saw the film at the Cannes Film Festival, still considers the film a wonder

Q: When did he see it first?

A: at the Cannes Film Festival||he first saw the film at the Cannes Film Festival,

Q: What over movies did Lee make?

A: "She's Gotta Have It" and "School Daze"||Lee's first two films, "She's Gotta Have It" (1986) and "School Daze" (1988),

Q: How old was he when he made Do the Right Thing?

A: 32||made when Lee was just 32

Q: Who was campaigning for mayor?

A: David Dinkins||David Dinkins, an African-American who was running for mayor of New York

Q: Of what city?

A: New York||mayor of New York

Q: What group ranked it as one of the best?

A: the American Film Institute||the American Film Institute ranked it as one of the 100 best

Q: When?

A: In 2007||In 2007

Q: Did Ebert laugh when he saw it?

A: no, who has written he cried when he first saw the film||who has written he cried when he first saw the film


Summary: ATLANTA, Georgia (CNN) -- In 1989, the warnings were dire.The Spike Lee film "Do the Right Thing," critics and columnists said, would provoke violence and disrupt race relations.Other commentators believed the film would harm the candidacy of David Dinkins, an African-American who was running for mayor of New York.Instead, what the film provoked was ... talk."Do the Right Thing" had a successful run at the box office -- if not as successful as Lee and his supporters hoped -- and was nominated for two Academy Awards.In 2007, the American Film Institute ranked it as one of the 100 best American films.Roger Ebert, who has written he cried when he first saw the film at the Cannes Film Festival, still considers the film a wonder: "Spike Lee had done an almost impossible thing.Lee's first two films, "She's Gotta Have It" (1986) and "School Daze" (1988), had marked him as a rising young filmmaker.But it was "Do the Right Thing," made when Lee was just 32, that showcased his confidence, from the deliberately striking color scheme (bright reds and oranges that make a hot day seem even hotter) to its heightened -- sometimes stagy -- atmosphere, to its grim, documentary-style riot climax.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXV. THE VELVET COACH No, my good Lord, Diana-- ALL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL A late autumn journey from the west coast to Paris was a more serious undertaking in the sixteenth century than the good seaman Master Hobbs was aware of, or he would have used stronger dissuasive measures against such an undertaking by the two youths, when the elder was in so frail a state of health; but there had been a certain deceptive strength and vigour about young Ribaumont while under strong excitement and determination, and the whole party fancied him far fitter to meet the hardships than was really the case. Philip Thistlewood always recollected that journey as the most distressing period of his life. They were out of the ordinary highways, and therefore found the hiring of horses often extremely difficult. They had intended to purchase, but found no animals that, as Philip said, they would have accepted as a gift, though at every wretched inn where they had to wait while the country was scoured for the miserable jades, their proposed requirements fell lower and lower. Dens of smoke, dirt, and boorishness were the great proportion of those inns, where they were compelled to take refuge by the breaking down of one or other of the beasts, or by stress of weather. Snow, rain, thaw and frost alternated, each variety rendering the roads impassable; and at the best, the beasts could seldom be urged beyond a walk, fetlock-deep in mire or water. Worse than all, Berenger, far from recovered, and under the heavy oppression of a heartrending grief, could hardly fail to lose the ground that he had gained under the influence of hope. The cold seemed to fix itself on the wound on his cheek, terrible pain and swelling set in, depriving him entirely of sleep, permitting him to take no nourishment but fragments of soft crumbs soaked in wine or broth--when the inns afforded any such fare--and rendering speech excessively painful, and at last unintelligible.


Q: What time of year was it?

A: autumn||late autumn journey

Q: who was described as having a deceptive strenght and vigor?

A: Ribaumont|| strength and vigour about young Ribaumont

Q: What was it that was diffuclt for them to hire?

A: horses|| found the hiring of horses often extremely difficult

Q: Where was it they were traveling from?

A: the west coast||journey from the west coast

Q: to where?

A: to Paris|| from the west coast to Paris

Q: Was was rendering the roads they were traveling impassable?

A: Snow, rain, thaw and frost|| Snow, rain, thaw and frost alternated

Q: Why were they have troubles hiring horses?

A: They were out of the ordinary highways||They were out of the ordinary highways, and therefore found the hiring of horses often extremely difficult

Q: How did they decribe a great proportion of the inns they were staying at?

A: Dens of smoke, dirt, and boorishness were the great proportion||Dens of smoke, dirt, and boorishness were the great proportion

Q: And why is it that they were compelled to stay in those inn?

A: breaking down of the beasts||breaking down of one or other of the beasts, or by stress of weather.

Q: Who was it that was far from recovered, had a wound on his cheek, and was deprived of sleep?

A: Berenger||Worse than all, Berenger, far from recovered,

Q: what was the only thing he was able to eat?

A: soft crumbs||nourishment but fragments of soft crumbs

Q: how was his speech?

A: unintelligible.||endering speech excessively painful, and at last unintelligible.

Q: Who recollected the Jurney from the west coast to Paris was the most distressing period of their life?

A: Philip Thistlewood||Philip Thistlewood always recollected that journey as the most distressing


Summary: THE VELVET COACH No, my good Lord, Diana-- ALL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL A late autumn journey from the west coast to Paris was a more serious undertaking in the sixteenth century than the good seaman Master Hobbs was aware of, or he would have used stronger dissuasive measures against such an undertaking by the two youths, when the elder was in so frail a state of health; but there had been a certain deceptive strength and vigour about young Ribaumont while under strong excitement and determination, and the whole party fancied him far fitter to meet the hardships than was really the case.Philip Thistlewood always recollected that journey as the most distressing period of his life.They were out of the ordinary highways, and therefore found the hiring of horses often extremely difficult.Dens of smoke, dirt, and boorishness were the great proportion of those inns, where they were compelled to take refuge by the breaking down of one or other of the beasts, or by stress of weather.Snow, rain, thaw and frost alternated, each variety rendering the roads impassable; and at the best, the beasts could seldom be urged beyond a walk, fetlock-deep in mire or water.Worse than all, Berenger, far from recovered, and under the heavy oppression of a heartrending grief, could hardly fail to lose the ground that he had gained under the influence of hope.The cold seemed to fix itself on the wound on his cheek, terrible pain and swelling set in, depriving him entirely of sleep, permitting him to take no nourishment but fragments of soft crumbs soaked in wine or broth--when the inns afforded any such fare--and rendering speech excessively painful, and at last unintelligible.

source: race

When William Stidger taught at Boston University, he once thought about the people he hadn't thanked in his life. They taught him, encouraged him or cared a lot about him. One was a teacher. She once taught William geography, and William loved geography all his life. So he wrote a letter of thanks to her. He got the teacher's letter later. It began, "My dear Willie." He was very happy. Now over 50, he didn't think someone would call him "Willie". Here is that letter. My dear Willie, I can't tell you how much your letter meant to me. I am in my eighties, living alone in a small room and cooking my own meals. You will be interested to know that I taught school for 50 years and yours is the first letter of appreciation I ever got. It came on a cold morning and it made me feel very warm. ... William cried when he read the letter. She was one of the people that William hadn't thanked in his past. She helped him to believe in himself. He would never forget her. There are some people we should always remember, because they helped to shape our life. William Stidger found a way to show his appreciation--he wrote them letters. Who are some of the people that you need to say thank you to in your past? It may not be too late to say "Thanks".


Q: who was someone in his life that William wanted otothank.

A: a teacher||One was a teacher

Q: what was her name?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: what subject had she taught him?

A: geography||She once taught William geography

Q: did he enjoy the subject?

A: yes||and William loved geography

Q: how did he decide to express his gratitude?

A: he wrote a letter||So he wrote a letter of thanks to her

Q: had she received such a note before?

A: no, yours is the first letter of appreciation I ever got||yours is the first letter of appreciation I ever got

Q: did she write back?

A: yes||He got the teacher's letter later

Q: how did she address him?

A: Willie||It began, "My dear Willie

Q: did anyone call him that these days?

A: no, he didn't think someone would call him "Willie|| he didn't think someone would call him "Willie

Q: how long was her teaching career?

A: 50 years||I taught school for 50 years

Q: how did William react to her message?

A: he cried||William cried when he read the letter

Q: how old was she when he wrote to her?

A: her eighties||I am in my eighties

Q: how did the note make her feel?

A: it meant a lot to her||I can't tell you how much your letter meant to me


Summary: When William Stidger taught at Boston University, he once thought about the people he hadn't thanked in his life.One was a teacher.She once taught William geography, and William loved geography all his life.So he wrote a letter of thanks to her.He got the teacher's letter later.It began, "My dear Willie."Now over 50, he didn't think someone would call him "Willie".My dear Willie, I can't tell you how much your letter meant to me.I am in my eighties, living alone in a small room and cooking my own meals.You will be interested to know that I taught school for 50 years and yours is the first letter of appreciation I ever got.... William cried when he read the letter.

source: wikipedia

Louisiana is a state located in the Southern United States. Louisiana is the 31st most extensive and the 25th most populous of the 50 United States. Its capital is Baton Rouge and largest city is New Orleans. Louisiana is the only state in the U.S. with political subdivisions termed parishes, which are the local government's equivalent to counties. The largest parish by population is East Baton Rouge Parish, and the largest by total area is Plaquemines. Louisiana is bordered by Arkansas to the north, Mississippi to the east, Texas to the west, and the Gulf of Mexico to the south. Much of the state's lands were formed from sediment washed down the Mississippi River, leaving enormous deltas and vast areas of coastal marsh and swamp. These contain a rich southern biota; typical examples include birds such as ibis and egrets. There are also many species of tree frogs, and fish such as sturgeon and paddlefish. In more elevated areas, fire is a natural process in the landscape, and has produced extensive areas of longleaf pine forest and wet savannas. These support an exceptionally large number of plant species, including many species of orchids and carnivorous plants. Louisiana has more Native American tribes than any other southern state, including four that are federally recognized, ten that are state recognized, and four that have not yet received recognition.


Q: Which southern state has the most tribes?

A: Louisiana||Louisiana has more Native American tribes than any other southern state

Q: How many in total?

A: 18||four that are federally recognized, ten that are state recognized, and four

Q: Are there any not recognized?

A: yes||four that have not yet received recognition

Q: How many?

A: four||four

Q: How many do the feds recognize?

A: four||four that are federally recognized

Q: What about the state?

A: 10||ten that are state recognized

Q: Where is LA located?

A: in the Southern United States||Louisiana is a state located in the Southern United States

Q: How does it rank as far as people?

A: 25th|| 25th most populous of the 50 United States

Q: And in size?

A: 31st||Louisiana is the 31st most extensive

Q: What are the counties known as?

A: parishes||termed parishes, which are the local government's equivalent to counties

Q: Do other states have these?

A: no, Louisiana is the only state in the U.S. with political subdivisions termed parishes||Louisiana is the only state in the U.S. with political subdivisions termed parishes

Q: What is the capitol?

A: Baton Rouge||Its capital is Baton Rouge

Q: And the biggest city?

A: New Orleans||largest city is New Orleans

Q: What formed the land?

A: from sediment washed down the Mississippi River||Much of the state's lands were formed from sediment washed down the Mississippi River

Q: Are there many plants?

A: yes||These support an exceptionally large number of plant species

Q: What body of water is to the south?

A: the Gulf of Mexico||the Gulf of Mexico to the south

Q: Are any states neighbors?

A: yes||Louisiana is bordered by Arkansas to the north, Mississippi to the east, Texas to the west

Q: Which ones?

A: Arkansas to the north, Mississippi to the east, Texas to the west||Arkansas to the north, Mississippi to the east, Texas to the west

Q: What kind of fish?

A: sturgeon and paddlefish||fish such as sturgeon and paddlefish

Q: And birds?

A: ibis and egrets||birds such as ibis and egrets


Summary: Louisiana is a state located in the Southern United States.Louisiana is the 31st most extensive and the 25th most populous of the 50 United States.Its capital is Baton Rouge and largest city is New Orleans.Louisiana is the only state in the U.S. with political subdivisions termed parishes, which are the local government's equivalent to counties.Louisiana is bordered by Arkansas to the north, Mississippi to the east, Texas to the west, and the Gulf of Mexico to the south.Much of the state's lands were formed from sediment washed down the Mississippi River, leaving enormous deltas and vast areas of coastal marsh and swamp.These contain a rich southern biota; typical examples include birds such as ibis and egrets.There are also many species of tree frogs, and fish such as sturgeon and paddlefish.These support an exceptionally large number of plant species, including many species of orchids and carnivorous plants.Louisiana has more Native American tribes than any other southern state, including four that are federally recognized, ten that are state recognized, and four that have not yet received recognition.

source: mctest

Shelly is in second grade. She is a new student at her school. Shelly's family has lived in many different places. Shelly was born in Florida. Her family moved to Tennessee when she was two years old. When she was four years old, they moved to Texas. They moved from there to Arizona, where they now live. Shelly is upset because she does not have any friends at her new school. She misses her old school. She had lots of friends at her old school. She really misses her best friend, Julie. When she gets to school on the first day, she feels very nervous. She wants to go back to her other school. She even misses Mrs. Bell, her first grade teacher. Her new teacher, Mrs. Borden, makes her stand in front of the class and say something about herself. She is so embarrassed! She is told to sit between two boys, Tim and John. When it is time for lunch, Mrs. Borden picks Shelly to lead the line. Maybe, she's not so bad after all, Shelly thinks. At lunch, she meets Mrs. Stewart. Mrs. Stewart works in the school office. She is very nice. Shelly finds a seat in the lunchroom. She smiles at the girl next to her. The girl's name is Sue. She is very nice to Shelly. She even shares a cookie with Shelly. Shelly is very happy that she has a new friend.


Q: What grade is Shelly in ?

A: second||second

Q: Was she a new student ?

A: Yes||new student

Q: Where did she move at 2 years old ?

A: Tennessee||Tennessee

Q: where do there live now ?

A: Arizona||Arizona

Q: why is she upset ?

A: she does not have any friends||she does not have any friends

Q: Who is Julie ?

A: best friend,|| best friend,

Q: Who is mrs bell ?

A: Her new teacher||er new teacher

Q: was she embarrassed ?

A: Yes||e is so

Q: who led the line ?

A: Shelly||Shelly

Q: why is shelly very happy ?

A: has a new friend.|| has a new friend.


Summary: Shelly is in second grade.She is a new student at her school.Her family moved to Tennessee when she was two years old.They moved from there to Arizona, where they now live.Shelly is upset because she does not have any friends at her new school.She really misses her best friend, Julie.Her new teacher, Mrs. Borden, makes her stand in front of the class and say something about herself.She is told to sit between two boys, Tim and John.Maybe, she's not so bad after all, Shelly thinks.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Climate is the statistics of weather over long periods of time. It is measured by assessing the patterns of variation in temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, precipitation, atmospheric particle count and other meteorological variables in a given region over long periods of time. Climate differs from weather, in that weather only describes the short-term conditions of these variables in a given region. A region's climate is generated by the climate system, which has five components: atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere. The climate of a location is affected by its latitude, terrain, and altitude, as well as nearby water bodies and their currents. Climates can be classified according to the average and the typical ranges of different variables, most commonly temperature and precipitation. The most commonly used classification scheme was the Köppen climate classification. The Thornthwaite system, in use since 1948, incorporates evapotranspiration along with temperature and precipitation information and is used in studying biological diversity and how climate change affects it. The Bergeron and Spatial Synoptic Classification systems focus on the origin of air masses that define the climate of a region. Paleoclimatology is the study of ancient climates. Since direct observations of climate are not available before the 19th century, paleoclimates are inferred from proxy variables that include non-biotic evidence such as sediments found in lake beds and ice cores, and biotic evidence such as tree rings and coral. Climate models are mathematical models of past, present and future climates. Climate change may occur over long and short timescales from a variety of factors; recent warming is discussed in global warming. Global warming results in redistributions. For example, "a 3°C change in mean annual temperature corresponds to a shift in isotherms of approximately 300–400 km in latitude (in the temperate zone) or 500 m in elevation. Therefore, species are expected to move upwards in elevation or towards the poles in latitude in response to shifting climate zones".


Q: Were direct observations of the climate around before the 19th century?

A: No.||Since direct observations of climate are not available before the 19th century,

Q: What is paleocimatology?

A: The study of ancient climates.||Paleoclimatology is the study of ancient climates.

Q: What are those climates called?

A: Paleoclimates.||paleoclimates are inferred from proxy variables

Q: What kind of variables are used to study them?

A: Proxy variables.||paleoclimates are inferred from proxy variables that include non-biotic evidence such as sediments found in lake beds and ice cores,

Q: What are two categories that the evidence falls under?

A: Non-biotic and biotic.||that include non-biotic evidence such as sediments found in lake beds and ice cores, and biotic evidence such as tree rings and coral.

Q: Which one are sediments?

A: Non-biotic.||non-biotic evidence such as sediments

Q: Where do scientists gather those?

A: In lake beds.||sediments found in lake beds

Q: Anywhere else?

A: Ice cores,||in lake beds and ice cores,

Q: Do you know of any biotic evidence?

A: Yes.||biotic evidence such as tree rings and coral.

Q: What?

A: Tree rings.||biotic evidence such as tree rings

Q: Anything else?

A: Coral.||biotic evidence such as tree rings and coral

Q: What is climate?

A: Statistics of weather over long periods of time.||Climate is the statistics of weather over long periods of time.

Q: Is it the same as weather?

A: No.||Climate differs from weather,

Q: What is the difference?

A: Weather only describes the short-term conditions.||Climate differs from weather, in that weather only describes the short-term conditions of these variables in a given region.

Q: What kind of patterns are examined to measure climate?

A: Variation in temperature.|| the patterns of variation in temperature

Q: anything else?

A: humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, precipitation.||patterns of variation in temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, precipitation,

Q: Are they studied regionally or for the whole world?

A: Regionally.|| variables in a given region

Q: What creates a region's climate?

A: The climate system.||A region's climate is generated by the climate system,

Q: How many parts does it have?

A: Five.||system, which has five components:

Q: Is one of them the atmosphere?

A: Yes.|| five components: atmosphere, hydrosphere,


Summary: Climate is the statistics of weather over long periods of time.It is measured by assessing the patterns of variation in temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind, precipitation, atmospheric particle count and other meteorological variables in a given region over long periods of time.Climate differs from weather, in that weather only describes the short-term conditions of these variables in a given region.A region's climate is generated by the climate system, which has five components: atmosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere.Paleoclimatology is the study of ancient climates.Since direct observations of climate are not available before the 19th century, paleoclimates are inferred from proxy variables that include non-biotic evidence such as sediments found in lake beds and ice cores, and biotic evidence such as tree rings and coral.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

A gene is a locus (or region) of DNA that encodes a functional RNA or protein product, and is the molecular unit of heredity.:Glossary The transmission of genes to an organism's offspring is the basis of the inheritance of phenotypic traits. Most biological traits are under the influence of polygenes (many different genes) as well as the gene–environment interactions. Some genetic traits are instantly visible, such as eye colour or number of limbs, and some are not, such as blood type, risk for specific diseases, or the thousands of basic biochemical processes that comprise life. Genes can acquire mutations in their sequence, leading to different variants, known as alleles, in the population. These alleles encode slightly different versions of a protein, which cause different phenotype traits. Colloquial usage of the term "having a gene" (e.g., "good genes," "hair colour gene") typically refers to having a different allele of the gene. Genes evolve due to natural selection or survival of the fittest of the alleles.


Q: do genes evolve?

A: Yes|| Genes evolve due to natural selection or survival of the fittest of the alleles.

Q: what are polygenes?

A: many different genes|| Most biological traits are under the influence of polygenes (many different genes)

Q: are all genetic traits visible?

A: No, Some genetic traits are instantly visible, such as eye colour or number of limbs, and some are not, ||Some genetic traits are instantly visible, such as eye colour or number of limbs, and some are not,

Q: can genes mutate?

A: Yes|| Genes can acquire mutations in their sequence

Q: what are different variants of genes called?

A: alleles||different variants, known as alleles,

Q: how many specific genetic traits are named?

A: Five||Some genetic traits are instantly visible, such as eye colour or number of limbs, and some are not, such as blood type, risk for specific diseases, or the thousands of basic biochemical processes that comprise life.

Q: what is a locus also called?

A: Region||locus (or region

Q: is eye color visible?

A: Yes|| Some genetic traits are instantly visible, such as eye colour or number of limbs,

Q: is blood type visible?

A: No, and some are not, such as blood type, risk for specific diseases, or the thousands of basic biochemical processes that comprise life. ||and some are not, such as blood type, risk for specific diseases, or the thousands of basic biochemical processes that comprise life.

Q: are genes related to DNA?

A: Yes||A gene is a locus (or region) of DNA t

Q: what is a gene?

A: DNA that encodes a functional RNA or protein product||A gene is a locus (or region) of DNA that encodes a functional RNA or protein product,


Summary: A gene is a locus (or region) of DNA that encodes a functional RNA or protein product, and is the molecular unit of heredity.Most biological traits are under the influence of polygenes (many different genes) as well as the gene–environment interactions.Some genetic traits are instantly visible, such as eye colour or number of limbs, and some are not, such as blood type, risk for specific diseases, or the thousands of basic biochemical processes that comprise life.Genes can acquire mutations in their sequence, leading to different variants, known as alleles, in the population.Genes evolve due to natural selection or survival of the fittest of the alleles.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XII MOLLY SIZER'S PARTY The people of Chazy County were very proud of the _Millville Tribune_, the only daily paper in that section of the state. It was really a very good newspaper, if small in size, and related the news of the day as promptly as the great New York journals did. Arthur Weldon had not been very enthusiastic about the paper at any time, although he humored the girls by attending in a good-natured way to the advertising, hiring some of the country folk to get subscriptions, and keeping the books. He was a young man of considerable education who had inherited a large fortune, safely invested, and therefore had no need, through financial necessity, to interest himself in business of any sort. He allowed the girls to print his name as editor in chief, but he did no editorial work at all, amusing himself these delightful summer days by wandering in the woods, where he collected botanical specimens, or sitting with Uncle John on the lawn, where they read together or played chess. Both the men were glad the girls were happy in their work and enthusiastic over the success of their audacious venture. Beth was developing decided talent as a writer of editorials and her articles were even more thoughtful and dignified than were those of Patsy. The two girls found plenty to occupy them at the office, while Louise did the reportorial work and flitted through Millville and down to Huntingdon each day in search of small items of local interest. She grew fond of this work, for it brought her close to the people and enabled her to study their characters and peculiarities. Her manner of approaching the simple country folk was so gracious and winning that they freely gave her any information they possessed, and chatted with her unreservedly.


Q: How many daily papers were there in town??

A: one||the only daily paper in that section of the state

Q: What was it called?

A: the Millville Tribune|| the _Millville Tribune_, the only daily paper

Q: Whose enthusiasm in the publication had gone down?

A: Arthur's||Arthur Weldon had not been very enthusiastic

Q: Was he a poor man?

A: no, He was a young man of considerable education who had inherited a large fortune|| He was a young man of considerable education who had inherited a large fortune

Q: How had he become wealthy?

A: he inherited a large fortune||who had inherited a large fortune

Q: What was his title at the paper?

A: editor in chief|| his name as editor in chief

Q: Did he have many tasks associated with it?

A: no, he did no editorial work at all||he did no editorial work at all

Q: Who actually ran it?

A: the girls||the girls were happy in their work

Q: What were their names?

A: Beth, Patsy, and Louise|| Beth was developing decided talent as a writer of editorials and her articles were even more thoughtful and dignified than were those of Patsy. The two girls found plenty to occupy them at the office, while Louise did the reportorial work

Q: Which one ventured out in the field?

A: Louise|| Louise did the reportorial work and flitted through Millville

Q: Who was a good writer?

A: Beth||Beth was developing decided talent as a writer


Summary: CHAPTER XII MOLLY SIZER'S PARTY The people of Chazy County were very proud of the _Millville Tribune_, the only daily paper in that section of the state.Arthur Weldon had not been very enthusiastic about the paper at any time, although he humored the girls by attending in a good-natured way to the advertising, hiring some of the country folk to get subscriptions, and keeping the books.He was a young man of considerable education who had inherited a large fortune, safely invested, and therefore had no need, through financial necessity, to interest himself in business of any sort.He allowed the girls to print his name as editor in chief, but he did no editorial work at all, amusing himself these delightful summer days by wandering in the woods, where he collected botanical specimens, or sitting with Uncle John on the lawn, where they read together or played chess.Both the men were glad the girls were happy in their work and enthusiastic over the success of their audacious venture.Beth was developing decided talent as a writer of editorials and her articles were even more thoughtful and dignified than were those of Patsy.The two girls found plenty to occupy them at the office, while Louise did the reportorial work and flitted through Millville and down to Huntingdon each day in search of small items of local interest.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

The Royal Victorian Order () is a dynastic order of knighthood established in 1896 by Queen Victoria. It recognises distinguished personal service to the monarch of the Commonwealth realms, members of the monarch's family, or to any viceroy or senior representative of the monarch. The present monarch, Queen Elizabeth II, is the Sovereign of the order, its motto is "Victoria", and its official day is 20 June. The order's chapel is the Savoy Chapel in London. There are no limits on the number honoured, and admission remains at the sole discretion of the monarch, with each of the order's five grades and one medal with three levels representing different levels of service. While all those honoured may use the prescribed styles of the order—the top two grades grant titles of knighthood, and all grades accord distinct post-nominal letters—the Royal Victorian Order's precedence amongst other honours differs from realm to realm and admission to some grades may be barred to citizens of those realms by government policy. Prior to the close of the 19th century, most general honours within the British Empire were bestowed by the sovereign on the advice of her British ministers, who sometimes forwarded advice from ministers of the Crown in the Dominions and colonies (appointments to the then most senior orders of chivalry—the Most Noble Order of the Garter and the Most Ancient and Most Noble Order of the Thistle—had been made on ministerial advice since the 18th century and were not restored to the personal gift of the sovereign until 1946 and 1947, respectively). Queen Victoria thus established on 21 April 1896 the Royal Victorian Order as a junior and personal order of knighthood that allowed her to bestow directly to an empire-wide community honours for personal services. The organisation was founded a year preceding Victoria's Diamond Jubilee, so as to give the Queen time to complete a list of first inductees. The order's official day was made 20 June of each year, marking the anniversary of Queen Victoria's accession to the throne.


Q: What is the name of the order being discussed?

A: The Royal Victorian Order||The Royal Victorian Order

Q: What type of order is it?

A: a dynastic order of knighthood||The Royal Victorian Order () is a dynastic order of knighthood

Q: Where is its chapel?

A: Savoy Chapel||The order's chapel is the Savoy Chapel in London.

Q: Before the 19th century, who gave honors?

A: bestowed by the sovereign on the advice of her British ministers,||Prior to the close of the 19th century, most general honours within the British Empire were bestowed by the sovereign on the advice of her British ministers,

Q: What is the official day of the order?

A: 20 June.||ts official day is 20 June.

Q: What's the date mark?

A: Queen Victoria's accession to the throne.||he order's official day was made 20 June of each year, marking the anniversary of Queen Victoria's accession to the throne.

Q: When did she create the order?

A: 1896||The Royal Victorian Order () is a dynastic order of knighthood established in 1896

Q: On what day?

A: 21 April 1896|| 21 April 1896

Q: What's its motto?

A: "Victoria"||its motto is "Victoria"

Q: What type of service does it reward?

A: distinguished personal service|| It recognises distinguished personal service

Q: How many can be rewarded?

A: unlimited||There are no limits on the number honoured


Summary: The Royal Victorian Order () is a dynastic order of knighthood established in 1896 by Queen Victoria.It recognises distinguished personal service to the monarch of the Commonwealth realms, members of the monarch's family, or to any viceroy or senior representative of the monarch.The present monarch, Queen Elizabeth II, is the Sovereign of the order, its motto is "Victoria", and its official day is 20 June.The order's chapel is the Savoy Chapel in London.There are no limits on the number honoured, and admission remains at the sole discretion of the monarch, with each of the order's five grades and one medal with three levels representing different levels of service.Prior to the close of the 19th century, most general honours within the British Empire were bestowed by the sovereign on the advice of her British ministers, who sometimes forwarded advice from ministers of the Crown in the Dominions and colonies (appointments to the then most senior orders of chivalry—the Most Noble Order of the Garter and the Most Ancient and Most Noble Order of the Thistle—had been made on ministerial advice since the 18th century and were not restored to the personal gift of the sovereign until 1946 and 1947, respectively).Queen Victoria thus established on 21 April 1896 the Royal Victorian Order as a junior and personal order of knighthood that allowed her to bestow directly to an empire-wide community honours for personal services.The order's official day was made 20 June of each year, marking the anniversary of Queen Victoria's accession to the throne.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER LXIV. "Questa montagna e tale, Che sempre al cominciar di sotto a grave. E quanto uom piu va su e men fa male." --DANTE: _Il Purgatorio_. It was not many days after her mother's arrival that Gwendolen would consent to remain at Genoa. Her desire to get away from that gem of the sea, helped to rally her strength and courage. For what place, though it were the flowery vale of Enna, may not the inward sense turn into a circle of punishment where the flowers are no better than a crop of flame-tongues burning the soles of our feet? "I shall never like to see the Mediterranean again," said Gwendolen, to her mother, who thought that she quite understood her child's feeling--even in her tacit prohibition of any express reference to her late husband. Mrs. Davilow, indeed, though compelled formally to regard this time as one of severe calamity, was virtually enjoying her life more than she had ever done since her daughter's marriage. It seemed that her darling was brought back to her not merely with all the old affection, but with a conscious cherishing of her mother's nearness, such as we give to a possession that we have been on the brink of losing. "Are you there, mamma?" cried Gwendolen, in the middle of the night (a bed had been made for her mother in the same room with hers), very much as she would have done in her early girlhood, if she had felt frightened in lying awake.


Q: Who cries out?

A: Gwendolen||Gwendolen

Q: When?

A: in the middle of the night|| in the middle of the night

Q: For whom?

A: her mother||her mother

Q: Was there a bed for her?

A: yes||a bed had been made for her mother in the same room with hers

Q: Where?

A: in the same room with hers||in the same room with hers

Q: What language is the quote that starts this?

A: Italian||"Questa montagna e tale, Che sempre al cominciar di sotto a grave. E quanto uom piu va su e men fa male." --DANTE: _Il Purgatorio_.

Q: Is there a translation?

A: no, "Questa montagna e tale, Che sempre al cominciar di sotto a grave. E quanto uom piu va su e men fa male." --DANTE: _Il Purgatorio_. ||"Questa montagna e tale, Che sempre al cominciar di sotto a grave. E quanto uom piu va su e men fa male." --DANTE: _Il Purgatorio_.

A: the Mediterranean||the Mediterranean again

Q: What did she consent to do?

A: to remain at Genoa||to remain at Genoa

Q: How long had she done that after her mom came?

A: not many days after||not many days after

Q: What's Genoa nicknamed?

A: flowery vale of Enna||flowery vale of Enn

A: yes||lowery vale of Enna, may not the inward sense turn into a circle of punishment where the flowers are no better than a crop of flame-tongues burning the soles of our feet?

Q: Does her mom understand how Gwen feels?

A: no, who thought that she quite understood her child's feeling||who thought that she quite understood her child's feeling

Q: Is her mom enjoying her life now that Gwen's married?

A: yes||enjoying her life more than she had ever done since her daughter's marriage

Q: Was she forced to view this time as one of calamity?

A: yes||hough compelled formally to regard this time as one of severe calamity,

Q: What was one of the things that Gwens desire to get away helped her rally?

A: strength||strength

Q: And the other?

A: courage||courage

Q: Did it become punishing to remain there?

A: yes||may not the inward sense turn into a circle of punishment where the flowers are no better than a crop of flame-tongues burning the soles of our feet?


Summary: "Questa montagna e tale, Che sempre al cominciar di sotto a grave.It was not many days after her mother's arrival that Gwendolen would consent to remain at Genoa.Her desire to get away from that gem of the sea, helped to rally her strength and courage.For what place, though it were the flowery vale of Enna, may not the inward sense turn into a circle of punishment where the flowers are no better than a crop of flame-tongues burning the soles of our feet?"I shall never like to see the Mediterranean again," said Gwendolen, to her mother, who thought that she quite understood her child's feeling--even in her tacit prohibition of any express reference to her late husband.Mrs. Davilow, indeed, though compelled formally to regard this time as one of severe calamity, was virtually enjoying her life more than she had ever done since her daughter's marriage.cried Gwendolen, in the middle of the night (a bed had been made for her mother in the same room with hers), very much as she would have done in her early girlhood, if she had felt frightened in lying awake.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- SeaWorld will resume killer whale shows while the company and two federal agencies investigate the death of a whale trainer at SeaWorld Orlando, company and federal officials announced Friday. The shows, which were suspended at all SeaWorld locations after the death Wednesday at SeaWorld Orlando, will resume Saturday with new precautionary measures in place, said Jim Atchison, president of SeaWorld Parks & Entertainment. Earlier Friday, the Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Agriculture Department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service announced they were looking into the death of Dawn Brancheau, 40. Brancheau was pulled underwater when a killer whale named Tilikum grabbed her ponytail. A source at SeaWorld said that after seizing her, the whale dove deep underwater. Trainers eventually had to wrangle the animal into a smaller pool before they could retrieve her body about 40 minutes later. WESH: Watch tourist's video just before attack A former head of animal training said Friday that Brancheau left herself vulnerable to attack and that she may have broken the park's training protocol. "Dawn, if she was standing here right now, would tell you that that was her mistake in allowing that to happen," said former SeaWorld trainer Thad Lacinak, who had worked with Brancheau in the past, on ABC's "Good Morning America." Lacinak called Brancheau "one the best killer whale trainers I ever worked with." Still, he said, Brancheau should not have been lying in a slideout -- a platform covered by roughly 4 inches of water -- so close to a killer whale.


Q: Who will resume killer whale shows?

A: SeaWorld||SeaWorld will resume killer whale shows

Q: Is there going to be any new precautionary measures in place?

A: yes||with new precautionary measures in place

Q: Who called Brancheai one of the best killer whale trainers they ever worked with?

A: Thad Lacinak||Lacinak called Brancheau "one the best killer whale trainers I ever worked with."

Q: Who is the President of Seaworld parks and Entertainment?

A: Jim Atchison||Jim Atchison, president of SeaWorld Parks & Entertainment.

Q: What city was the city The seaworld in that the event took place?

A: Orlando||at SeaWorld Orlando

Q: What did Lacinak say Brancheau shouldn't of been doing?

A: Brancheau should not have been lying in a slideout||Brancheau should not have been lying in a slideout

Q: What is the name of the killer whale involved in the event?

A: Tilikum||a killer whale named Tilikum

Q: What day of the week as of this article is Seaworld reopening?

A: Saturday|| will resume Saturday

Q: What show in the past did Thad Lacinak work with Brancheau on?

A: on ABC's "Good Morning America."||had worked with Brancheau in the past, on ABC's "Good Morning America."

Q: What day were the shows suspended?

A: Wednesday||which were suspended at all SeaWorld locations after the death Wednesday


Summary: (CNN) -- SeaWorld will resume killer whale shows while the company and two federal agencies investigate the death of a whale trainer at SeaWorld Orlando, company and federal officials announced Friday.The shows, which were suspended at all SeaWorld locations after the death Wednesday at SeaWorld Orlando, will resume Saturday with new precautionary measures in place, said Jim Atchison, president of SeaWorld Parks & Entertainment.Brancheau was pulled underwater when a killer whale named Tilikum grabbed her ponytail."Dawn, if she was standing here right now, would tell you that that was her mistake in allowing that to happen," said former SeaWorld trainer Thad Lacinak, who had worked with Brancheau in the past, on ABC's "Good Morning America."Lacinak called Brancheau "one the best killer whale trainers I ever worked with."Still, he said, Brancheau should not have been lying in a slideout -- a platform covered by roughly 4 inches of water -- so close to a killer whale.

source: gutenberg

Chapter XL. Keep Your Temper. On the next day but one, Randal arranged his departure for Sydenham, so as to arrive at the hotel an hour before the time appointed for the dinner. His prospects of success, in pleading for a favorable reception of his brother's message, were so uncertain that he refrained--in fear of raising hopes which he might not be able to justify--from taking Herbert into his confidence. No one knew on what errand he was bent, when he left the house. As he took his place in the carriage, the newspaper boy appeared at the window as usual. The new number of a popular weekly journal had that day been published. Randal bought it. After reading one or two of the political articles, he arrived at the columns specially devoted to "Fashionable Intelligence." Caring nothing for that sort of news, he was turning over the pages in search of the literary and dramatic articles, when a name not unfamiliar to him caught his eye. He read the paragraph in which it appeared. "The charming widow, Mrs. Norman, is, we hear, among the distinguished guests staying at Buck's Hotel. It is whispered that the lady is to be shortly united to a retired naval officer of Arctic fame; now better known, perhaps, as one of our leading philanthropists." The allusion to Bennydeck was too plain to be mistaken. Randal looked again at the first words in the paragraph. "The charming widow!" Was it possible that this last word referred to Catherine? To suppose her capable of assuming to be a widow, and--if the child asked questions--of telling Kitty that her father was dead, was, in Randal's estimation, to wrong her cruelly. With his own suspicions steadily contradicting him, he arrived at the hotel, obstinately believing that "the charming widow" would prove to be a stranger.


Q: how many articles were read ?

A: one or two||one or two

Q: what kind ?

A: political||political

Q: where were the guest staying ?

A: Buck's Hotel||Buck's Hotel

Q: what kind of guest ?

A: distinguished||distinguished

Q: who is charming ?

A: Mrs. Norman||Mrs. Norman

Q: is she charming ?

A: yes||charming

Q: who arranged his leaving for somewhere ?

A: Randal||Randal

Q: when ?

A: On the next day||On the next day

Q: where was he going ?

A: Sydenham||Sydenham

Q: how early did he want to get there ?

A: hour before||hour before

Q: for what event ?

A: dinner||dinner

Q: what was to plain ?

A: allusion||allusion

Q: to where ?

A: Bennydeck||Bennydeck

Q: whos father died ?

A: Kitty||Kitty

Q: who would be a stranger ?

A: widow||widow

Q: did he really beleive that ?

A: yes||obstinately believing

Q: what were the 1st words in the passage ?

A: he charming widow||he charming widow

Q: who is a philanthropists

A: naval officer||naval officer

Q: of what type of fame ?

A: Arctic||Arctic

Q: the columns were devoted to what ?

A: Fashionable Intelligence||Fashionable Intelligence


Summary: On the next day but one, Randal arranged his departure for Sydenham, so as to arrive at the hotel an hour before the time appointed for the dinner.After reading one or two of the political articles, he arrived at the columns specially devoted to "Fashionable Intelligence.""The charming widow, Mrs. Norman, is, we hear, among the distinguished guests staying at Buck's Hotel.It is whispered that the lady is to be shortly united to a retired naval officer of Arctic fame; now better known, perhaps, as one of our leading philanthropists."The allusion to Bennydeck was too plain to be mistaken.Was it possible that this last word referred to Catherine?To suppose her capable of assuming to be a widow, and--if the child asked questions--of telling Kitty that her father was dead, was, in Randal's estimation, to wrong her cruelly.With his own suspicions steadily contradicting him, he arrived at the hotel, obstinately believing that "the charming widow" would prove to be a stranger.

source: race

Robots are smart. With their computer brains, they help people work in dangerous places or do difficult jobs. Some robots do regular jobs. Bobby, the robot mail carrier, brings mail to a large office building in Washington, D.C. He is one of 250 robot mail carriers in the United States. Mr. Leachim, who weights two hundred pounds and is six feet tall, has some advantages as a teacher. One is that he does not forget details. He knows each child's name, their parents' names, and what each child knows and needs to know. In addition, he knows each child's pets and hobbies. Mr. Leachim does not make mistakes. Each child goes and tells him his or her name, then dials an identification number. His computer brain puts the child's voice and number together. He identifies the child with no mistakes. Another advantage is that Mr. Leachim is flexible. If the children need more time to do their lessons they can move switches. In this way they can repeat Mr. Leachim's lesson over and over again. When the children do a good job, he tells them something interesting about their hobbies. At the end of the lesson the children switch Mr. Leachim off.


Q: how tall is Mr. Leachim?

A: Six feet.||Mr. Leachim, who weights two hundred pounds and is six feet tall,

Q: and how much does he weigh?

A: 200 pounds.||Mr. Leachim, who weights two hundred pounds

Q: does he keep track of all the details about the children?

A: Yes.||One is that he does not forget details.

Q: is he a robot?

A: Yes.||His computer brain

Q: what does he have for a brain?

A: A computer.||His computer brain

Q: are robots smart?

A: Yes.||Robots are smart.

Q: what does bobby do for work?

A: Mail carrier,||Bobby, the robot mail carrier,

Q: how many robots are in the story?

A: Two.||Bobby, the robot mail carrier, brings mail to a large office building in Washington, D.C. He is one of 250 robot mail carriers in the United States. Mr. Leachim,

Q: how many mail carrying robots are there?

A: 250.||250 robot mail carriers

Q: where does bobby live?

A: Washington, D.C.||Bobby, the robot mail carrier, brings mail to a large office building in Washington, D.C.

Q: where does he take the mail?

A: Large office building.||brings mail to a large office building i

Q: what does Mr. Leachim tell the kids when they do a good job?

A: Something interesting about their hobbies..||When the children do a good job, he tells them something interesting about their hobbies.

Q: does Mr. Leachim ever get powered down?

A: Yes.||At the end of the lesson the children switch Mr. Leachim off.

Q: when?

A: At the end of the lesson.|| At the end of the lesson the children switch Mr. Leachim off.

Q: how do robots help people for example?

A: Do difficult jobs.||they help people work in dangerous places or do difficult jobs.

Q: do they help other ways?

A: Work in dangerous places.||hey help people work in dangerous places


Summary: Robots are smart.With their computer brains, they help people work in dangerous places or do difficult jobs.Bobby, the robot mail carrier, brings mail to a large office building in Washington, D.C.He is one of 250 robot mail carriers in the United States.Mr. Leachim, who weights two hundred pounds and is six feet tall, has some advantages as a teacher.One is that he does not forget details.His computer brain puts the child's voice and number together.When the children do a good job, he tells them something interesting about their hobbies.At the end of the lesson the children switch Mr. Leachim off.

source: mctest

Douglas loves to play soccer. He plays for the Dolphins. He is very good. He was excited about the big game with the Lions. The night before the game, he went to bed late. He was watching three TV shows that night. First, was Muffins the Cat. The second show was Ernie the Talking Donkey. The third was Laughing with Herman Hamster. His Mom told him to go to bed, but Douglas didn't listen. He fell asleep on the couch. He dreamed all night. First about sheep jumping fences. Second about playing fetch the ball with Ruffles. Third about Ernie the talking Donkey kicking a soccer ball over the moon. Fourth about his favorite soccer player, Pele, head the ball in the goal. Finally, the next morning, Douglas got up late because he was so tired. His Mom called him and the alarm went off, but he did not hear. To get Douglas up, his Mom got Ruffles the dog to lick him in the face. Douglas got up but had to eat breakfast fast. Then he quickly dressed into his uniform. He was yawning. His Mom drove him to the soccer field. The game had started. Douglas had to sit out the first quarter. His team was losing one to nothing when Howard scored for the Lions. Douglas started the second quarter. He was tired and could not keep up with the rest of his team. The coach was surprised that Douglas was so slow. Usually he was fast. After the second quarter, the Dolphins were losing two to one after Howard scored again for the Lions and Toby scored a goal for the Dolphins. While the coach gave energy drinks to the team, Douglas fell asleep. The third quarter started. Douglas was snoring when the coach told him to go in. When he saw Douglas was sleeping, he sent Billy into the game. Billy scored one goal and the Dolphins had tied the game two to two. Ruffles the dog started barking and then licking Douglas in the face. Douglas got up and stretched. He was finally well rested. The coach saw Douglas and sent him into the game. Douglas remembered his dream. In the last second, he headed the ball in the goal like Pele. He won the game. The team cheered. Since that time, Douglas goes to bed on time. He always wants to be well rested. His Mom was right. He gave her a hug.


Q: DId the boy have a pet?

A: yes||Ruffles the dog

Q: What kind?

A: a dog||Ruffles the dog

Q: What was it called?

A: Ruffles||Ruffles the dog

Q: What did the mother make him do?

A: lick Douglas||lick him in the face

Q: Why?

A: To get Douglas up||To get Douglas up

Q: Did he do the same thing to wake him up another time?

A: yes|| Ruffles the dog started barking and then licking Douglas in the face

Q: Where?

A: the face||the face

Q: And where were they?

A: The game||The game

Q: What kind of game?

A: soccer||soccer

Q: Who took them there?

A: His Mom||His Mom

Q: And who won it?

A: the Dolphins|| the Dolphins

Q: Which player helped them do that?

A: Douglas||he headed the ball in the goal like Pele


Summary: To get Douglas up, his Mom got Ruffles the dog to lick him in the face.His Mom drove him to the soccer field.The game had started.Douglas had to sit out the first quarter.Billy scored one goal and the Dolphins had tied the game two to two.Ruffles the dog started barking and then licking Douglas in the face.He was finally well rested.He won the game.

source: mctest

Jessica went to sit in her rocking chair. Today was her birthday and she was turning 80. Her granddaughter Annie was coming over in the afternoon and Jessica was very excited to see her. Her daughter Melanie and Melanie's husband Josh were coming as well. Jessica had a lot to do before they got here, but she was very tired. After taking a nap for half an hour Jessica got up and walked to the drier. She moved the dry clothes into a basket. Next, she took the clothes out of the washer and put them into the drier. She pressed the button on the drier to get it started then walked back out of the room. She also needed to feed her duck. The chickens in her backyard did not need to be fed as they belonged to her neighbor. Jack the dog had been fed earlier that morning and Becky the cat always had food in her bowl. After Jessica finished feeding the duck she came inside and heard the telephone ringing. She answered the phone to hear Annie's excited voice say "Happy birthday grandma!" Annie said they would be over very soon. Jessica smiled because she loved her family more than anything. She was very excited. She sat back on her rocking chair and waited until her family arrived.


Q: Who had a birthday?

A: Jessica||Jessica went to sit in her rocking chair. Today was her birthday and she was turning 80.

Q: How old would she be?

A: 80||she was turning 80

Q: Did she plan to have any visitors?

A: yes||Her granddaughter Annie was coming over

Q: How many?

A: Three||Her daughter Melanie and Melanie's husband Josh were coming as well

Q: Who?

A: Annie||Her granddaughter Annie was coming over

Q: How is Annie related?

A: her granddaughter||Her granddaughter Annie

Q: Did Jessica do anything before guests arrived?

A: yes||Jessica had a lot to do before they got here

Q: What did she do first?

A: she took a nap||After taking a nap

Q: Where?

A: in her rocking chair||Jessica went to sit in her rocking chair

Q: And after that?

A: she walked to the drier||Jessica got up and walked to the drier

Q: Was the drier full?

A: yes||She moved the dry clothes into a basket

Q: Was the washer also full?

A: yes||she took the clothes out of the washer

Q: Did she have any animals?

A: yes||She also needed to feed her duck

Q: How many?

A: Three||Jack the dog had been fed earlier that morning and Becky the cat always had food in her bowl

Q: Did she feed the chickens?

A: no, The chickens in her backyard did not need to be fed||The chickens in her backyard did not need to be fed

Q: Why not?

A: they belonged to her neighbor||they belonged to her neighbor

Q: Which animal did she feed?

A: the duck||After Jessica finished feeding the duck

Q: Why didn't she feed the dog?

A: he had been fed earlier||Jack the dog had been fed earlier


Summary: Jessica went to sit in her rocking chair.Today was her birthday and she was turning 80.Her granddaughter Annie was coming over in the afternoon and Jessica was very excited to see her.Her daughter Melanie and Melanie's husband Josh were coming as well.Jessica had a lot to do before they got here, but she was very tired.After taking a nap for half an hour Jessica got up and walked to the drier.She moved the dry clothes into a basket.Next, she took the clothes out of the washer and put them into the drier.She also needed to feed her duck.The chickens in her backyard did not need to be fed as they belonged to her neighbor.Jack the dog had been fed earlier that morning and Becky the cat always had food in her bowl.After Jessica finished feeding the duck she came inside and heard the telephone ringing.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: mctest

Once upon a time there were four children. Each of the children had a favorite color. John's favorite color was blue. Jack's favorite color was red. Jenny's favorite color was purple and Alice's favorite color was yellow. They walked along the road one day and stopped to pick flowers for their mother. Jack picked a handful of red flowers. "Mom is going to love these!" he said. Jenny picked a handful of purple flowers. "These are perfect for mother," She thought. Alice picked two handfuls of yellow flowers. "Yellow flowers are so pretty for mom's kitchen," she said. John looked and looked, but couldn't find any blue flowers. He looked along the road, but there were no blue flowers. He looked by the stream, but there were no blue flowers. He was very sad. They walked along the road toward home to give their flowers to their mother. John walked very slowly and hung his head because he didn't have any flowers to give his mother. As they neared their home, John saw a small bunch of blue flowers growing near the fence. He was so happy he picked them all and rushed to catch up with his brother and sisters. When they got home they gave their mother all the flowers they had picked. She thanked them and put them on her kitchen table. "I have the most thoughtful children in the world," She said.


Q: How many children were there?

A: Four.||there were four children.

Q: What was John's favorite color?

A: Blue.||John's favorite color was blue.

Q: And Jack's?

A: Red.||Jack's favorite color was red.

Q: Jenny's?

A: Purple .||Jenny's favorite color was purple

Q: And Alice's?

A: Yellow.||Alice's favorite color was yellow.

Q: Where'd they walk?

A: Along the road||They walked along the road

Q: Who had trouble finding their favorite color?

A: John.||John looked and looked, but couldn't find any blue flowers.

Q: Where'd he look?

A: Along the road and by the stream.||He looked along the road, but there were no blue flowers. He looked by the stream, but there were no blue flowers.

Q: Where they all siblings?

A: Yes.||When they got home they gave their mother all the flowers they had picked.

Q: Who'd they give them to?

A: Their mother.||When they got home they gave their mother all the flowers they had picked.

Q: Where'd John find his flowers?

A: The fence near their home.||As they neared their home, John saw a small bunch of blue flowers growing near the fence.

Q: Was their Mom angry?

A: No.||She thanked them and put them on her kitchen table. "I have the most thoughtful children in the world," She said.

Q: Where'd she place them?

A: On her kitchen table.||She thanked them and put them on her kitchen table.


Summary: Once upon a time there were four children.John's favorite color was blue.Jack's favorite color was red.Jenny's favorite color was purple and Alice's favorite color was yellow.They walked along the road one day and stopped to pick flowers for their mother.John looked and looked, but couldn't find any blue flowers.He looked along the road, but there were no blue flowers.As they neared their home, John saw a small bunch of blue flowers growing near the fence.When they got home they gave their mother all the flowers they had picked.She thanked them and put them on her kitchen table.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER III. A RAFT. Forester and Marco did not take breakfast on board the steamboat, but waited until they got on shore. They had inquired of a fellow-passenger, who seemed acquainted with the country, and were told that there was a very good tavern about a quarter of a mile from the mill. When they landed upon the logs, Marco, whose curiosity seemed to be stronger than his appetite, wanted to ramble about for a little time along the shore and among the piles of boards, but Forester thought it would be best first to go and get their breakfast. "Because," said he, "we can then amuse ourselves by rambling about here, and shall be ready to return to the steamboat whenever they send for us." So they went to the tavern. Forester seemed to have little appetite for his breakfast. He complained of feeling fatigued, and yet he had nothing to fatigue him. Marco ate, and talked fast all the time; but Forester seemed silent and dejected. "Come, cousin Forester, what is the matter with you?" said Marco at last. Forester said that he felt somewhat unwell, and as there was a sofa in the room, he concluded to lie down upon it, and not go out. Marco was, at first, disposed to stay and take care of him, but Forester said that he did not need anything, and he wished Marco to go out and amuse himself. "You may go and see the mill," said he, "and the logs along the shore; only be careful not to go where there is any danger; and come and let me know when the boat is coming from the steamer to take us on board again."


Q: What did they land on

A: the logs||When they landed upon the logs, Marco, whose curiosity seemed to be stronger than his appetite, wanted to ramble about for a little time along the shore and among the piles of boards, but Forester thought it would be best first to go and get their breakfast.

Q: Who wanted to walk around

A: Marco||, Marco, whose curiosity seemed to be stronger than his appetite, wanted to ramble about for a little time along the shore

Q: Who wanted to eat

A: Forester||, but Forester thought it would be best first to go and get their breakfast.

Q: Eat what?

A: breakfast||nd among the piles of boards, but Forester thought it would be best first to go and get their breakfast.

Q: What kind of ship was it

A: A raft||RAFT

Q: Where was the tavern

A: about a quarter of a mile away||and were told that there was a very good tavern about a quarter of a mile from the mill.

Q: From what?

A: the mill||from the mill.

Q: Was it good?

A: Yes||and were told that there was a very good tavern about a quarter of a mile from the mill.

Q: Did they go there

A: Yes||o they went to the tavern.

Q: Who wanted to go there first

A: Forester||, but Forester thought it would be best first to go and get their breakfast.

Q: Who told them about the tavern

A: a fellow passenger||hey had inquired of a fellow-passenger, who seemed acquainted with the country,

Q: Did Forester eat a big breakfast

A: No, orester seemed to have little appetite for his breakfast.||orester seemed to have little appetite for his breakfast.

Q: Did Marco eat?

A: Yes||Marco ate, and talked fast all the time; but Forester seemed silent and dejected.

Q: How did he talk?

A: fast||. Marco ate, and talked fast all the time; but Forester seemed silent and dejected.

Q: Was Forester feeling ill

A: Yes||Forester said that he felt somewhat unwell

Q: What did he want to do because of that

A: lie down||and as there was a sofa in the room, he concluded to lie down upon it, and not go out.

Q: on what?

A: a sofa|| and as there was a sofa in the room,


Summary: A RAFT.They had inquired of a fellow-passenger, who seemed acquainted with the country, and were told that there was a very good tavern about a quarter of a mile from the mill.When they landed upon the logs, Marco, whose curiosity seemed to be stronger than his appetite, wanted to ramble about for a little time along the shore and among the piles of boards, but Forester thought it would be best first to go and get their breakfast.So they went to the tavern.Forester seemed to have little appetite for his breakfast.Marco ate, and talked fast all the time; but Forester seemed silent and dejected.Forester said that he felt somewhat unwell, and as there was a sofa in the room, he concluded to lie down upon it, and not go out.
