source: cnn

George Zimmerman, set to stand trial in the 2012 shooting death of teenager Trayvon Martin, on Tuesday waived his right to a "stand your ground" pretrial immunity hearing. Zimmerman's attorneys have decided they will try this as a self-defense case. Florida's deadly force law, also called "stand your ground", was passed in 2005. It allows people to meet "force with force" if they believe they or someone else is in danger of being seriously harmed by an assailant. Under the law, a person can use deadly force anywhere as long as he is not engaged in an unlawful activity, is being attacked in a place he has a right to be, and reasonably believes that his life and safety are in danger as a result of an overt act or perceived threat committed by someone else. In a pretrial immunity hearing, a judge would have ruled whether Zimmerman's actions were protected under the "stand your ground" law; a ruling in favor of the defendant would have meant that no criminal or civil trial could proceed. Martin was shot and killed on February 26, 2012, while returning from a nearby convenience store to his father's fiancée's house in a gated community in Sanford, Florida. Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch captain, acknowledged that he shot the unarmed 17-year-old, but said Martin physically attacked him and he fired in self-defense. Initially, no charges were pursued, and the case soon became the center of a national controversy. Zimmerman was charged with second-degree murder on April 11, 2012.


Q: Who was in court on Tuesday?

A: George Zimmerman||George Zimmerman, set to stand trial in the 2012 shooting death of teenager Trayvon Martin, on Tuesday waived his right to a "stand your ground" pretrial immunity hearing.

Q: What job did he have where he lived?

A: neighborhood watch captain||Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch captain

Q: What was he charged with?

A: second-degree murder||Zimmerman was charged with second-degree murder on April 11, 2012.

Q: What state is he from?

A: Florida||Martin was shot and killed on February 26, 2012, while returning from a nearby convenience store to his father's fiancée's house in a gated community in Sanford, Florida.

Q: And what city?

A: Sanford, Florida||Martin was shot and killed on February 26, 2012, while returning from a nearby convenience store to his father's fiancée's house in a gated community in Sanford, Florida.

Q: What kind of defense will the lawyers use?

A: a self-defense case|| Zimmerman's attorneys have decided they will try this as a self-defense case.

Q: What is the deadly force law nicknamed?

A: "stand your ground"||Florida's deadly force law, also called "stand your ground"

Q: When was it passed?

A: 2005||Florida's deadly force law, also called "stand your ground", was passed in 2005.

Q: When can Floridians use deadly force?

A: if they believe they or someone else is in danger of being seriously harmed by an assailant||Florida's deadly force law, also called "stand your ground", was passed in 2005. It allows people to meet "force with force" if they believe they or someone else is in danger of being seriously harmed by an assailant.

Q: Can a person robbing a bank use this excuse?

A: no, Under the law, a person can use deadly force anywhere as long as he is not engaged in an unlawful activity,|| Under the law, a person can use deadly force anywhere as long as he is not engaged in an unlawful activity,

Q: Who is Zimmerman accused of killing?

A: Trayvon Martin||George Zimmerman, set to stand trial in the 2012 shooting death of teenager Trayvon Martin

A: 17||Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch captain, acknowledged that he shot the unarmed 17-year-old

Q: Where was he going?

A: to his father's fiancée's house||Martin was shot and killed on February 26, 2012, while returning from a nearby convenience store to his father's fiancée's house

Q: Will there be a pretrial immunity hearing?

A: no, George Zimmerman, set to stand trial in the 2012 shooting death of teenager Trayvon Martin, on Tuesday waived his right to a "stand your ground" pretrial immunity hearing.||George Zimmerman, set to stand trial in the 2012 shooting death of teenager Trayvon Martin, on Tuesday waived his right to a "stand your ground" pretrial immunity hearing.

Q: Did Martin have a gun?

A: no, Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch captain, acknowledged that he shot the unarmed 17-year-old||Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch captain, acknowledged that he shot the unarmed 17-year-old


Summary: George Zimmerman, set to stand trial in the 2012 shooting death of teenager Trayvon Martin, on Tuesday waived his right to a "stand your ground" pretrial immunity hearing.Zimmerman's attorneys have decided they will try this as a self-defense case.Florida's deadly force law, also called "stand your ground", was passed in 2005.Under the law, a person can use deadly force anywhere as long as he is not engaged in an unlawful activity, is being attacked in a place he has a right to be, and reasonably believes that his life and safety are in danger as a result of an overt act or perceived threat committed by someone else.Martin was shot and killed on February 26, 2012, while returning from a nearby convenience store to his father's fiancée's house in a gated community in Sanford, Florida.Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch captain, acknowledged that he shot the unarmed 17-year-old, but said Martin physically attacked him and he fired in self-defense.Zimmerman was charged with second-degree murder on April 11, 2012.

source: cnn

Los Angeles (CNN) -- Dr. Conrad Murray, who was Michael Jackson's personal physician, is refusing to testify in the wrongful death lawsuit that the singer's mother filed against concert promoter AEG Live. If called, he will plead the fifth so as not to incriminate himself, the doctor said in a statement sent to the Jackson family. Murray has never been questioned under oath about Jackson's death, which occurred on his watch. He did not testify at his trial, where he was found guilty of causing Jackson's death on June 25, 2009, by administering a deadly overdose of sedatives and the surgical anesthetic propofol in what he told police was an attempt to cure the singer's insomnia. He is serving a four-year sentence but could be out in two. On Monday, he was supposed to be deposed in the wrongful death suit. But lawyers for Jackson's mother, Katherine, and her three children called off their jailhouse visit because Murray swore "he would not answer any questions at the deposition or the trial," Jackson lawyer Kevin Boyle told CNN. He said the Jackson case would not suffer without his testimony. AEG's lawyer suggests the Jacksons canceled Murray's deposition because his testimony would "destroy" their case. "They are not interested in the truth," said the lawyer, Marvin Putnam. Asserting his 'Fifth Amendment privilege' The cancellation came after Murray's attorney Valerie Wass sent the Jacksons a sworn statement signed by Murray making it clear he would not answer any questions while his involuntary manslaughter conviction in Michael Jackson's death is being appealed.


Q: Who was the singer's doctor?

A: Conrad Murray||Dr. Conrad Murray, who was Michael Jackson's personal physician,

Q: Is he involved in the lawsuit?

A: he refused to testify in it||who was Michael Jackson's personal physician, is refusing to testify in the wrongful death lawsuit

Q: Who filed the lawsuit?

A: the singer's mother||lawsuit that the singer's mother filed

Q: Against who?

A: AEG Live.||lawsuit that the singer's mother filed against concert promoter AEG Live.

Q: What was the lawsuit about?

A: wrongful death||the wrongful death lawsuit

Q: Did he testify when he was the subject of a suit?

A: No, He did not testify at his trial||He did not testify at his trial

Q: When did Jackson die?

A: June 25||Jackson's death on June 25

Q: What year?

A: 2009||Jackson's death on June 25, 2009

Q: He died of what?

A: an overdose||Jackson's death on June 25, 2009, by administering a deadly overdose

Q: Of what?

A: sedatives||deadly overdose of sedatives

Q: And what else?

A: Yes||overdose of sedatives and the surgical anesthetic propofol

Q: What is the singer's mother's name?

A: Katherine||Jackson's mother, Katherine


Summary: Los Angeles (CNN) -- Dr. Conrad Murray, who was Michael Jackson's personal physician, is refusing to testify in the wrongful death lawsuit that the singer's mother filed against concert promoter AEG Live.He did not testify at his trial, where he was found guilty of causing Jackson's death on June 25, 2009, by administering a deadly overdose of sedatives and the surgical anesthetic propofol in what he told police was an attempt to cure the singer's insomnia.But lawyers for Jackson's mother, Katherine, and her three children called off their jailhouse visit because Murray swore "he would not answer any questions at the deposition or the trial," Jackson lawyer Kevin Boyle told CNN.

source: mctest

One morning, Justin woke up very excited. He was excited because it was his birthday. He went downstairs to eat breakfast. When he got downstairs his mom said, "Happy Birthday." "Thank you!" Justin said. "Am I going to have lots of presents?" he asked his mom. "Yes, Justin. When your friends come over for your birthday party you'll get lots!" "Hooray!" Justin said, eating his breakfast. Later that day, Justin's friends came over for his birthday party, and they brought over lots of presents. They ate cake and ice cream. They played games like tag and played with a football. After they were done playing Justin got to open his presents. He saw lots of presents. Red ones, blue ones, tall ones, round ones. "Thank you!" Justin said, as he started to open his presents. He got a basketball, a robot toy, a new bike and some super hero toys! After all of Justin's friends left, Justin fell asleep very fast because of the exciting day he had and he was happy he got all of those nice things.


Q: was justin sad?

A: no, Justin woke up very excited||Justin woke up very excited

Q: was he overjoyed?

A: yes||Justin woke up very excited.

Q: why?

A: it was his birthday.||because it was his birthday.

Q: did he receive gifts

A: yes||and they brought over lots of presents

Q: what were they?

A: a basketball, a robot toy, a new bike and some super hero toys||He got a basketball, a robot toy, a new bike and some super hero toys

Q: who greeted Justin in after he woke up?

A: his mom||When he got downstairs his mom said, "Happy Birthday."

Q: what types of diversion did the kids engage in?

A: They played games||They played games like tag and played with a football.

Q: which ones?

A: tag and football.||tag and played with a football.

Q: did they enjoy food?

A: yes||They ate cake and ice cream

Q: what food?

A: cake and ice cream||cake and ice cream

Q: who was at the function?

A: Justin's friends||Justin's friends

Q: did they bring anything?

A: yes|| and they brought over lots of presents

Q: what?

A: presents.||presents.

Q: was Justin grateful?

A: yes||he had and he was happy he got all of those nice things.

Q: did it take him a long time to snooze?

A: no, Justin fell asleep very fast ||Justin fell asleep very fast

Q: why?

A: because of the exciting day he had||because of the exciting day he had

Q: did he go to sleep sad?

A: no, he was happy he got all of those nice things.||he was happy he got all of those nice things.


Summary: One morning, Justin woke up very excited.He was excited because it was his birthday.When he got downstairs his mom said, "Happy Birthday."Later that day, Justin's friends came over for his birthday party, and they brought over lots of presents.They ate cake and ice cream.They played games like tag and played with a football.He got a basketball, a robot toy, a new bike and some super hero toys!After all of Justin's friends left, Justin fell asleep very fast because of the exciting day he had and he was happy he got all of those nice things.

source: mctest

John was in the third grade, and nine years old. Every day he had to walk home from school. There were some kids in his class who were mean to him, and during the winter they would throw snowballs at him. John could have told the teacher, but one of the kids was a very pretty girl. She was mean, but John liked her because she was pretty and did not want her to get in trouble. One day, his teacher asked John to stay after class to wipe off the chalkboard and to empty the pencil sharpener. By the time he was done, the other kids had gone home. They could no longer throw snowballs at him. John did not mind helping out his teacher, and he soon stayed after class every day. John was not very good at math, and sometimes his teacher would help him when he stayed after school. She said if John could help her out for at least two weeks, he could pass his math class. John thought it was a good deal, and ended up being much better at math.


Q: Who is in third grade?

A: JOhn||ohn was in the third grade,

Q: How old is he?

A: Nine||nine years old.

Q: What did kids do to him?

A: throw snowballs at him.||during the winter they would throw snowballs at him.

Q: Did he tell on them?

A: no, hn could have told the teacher, but one of the kids was a very pretty girl. ||hn could have told the teacher, but one of the kids was a very pretty girl.

Q: Why not?

A: one was a very pretty girl.||John could have told the teacher, but one of the kids was a very pretty girl.

Q: What happened when he helped?

A: better at math.||ended up being much better at math.

Q: What did he have to do in the beginning?

A: owipe off the chalkboard||o wipe off the chalkboard

Q: What happened when he left?

A: the other kids had gone home||By the time he was done, the other kids had gone home

Q: How did that make John feel?

A: good||hey could no longer throw snowballs at him.

Q: How often did he assist?

A: every day.||he soon stayed after class every day.


Summary: John was in the third grade, and nine years old.There were some kids in his class who were mean to him, and during the winter they would throw snowballs at him.John could have told the teacher, but one of the kids was a very pretty girl.One day, his teacher asked John to stay after class to wipe off the chalkboard and to empty the pencil sharpener.By the time he was done, the other kids had gone home.They could no longer throw snowballs at him.John did not mind helping out his teacher, and he soon stayed after class every day.John thought it was a good deal, and ended up being much better at math.

source: race

Running Man is a variety show which is aired in SBS, a famous South Korean TV channel. The show broadcasts on Sunday every week. The translation can be watched on the Internet every Monday. It's very interesting and funny. In the program, everyone should keep running. Here are some information of its hosts and hostess. Liu Zaishi, the main host of the show, is known as National Moderator(,). His friendly, witty and lovely hosting style makes him become one of the most popular hosts and comedians in South Korean. Jin Zhongguo, the strongest man on the show, is known as Sparta-kooks . During the race, he can capture others quickly. But sometimes, he can be very cute. Song Zhixiao, the beautiful actress who is also called Mong Zhi, where "mong" means "confused", because of her facial expressions which makes her seem confused. During the race mission, she is ace because of her superior ability to capture. Young people in Korea love the program very much. Why? Because some South Korean stars will be invited to take part in the race every week . They are divided into several teams with MCs. Many stars have participated in the program, for example, Li Minhao, Girls'Generation , Jin Xiuxian etc. What's more, the program is not only relaxing but also educational--- It teaches people the importance of team spirit.


Q: What's the name of the show the story is about?

A: Running Man||Running Man is a variety show which is aired in SBS

Q: What channel is it on?

A: SBS||SBS, a famous South Korean TV channel

Q: Where is that channel based?

A: South Korea||SBS, a famous South Korean TV channel

Q: What day is the show aired?

A: Sunday||The show broadcasts on Sunday every week.

Q: And what day is it translated for the Internet?

A: Monday||The translation can be watched on the Internet every Monday

Q: What kind of show is it?

A: variety show||Running Man is a variety show

Q: Who hosts it?

A: Liu Zaishi||Liu Zaishi, the main host of the show,

Q: What kind of style does he have?

A: friendly, witty and lovely||His friendly, witty and lovely hosting style makes him become one of the most popular hosts and comedians in South Korean.

Q: Do people like him?

A: yes||His friendly, witty and lovely hosting style makes him become one of the most popular hosts and comedians in South Korean.

Q: Who's the strongest man?

A: Jin Zhongguo||Jin Zhongguo, the strongest man on the show

Q: Does he have a nickname?

A: Sparta-kooks||is known as Sparta-kooks

Q: What's the meaning of "mong"?

A: confused|| "mong" means "confused",

Q: Who is given that nickname?

A: Song Zhixiao||Song Zhixiao, the beautiful actress who is also called Mong Zhi

Q: Is Song Zhixiao a man or woman?

A: woman||Song Zhixiao, the beautiful actress

Q: Why is she good at the mission?

A: superior ability to capture||she is ace because of her superior ability to capture

Q: Why do Koreans like the show so much?

A: South Korean stars||Young people in Korea love the program very much. Why? Because some South Korean stars will be invited to take part in the race every week .

Q: Are they all on the same team?

A: no, They are divided into several teams with MCs||They are divided into several teams with MCs

Q: What are some stars who have been on?

A: Li Minhao, Girls'Generation, Jin Xiuxian||Many stars have participated in the program, for example, Li Minhao, Girls'Generation , Jin Xiuxian etc

Q: What can you learn from the show?

A: team spirit||What's more, the program is not only relaxing but also educational--- It teaches people the importance of team spirit.


Summary: Running Man is a variety show which is aired in SBS, a famous South Korean TV channel.The show broadcasts on Sunday every week.The translation can be watched on the Internet every Monday.Liu Zaishi, the main host of the show, is known as National Moderator(,).His friendly, witty and lovely hosting style makes him become one of the most popular hosts and comedians in South Korean.Jin Zhongguo, the strongest man on the show, is known as Sparta-kooks .Song Zhixiao, the beautiful actress who is also called Mong Zhi, where "mong" means "confused", because of her facial expressions which makes her seem confused.During the race mission, she is ace because of her superior ability to capture.Young people in Korea love the program very much.They are divided into several teams with MCs.Many stars have participated in the program, for example, Li Minhao, Girls'Generation , Jin Xiuxian etc.What's more, the program is not only relaxing but also educational--- It teaches people the importance of team spirit.

source: mctest

A young mother had a child that was in kindergarten. One day, the class took a trip to the zoo. This was the start of a very good day. The child had a lot of fun. The animals were very friendly, and the friendliest of all was a baby tiger, which the child called 'kitty'. The mother laughed when her child asked to see a unicorn. Instead, she gave her daughter a cookie and they had some ham sandwiches for lunch. They had lunch by the stone benches in the park area. There was a trashcan nearby. The mother threw their trash in the trashcan when they were done. Then they went to go see the pigs. The pigs made a noise like 'oink'. There were also cows. There was also a slide. The slide was a water slide, and the child begged her mother to let her go down it. At the end of the day, the child was dirty and tired, but she had a lot of fun.


Q: Was the mother old?

A: no, A young mother||A young mother

Q: What did she have?

A: a child||a child

Q: What grade were they in?

A: kindergarten||child that was in kindergarten

Q: Where was the school outing to?

A: the zoo||the zoo

Q: What did they name the friendly animal?

A: kitty||kitty

Q: Did they want to play with an elephant?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: Did they eat while there?

A: They had lunch||They had lunch

Q: Did they eat three things?

A: no, a cookie and they had some ham sandwiches||a cookie and they had some ham sandwiches

Q: What did they sit on to eat?

A: by the stone benches|| by the stone benches

Q: Where were those?

A: in the park||in the park

Q: What did they do when they were done?

A: threw away their trash||threw their trash in the trashcan

Q: What did they visit next?

A: the pigs||the pigs

Q: Were they quiet?

A: no, pigs made a noise ||pigs made a noise

Q: What else did they visit?

A: cows||cows

Q: Did they play on any rides?

A: yes||a slide

Q: How did they feel after the visit?

A: dirty and tired||dirty and tired

Q: Was their dessert a cake?

A: no, a cookie ||a cookie


Summary: A young mother had a child that was in kindergarten.One day, the class took a trip to the zoo.The animals were very friendly, and the friendliest of all was a baby tiger, which the child called 'kitty'.Instead, she gave her daughter a cookie and they had some ham sandwiches for lunch.They had lunch by the stone benches in the park area.The mother threw their trash in the trashcan when they were done.The pigs made a noise like 'oink'.There was also a slide.The slide was a water slide, and the child begged her mother to let her go down it.At the end of the day, the child was dirty and tired, but she had a lot of fun.

source: wikipedia

The Christian Science Monitor (CSM) is an international news organization that delivers global coverage via its website, weekly magazine, daily news briefing, email newsletters, Amazon Kindle subscription, and mobile site. It was started in 1908 by Mary Baker Eddy, the founder of the Church of Christ, Scientist. , the print circulation was 75,052. The "Monitor" is a newspaper that covers international and United States current events. The paper includes a daily religious feature on "The Home Forum" page, but states the publication is not a platform for evangelizing. In 2008 the "Monitor" discontinued its daily print version to focus on web-based publishing, replacing its daily print edition with a weekly news magazine with an international focus. Mark Sappenfield became the editor in March of 2017. Despite its name, the "Monitor" does not claim to be a religious-themed paper, and says it does not promote the doctrine of its patron church. However, at its founder Eddy's request, a daily religious article has appeared in every issue of the "Monitor". Eddy also required the inclusion of "Christian Science" in the paper's name, over initial opposition by some of her advisors who thought the religious reference might repel a secular audience. The "Monitor"'s inception was, in part, a response by Eddy to the journalism of her day, which relentlessly covered the sensations and scandals surrounding her new religion with varying degrees of accuracy. In addition, Joseph Pulitzer's "New York World" was consistently critical of Eddy, and this, along with a derogatory article in "McClure's", furthered Eddy's decision to found her own media outlet.


Q: What does CSM stand for?

A: Christian Science Monitor||he Christian Science Monitor (CSM)

Q: what are they?

A: an international news organization||The Christian Science Monitor (CSM) is an international news organization

Q: do they have a website?

A: Yes||The Christian Science Monitor (CSM) is an international news organization that delivers global coverage via its website

Q: who was the founder?

A: Mary Baker Eddy|| It was started in 1908 by Mary Baker Eddy

Q: When did she start it?

A: 1908||started in 1908 by Mary Baker Eddy

Q: What did she also start?

A: the Church of Christ, Scientist.||Mary Baker Eddy, the founder of the Church of Christ, Scientist.

Q: Did they offer daily print version?

A: Yes||the print circulation

Q: Is it still offered or is it discontinued?

A: discontinued||In 2008 the "Monitor" discontinued its daily print version

Q: When did it stop?

A: In 2008||In 2008 the "Monitor" discontinued its daily print version

Q: Why did it stop?

A: to focus on web-based publishing||discontinued its daily print version to focus on web-based publishing

Q: Who's the editor?

A: Mark Sappenfield||Mark Sappenfield became the editor

Q: When did he start?

A: 2017||Mark Sappenfield became the editor in March of 2017

Q: Is the Monitor a religious themed paper?

A: No, Despite its name, the "Monitor" does not claim to be a religious-themed paper,||Despite its name, the "Monitor" does not claim to be a religious-themed paper,

Q: Who is the Founder?

A: Mary Baker Eddy||It was started in 1908 by Mary Baker Eddy

Q: Who was critical of her?

A: New York World||New York World" was consistently critical of Eddy

Q: Who owned that?

A: Joseph Pulitzer||Joseph Pulitzer's "New York World"

Q: Did he influence Eddy to start the Monitor?

A: Yes||Joseph Pulitzer's "New York World" was consistently critical of Eddy, and this, along with a derogatory article in "McClure's", furthered Eddy's decision to found her own media outlet.

Q: Where did another bad article appear?

A: McClure's||along with a derogatory article in "McClure's"

Q: How much circulation does CSM have?

A: the print circulation was 75,052.||the print circulation was 75,052.


Summary: The Christian Science Monitor (CSM) is an international news organization that delivers global coverage via its website, weekly magazine, daily news briefing, email newsletters, Amazon Kindle subscription, and mobile site.It was started in 1908 by Mary Baker Eddy, the founder of the Church of Christ, Scientist., the print circulation was 75,052.In 2008 the "Monitor" discontinued its daily print version to focus on web-based publishing, replacing its daily print edition with a weekly news magazine with an international focus.Mark Sappenfield became the editor in March of 2017.Despite its name, the "Monitor" does not claim to be a religious-themed paper, and says it does not promote the doctrine of its patron church.In addition, Joseph Pulitzer's "New York World" was consistently critical of Eddy, and this, along with a derogatory article in "McClure's", furthered Eddy's decision to found her own media outlet.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Cork was originally a monastic settlement, reputedly founded by Saint Finbarr in the 6th century. Cork achieved an urban character at some point between 915 and 922 when Norseman (Viking) settlers founded a trading port. It has been proposed that, like Dublin, Cork was an important trading centre in the global Scandinavian trade network. The ecclesiastical settlement continued alongside the Viking longphort, with the two developing a type of symbiotic relationship; the Norsemen providing otherwise unobtainable trade goods for the monastery, and perhaps also military aid. The city's charter was granted by Prince John, as Lord of Ireland, in 1185. The city was once fully walled, and some wall sections and gates remain today. For much of the Middle Ages, Cork city was an outpost of Old English culture in the midst of a predominantly hostile Gaelic countryside and cut off from the English government in the Pale around Dublin. Neighbouring Gaelic and Hiberno-Norman lords extorted "Black Rent" from the citizens to keep them from attacking the city. The present extent of the city has exceeded the medieval boundaries of the Barony of Cork City; it now takes in much of the neighbouring Barony of Cork. Together, these baronies are located between the Barony of Barrymore to the east, Muskerry East to the west and Kerrycurrihy to the south.


Q: Who granted the city's charter?

A: Prince John||The city's charter was granted by Prince John

Q: what was his title?

A: Lord of Ireland||Lord of Ireland

Q: What type of settlement was Cork originally?

A: monastic||Cork was originally a monastic settlement

Q: Founded by whom?

A: Saint Finbarr||Saint Finbarr

Q: when?

A: 6th century||in the 6th century

Q: Was cork a trading center for Alaskans?

A: No, global Scandinavian trade network||global Scandinavian trade network

Q: What was Cork an important trading centre for?

A: Scandinavians||Scandinavian

Q: Who provided military aid?

A: the Norsemen||the Norsemen

Q: Are all of the walls gone from the city?

A: No, some wall sections and gates remain today|| some wall sections and gates remain today

Q: Who extorted black rent?

A: Neighbouring lords||Neighbouring Gaelic and Hiberno-Norman lords

Q: why?

A: to keep them from attacking the city||to keep them from attacking the city

Q: was Cork an outpost of New English culture?

A: No, outpost of Old English culture ||outpost of Old English culture

Q: when did Cork get an urban character

A: between 915 and 922||some point between 915 and 922


Summary: Cork was originally a monastic settlement, reputedly founded by Saint Finbarr in the 6th century.Cork achieved an urban character at some point between 915 and 922 when Norseman (Viking) settlers founded a trading port.It has been proposed that, like Dublin, Cork was an important trading centre in the global Scandinavian trade network.The ecclesiastical settlement continued alongside the Viking longphort, with the two developing a type of symbiotic relationship; the Norsemen providing otherwise unobtainable trade goods for the monastery, and perhaps also military aid.The city's charter was granted by Prince John, as Lord of Ireland, in 1185.The city was once fully walled, and some wall sections and gates remain today.For much of the Middle Ages, Cork city was an outpost of Old English culture in the midst of a predominantly hostile Gaelic countryside and cut off from the English government in the Pale around Dublin.Neighbouring Gaelic and Hiberno-Norman lords extorted "Black Rent" from the citizens to keep them from attacking the city.

source: mctest

There was once a pig named Oink, who lived on a farm, but spent most of his days in a factory making shoes. In his free time, he would make drawings about how much he wished he could fly. He would look up at the stars in wonder, hoping that some day, his dream might come true. For many years, his life carried on this way. He would wake up on the farm, go to work, and then come home to dream about flying. That is, until one day, he got a letter with a strange sticker on it, that was shaped like a star. He opened the letter in excitement, wondering what it said. The letter said that Oink was invited to a special party that took place every year in the clouds. Animals from all across the world were chosen so that they could know what it's like to fly. If he chose to go to the party, he would get his own set of wings to fly up into the sky and meet the other animals. Oink was so happy, he barely knew how to react. He accepted the invitation, and two days later, got a package containing his wings. Oink's dream was finally coming true. He put the wings on his back and flew up into the sky, where the party was being held. Once he arrived, he saw a bunch of other animals with wings also. He saw horses, dogs, cats, and plenty of birds. Oink had found out that it was the birds who had invited everyone, since they wanted the other animals to know what it is like to fly. Oink spent that day flying in the clouds with his new friends. But when the clock reached midnight, he knew his time flying was up, and he had to return the wings and go back to his farm. But the birds told him that they saw how much he enjoyed flying, and would allow him to keep his wings so he could fly with them whenever he wanted. Oink was really thankful, and next time he saw the birds, gave them their own pair of shoes for free as a thank you gift.


Q: What was Oink?

A: a pig||a pig named Oink

Q: Where did he live?

A: on a farm||Oink, who lived on a farm,

Q: Did he make hats in a factory?

A: no, factory making shoe|| factory making shoe

Q: What did he make?

A: shoes.||shoes.

Q: What did he do in his free time?

A: he'd draw||he would make drawings

Q: What was the subject of his drawings?

A: he wished to fly||he wished he could fly

Q: Did he dream about it?

A: Yes||some day, his dream might come true

Q: What did he get with a star sticker on it?

A: a letter|| a letter with a strange sticker on it, that was shaped like a star.

Q: Where did it invite him?

A: the clouds||a special party that took place every year in the clouds

Q: What was happening in the clouds?

A: a party||a special party

Q: What would happen if he went?

A: he'd get wings so he could go||he would get his own set of wings to fly up into the sky and meet the other animals.

Q: How many days did it take to get his wings?

A: Two||two days later, got a package containing his wings

Q: What kind of animals did he see when he arrived at the party?

A: horses, dogs, cats, and birds||He saw horses, dogs, cats, and plenty of birds

Q: Who invited everyone?

A: the birds|| the birds who had invited everyone

Q: Why?

A: so other animals could see what flying was like||they wanted the other animals to know what it is like to fly.

Q: What did the birds say when they saw how much he liked flying?

A: he could keep his wings||But the birds told him that they saw how much he enjoyed flying, and would allow him to keep his wings so he could fly with them whenever he wanted.

Q: What did he give them?

A: shoes|| gave them their own pair of shoes for free as a thank you gift.


Summary: There was once a pig named Oink, who lived on a farm, but spent most of his days in a factory making shoes.In his free time, he would make drawings about how much he wished he could fly.He would look up at the stars in wonder, hoping that some day, his dream might come true.That is, until one day, he got a letter with a strange sticker on it, that was shaped like a star.The letter said that Oink was invited to a special party that took place every year in the clouds.If he chose to go to the party, he would get his own set of wings to fly up into the sky and meet the other animals.He accepted the invitation, and two days later, got a package containing his wings.He saw horses, dogs, cats, and plenty of birds.Oink had found out that it was the birds who had invited everyone, since they wanted the other animals to know what it is like to fly.But the birds told him that they saw how much he enjoyed flying, and would allow him to keep his wings so he could fly with them whenever he wanted.Oink was really thankful, and next time he saw the birds, gave them their own pair of shoes for free as a thank you gift.

source: cnn

Sydney (CNN) -- Kevin Rudd and Tony Abbott, the two men vying to be Australia's prime minister in the September 7 national election, offer contrasting views on China, the country that looms largest on Australia's economic and strategic horizon. Rudd, the Chinese-speaking incumbent prime minister in the Labor-led government, says the China resources boom is over and Australia needs to prepare for that transition, given how important China has become as a trade partner in the past decade. China is a key destination for Australian resources such as iron ore, coal and LNG. But in recent months, even China's breakneck economic pace has hit some speed bumps. On the broader geopolitical front, Rudd wants China and the United States to carve out a new Asia-Pacific "strategic road-map" that will enhance trade, investment and security in the region. READ MORE: Rudd: Better second time around? The Opposition's view on China Abbott, who has led the opposition Liberal Party since 2009, wants the Australia-China relationship to move from one based on shared interests to one of "shared values." But he notes that Australia's friendship with China is more recent than that with Japan, and less developed than that with the United States. In a major policy speech to a business audience in Beijing last year, Abbott said he believed it would take time before Australia's ties with China approached "the warmth that we take for granted with America." Still, he believes it is an effort worth making. Like his mentor, former Australian prime minister John Howard, Abbott is a rock-solid supporter of Australia's military alliance with the United States, and believes that it is possible to be friends both with Washington and Beijing. Howard, he said, "understood that you could make a new friend without losing an old one."


Q: Who has led the Liberal Party?

A: Tony Abbott||Tony Abbott

Q: Who is he running against?

A: Kevin Rudd||Kevin Rudd

Q: What language does Rudd speak?

A: Chinese||Chinese

Q: Why is China important to Australia?

A: China is a key destination for Australian resources||China is a key destination for Australian resources

Q: What does Rudd want China and the United States to do?

A: carve out a new Asia-Pacific "strategic road-map"||carve out a new Asia-Pacific "strategic road-map"

Q: What is Abbott's view on the Australia-China relationship?

A: to move from one based on shared interests to one of "shared values."||to move from one based on shared interests to one of "shared values."

Q: Who does Australia have a more recent friendship with?

A: China||China

Q: Is China important to Australia?

A: Yes||looms largest

Q: Do Abbot and Rudd hold the same views on China?

A: No, contrasting views on China||contrasting views on China

Q: Who is Abbott's mentor?

A: John Howard||John Howard

Q: Who is John Howard?

A: former Australian prime minister|| former Australian prime minister

Q: Does Abbott think it's worth the effort to maintain ties with China?

A: Yes||he believes it is an effort worth making

Q: What will the "strategic road-map" help do?

A: enhance trade, investment and security||enhance trade, investment and security

Q: Where did Abbott give a policy speech last year?

A: Beijing||Beijing

Q: How long has Abbott led the Liberal Party?

A: since 2009||since 2009

Q: When is the election?

A: September 7||September 7

Q: What office are the two running for?

A: prime minister||prime minister

Q: Does Australia have a longer friendship with Japan or China?

A: Japan||China is more recent than that with Japan

Q: What did Abbot say in his speech in Beijing?

A: it would take time before Australia's ties with China approached "the warmth that we take for granted with America."||it would take time before Australia's ties with China approached "the warmth that we take for granted with America."

Q: What does John Howard think of Abbott?

A: understood that you could make a new friend without losing an old one."||understood that you could make a new friend without losing an old one."


Summary: Sydney (CNN) -- Kevin Rudd and Tony Abbott, the two men vying to be Australia's prime minister in the September 7 national election, offer contrasting views on China, the country that looms largest on Australia's economic and strategic horizon.Rudd, the Chinese-speaking incumbent prime minister in the Labor-led government, says the China resources boom is over and Australia needs to prepare for that transition, given how important China has become as a trade partner in the past decade.China is a key destination for Australian resources such as iron ore, coal and LNG.On the broader geopolitical front, Rudd wants China and the United States to carve out a new Asia-Pacific "strategic road-map" that will enhance trade, investment and security in the region.The Opposition's view on China Abbott, who has led the opposition Liberal Party since 2009, wants the Australia-China relationship to move from one based on shared interests to one of "shared values."But he notes that Australia's friendship with China is more recent than that with Japan, and less developed than that with the United States.In a major policy speech to a business audience in Beijing last year, Abbott said he believed it would take time before Australia's ties with China approached "the warmth that we take for granted with America."Still, he believes it is an effort worth making.Like his mentor, former Australian prime minister John Howard, Abbott is a rock-solid supporter of Australia's military alliance with the United States, and believes that it is possible to be friends both with Washington and Beijing.Howard, he said, "understood that you could make a new friend without losing an old one."

source: race

I never wanted a dog, but now I'm so glad I have one. About two years ago, my wife, Cathy, got a little dog with a face only a mother could love. We named her Gertie. Gertie is the kind of dog that has to grow on you. So I dicided that the dog would be trained. This didn't quite go as planned. At 15 weeks old, she was nearly made to leave the Petsmart Training School. She spent every night lying in our bed-snoring so loudly that I hardly got a good night's sleep. Then, about six months after she arrived, I felt that something in my heart was taking place, and I was unable to stop it. My behaviour began to change. I began to smile at people when passing them in a street. I returned from neighbours. I started calling my kids, and to my surprise, they started calling me. I even tried to speak to my grandchildren over the phone once. I even was glad to listen to laughter from a 10-month-old granddaughter. The point is that I was changing. My wife and I both agree that it is Gertie who has changed my behaviour. Gertie is now nearly two years old and almost fully grown.I have come to like the pet little by little, though she is my wife's dog.


Q: What is my dog's name?

A: Gertie||We named her Gertie

Q: What does she look like?

A: little dog with a face only a mother could love.||got a little dog with a face only a mother could love.

Q: Is she obedient?

A: no, he was nearly made to leave the Petsmart Training School.||he was nearly made to leave the Petsmart Training School.

Q: Did she go to training?

A: yes||she was nearly made to leave the Petsmart Training School.

Q: Where?

A: Petsmart Training School||Petsmart Training School

Q: What changed in my life after getting Gertie?

A: behaviour||My behaviour began to change

Q: What did I do differently?

A: I would smile at people|| I began to smile at people

Q: Did I do anything else differently?

A: started calling my kids|| I started calling my kids,

Q: Did they return my calls?

A: yes|| they started calling me

Q: how old is Gertie now?

A: nearly two||Gertie is now nearly two years old

Q: Did I want a dog?

A: no, I never wanted a dog,||I never wanted a dog,

Q: Is Gertie my dog?

A: no, she is my wife's dog.||she is my wife's dog.

Q: Who does Gertie belong to?

A: my wife||she is my wife's dog.


Summary: I never wanted a dog, but now I'm so glad I have one.About two years ago, my wife, Cathy, got a little dog with a face only a mother could love.We named her Gertie.At 15 weeks old, she was nearly made to leave the Petsmart Training School.My behaviour began to change.I began to smile at people when passing them in a street.I started calling my kids, and to my surprise, they started calling me.Gertie is now nearly two years old and almost fully grown.I have come to like the pet little by little, though she is my wife's dog.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- Manchester City thrashed Sunderland 5-0 to keep alive their slim English Premier League title hopes and to cement their position in the top four Champions League places. England international Adam Johnson, making his first start since injuring his ankle in January, opened the scoring in the ninth minute while captain Carlos Tevez doubled the Blues' advantage on the quarter hour from the penalty spot. Second-half strikes from David Silva, Patrick Vieira and Yaya Toure completed the rout as City went above reigning champions Chelsea into third in the standings. They are six points clear of fifth-placed Tottenham, who pipped them for the final Champions League place last season, but have played a game more. Leaders Manchester United have a seven-point lead over Arsenal, who have played a game less, with their neighbors City 10 points adrift. The strikes from Johnson, who exchanged passes with Toure before finishing neatly, and Tevez, who was fouled by Michael Turner to draw the penalty, effectively ended the match as a contest with City always in command against a Sunderland side in poor recent form. Silva scored after a Mario Balotelli shot was blocked, Vieira with his first touch after coming off the bench and Toure after an error by Sunderland captain Lee Cattermole. City's Dutch international Nigel de Jong said the result was important for their Champions League ambitions. "There are still seven games to go and anything can happen but this is a great confidence boost for our team -- we are real contenders for the Champions League places." he told Sky Sports.


Q: What contest were they contending for?

A: Champions League||Champions League

Q: What teams were playing?

A: Manchester City and Sunderland||Manchester City thrashed Sunderland 5-0

Q: Who won?

A: Manchester City||Manchester City thrashed Sunderland 5-0

Q: Who started for the first time since January?

A: Adam Johnson||Adam Johnson, making his first start since injuring his ankle in January,

Q: Why had he not been playing?

A: he injured his ankle||Adam Johnson, making his first start since injuring his ankle in January

Q: Who made the first score?

A: England international Adam Johnson||England international Adam Johnson, making his first start since injuring his ankle in January, opened the scoring

Q: How many points difference are they from Tottenham?

A: six||They are six points clear of fifth-placed Tottenham

Q: What is their rank?

A: fifth||fifth-placed Tottenham

Q: Have they played more games?

A: yes||but have played a game more

Q: What nationality is player Nigel de Jong?

A: City's Dutch international||City's Dutch international Nigel de Jong

Q: How many games remain

A: seven||There are still seven games to go

Q: Where did winning this game move them up in the rankings?

A: to the top four|| to cement their position in the top four

Q: Who did they move ahead of?

A: Tottenham||They are six points clear of fifth-placed Tottenham


Summary: (CNN) -- Manchester City thrashed Sunderland 5-0 to keep alive their slim English Premier League title hopes and to cement their position in the top four Champions League places.England international Adam Johnson, making his first start since injuring his ankle in January, opened the scoring in the ninth minute while captain Carlos Tevez doubled the Blues' advantage on the quarter hour from the penalty spot.They are six points clear of fifth-placed Tottenham, who pipped them for the final Champions League place last season, but have played a game more.City's Dutch international Nigel de Jong said the result was important for their Champions League ambitions."There are still seven games to go and anything can happen but this is a great confidence boost for our team -- we are real contenders for the Champions League places."


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

A social class (or, simply, class), as in class society, is a set of subjectively defined concepts in the social sciences and political theory centered on models of social stratification in which people are grouped into a set of hierarchical social categories, the most common being the upper, middle, and lower classes. Class is a subject of analysis for sociologists, political scientists, anthropologists, and social historians. However, there is not a consensus on a definition of "class", and the term has a wide range of sometimes conflicting meanings. In common parlance, the term "social class" is usually synonymous with "socio-economic class", defined as "people having the same social, economic, cultural, political or educational status", e.g., "the working class"; "an emerging professional class". However, academics distinguish social class and socioeconomic status, with the former referring to one’s relatively stable sociocultural background and the latter referring to one’s current social and economic situation and, consequently, being more changeable over time. The precise measurements of what determines social class in society has varied over time. Karl Marx thought "class" was defined by one's relationship to the means of production (their relations of production). His simple understanding of classes in modern capitalist society, are the proletariat, those who work but do not own the means of production; and the bourgeoisie, those who invest and live off of the surplus generated by the former. This contrasts with the view of the sociologist Max Weber, who argued "class" is determined by economic position, in contrast to "social status" or ""Stand"" which is determined by social prestige rather than simply just relations of production.


Q: What is one group that analyzes classes?

A: sociologists||Class is a subject of analysis for sociologists

Q: Ad another?

A: political scientists||Class is a subject of analysis for sociologists, political scientists

Q: And one more?

A: anthropologists||Class is a subject of analysis for sociologists, political scientists, anthropologists

Q: Does everyone agree on what class means?

A: No, there is not a consensus on a definition of "class"||there is not a consensus on a definition of "class"

Q: Which two terms are generally the same in common usage?

A: "social class" and "socio-economic class"||In common parlance, the term "social class" is usually synonymous with "socio-economic class"

Q: Do scholars think they are the same?

A: No, However, academics distinguish social class and socioeconomic status||However, academics distinguish social class and socioeconomic status

Q: True or False: Scholars consider social class to be more changeable than the other term.

A: False||However, academics distinguish social class and socioeconomic status, with the former referring to one’s relatively stable sociocultural background and the latter referring to one’s current social and economic situation and, consequently, being more changeable over time.

Q: What are the three most common class groupings?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: By what relationship did Marx define class?

A: the means of production||Karl Marx thought "class" was defined by one's relationship to the means of production

Q: Which group did not own that means?

A: proletariat|| are the proletariat, those who work but do not own the means of production

Q: What is the other group called?

A: bourgeoisie||and the bourgeoisie

Q: What did they live off?

A: surplus generated by the former||the bourgeoisie, those who invest and live off of the surplus generated by the former

Q: What kind of society did Mark see these classes in?

A: modern capitalist society||modern capitalist society

Q: Was his theory very complex?

A: No, His simple understanding of classes in modern capitalist society||His simple understanding of classes in modern capitalist society

Q: Did Weber have the same ideas?

A: No, This contrasts with the view of the sociologist Max Weber||This contrasts with the view of the sociologist Max Weber

Q: What did Weber think class was decided by?

A: economic position|| Max Weber, who argued "class" is determined by economic position


Summary: A social class (or, simply, class), as in class society, is a set of subjectively defined concepts in the social sciences and political theory centered on models of social stratification in which people are grouped into a set of hierarchical social categories, the most common being the upper, middle, and lower classes.Class is a subject of analysis for sociologists, political scientists, anthropologists, and social historians.However, there is not a consensus on a definition of "class", and the term has a wide range of sometimes conflicting meanings.In common parlance, the term "social class" is usually synonymous with "socio-economic class", defined as "people having the same social, economic, cultural, political or educational status", e.g., "the working class"; "an emerging professional class".However, academics distinguish social class and socioeconomic status, with the former referring to one’s relatively stable sociocultural background and the latter referring to one’s current social and economic situation and, consequently, being more changeable over time.Karl Marx thought "class" was defined by one's relationship to the means of production (their relations of production).His simple understanding of classes in modern capitalist society, are the proletariat, those who work but do not own the means of production; and the bourgeoisie, those who invest and live off of the surplus generated by the former.This contrasts with the view of the sociologist Max Weber, who argued "class" is determined by economic position, in contrast to "social status" or ""Stand"" which is determined by social prestige rather than simply just relations of production.

source: mctest

The cat woke up from its nap under the couch. Poking his head out from under the couch, there were no dogs there. He walked out from under the couch and stretched out his paws along the hard wood floor. Far outside there was some barking from the dogs, but he was safe from them for now. The smell of tuna was in the air and the cat followed the scent to the kitchen. A woman was making a tuna sandwich for her two kids. When she finished, she put the tuna can on to the floor. The cat slowly walked up to the can and saw some juice inside. He licked up the yummy tuna juice and was sad when it was all gone. The woman brought the tuna sandwiches over to her sons at the table, then she opened the back door to let the dogs in. The cat's fur stood on end as the dogs came running after him. He ran away into the other and back to under the couch where it was safe.


Q: Were there dogs there?

A: no, no||no

Q: What could be heard?

A: barking||barking

Q: What did the cat smell?

A: tuna|| tuna

Q: Who was using tuna?

A: A woman||A woman

Q: What was she preparing?

A: tuna sandwich||tuna sandwich

Q: For whom?

A: her kids||her two kids

Q: Were they girls?

A: no, no||no

Q: Where'd she place the container?

A: at the table||at the table

Q: Was the floor carpeted?

A: no, no||no

Q: Did the cat get a treat?

A: yes||o th

Q: Did she open the door?

A: yes||d ou

Q: Where'd the kitty go?

A: under the couch||under the couch


Summary: Poking his head out from under the couch, there were no dogs there.He walked out from under the couch and stretched out his paws along the hard wood floor.Far outside there was some barking from the dogs, but he was safe from them for now.The smell of tuna was in the air and the cat followed the scent to the kitchen.A woman was making a tuna sandwich for her two kids.The woman brought the tuna sandwiches over to her sons at the table, then she opened the back door to let the dogs in.He ran away into the other and back to under the couch where it was safe.

source: mctest

There is a large tree in a park where all the kids in the neighborhood can hang out and play. The tree was planted in 1896 and has grown to over fifty feet tall with branches that were another thirty feet wide. Next to the tree is a jungle gym. The jungle gym has two slides, a fireman pole, a rock climbing wall, and much more. One day the kids in the neighborhood came up with the idea of building a tree house so they could spend all of their time at the park, even when it was raining outside. The children all went to their parents begging them to help and get wood. The families of the neighborhood began building the master tree house. Upon completion the tree house was ten by twelve feet high, with two windows, and plenty of space for the children to have fun. Every day during the summer that year the children played in the park and went in the tree house from sunrise to sunset every day. Fifteen years have gone by and the children are now too old to use the tree house. The tree house still sits on the tree but instead has a new group of kids that get to enjoy the house. Now the first kids have become parents and get to watch their idea live on and make the children of the neighborhood happy.


Q: Where is the tree?

A: in a park||There is a large tree in a park

Q: What year was the tree planted?

A: 1896||The tree was planted in 1896

Q: Does the tree house still exist?

A: yes||The tree house still sits on the tree

Q: How many years have gone by since the children started to play at the park?

A: Fifteen||Fifteen years have gone by

Q: How tall is the tree?

A: over fifty feet||The tree was planted in 1896 and has grown to over fifty feet tall

Q: What is thirty feet wide?

A: the branches||with branches that were another thirty feet wide.

Q: Where is the jungle gym located?

A: Next to the tree||Next to the tree is a jungle gym.

Q: During what season did the kids play in the park on a daily basis?

A: summer|| Every day during the summer that year the children played in the park

Q: Do the children still use the tree house?

A: No, Now the first kids have become parents and get to watch their idea live on||Now the first kids have become parents and get to watch their idea live on

Q: Why not?

A: They're parents now||Now the first kids have become parents

Q: Why did the kids come up with the idea of building the tree house?

A: so they could spend all of their time at the park,||One day the kids in the neighborhood came up with the idea of building a tree house so they could spend all of their time at the park,

Q: Could they still play at the park when it rained?

A: yes||One day the kids in the neighborhood came up with the idea of building a tree house so they could spend all of their time at the park, even when it was raining outside.

Q: Does the tree house have three windows?

A: no, Upon completion the tree house was ten by twelve feet high, with two windows, ||Upon completion the tree house was ten by twelve feet high, with two windows,

Q: Is the tree house spacious?

A: It was ten by twelve feet high,||the tree house was ten by twelve feet high,

Q: What did the children beg their parents to do?

A: to get wood.||The children all went to their parents begging them to help and get wood.

Q: How do the current neighborhood kids feel about the tree house?

A: happy||make the children of the neighborhood happy.


Summary: There is a large tree in a park where all the kids in the neighborhood can hang out and play.The tree was planted in 1896 and has grown to over fifty feet tall with branches that were another thirty feet wide.Next to the tree is a jungle gym.One day the kids in the neighborhood came up with the idea of building a tree house so they could spend all of their time at the park, even when it was raining outside.The children all went to their parents begging them to help and get wood.Upon completion the tree house was ten by twelve feet high, with two windows, and plenty of space for the children to have fun.Every day during the summer that year the children played in the park and went in the tree house from sunrise to sunset every day.Fifteen years have gone by and the children are now too old to use the tree house.The tree house still sits on the tree but instead has a new group of kids that get to enjoy the house.Now the first kids have become parents and get to watch their idea live on and make the children of the neighborhood happy.

source: mctest

Josie could hear the birds singing outside the classroom window. She could see some of them sitting on the branches of an apple tree. Mrs. Harper checked to see if everyone was present. Each child called out when they heard their name. She then asked for a volunteer to read a story about a family of grasshoppers. Many hands were raised but she picked Josie's friend, Mary. While Mary was reading the story, she got a tickle in her throat. She began to cough. Mrs. Harper told her to go get some water to drink and a boy named Henry finished the story. Next, Mrs. Harper showed the class a butterfly garden. Someone asked if butterflies ate other bugs. Mrs. Harper said that butterflies don't eat but only drink. Josie was chosen to pass out turkey sandwiches for lunch. Mrs. Harper went to the refrigerator. She got out some vanilla yoghurt for each of the boys and girls. All the students cheered.


Q: what did josie hear?

A: birds singing||Josie could hear the birds singing outside the classroom window.

Q: what kind of tree did he have?

A: apple tree||She could see some of them sitting on the branches of an apple tree

Q: what was the story about?

A: a family of grasshoppers||to read a story about a family of grasshoppers

Q: who's hand was chosen?

A: Mary||Many hands were raised but she picked Josie's friend, Mary

Q: was mary feeling well

A: no, While Mary was reading the story, she got a tickle in her throat. She began to cough||While Mary was reading the story, she got a tickle in her throat. She began to cough

Q: what did she feel in her throat?

A: a tickle||she got a tickle in her throat

Q: did she cough?

A: yes||She began to cough

Q: who finished the story?

A: Henry||a boy named Henry finished the story.

Q: what did mary do to help her throat?

A: drank water||old her to go get some water to drink

Q: do butterflies eat?

A: no, butterflies don't eat but only drink||butterflies don't eat but only drink

Q: what did they have for lunch?

A: turkey sandwiches||osie was chosen to pass out turkey sandwiches for lunch

Q: were the kids happy

A: yes||All the students cheered.

Q: why?

A: they were getting vanilla yoghurt||She got out some vanilla yoghurt for each of the boys and girls


Summary: Josie could hear the birds singing outside the classroom window.She could see some of them sitting on the branches of an apple tree.She then asked for a volunteer to read a story about a family of grasshoppers.Many hands were raised but she picked Josie's friend, Mary.While Mary was reading the story, she got a tickle in her throat.She began to cough.Mrs. Harper told her to go get some water to drink and a boy named Henry finished the story.Mrs. Harper said that butterflies don't eat but only drink.Josie was chosen to pass out turkey sandwiches for lunch.She got out some vanilla yoghurt for each of the boys and girls.All the students cheered.

source: cnn

BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- The Iraqi man who was jailed after throwing his shoes at then-President George W. Bush last year arrived in Syria on Tuesday night, hours after being released from prison, his employer said. Muntadhar al-Zaidi speaks to reporters shorlty after his release from an Iraqi jail. Al-Baghdadia TV said Muntadhar al-Zaidi had arrived in Damascus. Al-Zaidi's brother, Dhirgham al-Zaidi, told CNN that the 30-year-old journalist was to travel in a private plane to Greece for medical treatment. Shortly after he left prison, the 30-year-old journalist visited the studios of his employer, Al-Baghdadia TV, where he spoke to other reporters about his experience. He wore a sash in the colors of the Iraqi national flag draped around his shoulders. Muntadhar al-Zaidi said he was beaten with cables and pipes and tortured with electricity immediately after guards removed him from a news conference for hurling both shoes at Bush. He said he was taken into another room and beaten even as the news conference continued. However, he remained defiant about the incident that landed him in prison. "I got my chance, and I didn't miss it," he said. "I am not a hero, and I admit that," he added. "I am a person with a stance. I saw my country burning." Al-Zaidi, who was serving a one-year sentence after the jail-throwing incident December 14, was given a "conditional discharge." Under Iraqi law, a "conditional discharge" allows for the release of a prisoner after he serves three-quarters of his sentence, on good behavior. Watch more about al-Zaidi's release »

A: His shoes.||Iraqi man who was jailed after throwing his shoes

Q: What was his name?

A: Muntadhar al-Zaidi||Muntadhar al-Zaidi said he was beaten with cables and pipes and tortured with electricity immediately after guards removed him from a news conference for hurling both shoes at Bush.

Q: Was he arrested?

A: Yes.||The Iraqi man who was jailed

Q: Who did he throw his shoes at?

A: George W. Bush||throwing his shoes at then-President George W. Bush

Q: Is he still president?

A: No.||then-President George W. Bush

A: Yes||Muntadhar al-Zaidi speaks to reporters shorlty after his release from an Iraqi jail.

A: Damascus||Muntadhar al-Zaidi had arrived in Damascus

A: Unknown.||Al-Zaidi's brother, Dhirgham al-Zaidi

A: Greece.|| the 30-year-old journalist was to travel in a private plane to Greece for medical treatment.

A: In a private plane.|| the 30-year-old journalist was to travel in a private plane to Greece

A: One year.||Al-Zaidi, who was serving a one-year sentenc

A: No.||Al-Zaidi, who was serving a one-year sentence after the jail-throwing incident December 14, was given a "conditional discharge."

Q: Did he regret his choice?

A: No.||he remained defiant about the incident that landed him in prison.

Q: How many shoes did he throw?

A: Two.||hurling both shoes

Q: Why was he released early?

A: For good behavior.||a "conditional discharge" allows for the release of a prisoner after he serves three-quarters of his sentence, on good behavior.

Q: Does he consider himself a hero?

A: No.||I am not a hero


Summary: BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- The Iraqi man who was jailed after throwing his shoes at then-President George W. Bush last year arrived in Syria on Tuesday night, hours after being released from prison, his employer said.Muntadhar al-Zaidi speaks to reporters shorlty after his release from an Iraqi jail.Al-Baghdadia TV said Muntadhar al-Zaidi had arrived in Damascus.Al-Zaidi's brother, Dhirgham al-Zaidi, told CNN that the 30-year-old journalist was to travel in a private plane to Greece for medical treatment.Muntadhar al-Zaidi said he was beaten with cables and pipes and tortured with electricity immediately after guards removed him from a news conference for hurling both shoes at Bush.However, he remained defiant about the incident that landed him in prison."I am not a hero, and I admit that," he added.Al-Zaidi, who was serving a one-year sentence after the jail-throwing incident December 14, was given a "conditional discharge."Under Iraqi law, a "conditional discharge" allows for the release of a prisoner after he serves three-quarters of his sentence, on good behavior.

source: race

Bob was happy. He was at a new school, and students there were friendly. "Hi, Bob!" some students greeted him, but some students said, "Hi, Peter!" Bob didn't understand. He asked one student. "Why do some students call me Peter?" "Oh, that's easy to answer," the students said, "Peter was a student here last year. Now he is at a different school. You look like Peter. Some students thought that you were Peter." Bob wanted to meet Peter. He got Peter's address from a student and went to Peter's house. Peter opened the door. Bob couldn't believe his eyes. He looked really like Peter! Bob and Peter had the same color eyes and same smile. They had the same black hair. They also had the same birthday. And they both were adopted by two different families. Bob and Peter found out that they were twin brothers. Soon after the boys were born, one family adopted Bob, and another family adopted Peter. Bob's family never knew about Peter, and Peter's family never knew about Bob. Soon Bob and Peter's story appeared in the newspaper. There was a photo of Bob and Peter next to the story. A young man called John saw the photo in the newspaper. John couldn't believe his eyes. He looked like Bob and Peter! He had the same color eyes and the same smile. He had the same black hair. He had the same birthday. And he, too, was adopted by another family. Later John met Bob and Peter. When Bob and Peter saw John, they couldn't believe their eyes. John looked really like them! Why did John looked really like Bob and Peter? You can guess. Bob and Peter are not twins. Bob, Peter and John are triplets.


Q: Why was Bob happy?

A: He was at a new school, and students there were friendly.||He was at a new school, and students there were friendly.

Q: What did some students call Bob?

A: Peter||some students said, "Hi, Peter!"

Q: Why did they call him that?

A: He looked like Peter||Peter was a student here last year. Now he is at a different school. You look like Peter.

Q: What did Bob want to do?

A: Meet Peter||Bob wanted to meet Peter.

Q: Did he?

A: yes||He got Peter's address from a student and went to Peter's house.

Q: Did they look alike?

A: Yes||He looked really like Peter!

Q: How so?

A: Same color eyes and smile||Bob and Peter had the same color eyes and same smile.

Q: Anything else the same?

A: Same black hair||They had the same black hair.

Q: Anything else?

A: Same birthday||They also had the same birthday.

Q: Were they adopted?

A: yes||And they both were adopted by two different families.

Q: Did the two sets of parents know each other?

A: No, Bob's family never knew about Peter, and Peter's family never knew about Bob. ||Bob's family never knew about Peter, and Peter's family never knew about Bob.

Q: Were the boys related?

A: yes||Bob and Peter found out that they were twin brothers

Q: How?

A: They are twin brothers||Bob and Peter found out that they were twin brothers

Q: Did their story make the TV news?

A: No, Soon Bob and Peter's story appeared in the newspaper||Soon Bob and Peter's story appeared in the newspaper

Q: What kind of news did it make?

A: The newspaper||A young man called John saw the photo in the newspaper

Q: Was there one other person related to them?

A: yes||Bob, Peter and John are triplets.

Q: who

A: John||Bob, Peter and John are triplets.

Q: how did bob get peter's address?

A: From a student||He got Peter's address from a student


Summary: He was at a new school, and students there were friendly.some students greeted him, but some students said, "Hi, Peter!""Oh, that's easy to answer," the students said, "Peter was a student here last year.Bob wanted to meet Peter.He got Peter's address from a student and went to Peter's house.He looked really like Peter!Bob and Peter had the same color eyes and same smile.They had the same black hair.They also had the same birthday.And they both were adopted by two different families.Bob and Peter found out that they were twin brothers.Bob's family never knew about Peter, and Peter's family never knew about Bob.Soon Bob and Peter's story appeared in the newspaper.A young man called John saw the photo in the newspaper.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- Each year, Grammy Week offers up a full calendar of events -- each one boasting a guest list more spectacular than the next. But this year, the most coveted ticket was Friday night's "2013 MusiCares Person of the Year Tribute" honoring Bruce Springsteen. The evening's entertainment featured six Rock and Roll Hall of Famers, a few critically acclaimed young artists -- and The Boss himself. Neil Young and Crazy Horse turned up the volume with a spirited version of "Born in the U.S.A," flanked by a pair of cheerleaders with the letter "S" emblazoned on their sweaters. Colombian superstar Juanes put a bilingual spin on "Hungry Heart," singing verses in both Spanish and English, and John Legend transformed "Dancing in the Dark" into a jazzy piano ballad, which led Springsteen to later remark that "he made me sound like Gershwin. I love that." Other standout performances included Mumford & Sons' banjo-laced cover of "I'm on Fire," Tom Morello and Jim James' mesmerizing take on "The Ghost of Tom Joad," and country superstar Kenny Chesney's quietly effective rendition of "One Step Up." Elton John also opted for simplicity, accompanied only by his piano on "Streets of Philadelphia." But the most curious vocal of the night was on "Lonesome Day," where Sting exhibited a raspy growl that suggested he was looking to honor Springsteen by sounding like him. The evening was part all-star concert, part fundraiser to benefit the MusiCares Foundation, the Recording Academy's philanthropic arm that provides assistance to members of the music industry.


Q: Does Elton John like simplicity?

A: yes||opted for

Q: What was he joined by when he played Streets of Philadelphia?

A: his piano||his piano

Q: Anything else?

A: no, only||only

Q: Who had a raspy growl?

A: Sting||Sting

Q: Was there something unusual about that vocal?

A: yes||curious

Q: What song was he singing?

A: Lonesome Day||Lonesome Day

Q: Who was he probably trying to pay homage to?

A: yes||honor

Q: Were there a lot of stars at the concert?

A: yes||all-star

Q: Did it raise money as well?

A: yes||fundraiser

Q: For whose benefit?

A: MusiCares Foundation||MusiCares Foundation

Q: What association are they an arm of?

A: Recording Academy's philanthropic||Recording Academy's philanthropic

Q: Who do they provide assistance to?

A: members of the music industry||members of the music industry

Q: How many Rock and Roll hall of famers were there?

A: six||six

Q: Was The Boss himself present?

A: yes||himself

Q: Who really pumped up the volume?

A: Neil Young and Crazy Horse||Neil Young and Crazy Horse

Q: For which song?

A: Born in the U.S.A||Born in the U.S.A

Q: Was it energetic, or dull?

A: energetic||spirited

Q: Was Hungry Heart sung all in English?

A: no, Spanish ||Spanish

Q: What other language then?

A: Spanish||Spanish

Q: What song had some banjo happening in it?

A: "I'm on Fire||"I'm on Fire


Summary: The evening's entertainment featured six Rock and Roll Hall of Famers, a few critically acclaimed young artists -- and The Boss himself.Neil Young and Crazy Horse turned up the volume with a spirited version of "Born in the U.S.A," flanked by a pair of cheerleaders with the letter "S" emblazoned on their sweaters.Colombian superstar Juanes put a bilingual spin on "Hungry Heart," singing verses in both Spanish and English, and John Legend transformed "Dancing in the Dark" into a jazzy piano ballad, which led Springsteen to later remark that "he made me sound like Gershwin.Other standout performances included Mumford & Sons' banjo-laced cover of "I'm on Fire," Tom Morello and Jim James' mesmerizing take on "The Ghost of Tom Joad," and country superstar Kenny Chesney's quietly effective rendition of "One Step Up."Elton John also opted for simplicity, accompanied only by his piano on "Streets of Philadelphia."But the most curious vocal of the night was on "Lonesome Day," where Sting exhibited a raspy growl that suggested he was looking to honor Springsteen by sounding like him.The evening was part all-star concert, part fundraiser to benefit the MusiCares Foundation, the Recording Academy's philanthropic arm that provides assistance to members of the music industry.

source: cnn

Tehran, Iran (CNN) -- A nuclear scientist was killed in a blast in Tehran on Wednesday morning, an Iranian news agency reported, in the latest in a string of attacks that Iran has blamed on Israel. A motorcyclist placed a magnetic bomb under Mostafa Ahmadi Roshan's Peugeot 405, the state-run IRNA news agency said. The blast also wounded two others, IRNA said. State television channel Press TV reported later Wednesday that Roshan's driver, Reza Qashqaei, had died in a hospital from his injuries. Mohammad Khazaee, Iranian ambassador to the United Nations, condemned what he called "cruel, inhumane and criminal acts of terrorism against the Iranian scientists." "Based on the existing evidence collected by the relevant Iranian security authorities, similar to previous incidents, perpetrators used the same terrorist method in assassinating Iranian nuclear scientists, i.e., attaching a sticky magnetic bomb to the car carrying the scientists and detonating it," Khazaee said in a statement. "I would like to emphasize, once again, that the Islamic Republic (of) Iran would not compromise over its inalienable right to use nuclear energy for peaceful purposes and any kind of political and economic pressures or terrorist attacks targeting the Iranian nuclear scientists, could not prevent our nation in exercising this right," Khazaee said. Lawmaker Kazem Jalali blamed the intelligence agencies of the United States and Israel for the latest attack, saying the United Nations' nuclear watchdog, the International Atomic Energy Agency, also bore responsibility for passing on information about Iran's nuclear scientists to other countries, IRNA reports.


Q: what kind of bomb was used?

A: magnetic bomb||magnetic bomb

Q: who was killed?

A: Mostafa Ahmadi Roshan||Mostafa Ahmadi Roshan

Q: what was his job?

A: nuclear scientist||nuclear scientist

Q: who else died?

A: Roshan's driver||Roshan's driver

Q: what was his name?

A: Reza Qashqaei||Reza Qashqaei

Q: where did this take place?

A: Tehran||Tehran

Q: in what country?

A: Iran||Iran

Q: what kind of vehicle exploded?

A: Peugeot 405||Peugeot 405

Q: who reported that?

A: IRNA||IRNA

Q: what day did this all take place?

A: Wednesday||Wednesday

Q: who blamed US intelligence agencies?

A: Kazem Jalali||Kazem Jalali

Q: did he blame Israel too?

A: Yes||Israel

Q: who else bore responsibility

A: International Atomic Energy Agency||International Atomic Energy Agency


Summary: Tehran, Iran (CNN) -- A nuclear scientist was killed in a blast in Tehran on Wednesday morning, an Iranian news agency reported, in the latest in a string of attacks that Iran has blamed on Israel.A motorcyclist placed a magnetic bomb under Mostafa Ahmadi Roshan's Peugeot 405, the state-run IRNA news agency said.The blast also wounded two others, IRNA said.State television channel Press TV reported later Wednesday that Roshan's driver, Reza Qashqaei, had died in a hospital from his injuries.Lawmaker Kazem Jalali blamed the intelligence agencies of the United States and Israel for the latest attack, saying the United Nations' nuclear watchdog, the International Atomic Energy Agency, also bore responsibility for passing on information about Iran's nuclear scientists to other countries, IRNA reports.
