source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XII The crowd fell back, leaving a lane down which Walter walked, carrying the apple. There was dead silence as he passed. Then the people began to whisper excitedly to one another. "Shall this be done before our eyes?" said Arnold of Melchthal to Werner Stauffacher. "Of what use was it that we swore an oath to rebel if we permit this? Let us rise and slay the tyrant." Werner Stauffacher, prudent man, scratched his chin thoughtfully. "We-e-ll," he said, "you see, the difficulty is that we are not armed and the soldiers _are_. There is nothing I should enjoy more than slaying the tyrant, only I have an idea that the tyrant would slay us. You see my point?" "Why were we so slow!" groaned Arnold. "We should have risen before, and then this would never have happened. Who was it that advised us to delay?" "We-e-ll," said Stauffacher (who had himself advised delay), "I can't quite remember at the moment, but I dare say you could find out by looking up the minutes of our last meeting. I know the motion was carried by a majority of two votes. See! Gessler grows impatient." Gessler, who had been fidgeting on his horse for some time, now spoke again, urging Tell to hurry. "Begin!" he cried--"begin!" "Immediately," replied Tell, fitting the arrow to the string. Gessler began to mock him once more. "You see now," he said, "the danger of carrying arms. I don't know if you have ever noticed it, but arrows very often recoil on the man who carries them. The only man who has any business to possess a weapon is the ruler of a country--myself, for instance. A low, common fellow--if you will excuse the description--like yourself only grows proud through being armed, and so offends those above him. But, of course, it's no business of mine. I am only telling you what I think about it. Personally, I like to encourage my subjects to shoot; that is why I am giving you such a splendid mark to shoot at. You see, Tell?"


Q: who itched their chin?

A: Werner Stauffacher,||Werner Stauffacher, prudent man, scratched his chin thoughtfully.

Q: who is armed?

A: the soldiers||the difficulty is that we are not armed and the soldiers _are_

Q: was there an animal present?

A: yes||Gessler, who had been fidgeting on his horse f

Q: what animal?

A: his horse||his horse

Q: was Walter holding anything?

A: yes|| Walter walked, carrying the apple

Q: what?

A: the apple||Walter walked, carrying the apple

Q: who was going to be slayed?

A: the tyrant."||slay the tyrant."

Q: who recommended the delay?

A: Stauffacher||Stauffacher (who had himself advised delay)

Q: how many voted for it?

A: it was carried by a majority of two votes|| I know the motion was carried by a majority of two votes. See! Gessler grows impatient."

Q: where was it voted upon?

A: at the last meeting.|| looking up the minutes of our last meeting. I

Q: who held the arrow

A: Tell||Immediately," replied Tell, fitting the arrow to the string.

Q: did they ever shoot it?

A: No, Immediately," replied Tell, fitting the arrow to the string. Gessler began to mock him once more. "You see now," he said, "the danger of carrying arms. I don't know if you have ever noticed it, but arrows very often recoil on the man who carries them. The only man who has any business to possess a weapon is the ruler of a country--myself, for instance. A low, common fellow--if you will excuse the description--like yourself only grows proud through being armed, and so offends those above him. But, of course, it's no business of mine. I am only telling you what I think about it. Personally, I like to encourage my subjects to shoot; that is why I am giving you such a splendid mark to shoot at. You see, Tell?"||Immediately," replied Tell, fitting the arrow to the string. Gessler began to mock him once more. "You see now," he said, "the danger of carrying arms. I don't know if you have ever noticed it, but arrows very often recoil on the man who carries them. The only man who has any business to possess a weapon is the ruler of a country--myself, for instance. A low, common fellow--if you will excuse the description--like yourself only grows proud through being armed, and so offends those above him. But, of course, it's no business of mine. I am only telling you what I think about it. Personally, I like to encourage my subjects to shoot; that is why I am giving you such a splendid mark to shoot at. You see, Tell?"


Summary: CHAPTER XII The crowd fell back, leaving a lane down which Walter walked, carrying the apple.Let us rise and slay the tyrant."Werner Stauffacher, prudent man, scratched his chin thoughtfully."We-e-ll," he said, "you see, the difficulty is that we are not armed and the soldiers _are_."We-e-ll," said Stauffacher (who had himself advised delay), "I can't quite remember at the moment, but I dare say you could find out by looking up the minutes of our last meeting.I know the motion was carried by a majority of two votes.Gessler, who had been fidgeting on his horse for some time, now spoke again, urging Tell to hurry."Immediately," replied Tell, fitting the arrow to the string.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Argentina is subdivided into twenty-three provinces (, singular "provincia") and one autonomous city ("ciudad autónoma"), Buenos Aires, which is the federal capital of the nation () as decided by Congress. The provinces and the capital have their own constitutions, but exist under a federal system. During the War of Independence the main cities and their surrounding countrysides became provinces though the intervention of their "cabildos". The Anarchy of the Year XX completed this process, shaping the original thirteen provinces. Jujuy seceded from Salta in 1834, and the thirteen provinces became fourteen. After seceding for a decade, Buenos Aires Province accepted the 1853 Constitution of Argentina in 1861, and its capital city was made a federal territory in 1880. A law from 1862 designated as national territories those under federal control but outside the frontiers of the provinces. In 1884 they served as bases for the establishment of the governorates of Misiones, Formosa, Chaco, La Pampa, Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, Santa Cruz and Tierra del Fuego. The agreement about a frontier dispute with Chile in 1900 created the National Territory of Los Andes; its lands were incorporated into Jujuy, Salta and Catamarca in 1943. La Pampa and Chaco became provinces in 1951. Misiones did so in 1953, and Formosa, Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut and Santa Cruz, in 1955. The last national territory, Tierra del Fuego, became the Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province in 1990.


Q: what created the National Territory of Los Andes?

A: The agreement about a frontier dispute with Chile|| The agreement about a frontier dispute with Chile in 1900 created the National Territory of Los Andes

Q: what year did that happen?

A: 1900||The agreement about a frontier dispute with Chile in 1900 created the National Territory of Los Andes

Q: when did the last territory become a province?

A: 1990||The last national territory, Tierra del Fuego, became the Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province in 1990

Q: what is the full name of that territory?

A: Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province||The last national territory, Tierra del Fuego, became the Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province

Q: how many provinces are there in Argentina?

A: twenty-three||Argentina is subdivided into twenty-three provinces

Q: do they all have their own constitution?

A: yes||The provinces and the capital have their own constitutions

Q: how many autonomous cities are there?

A: one||one autonomous city

Q: which one?

A: Buenos Aires|| one autonomous city ("ciudad autónoma"), Buenos Aires

Q: is that the capital of the country?

A: yes||Buenos Aires, which is the federal capital of the nation

Q: in 1862 what were declared as territories?

A: those under federal control but outside the frontiers of the provinces.||A law from 1862 designated as national territories those under federal control but outside the frontiers of the provinces.

Q: what are a few examples?

A: Misiones, Formosa, Chaco, La Pampa, Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, Santa Cruz and Tierra del Fuego||ey served as bases for the establishment of the governorates of Misiones, Formosa, Chaco, La Pampa, Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, Santa Cruz and Tierra del Fuego

Q: what shaped the original 13 provinces?

A: The Anarchy of the Year XX||The Anarchy of the Year XX completed this process, shaping the original thirteen provinces

Q: who seceded from Salta?

A: Jujuy||Jujuy seceded from Salta

Q: what did it then become?

A: a province||Jujuy seceded from Salta in 1834, and the thirteen provinces became fourteen

Q: what year did that happen?

A: 1834||Jujuy seceded from Salta in 1834

Q: when did Buenos Aires accept the constitution of Argentina?

A: 1861||Buenos Aires Province accepted the 1853 Constitution of Argentina in 1861

Q: what happened in 1880?

A: it was made a federal territory in 1880||its capital city was made a federal territory in 1880


Summary: Argentina is subdivided into twenty-three provinces (, singular "provincia") and one autonomous city ("ciudad autónoma"), Buenos Aires, which is the federal capital of the nation () as decided by Congress.The provinces and the capital have their own constitutions, but exist under a federal system.The Anarchy of the Year XX completed this process, shaping the original thirteen provinces.Jujuy seceded from Salta in 1834, and the thirteen provinces became fourteen.After seceding for a decade, Buenos Aires Province accepted the 1853 Constitution of Argentina in 1861, and its capital city was made a federal territory in 1880.A law from 1862 designated as national territories those under federal control but outside the frontiers of the provinces.In 1884 they served as bases for the establishment of the governorates of Misiones, Formosa, Chaco, La Pampa, Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, Santa Cruz and Tierra del Fuego.The agreement about a frontier dispute with Chile in 1900 created the National Territory of Los Andes; its lands were incorporated into Jujuy, Salta and Catamarca in 1943.The last national territory, Tierra del Fuego, became the Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province in 1990.

source: mctest

There once was a little old lady who had no friends. She rode her bike to and from the store and didn't say hello to anyone along the way. One day she saw a little girl crying in the street. No one else was around to take care of the girl so the little old lady stopped her bike and asked the girl, "What is wrong, Dear?" The little girl said, "I hurt my knee when I fell down!" "Oh dear!" cried the little old lady and bent down and looked at the girl's knee. "It looks to me like you have a scrape," she said. The little girl cried and the little old lady said, "Don't worry, all boo-boos hurt a little but it's the medicine that makes it go away." The little old lady bent down and blew on the girl's knee and whispered, "Go away, go away, no boo-boos here today!" The little girl smiled and that little old lady found her first friend.


Q: Who was antosocial at first?

A: the old lady||old lady who had no friends.

Q: WHo did she find?

A: a little girl||One day she saw a little girl

Q: Where her parents around?

A: No one else was around to take care of the girl||No one else was around to take care of the girl

Q: Was she ok?

A: no, One day she saw a little girl crying||One day she saw a little girl crying

Q: How badly was she hurt?

A: no, It looks to me like you have a scrape||It looks to me like you have a scrape

Q: How did the woman help her?

A: she blew on her knee||blew on the girl's knee

Q: What else did she do?

A: whispered||whispered, "Go away, go away, no boo-boos here today!

Q: WHat happened then?

A: the girll smiled||he little girl smiled

Q: Did she like the woman who helped?

A: yes||that little old lady found her first friend

Q: How many friends she have now?

A: one||old lady found her first friend


Summary: There once was a little old lady who had no friends.One day she saw a little girl crying in the street.No one else was around to take care of the girl so the little old lady stopped her bike and asked the girl, "What is wrong, Dear?""It looks to me like you have a scrape," she said.The little old lady bent down and blew on the girl's knee and whispered, "Go away, go away, no boo-boos here today!"The little girl smiled and that little old lady found her first friend.

source: race

Steven Spielberg was not a scholar, and his classmates teased him. Rather than read, the kid really preferred running around with an 8mm camera, shooting homemade movies, which he showed to friends for a small fee. In his first year of high school, he dropped out. But when his parents persuaded him to return, he was mistakenly placed in a learningdisabled class, which lasted one month. Only when the family moved to another town did he land up in a more suitable high school, where he eventually graduated. After being denied entrance into a traditional filmmaking school, Steven Spielherg enrolled in English at California State University at Long Beach. Then in 1965, he recalls, in one of those serendipitous moments, his life took a complete turn. Visiting Universal Studios, he met Chuck Silvers, an executive in the editorial department. Silvers liked the kid who made 8mm films and invited him back sometime to visit. He appeared the next day. Spielberg, dressed in a dark suit, carrying his father's briefcase with nothing inside but a sandwich and candy bars walked confidently up to the guard at the gate of Universal and gave him a casual wave. The guard waved back. He was in. "For the entire summer," Spielberg remembers, "I dressed in my suit and hung out with the directors and writers, including Silvers, who knew the kid wasn't a studio employee, but winked at him. I even found an office that wasn't being used, and became a squatter . I bought some plastic tiles and put my name in the building directory: Steven Spielberg, Room 23C." It paid off for everyone. Ten years later, the 28yearold Spielberg directed Jaws, which took in $470 million, then the biggest grossing movie of all time. Dozens of films and awards have followed because Steven Spielberg knew what his teachers didn't--talent is in the eyes of the filmmaker.


Q: Was Steven Spielberg a scholar

A: No, Steven Spielberg was not a scholar||Steven Spielberg was not a scholar

Q: What did his classmates do to him

A: teased him||Steven Spielberg was not a scholar, and his classmates teased him

Q: What did he prefer to do?

A: shooting homemade movies|| the kid really preferred running around with an 8mm camera, shooting homemade movies

Q: What did he do in highschool?

A: In his first year he dropped out.||In his first year of high school, he dropped out.

Q: Did he go back?

A: Yes||Only when the family moved to another town did he land up in a more suitable high school, where he eventually graduated.

Q: Did he graduate?

A: Yes|| he eventually graduated.

Q: What did he enroll in?

A: English||Steven Spielherg enrolled in English at California State University at Long Beach.

Q: At a university?

A: Yes||Steven Spielherg enrolled in English at California State University at Long Beach.

Q: Which one?

A: California State University at Long Beach.||Steven Spielherg enrolled in English at California State University at Long Beach.

Q: Did he visit Universal Studios?

A: Yes||Visiting Universal Studios

Q: When?

A: 1965||in 1965, he recalls, in one of those serendipitous moments, his life took a complete turn. Visiting Universal Studios,

Q: Who did he meet?

A: Chuck Silvers||Visiting Universal Studios, he met Chuck Silvers

Q: Did he like him?

A: Silvers liked the kid||Silvers liked the kid

A: invited him back to visit.||invited him back sometime to visit.

Summary: Steven Spielberg was not a scholar, and his classmates teased him.Rather than read, the kid really preferred running around with an 8mm camera, shooting homemade movies, which he showed to friends for a small fee.In his first year of high school, he dropped out.Only when the family moved to another town did he land up in a more suitable high school, where he eventually graduated.After being denied entrance into a traditional filmmaking school, Steven Spielherg enrolled in English at California State University at Long Beach.Then in 1965, he recalls, in one of those serendipitous moments, his life took a complete turn.Visiting Universal Studios, he met Chuck Silvers, an executive in the editorial department.Silvers liked the kid who made 8mm films and invited him back sometime to visit.Spielberg, dressed in a dark suit, carrying his father's briefcase with nothing inside but a sandwich and candy bars walked confidently up to the guard at the gate of Universal and gave him a casual wave."For the entire summer," Spielberg remembers, "I dressed in my suit and hung out with the directors and writers, including Silvers, who knew the kid wasn't a studio employee, but winked at him.Ten years later, the 28yearold Spielberg directed Jaws, which took in $470 million, then the biggest grossing movie of all time.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: race

Most people know precious gemstones by their appearances. An emerald flashes deep green, a ruby seems to hold a red fire inside, and a diamond shines like a star. It's more difficult to tell where the gem was mined, since a diamond from Australia or Arkansas may appear the same to one from the Democratic Republic of the Congo. However, recently, a team of scientists has found a way to identify a gemstone's origin. Beneath the surface of a gemstone, on the tiny level of atoms and molecules , lie clues to its origin. At this year's meeting of the Geological Society of America in Minneapolis, Catherine McManus reported on a technique that uses lasers to clarify these clues and identify a stone's homeland. McManus directs scientific research at Materialytics, in Killeen, Texas. The company is developing the technique. "With enough data, we could identify which country, which mining place, even the individual mine a gemstone comes from," McManus told Science News. Some gemstones, including many diamonds, come from war-torn countries. Sales of those "blood minerals" may encourage violent civil wars where innocent people are injured or killed. In an effort to reduce the trade in blood minerals, the U.S. government passed law in July 2010 that requires companies that sell gemstones to determine the origins of their stones. To figure out where gemstones come from, McManus and her team focus a powerful laser on a small sample of the gemstone. The technique is called laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy. Just as heat can turn ice into water or water into steam, energy from the laser changes the state of matter of the stone. The laser changes a miniscule part of the gemstone into plasma, a gas state of matter in which tiny particles called electrons separate from atoms. The plasma, which is superhot, produces a light pattern. (The science of analyzing this kind of light pattern is called spectroscopy.) Different elements produce different patterns, but McManus and her team say that gemstones from the same area produce similar patterns. Materialytics has already collected patterns from thousands of gemstones, including more than 200 from diamonds. They can compare the light pattern from an unknown gemstone to patterns they do know and look for a match. The light pattern acts like a signature, telling the researchers the origin of the gemstone. In a small test, the laser technique correctly identified the origins of 95 out of every 100 diamonds. For gemstones like emeralds and rubies, the technique proved successful for 98 out of every 100 stones. The scientists need to collect and analyze more samples, including those from war-torn countries, before the tool is ready for commercial use. Scientists like Barbara Dutrow, a mineralogist from Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge, find the technique exciting. "This is a basic new tool that could provide a better fingerprint of a material from a particular locality," she told Science News.


Q: Has a team of scientists found a way to identify a gemstone's origin?

A: Yes||. However, recently, a team of scientists has found a way to identify a gemstone's origin.

Q: Where lie clues to a gemstone's origin?

A: Beneath the surface of a gemstone||Beneath the surface of a gemstone, on the tiny level of atoms and molecules

Q: Who reported on a technique that uses lasers to clarify these clues?

A: Catherine McManus||Catherine McManus reported

Q: Where?

A: At the Geological Society of America||. At this year's meeting of the Geological Society of America in Minneapolis, Catherine McManus reported

Q: in what city?

A: Minneapolis||Geological Society of America in Minneapolis,

Q: What is McManus' job?

A: Director of Scientific Research||cManus directs scientific research at Materialytics, in Killeen, Texas.

Q: for which company?

A: Materialytics||McManus directs scientific research at Materialytics, in Killeen, Texas.

Q: located where?

A: in Killeen||in Killeen, Texas.

Q: in which state?

A: Texas||McManus directs scientific research at Materialytics, in Killeen, Texas.

Q: Do many diamonds come from war-torn countries?

A: Yes||Some gemstones, including many diamonds, come from war-torn countries.

Q: What happens to innocent people in those countries?

A: injured||may encourage violent civil wars where innocent people are injured or killed

Q: What else?

A: killed||Sales of those "blood minerals" may encourage violent civil wars where innocent people are injured or killed

Q: What did the US government do to stop this?

A: Passed a law|| In an effort to reduce the trade in blood minerals, the U.S. government passed law in July 2010 that requires companies that sell gemstones to determine the origins of their stones.

Q: What did the law do?

A: Requires companies that sell gemstones to determine the origins of their stones|| the U.S. government passed law in July 2010 that requires companies that sell gemstones to determine the origins of their stones.

Q: How does McManus determine where a gemstone came from?

A: With a laser||McManus and her team focus a powerful laser on a small sample of the gemstone.

Q: What is the process called?

A: spectroscopy|| The technique is called laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy.

Q: What does the laser change a part of the gemstone to?

A: plasma||scule part of the gemstone into plasma,

Q: What is that?

A: a gas state of matter||a gas state of matter in which tiny particles called electrons separate from atoms.

Q: Is the plasma supercold?

A: No, The plasma, which is superhot, produces a light pattern.||The plasma, which is superhot, produces a light pattern.

Q: What does the plasma produce?

A: a light pattern|| produces a light pattern.


Summary: However, recently, a team of scientists has found a way to identify a gemstone's origin.Beneath the surface of a gemstone, on the tiny level of atoms and molecules , lie clues to its origin.At this year's meeting of the Geological Society of America in Minneapolis, Catherine McManus reported on a technique that uses lasers to clarify these clues and identify a stone's homeland.McManus directs scientific research at Materialytics, in Killeen, Texas.Some gemstones, including many diamonds, come from war-torn countries.Sales of those "blood minerals" may encourage violent civil wars where innocent people are injured or killed.In an effort to reduce the trade in blood minerals, the U.S. government passed law in July 2010 that requires companies that sell gemstones to determine the origins of their stones.To figure out where gemstones come from, McManus and her team focus a powerful laser on a small sample of the gemstone.The technique is called laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy.The laser changes a miniscule part of the gemstone into plasma, a gas state of matter in which tiny particles called electrons separate from atoms.The plasma, which is superhot, produces a light pattern.

source: mctest

Jenny loves singing. But her baby sister is crying so loud that Jenny can't hear herself, so she was angry! Her Mom said she could try to play with her sister, but that only made her baby sister cry louder. Jenny tried to ask the baby to stop crying, but that didn't work. Jenny was getting tired, but she had an idea. She would give her baby sister one of her toy horses. The baby loved horses! The baby played with the horse, but then she started crying again. This made Jenny sad. She wanted to sing! Then she had a great idea. She would give the baby a pacifier! This worked. The baby stopped crying and Jenny started singing. Everyone was so happy!


Q: Who loves singing?

A: Jenny.||Jenny loves singing

Q: How is she feeling?

A: Angry.||she was angry

Q: Why?

A: Because her baby sister is crying so loud that Jenny can't hear herself.||But her baby sister is crying so loud that Jenny can't hear herself, so she was angry!

Q: How did she ultimately solve that?

A: She gave the baby a pacifier.||She would give the baby a pacifier! This worked. The baby stopped crying and Jenny started singing

Q: What did she try just before that?

A: She gave her a toy horse.||She would give her baby sister one of her toy horses.

Q: And what was the first thing she tried?

A: She played with her.||Her Mom said she could try to play with her sister, but that only made her baby sister cry louder.

Q: What happened when the baby stopped crying?

A: She started singing.|| The baby stopped crying and Jenny started singing.

Q: How did everyone feel then?

A: Happy.||The baby stopped crying and Jenny started singing. Everyone was so happy!

Q: Does Jenny have a sister?

A: Yes.||But her baby sister is crying so loud that Jenny can't hear herself, so she was angry!

Q: Is Jenny older or younger?

A: Older.||But her baby sister is crying so loud that Jenny can't hear herself, so she was angry!


Summary: Jenny loves singing.But her baby sister is crying so loud that Jenny can't hear herself, so she was angry!Her Mom said she could try to play with her sister, but that only made her baby sister cry louder.She would give her baby sister one of her toy horses.She would give the baby a pacifier!The baby stopped crying and Jenny started singing.

A boy named Eduardo in a far away place is thinking about a girl he loves. He is cold. It is snowing where he lives. He lives in Argentina. It's warm where she lives in Hawaii. She eats fresh fruit. Her shower is outdoors under the warm sun as red birds fly around her. It is nice, but she misses him. She remembers he is very pretty. She wondered if he would really love her always, because she is older. He didn't care. Eduardo was poor, so he could not visit her. Maybe a time machine would help!! She can give back her birthdays! But she didn't want to bring back any dinosaurs back by accident. Like last time. Then an angel flew down from a star called the Pleiades to help her. His name was Eh. He said, "close your eyes! Then remember the most happy you have ever felt! Let go of any thing that feels like clouds. Imagine puppies hugging you, and kitties purring with you. Imagine you are eating chocolate ice cream! As long as you remember how to be happy you can ALWAYS be as young as Eduardo! And you can think of GREAT ways you can see him again!" It worked! She had an idea. Someone in a place called MR was buying stories that people wrote. She wrote one about her & Eduardo! It paid for her airplane ride. Wow. Then they were together again. Hugging each other in happiness, they said, "Thank you everyone, for helping us!"

source: mctest

Tom had to fix some things around the house. He had to fix the door. He had to fix the window. But before he did anything he had to fix the toilet. Tom called over his best friend Jim to help him. Jim brought with him his friends Molly and Holly. Tom thought that Jim was going to bring Dolly with him but he didn't. The four of them got to work right away. Fixing the toilet was easy. Fixing the door was also easy but fixing the window was very hard. The window was stuck and could not be opened. They all pushed on the window really hard until finally it opened. Once the window was fixed the four of them made a delicious dinner and talked about all of the good work that they had done. Tom was glad that he had such good friends to help him with his work.


Q: How many things needed reparing?

A: 3 things.||He had to fix the door. He had to fix the window. But before he did anything he had to fix the toilet

A: The door, window, and toilet.||He had to fix the door. He had to fix the window. But before he did anything he had to fix the toilet

A: In the house.||had to fix some things around the house

A: Jim.||Tom called over his best friend Jim to help him.

Q: did he assist?

A: Yes.||im brought with him his friends Molly and Holly. Tom thought that Jim was going to bring Dolly with him but he didn't. The four of them got to work right away.

Q: did anyone else assist?

A: Yes.|| brought with him his friends Molly and Holly. Tom thought that Jim was going to bring Dolly with him but he didn't. The four of them got to work right away.

Q: who?

A: Molly and Holly|| him his friends Molly and Holly. Tom thought that Jim was going to bring Dolly with him but he didn't. The four of them got to work right away

Q: what was difficult to repair?

A: The window.|| but fixing the window was very hard.

Q: why?

A: It was stuck and wouldn't open.||as very hard. The window was stuck and could not be opened.

Q: After completing the repairs what did everyone do?

A: Made dinner.||fixed the four of them made a delicious dinner and talked about all of the good work that they had done

Q: and?

A: Talked.||and talked about all of the good work that they had done

A: all the good work they've done.||talked about all of the good work that they had done.

A: Dolly.||Tom thought that Jim was going to bring Dolly with him but he didn't


Summary: Tom had to fix some things around the house.He had to fix the door.Tom called over his best friend Jim to help him.Jim brought with him his friends Molly and Holly.Tom thought that Jim was going to bring Dolly with him but he didn't.Fixing the door was also easy but fixing the window was very hard.Once the window was fixed the four of them made a delicious dinner and talked about all of the good work that they had done.

source: wikipedia

Telephone numbers in the United Kingdom are administered by the UK government's Office of Communications (Ofcom). For this purpose Ofcom established a telephone numbering plan, known as the "National Telephone Numbering Plan", which is the system for assigning telephone numbers to subscriber stations. Since 28 April 2001, almost all geographic numbers and most non-geographic numbers have 9 or 10 national (significant) numbers after the "0" trunk code. All mobile telephone numbers have 10 national (significant) numbers after the "0" trunk code. The overall structure of the UK's National Numbering Plan is: A short sample of geographic numbers, set out in the officially approved (Ofcom) number groups: In the United Kingdom, area codes are two, three, four, or, rarely, five digits long (after the initial zero). Regions with shorter area codes, typically large cities, permit the allocation of more telephone numbers as the local number portion has more digits. Local customer numbers are four to eight figures long. The total number of digits is ten, but in a very few areas the total may be nine digits (after the initial zero). The "area code" is also referred to as an "STD (code)" (subscriber trunk dialling) or a "dialling code" in the UK.


Q: Who is responsible for phone numbers in the UK?

A: the UK government's Office of Communications||Telephone numbers in the United Kingdom are administered by the UK government's Office of Communications (Ofcom

Q: How is the office's name abbreviated?

A: Ofcom||K government's Office of Communications (Ofcom

Q: What did they establish to assign numbers?

A: the "National Telephone Numbering Plan",||"National Telephone Numbering Plan", which is the system for assigning telephone numbers to subscriber stations

Q: What is the first digit in UK phone numbers?

A: 0|| almost all geographic numbers and most non-geographic numbers have 9 or 10 national (significant) numbers after the "0" trunk code

Q: What's this called?

A: a trunk code|| "0" trunk code

Q: How many digits follow it?

A: 9 or 10 (significant) numbers|| numbers have 9 or 10 national (significant) numbers after the "0" trunk code

Q: How many for mobile phones?

A: 10||mobile telephone numbers have 10

Q: What is the overall structure of the plan?

A: A short sample of geographic numbers, set out in the officially approved (Ofcom) number groups||The overall structure of the UK's National Numbering Plan is: A short sample of geographic numbers, set out in the officially approved (Ofcom) number groups

Q: How long are area codes?

A: from two to 5 digits||In the United Kingdom, area codes are two, three, four, or, rarely, five digits long (after the initial zero)

Q: Where are shorter ones usually found?

A: large cities||shorter area codes, typically large cities

Q: What do they have more of?

A: telephone numbers||Regions with shorter area codes, typically large cities, permit the allocation of more telephone numbers

Q: How long are local customer numbers?

A: four to eight figures long|| Local customer numbers are four to eight figures long

Q: How long is the total amount of digits?

A: generally ten||The total number of digits is ten

Q: Is it ever different?

A: Yes||but in a very few areas the total may be nine digits

Q: What's another term for the area code?

A: STD code||"area code" is also referred to as an "STD (code)

Q: Any others?

A: Yes||"area code" is also referred to as an "STD (code)" (subscriber trunk dialling) or a "dialling code"

Q: What?

A: a "dialling code"||"area code" is also referred to as an "STD (code)" (subscriber trunk dialling) or a "dialling code"

Q: Since what date has this system been in place?

A: 28 April 2001|| Since 28 April 2001, almost all geographic numbers and most non-geographic numbers have 9 or 10


Summary: Telephone numbers in the United Kingdom are administered by the UK government's Office of Communications (Ofcom).For this purpose Ofcom established a telephone numbering plan, known as the "National Telephone Numbering Plan", which is the system for assigning telephone numbers to subscriber stations.Since 28 April 2001, almost all geographic numbers and most non-geographic numbers have 9 or 10 national (significant) numbers after the "0" trunk code.All mobile telephone numbers have 10 national (significant) numbers after the "0" trunk code.The overall structure of the UK's National Numbering Plan is: A short sample of geographic numbers, set out in the officially approved (Ofcom) number groups: In the United Kingdom, area codes are two, three, four, or, rarely, five digits long (after the initial zero).Regions with shorter area codes, typically large cities, permit the allocation of more telephone numbers as the local number portion has more digits.Local customer numbers are four to eight figures long.The total number of digits is ten, but in a very few areas the total may be nine digits (after the initial zero).The "area code" is also referred to as an "STD (code)" (subscriber trunk dialling) or a "dialling code" in the UK.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: gutenberg

CHAPTER V AT OAK HALL ONCE MORE "Hurrah! here we are at Oakdale at last!" "Old town looks natural, doesn't it?" "So it does, Roger. See any of the fellows?" "Not yet, Dave. But we are sure to meet somebody, even if it is a school-day," went on the senator's son. "Uncle Dunston, let me take the auto around to the hotel," said our hero. "I know the streets better than you do. We have to make several turns." "All right, Dave," was the ready answer, and Dunston Porter arose and allowed his nephew to crowd into the driver's seat. The run to the town in the vicinity of which Oak Hall was located had been made without further incident. On the way the party had talked over Mrs. Breen's affairs, and Dunston Porter had promised to take the matter up, through his lawyer. "I think it best that our names don't appear in the case," said he. "Otherwise, Mr. Haskers might not treat you so well during the term." "He never treats us well, anyway," grumbled Phil. "But you are right, don't mention our names." On this late winter day the town looked rather dreary, but the young folks were in high spirits, and Dave, with a grand flourish, ran the car up to one of the best hotels the place afforded. As before, word had been sent ahead that they were coming, and the host of the resort came out to meet them. "We'll have dinner ready inside of quarter of an hour," he said. "Come in and make yourselves at home."


Q: Where are they?

A: at Oakdale|| "Hurrah! here we are at Oakdale at last!"

Q: Are they excited?

A: yes||"Hurrah! here we are at Oakdale at last!"

Q: Who are they looking for?

A: the fellows||"So it does, Roger. See any of the fellows?"

Q: Do they see them?

A: no, "Not yet, Dave. But we are sure to meet somebody,||"Not yet, Dave. But we are sure to meet somebody,

Q: Where do they want to take the car?

A: to the hotel||"Uncle Dunston, let me take the auto around to the hotel,"

Q: Who does he ask this?

A: Uncle Dunston||"Uncle Dunston, let me take the auto around to the hotel,"

Q: Why?

A: Because Dave knew the streets better||"Uncle Dunston, let me take the auto around to the hotel," said our hero. "I know the streets better than you do.

Q: Is it a straight drive?

A: no, We have to make several turns." || We have to make several turns."

Q: Do they switch seats?

A: yes||"All right, Dave," was the ready answer, and Dunston Porter arose and allowed his nephew to crowd into the driver's seat.

Q: How did the drive go?

A: without further incident||The run to the town in the vicinity of which Oak Hall was located had been made without further incident.


Summary: CHAPTER V AT OAK HALL ONCE MORE "Hurrah!"So it does, Roger."Not yet, Dave."Uncle Dunston, let me take the auto around to the hotel," said our hero.We have to make several turns.""All right, Dave," was the ready answer, and Dunston Porter arose and allowed his nephew to crowd into the driver's seat.The run to the town in the vicinity of which Oak Hall was located had been made without further incident.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

A National Olympic Committee (NOC) is a national constituent of the worldwide Olympic movement. Subject to the controls of the International Olympic Committee, NOCs are responsible for organizing their people's participation in the Olympic Games. They may nominate cities within their respective areas as candidates for future Olympic Games. NOCs also promote the development of athletes and training of coaches and officials at a national level within their geographies. As of 2016, there are 206 NOCs: Each of the 193 member states of the United Nations; United Nations observer state Palestine; the Cook Islands, a state in free association with New Zealand whose capacity to participate in international organizations has been recognized by the United Nations Secretariat; and two states with limited recognition, Kosovo and Taiwan (designated as "Chinese Taipei" by the IOC). There are also nine dependent territories with NOCs: Prior to 1996, rules for recognising separate countries within the IOC were not as strict as those within the United Nations, which allowed these territories to field teams separately from their sovereign state. Following an amendment to the Olympic Charter in 1996, NOC recognition can only be granted after recognition as an independent state by the international community. Since the rule does not apply retroactively, the dependent territories which were recognised before the rule change are allowed to continue sending separate teams to the Olympics, while the Faroe Islands and Macau send their own Paralympic teams.


Q: How many NOCs were there in 2016?

A: 206||As of 2016, there are 206 NOCs:

Q: What does NOC stand for?

A: National Olympic Committee||A National Olympic Committee (NOC) is a national constituent of the worldwide Olympic movement.

Q: So is there only one NOC per nation?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: Can you name two NOCs?

A: United Nations observer state Palestine and the Cook Islands||As of 2016, there are 206 NOCs: Each of the 193 member states of the United Nations; United Nations observer state Palestine; the Cook Islands, a state in free association with New Zealand whose capacity to participate in international organizations has been recognized by the United Nations Secretariat; and two states with limited recognition, Kosovo and Taiwan (designated as "Chinese Taipei" by the IOC).

Q: What is one thing an NOC can do?

A: organizing their people's participation in the Olympic Games||A National Olympic Committee (NOC) is a national constituent of the worldwide Olympic movement. Subject to the controls of the International Olympic Committee, NOCs are responsible for organizing their people's participation in the Olympic Games.

Q: Anything else?

A: They nominate cities within their respective areas as candidates for future Olympic Games||They may nominate cities within their respective areas as candidates for future Olympic Games

Q: Is there an entity that controls NOCs?

A: Yes|| Subject to the controls of the International Olympic Committee, NOCs are responsible for organizing their people's participation in the Olympic Games.

Q: What is it called?

A: International Olympic Committee||Subject to the controls of the International Olympic Committee, NOCs are responsible for organizing their people's participation in the Olympic Games

Q: How many dependent territories have NOCs?

A: nine||There are also nine dependent territories with NOCs:

Q: Was there an amendment to the Olympic Charter?

A: Yes||Following an amendment to the Olympic Charter in 1996, NOC recognition can only be granted after recognition as an independent state by the international community.

Q: When?

A: 1996|| Following an amendment to the Olympic Charter in 1996, NOC recognition can only be granted after recognition as an independent state by the international community.

Q: Was it good retroactively?

A: no, Since the rule does not apply retroactively, the dependent territories which were recognised before the rule change are allowed to continue sending separate teams to the Olympics, while the Faroe Islands and Macau send their own Paralympic teams.||Since the rule does not apply retroactively, the dependent territories which were recognised before the rule change are allowed to continue sending separate teams to the Olympics, while the Faroe Islands and Macau send their own Paralympic teams.

Q: How many member states does the Uniter Nations have?

A: 193||As of 2016, there are 206 NOCs: Each of the 193 member states of the United Nations; United Nations observer state Palestine; the Cook Islands, a state in free association with New Zealand whose capacity to participate in international organizations has been recognized by the United Nations Secretariat; and two states with limited recognition, Kosovo and Taiwan (designated as "Chinese Taipei" by the IOC).

Q: Can you name a United Nations observer state?

A: Palestine||Each of the 193 member states of the United Nations; United Nations observer state Palestine;

Q: Do the Cook Islands have something to do with New Zealand?

A: Yes||Each of the 193 member states of the United Nations; United Nations observer state Palestine; the Cook Islands, a state in free association with New Zealand whose capacity to participate in international organizations has been recognized by the United Nations Secretariat

Q: What's another name for Taiwan?

A: Chinese Taipei|| and two states with limited recognition, Kosovo and Taiwan (designated as "Chinese Taipei" by the IOC).


Summary: A National Olympic Committee (NOC) is a national constituent of the worldwide Olympic movement.Subject to the controls of the International Olympic Committee, NOCs are responsible for organizing their people's participation in the Olympic Games.They may nominate cities within their respective areas as candidates for future Olympic Games.As of 2016, there are 206 NOCs: Each of the 193 member states of the United Nations; United Nations observer state Palestine; the Cook Islands, a state in free association with New Zealand whose capacity to participate in international organizations has been recognized by the United Nations Secretariat; and two states with limited recognition, Kosovo and Taiwan (designated as "Chinese Taipei" by the IOC).There are also nine dependent territories with NOCs: Prior to 1996, rules for recognising separate countries within the IOC were not as strict as those within the United Nations, which allowed these territories to field teams separately from their sovereign state.Following an amendment to the Olympic Charter in 1996, NOC recognition can only be granted after recognition as an independent state by the international community.Since the rule does not apply retroactively, the dependent territories which were recognised before the rule change are allowed to continue sending separate teams to the Olympics, while the Faroe Islands and Macau send their own Paralympic teams.

source: race

We were standing at the top of a church not far from my home. I didn't know why. "Look down," Father said. I tried and saw the square in the center of the village. And I saw the streets to the square. "See, Elsa," Father said. "There is more than one way to the square. If you can't get where you want to go by one road, try another." Earlier that day, I asked Mother to do something about what we had for lunch at school. But she didn't think the food was as bad as I said. When I turned to Father for help, he brought me to the church. At school the next day, I filled a bottle with the soup for our lunch and took it home. I told the cook to pour the soup in a plate and bring it to Mother. She drank it and cried out, "What's the matter with the soup today?" I at once told her what I had done , and Mother said that she would take up the matter of lunches at school the next day . Now I really understood why Father had taken me to the church. I began to work as a fashion designer two years ago. I wouldn't stop working until I tried every way to my goal.


Q: Where were we standing?

A: at the top of a church||We were standing at the top of a church not far from my home

Q: Why?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: What is my name?

A: Elsa|| And I saw the streets to the square. "See, Elsa," Father said.

Q: What did I ask my mom to do?

A: to do something about lunch at school.|| I asked Mother to do something about what we had for lunch at school.

Q: What did I put in the bottle?

A: the soup|| I filled a bottle with the soup for our lunch

Q: Who did I give it to?

A: the cook||I filled a bottle with the soup for our lunch and took it home. I told the cook to pour the soup in a plate and bring it to Mother.

Q: Who did she give it to?

A: mother|| I told the cook to pour the soup in a plate and bring it to Mother.

Q: Did she like it?

A: no, She drank it and cried out, "What's the matter with the soup today?"|| She drank it and cried out, "What's the matter with the soup today?"

Q: What did she decide to do?

A: take up the matter of lunch||and Mother said that she would take up the matter of lunches at school the next day

Q: What is my profession?

A: a fashion designer||I began to work as a fashion designer two years ago

Q: For how long?

A: two years||I began to work as a fashion designer two years ago

Q: What did I learn?

A: why Father had taken her to the church.||Now I really understood why Father had taken me to the church.


Summary: We were standing at the top of a church not far from my home.And I saw the streets to the square.Earlier that day, I asked Mother to do something about what we had for lunch at school.At school the next day, I filled a bottle with the soup for our lunch and took it home.I told the cook to pour the soup in a plate and bring it to Mother.She drank it and cried out, "What's the matter with the soup today?"I at once told her what I had done , and Mother said that she would take up the matter of lunches at school the next day .Now I really understood why Father had taken me to the church.I began to work as a fashion designer two years ago.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XI Peter Rabbit and Jerry Muskrat Are Puzzled. Jerry Muskrat was more and more sure that his big cousin, Paddy the Beaver, didn't know quite so much as he might about house-building. Jerry would have liked to offer some suggestions, but he didn't quite dare. You see, he was very anxious not to displease his big cousin. But he felt that he simply had got to speak his mind to someone, so he swam across to where he had seen Peter Rabbit almost every night since Paddy began to build. Sure enough, Peter was there, sitting up very straight and staring with big round eyes at the platform of mud and sticks out in the water where Paddy the Beaver was at work. "Well, Peter, what do you think of it?" asked Jerry "What is it?" asked Peter innocently. "Is it another dam?" Jerry threw back his head and laughed and laughed. Peter looked at him suspiciously. "I don't see anything to laugh at," said he. "Why, it's a house, you stupid. It's Paddy's new house," replied Jerry, wiping the tears of laughter from his eyes. "I'm not stupid!" retorted Peter. "How was I to know that that pile of mud and sticks is meant for a house? It certainly doesn't look it. Where is the door?" "To tell you the truth, I don't think it is much of a house myself," replied Jerry. "It has got a door, all right. In fact it has got three. You can't see them because they are under water, and there is a passage from each right up through that platform of mud and sticks, which is the foundation of the house. It really is a very fine foundation, Peter; it really is. But what I can't understand is what Paddy is thinking of by building that great pile of mud right in the middle. When he gets his walls built, where will his bedroom be? There won't be any room at all. It won't be a house at all--just a big useless pile of sticks and mud.


Q: Who was laughing a bunch?

A: Jerry||Jerry threw back his head and laughed and laughed.

Q: Who was annoyed by it?

A: Peter||Peter looked at him suspiciously. "I don't see anything to laugh at," said he.

Q: What were they talking of at that moment?

A: Paddy's new house||"Why, it's a house, you stupid. It's Paddy's new house,"

Q: What did the annoyed boy this is was at first?

A: Another dam||"What is it?" asked Peter innocently. "Is it another dam?"

Q: Was the laughing boy polite about the misunderstanding?

A: No, Why, it's a house, you stupid. It's Paddy's new house," replied Jerry, wiping the tears of laughter from his eyes||Why, it's a house, you stupid. It's Paddy's new house," replied Jerry, wiping the tears of laughter from his eyes

Q: What did he call him?

A: Stupid||"Why, it's a house, you stupid. It's Paddy's new house," replied Jerry

Q: Why didn't the annoyed boy believe it wasn't a home?

A: It doesn't look it||"I'm not stupid!" retorted Peter. "How was I to know that that pile of mud and sticks is meant for a house? It certainly doesn't look it. Where is the door?"

Q: What's missing?

A: the door||Where is the door?"

Q: How many does the laughing boy point out there actually are?

A: Three||It has got a door, all right. In fact it has got three.

Q: Why can't they be easily noticed?

A: because they are under water||You can't see them because they are under water

Q: What is the base made of?

A: mud and sticks|| that platform of mud and sticks, which is the foundation of the house.

Q: Is the builder related to anyone?

A: Yes||Jerry Muskrat was more and more sure that his big cousin, Paddy the Beaver, didn't know quite so much as he might about house-building

Q: Who?

A: Jerry Muskrat||Jerry Muskrat was more and more sure that his big cousin, Paddy the Beaver, didn't know quite so much as he might about house-building

Q: Does he say his critiques to the builder?

A: No, Jerry would have liked to offer some suggestions, but he didn't quite dare.||Jerry would have liked to offer some suggestions, but he didn't quite dare.

Q: Why not?

A: He was anxious not to displease his big cousin||he was very anxious not to displease his big cousin

Q: Who had been there watching most of the process?

A: Peter Rabbit|| he had seen Peter Rabbit almost every night since Paddy began to build.

Q: Was he slouching?

A: No, Peter was there, sitting up very straight and staring|| Peter was there, sitting up very straight and staring

Q: What was his posture then?

A: sitting up very straight||sitting up very straight

Q: What living space will the builder have trouble adding?

A: his bedroom||When he gets his walls built, where will his bedroom be?

Q: Why?

A: There won't be any room||There won't be any room at all


Summary: Jerry Muskrat was more and more sure that his big cousin, Paddy the Beaver, didn't know quite so much as he might about house-building.Jerry would have liked to offer some suggestions, but he didn't quite dare.You see, he was very anxious not to displease his big cousin.But he felt that he simply had got to speak his mind to someone, so he swam across to where he had seen Peter Rabbit almost every night since Paddy began to build.Sure enough, Peter was there, sitting up very straight and staring with big round eyes at the platform of mud and sticks out in the water where Paddy the Beaver was at work.asked Jerry "What is it?"Jerry threw back his head and laughed and laughed.Peter looked at him suspiciously."Why, it's a house, you stupid.retorted Peter."To tell you the truth, I don't think it is much of a house myself," replied Jerry.In fact it has got three.You can't see them because they are under water, and there is a passage from each right up through that platform of mud and sticks, which is the foundation of the house.When he gets his walls built, where will his bedroom be?It won't be a house at all--just a big useless pile of sticks and mud.

source: cnn

The critical moment for Sen. Ted Cruz and his allies came around 7 p.m. on Tuesday night. The Texas Republican's suit was still crisp, despite more than four hours into what would become a rhetorical marathon of more than 21 hours on the Senate floor aimed at derailing Obamacare. But until that point, the brunt of the speaking had been done by Cruz and his ally, Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah. Without more help, Lee's aides weren't sure how long the effort could continue. Then Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Florida, arrived. It was a sign that they'd get the bodies they needed for the long haul. "When he showed up, we had a feeling that we could go until noon (the next day)," said Lee spokesman Brian Phillips. Lee was on or near the floor all night. Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, who held the floor for 12 hours in March, jumped in. Even ideological opponent Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Illinois, shouldered some speaking time while trying to refute Cruz' points. That gave Cruz some time for mental breaks even though he couldn't leave the floor to eat, use the restroom or do anything else. For material, staff pulled together binders of articles, talking points and documents that could be used to fill time. And as social networks heated up, aides ferried in a stream of tweets for Cruz to read. But to the big and less comfortable question: How did he manage physically? Good, pliable shoes, for a start. Cruz left his trademark Ostrich boots behind and told the chamber that he picked up some sneakers in preparation for the long hours of standing.


Q: Who's the main character in this article?

A: Sen. Ted Cruz||The critical moment for Sen. Ted Cruz and his allies came around 7 p.m. on Tuesday night.

Q: What's his political affiliation?

A: Hes a Republican||Republican

Q: What State does he represent?

A: He represents Texas||Texas

Q: What was the topic of the 21 hour rhetorical marathon?

A: It was aimed at derailing Obamacare.||derailing Obamacare.

Q: Where did it happen?

A: on the Senate floor||on the Senate floor

Q: Who did most of the talking?

A: Cruz||Cruz

Q: And who else?

A: his ally, Sen. Mike Lee||his ally, Sen. Mike Le

Q: Was Lee a Liberal?

A: No, Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah||Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah

Q: What State was he from?

A: Utah||Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah

Q: Who then arrived to the meeting?

A: Sen. Marco Rubio||Sen. Marco Rubio

Q: From what State?

A: Florida||R-Florida

Q: What political party?

A: Republican||R-Florida

Q: Who held the floor for 12 hours?

A: Sen. Rand Paul||Sen. Rand Paul

Q: When?

A: in March|| in March

Q: Which Illinois opponent also commented?

A: Sen. Dick Durbin||Sen. Dick Durbin


Summary: The critical moment for Sen. Ted Cruz and his allies came around 7 p.m. on Tuesday night.The Texas Republican's suit was still crisp, despite more than four hours into what would become a rhetorical marathon of more than 21 hours on the Senate floor aimed at derailing Obamacare.But until that point, the brunt of the speaking had been done by Cruz and his ally, Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah.Then Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Florida, arrived.Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, who held the floor for 12 hours in March, jumped in.Even ideological opponent Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Illinois, shouldered some speaking time while trying to refute Cruz' points.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XIII. ST. VALENTINE'S DAY Miss Mohun came back in the dark after a long day, for once in her life quite jaded, and explaining that the health-officer and the landlord had been by no means agreed, and that nothing could be done till Sir Jasper came home and decided whether to retain the house or not. All that she was clear about, and which she had telegraphed to Aden, was, that there must be no going back to Silverfold for the present, and she was prepared to begin lodging-hunting as soon as she received an answer. 'And how have you got on?' she asked, thinking all looked rather blank. 'We haven't been to see Fly,' broke out Valetta, 'though she went out on the beach, and Mysie must not stay out after dark, for fear she should cough.' 'Mysie says they are afraid of excitement,' said Gillian gloomily. 'Then you have seen nothing of the others?' 'Yes, I have seen Victoria, said Aunt Adeline, with a meaning smile. Miss Mohun went up to take off her things, and Gillian followed her, shutting the door with ominous carefulness, and colouring all over. 'Aunt Jane, I ought to tell you. A dreadful thing has happened!' 'Indeed, my dear! What?' 'I have had a valentine.' 'Oh!' repressing a certain inclination to laugh at the bathos from the look of horror and shame in the girl's eyes. 'It is from that miserable Alexis! Oh, I know I brought it on myself, and I have been so wretched and so ashamed all day.'


Q: He returned after dark?

A: yes||Miss Mohun came back in the dark after a long day,

Q: Who returned after dark?

A: Miss Mohun||Miss Mohun came back in the dark

Q: After how long?

A: after a long day||Miss Mohun came back in the dark after a long day,

Q: Who did they have to wait for before acting?

A: Sir Jasper||nothing could be done till Sir Jasper came home

Q: And would would they act on?

A: whether to retain the house or not||nothing could be done till Sir Jasper came home and decided whether to retain the house or not.

Q: Who did she send message to?

A: Aden||she had telegraphed to Aden

Q: And what was she presently sure of?

A: there must be no going back to Silverfold for the present,||All that she was clear about, and which she had telegraphed to Aden, was, that there must be no going back to Silverfold for the present,

Q: What did Valetta think Mysie mustn't do?

A: stay out after dark||though she went out on the beach, and Mysie must not stay out after dark,

Q: Why?

A: fear she should cough||Mysie must not stay out after dark, for fear she should cough

Q: Is Gillian happy when referring to Mysie?

A: no, Mysie says they are afraid of excitement,' said Gillian gloomily||Mysie says they are afraid of excitement,' said Gillian gloomily

Q: Where does Miss Mohun go?

A: upstairs||Miss Mohun went up to take off her things,

Q: To do what?

A: to take off her things||Miss Mohun went up to take off her things,

Q: What terrible news did Aunt Jane receive?

A: Gillian has had a valentine||. A dreadful thing has happened!' 'Indeed, my dear! What?' 'I have had a valentine.'

Q: Who was it from?

A: Alexis||'It is from that miserable Alexis


Summary: ST. VALENTINE'S DAY Miss Mohun came back in the dark after a long day, for once in her life quite jaded, and explaining that the health-officer and the landlord had been by no means agreed, and that nothing could be done till Sir Jasper came home and decided whether to retain the house or not.All that she was clear about, and which she had telegraphed to Aden, was, that there must be no going back to Silverfold for the present, and she was prepared to begin lodging-hunting as soon as she received an answer.'We haven't been to see Fly,' broke out Valetta, 'though she went out on the beach, and Mysie must not stay out after dark, for fear she should cough.''Mysie says they are afraid of excitement,' said Gillian gloomily.Miss Mohun went up to take off her things, and Gillian followed her, shutting the door with ominous carefulness, and colouring all over.A dreadful thing has happened!'Oh, I know I brought it on myself, and I have been so wretched and so ashamed all day.'


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: race

History is full of examples of leaders joining together to meet common goals. But rarely have two leaders worked together with such friendship and cooperation as American President Franklin Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill. They both were born in wealthy families and were active in politics for many years. Both men loved the sea and the navy,history and nature. Roosevelt and Churchill first met when they were lowerlevel officials in World War One. But neither man remembered much about that meeting. However,as they worked together during the Second World War they came to like and trust each other. Roosevelt and Churchill exchanged more than one thousand seven hundred letters and messages during five and a half years. They met many times,at large national gatherings and in private talks. But the closeness of their friendship might be seen best in a story told by one of Roosevelt's close advisors,Harry Hopkins. Hopkins remembered how Churchill was visiting Roosevelt at the White House one day. Roosevelt went into Churchill's room in the morning to say hello. But the president was shocked to see Churchill coming from the washing room with no clothes at all. Roosevelt immediately apologized to the British leader for seeing him naked. But Churchill reportedly said: "The Prime Minister of Great Britain has nothing to hide from the president of the United States." And then both men laughed. The United States and Great Britain were only two of several nations that joined together in the war to resist Hitler and his Allies. In January,1942,twentysix of these nations signed an agreement promising to fight for peace,religious freedom,human rights,and justice. The three major Allies,however,were the most important for the war effort: the United States,Britain,and the Soviet Union. Yet,Churchill and Roosevelt disagreed about when to attack Hitler in western Europe. And Churchill resisted Roosevelt's suggestions that Britain give up some of its colonies. But in general,the friendship between Roosevelt and Churchill,and between the United States and Britain led the two nations to cooperate closely.


Q: Which two leaders worked together?

A: Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill||American President Franklin Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill

Q: when did they first meet?

A: World War One||when they were lowerlevel officials in World War One

Q: did they remember it?

A: no, But neither man remembered much about that meeting.||But neither man remembered much about that meeting.

Q: when did they remember each other?

A: Second World War||Second World War

Q: Did they like each other?

A: yes||they came to like and trust each other

Q: how many letters exchanged?

A: more than one thousand seven hundred letters||more than one thousand seven hundred letters

Q: two nations that joined the war?

A: United States and Great Britain||United States and Great Britain

Q: how many signed agreement?

A: 26||twentysix

Q: how many allies?

A: Three||three

Q: who?

A: United States, Britain, and Soviet Union||United States,Britain,and the Soviet Union

Q: Did Churchill visit Roosevelt at White house?

A: yes||Churchill was visiting Roosevelt at the White House one day

Q: what did he do?

A: came from the washing room with no clothes at all||coming from the washing room with no clothes at all

Q: who was Roosevelt adviser?

A: Harry Hopkins||Harry Hopkins

Q: was he close to him?

A: yes||close advisors,

Q: did they disagree?

A: yes||Churchill and Roosevelt disagreed about when to attack Hitler in western Europe

Q: what about?

A: when to attack Hitler in western Europe||when to attack Hitler in western Europe


Summary: But rarely have two leaders worked together with such friendship and cooperation as American President Franklin Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.Roosevelt and Churchill first met when they were lowerlevel officials in World War One.But neither man remembered much about that meeting.However,as they worked together during the Second World War they came to like and trust each other.Roosevelt and Churchill exchanged more than one thousand seven hundred letters and messages during five and a half years.But the closeness of their friendship might be seen best in a story told by one of Roosevelt's close advisors,Harry Hopkins.Hopkins remembered how Churchill was visiting Roosevelt at the White House one day.But the president was shocked to see Churchill coming from the washing room with no clothes at all.The United States and Great Britain were only two of several nations that joined together in the war to resist Hitler and his Allies.In January,1942,twentysix of these nations signed an agreement promising to fight for peace,religious freedom,human rights,and justice.The three major Allies,however,were the most important for the war effort: the United States,Britain,and the Soviet Union.Yet,Churchill and Roosevelt disagreed about when to attack Hitler in western Europe.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Buddhism /ˈbudɪzəm/ is a nontheistic religion[note 1] or philosophy (Sanskrit: धर्म dharma; Pali: धम्म dhamma) that encompasses a variety of traditions, beliefs and spiritual practices largely based on teachings attributed to Gautama Buddha, commonly known as the Buddha ("the awakened one"). According to Buddhist tradition, the Buddha lived and taught in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent, present-day Nepal sometime between the 6th and 4th centuries BCE.[note 1] He is recognized by Buddhists as an awakened or enlightened teacher who shared his insights to help sentient beings end their suffering through the elimination of ignorance and craving. Buddhists believe that this is accomplished through the direct understanding and perception of dependent origination and the Four Noble Truths. Two major extant branches of Buddhism are generally recognized by scholars: Theravada ("The School of the Elders") and Mahayana ("The Great Vehicle"). Vajrayana, a body of teachings attributed to Indian siddhas, may be viewed as a third branch or merely a part of Mahayana. Theravada has a widespread following in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia. Mahayana which includes the traditions of Pure Land, Zen, Nichiren Buddhism, Shingon, and Tiantai (Tendai) is found throughout East Asia. Tibetan Buddhism, which preserves the Vajrayana teachings of eighth century India, is practiced in regions surrounding the Himalayas, Mongolia and Kalmykia. Buddhists number between an estimated 488 million[web 1] and 535 million, making it one of the world's major religions.


Q: How many Buddhists are there estimated to be?

A: Between 488 million and 535 million.||Buddhists number between an estimated 488 million[web 1] and 535 million

Q: What is Buddhism?

A: A religion.||Buddhism /ˈbudɪzəm/ is a nontheistic religion[note 1] or philosophy (Sanskrit: धर्म dharma; Pali: धम्म dhamma) that encompasses a variety of traditions, beliefs and spiritual practices largely based on teachings attributed to Gautama Buddha, commonly known as the Buddha ("the awakened one").

Q: Who is it attributed to?

A: Guatama Buddha||based on teachings attributed to Gautama Buddha,

Q: What is another name for Buddha?

A: The awakened one.||Gautama Buddha, commonly known as the Buddha ("the awakened one")

Q: How many branches of Buddhism are recognized in general?

A: Two||Two major extant branches of Buddhism are generally recognized by scholars:

Q: What are they?

A: Theravada and Mahayana||Theravada ("The School of the Elders") and Mahayana ("The Great Vehicle")

Q: Where did Buddha live and teach?

A: The eastern part of the Indian subcontinent.||the Buddha lived and taught in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent, present-day Nepal

Q: Around when?

A: Between the 6th and 4th centuries BCE.||sometime between the 6th and 4th centuries BCE

Q: Why did he share his insights?

A: To help people end their suffering.||who shared his insights to help sentient beings end their suffering through the elimination of ignorance and craving

Q: How many Noble Truths are there?

A: Four||the Four Noble Truths.

Q: Where does Theravada have a large following?

A: Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia||Theravada has a widespread following in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia


Summary: Buddhism /ˈbudɪzəm/ is a nontheistic religion[note 1] or philosophy (Sanskrit: धर्म dharma; Pali: धम्म dhamma) that encompasses a variety of traditions, beliefs and spiritual practices largely based on teachings attributed to Gautama Buddha, commonly known as the Buddha ("the awakened one").According to Buddhist tradition, the Buddha lived and taught in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent, present-day Nepal sometime between the 6th and 4th centuries BCE.[note 1] He is recognized by Buddhists as an awakened or enlightened teacher who shared his insights to help sentient beings end their suffering through the elimination of ignorance and craving.Buddhists believe that this is accomplished through the direct understanding and perception of dependent origination and the Four Noble Truths.Two major extant branches of Buddhism are generally recognized by scholars: Theravada ("The School of the Elders") and Mahayana ("The Great Vehicle").Theravada has a widespread following in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia.Buddhists number between an estimated 488 million[web 1] and 535 million, making it one of the world's major religions.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXX. HOW THE BRUSHWOOD MEN CAME TO THE CHATEAU OF VILLEFRANCHE. It was late ere Alleyne Edricson, having carried Sir Nigel the goblet of spiced wine which it was his custom to drink after the curling of his hair, was able at last to seek his chamber. It was a stone-flagged room upon the second floor, with a bed in a recess for him, and two smaller pallets on the other side, on which Aylward and Hordle John were already snoring. Alleyne had knelt down to his evening orisons, when there came a tap at his door, and Ford entered with a small lamp in his hand. His face was deadly pale, and his hand shook until the shadows flickered up and down the wall. "What is it, Ford?" cried Alleyne, springing to his feet. "I can scarce tell you," said he, sitting down on the side of the couch, and resting his chin upon his hand. "I know not what to say or what to think." "Has aught befallen you, then?" "Yes, or I have been slave to my own fancy. I tell you, lad, that I am all undone, like a fretted bow-string. Hark hither, Alleyne! it cannot be that you have forgotten little Tita, the daughter of the old glass-stainer at Bordeaux?" "I remember her well." "She and I, Alleyne, broke the lucky groat together ere we parted, and she wears my ring upon her finger. 'Caro mio,' quoth she when last we parted, 'I shall be near thee in the wars, and thy danger will be my danger.' Alleyne, as God is my help, as I came up the stairs this night I saw her stand before me, her face in tears, her hands out as though in warning--I saw it, Alleyne, even as I see those two archers upon their couches. Our very finger-tips seemed to meet, ere she thinned away like a mist in the sunshine."


Q: Did Alleyene seek his chamber early?

A: No, It was late ere Alleyne Edricson, having carried Sir Nigel the goblet of spiced wine which it was his custom to drink after the curling of his hair, was able at last to seek his chamber. || It was late ere Alleyne Edricson, having carried Sir Nigel the goblet of spiced wine which it was his custom to drink after the curling of his hair, was able at last to seek his chamber.

A: Sir Nigel||Sir Nigel the goblet of spiced wine which it was his custom to drink after the curling of his hair, was able at last to seek his chamber.

Summary: CHAPTER XXX.It was late ere Alleyne Edricson, having carried Sir Nigel the goblet of spiced wine which it was his custom to drink after the curling of his hair, was able at last to seek his chamber.It was a stone-flagged room upon the second floor, with a bed in a recess for him, and two smaller pallets on the other side, on which Aylward and Hordle John were already snoring.Alleyne had knelt down to his evening orisons, when there came a tap at his door, and Ford entered with a small lamp in his hand.His face was deadly pale, and his hand shook until the shadows flickered up and down the wall."I can scarce tell you," said he, sitting down on the side of the couch, and resting his chin upon his hand.it cannot be that you have forgotten little Tita, the daughter of the old glass-stainer at Bordeaux?""She and I, Alleyne, broke the lucky groat together ere we parted, and she wears my ring upon her finger.'Caro mio,' quoth she when last we parted, 'I shall be near thee in the wars, and thy danger will be my danger.'Alleyne, as God is my help, as I came up the stairs this night I saw her stand before me, her face in tears, her hands out as though in warning--I saw it, Alleyne, even as I see those two archers upon their couches.

source: wikipedia

The Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (Russian SFSR or RSFSR; Russian: Российская Советская Федеративная Социалистическая Республика, tr. Rossiyskaya Sovetskaya Federativnaya Sotsialisticheskaya Respublika listen (help·info)) commonly referred to as Soviet Russia or simply as Russia, was a sovereign state in 1917–22, the largest, most populous, and most economically developed republic of the Soviet Union in 1922–91 and a sovereign part of the Soviet Union with its own legislation in 1990–91. The Republic comprised sixteen autonomous republics, five autonomous oblasts, ten autonomous okrugs, six krais, and forty oblasts. Russians formed the largest ethnic group. To the west it bordered Finland, Norway and Poland; and to the south, China, Mongolia and North Korea whilst bordering the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Pacific Ocean to the east and the Black sea and Caspian Sea to the south. Within the USSR, it bordered the Baltic republics (Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia), the Byelorussian SSR and the Ukrainian SSR to the west. To the south it bordered the Georgian, Azerbaijan and Kazakh SSRs.


Q: what is commonly referred to as Soviet Russia ?

A: Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic||Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic

Q: what kind of state was it ?

A: sovereign||sovereign

Q: was if from 1817-22 ?

A: yes||1917–22

Q: was it a small poor state ?

A: no, not at all||largest, most populous, and most economically developed

Q: when was it a part of the Soviet Union with its own legislation

A: 1990–91||1990–91

Q: how many autonomous republics does it make ?

A: sixteen||sixteen

Q: how many areas did it border to the west ?

A: three|| Finland, Norway and Poland

Q: what does it border to the north ?

A: Arctic Ocean||Arctic Ocean

Q: how many oblasts is it made of ?

A: five||five

Q: what area does china border ?

A: south||south

Q: how many Baltic republics ?

A: three||Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia

Q: what are they ?

A: Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia||Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia


Summary: The Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (Russian SFSR or RSFSR; Russian: Российская Советская Федеративная Социалистическая Республика, tr.Rossiyskaya Sovetskaya Federativnaya Sotsialisticheskaya Respublika listen (help·info)) commonly referred to as Soviet Russia or simply as Russia, was a sovereign state in 1917–22, the largest, most populous, and most economically developed republic of the Soviet Union in 1922–91 and a sovereign part of the Soviet Union with its own legislation in 1990–91.The Republic comprised sixteen autonomous republics, five autonomous oblasts, ten autonomous okrugs, six krais, and forty oblasts.To the west it bordered Finland, Norway and Poland; and to the south, China, Mongolia and North Korea whilst bordering the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Pacific Ocean to the east and the Black sea and Caspian Sea to the south.Within the USSR, it bordered the Baltic republics (Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia), the Byelorussian SSR and the Ukrainian SSR to the west.
