source: cnn

(CNN) -- November 6, 2008, 9:06 a.m.: Ernie Casillas can peg the downward spiral of his life to that exact minute, when he was fired from his job as a mortgage broker. Barack Obama had just been elected president as Casillas was leaving the work force. Nearly four years later, as Obama seeks reelection, Casillas has finally landed his first full-time job, emerging out of the group known as the long-term unemployed. The Labor Department's July employment figures on Friday showed the average duration of unemployment shrank from 39.9 weeks in June to 38.8 weeks in July. The percentage of people who are unemployed long-term (27 weeks or longer) shrank from 41.9% in June to 40.7% in July. Casillas says his life is evidence that the economy is beginning to turn around. But the road to his new job was painful, heartbreaking and financially devastating. July jobs report: Hiring picks up, unemployment rises He remembers his life pre-November 2008: He wore expensive suits, drove a Mercedes and spent every cent of his paycheck. When he was laid off, he thought he'd be back at work in two weeks. He was wrong. The subprime mortgage crisis was eating away at the U.S. economy. Employers were shedding jobs, not adding them. A few credits shy of his associate degree, Casillas found himself overqualified for many jobs but underqualified for higher-paid middle-class ones. "Overqualified, what does that mean?" Casillas remembers. "They kept telling me that. Meanwhile, my life is going down the drain." He lost his house, his Mercedes, and then his wife left him. In his 40s, he was forced to take the humiliating step of moving in with his mother. A year after he lost his job, he began selling everything he owned on Craigslist.


Q: Who's the article about?

A: Ernie Casillas||Ernie Casillas

Q: When was he fired?

A: November 6, 2008||November 6, 2008

Q: What was his profession?

A: mortgage broker||mortgage broker

Q: How much later did he get his next job?

A: four years later,||four years later,

Q: What were the reports posting about employment then?

A: the average duration of unemployment shrank from 39.9 weeks in June to 38.8 weeks in July|| the average duration of unemployment shrank from 39.9 weeks in June to 38.8 weeks in July. The percentage

Q: Who was seeking reelection around this time?

A: Obama||Obama

Q: What ate away at the economy in the US?

A: subprime mortgage crisis|| subprime mortgage crisis

Q: What type of car did he drive?

A: his Mercedes||his Mercedes

Q: What was the car's fate?

A: He lost it||e lost his house, his Mercedes

Q: Did he own a home?

A: Yes||He lost his house,

Q: What did he have to do 12 months after becoming unemployed?

A: moving in with his mother||moving in with his mother

Q: How old was he then?

A: In his 40s||In his 40

Q: Was he ever married?

A: Yes|| his wife

Q: Did the wife move in with his mom too?

A: No, and then his wife left him||and then his wife left him

Q: What did he have to do with his belongings after?

A: Sell them on Craigslist|| selling everything he owned on Craigslis


Summary: (CNN) -- November 6, 2008, 9:06 a.m.: Ernie Casillas can peg the downward spiral of his life to that exact minute, when he was fired from his job as a mortgage broker.Nearly four years later, as Obama seeks reelection, Casillas has finally landed his first full-time job, emerging out of the group known as the long-term unemployed.The Labor Department's July employment figures on Friday showed the average duration of unemployment shrank from 39.9 weeks in June to 38.8 weeks in July.The subprime mortgage crisis was eating away at the U.S. economy.He lost his house, his Mercedes, and then his wife left him.In his 40s, he was forced to take the humiliating step of moving in with his mother.A year after he lost his job, he began selling everything he owned on Craigslist.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Sports Illustrated is an American sports media franchise owned by Time Inc. Its self-titled magazine has over 3 million subscribers and is read by 23 million people each week, including over 18 million men. It was the first magazine with circulation over one million to win the National Magazine Award for General Excellence twice. Its swimsuit issue, which has been published since 1964, is now an annual publishing event that generates its own television shows, videos and calendars. There were two magazines named "Sports Illustrated" before the current magazine began on August 16, 1954. In 1936, Stuart Scheftel created "Sports Illustrated" with a target market for the sportsman. He published the magazine from 1936 to 1938 on a monthly basis. The magazine was a life magazine size and focused on golf, tennis, and skiing with articles on the major sports. He then sold the name to Dell Publications, which released "Sports Illustrated" in 1949 and this version lasted 6 issues before closing. Dell's version focused on major sports (baseball, basketball, boxing) and competed on magazine racks against "Sport" and other monthly sports magazines. During the 1940s these magazines were monthly and they did not cover the current events because of the production schedules. There was no large-base, general, weekly sports magazine with a national following on actual active events. It was then that "Time" patriarch Henry Luce began considering whether his company should attempt to fill that gap. At the time, many believed sports was beneath the attention of serious journalism and did not think sports news could fill a weekly magazine, especially during the winter. A number of advisers to Luce, including "Life" magazine's Ernest Havemann, tried to kill the idea, but Luce, who was not a sports fan, decided the time was right.


Q: What's the topic of focus?

A: Sports Illustrated||Sports Illustrated

Q: How many people read their magazine?

A: 23 million||read by 23 million people

Q: How many subscribe to it?

A: over 3 million||magazine has over 3 million subscribers

Q: How many of the readers of male?

A: over 18 million||including over 18 million men

Q: Since when has the swimsuit issue been published?

A: 1964||ts swimsuit issue, which has been published since 1964

Q: How many of the Sports Illustrations were there initially?

A: two||There were two magazines named "Sports Illustrated"

Q: When did that change?

A: August 16, 1954||before the current magazine began on August 16, 1954

Q: Who was their target group?

A: the sportsman||a target market for the sportsman

Q: What was created in 1936?

A: the magazine|| He published the magazine from 1936

Q: Who created it?

A: Stuart Scheftel||Stuart Scheftel created "Sports Illustrated

Q: How often would it come out then?

A: monthly||on a monthly basis

Q: Who worked for Time magazine?

A: Henry Luce||"Time" patriarch Henry Luce

Q: What did people think of sports journalism then?

A: many believed sports was beneath the attention of serious journalism||many believed sports was beneath the attention of serious journalism


Summary: Sports Illustrated is an American sports media franchise owned by Time Inc. Its self-titled magazine has over 3 million subscribers and is read by 23 million people each week, including over 18 million men.Its swimsuit issue, which has been published since 1964, is now an annual publishing event that generates its own television shows, videos and calendars.There were two magazines named "Sports Illustrated" before the current magazine began on August 16, 1954.In 1936, Stuart Scheftel created "Sports Illustrated" with a target market for the sportsman.He published the magazine from 1936 to 1938 on a monthly basis.It was then that "Time" patriarch Henry Luce began considering whether his company should attempt to fill that gap.At the time, many believed sports was beneath the attention of serious journalism and did not think sports news could fill a weekly magazine, especially during the winter.

source: mctest

Scott Alan woke up very early that morning in his bedroom in his house. He felt something licking his face and he wasn't sure what it was. As he opened his green eyes slowly, he saw a bit of fur. Then he saw a tongue. After that, some more fur and then slurp! He was licked again! "Oh, Boscoe!" the little boy said with joy as he kissed his furry little brown dog. The dog had been Scott's friend for as long as could remember. They went on many adventures together. The two of them really never left each other's side and Scott woke up many times this way. One of the most memorable adventures that Scott and Boscoe had happened when Scott was 12. Scott wanted to have a little fun. He also wanted to adventure with Boscoe. Scott had got done eating breakfast and wanted to ride his bicycle. Boscoe was walking and Scott was riding his bicycle down by the park very close to the river near Scott's house. He wanted to do a little adventuring. Boscoe was walking next to the shore and started barking his head off! Scott wasn't sure what he was barking at, so he got off his bicycle and ran down into the river to see what all the noise was about. All of the sudden, Boscoe fell in the water and was taken down stream with the fast water. Scott yelled, "Boscoe!" and he was off. He jumped into the water and began swimming after Boscoe. Boscoe's little legs were doggy paddling as fast as they could, but had no hope! Finally, Scott caught up to him, but he couldn't get back to the side of the river! As Scott was thinking this was the last of him and Boscoe, a large stick from a fallen log was well in reach and Scott grabbed it and using all of this might, he pulled him and Boscoe out of the river. "Boy, was that close!" Scott yelled out loud! That was the best adventure ever!


Q: Who awoke?

A: Scott Alan||Scott Alan

Q: what time of day?

A: morning||morning

Q: late?

A: No, early ||early

Q: where was he?

A: in his bedroom|| in his bedroom

Q: what was touching him that made him awake?

A: a dog||dog

Q: what was it doing?

A: licking||licked

Q: What was the dog's name?

A: Boscoe||Boscoe

Q: what color was he?

A: brown||brown

Q: how long had they known each other?

A: as long as he could remember||as long as could remember

Q: How old was the child for most of his adventures?

A: 12||12

Q: what did scott want to do after he ate?

A: ride his bicycle||to ride his bicycle

Q: where at?

A: by the park||by the park

Q: what was it near?

A: the river|| the river

Q: What did the animal start doing?

A: barking||barking

Q: did scott get off his bike?

A: yes||he got off his bicycle

Q: what happened to the animal all of a sudden?

A: it fell in the water||fell in the water

Q: where did it take him?

A: down stream||down stream

Q: what did the child yell?

A: "Boscoe!"||"Boscoe!"

Q: what did he do after that?

A: jumped into the water||jumped into the water

Q: what did he say after he got the animal out?

A: "Boy, was that close!"||"Boy, was that close


Summary: Scott Alan woke up very early that morning in his bedroom in his house.He was licked again!the little boy said with joy as he kissed his furry little brown dog.The dog had been Scott's friend for as long as could remember.Scott wanted to have a little fun.Scott had got done eating breakfast and wanted to ride his bicycle.Boscoe was walking and Scott was riding his bicycle down by the park very close to the river near Scott's house.Scott wasn't sure what he was barking at, so he got off his bicycle and ran down into the river to see what all the noise was about.All of the sudden, Boscoe fell in the water and was taken down stream with the fast water.He jumped into the water and began swimming after Boscoe.Scott yelled out loud!

source: race

Living in a foreign culture can be exciting, but it can also be confusing . A group of Americans who taught English in other countries recently discussed their experiences. They decided that miscommunications were always possible, even over something as simple as"yes"and"no". On her first day in Micronesia, an island in the Pacific, Lisa thought people weren't paying any attention to her. The day was hot. She went into a store and asked, "Do you have cold drinks? "The woman there didn't say anything. Lisa repeated the question. Still the woman said nothing. She later learned that the woman had answered her: She had raised her eyebrows , which in Micronesia means"yes". Jan remembered an experience she had in Bulgaria, a country in Europe. She went to a restaurant that was known for its cabbage. She asked the waiter, "Do you have cabbage today? "He nodded his head. Jan waited, but the cabbage never came. In that country, a nod means"no". Tom had a similar problem when he arrived in India. After explaining something in class, he asked his students if they understood. They answered with many different nods and shakes of the head. He thought some people had not understood, so he explained again. When he asked again, they did the same thing. He soon found out that his students did understand. In India, people nod and shake their heads in different ways depending on where they come from. You have to know where a person is from to understand whether they mean"yes"or"no".


Q: Where did Lisa talk about?

A: Micronesia||On her first day in Micronesia, an island in the Pacific

Q: and what is that?

A: an island in the Pacific||Micronesia, an island in the Pacific

Q: what did she think?

A: people weren't paying any attention to her||Lisa thought people weren't paying any attention to her

Q: what did she ask the woman?

A: Do you have cold drinks?||She went into a store and asked, "Do you have cold drinks? "

Q: how did the woman reply?

A: She didn't say anything||The woman there didn't say anything.

Q: Did she move anything?

A: yes||She had raised her eyebrows

Q: what?

A: her eyebrows||She had raised her eyebrows

Q: what does that mean in that country?

A: yes||She had raised her eyebrows , which in Micronesia means"yes"

Q: Where did Jan talk about?

A: Bulgaria||Jan remembered an experience she had in Bulgaria,

Q: where is that located?

A: Europe||Jan remembered an experience she had in Bulgaria, a country in Europe.

Q: What did she ask?

A: Do you have cabbage today?||She asked the waiter, "Do you have cabbage today?

Q: how did the server respond?

A: He nodded||He nodded

Q: does that mean yes or no there?

A: no, In that country, a nod means"no".||In that country, a nod means"no".

Q: Where did Tom have his experience?

A: India.||Tom had a similar problem when he arrived in India.

Q: what did he ask his students?

A: if they understood||he asked his students if they understood.

Q: how did they respond?

A: different nods and shakes of the head||They answered with many different nods and shakes of the head

Q: did Tom misunderstand the response?

A: yes||He thought some people had not understood, so he explained again.

Q: did his students understand?

A: yes||He soon found out that his students did understand

Q: do head shakes and nods mean the same thing in India?

A: yes||He soon found out that his students did understand. In India, people nod and shake their heads in different ways depending on where they come from

Q: what do all these people I've mentioned do in common?

A: They experienced different cultures||You have to know where a person is from to understand whether they mean"yes"or"no".


Summary: On her first day in Micronesia, an island in the Pacific, Lisa thought people weren't paying any attention to her.She went into a store and asked, "Do you have cold drinks?"The woman there didn't say anything.She later learned that the woman had answered her: She had raised her eyebrows , which in Micronesia means"yes".Jan remembered an experience she had in Bulgaria, a country in Europe.She asked the waiter, "Do you have cabbage today?"He nodded his head.In that country, a nod means"no".Tom had a similar problem when he arrived in India.After explaining something in class, he asked his students if they understood.They answered with many different nods and shakes of the head.He thought some people had not understood, so he explained again.He soon found out that his students did understand.You have to know where a person is from to understand whether they mean"yes"or"no".

source: mctest

Once upon a time there was a cute brown puppy. He was a very happy puppy. His name was Rudy. Rudy had a best friend. His name was Thomas. Thomas had a nice dad named Rick. Thomas and Rudy had been friends for almost a year. Rudy and Thomas loved to play in the big back yard. Sometimes, Thomas would ask his friend Jacob to come to the back yard and play with them. Jacob would always bring his puppy too. Jacob's puppy was named Sally. Thomas and Jacob would run around the back yard and Rudy and Sally chased them and barked. They all had so much fun playing together. One day, Thomas told Rudy that tomorrow would be a very special day. It would be Rudy's birthday. Rudy was very excited. The next day came and Thomas threw a birthday party for Rudy. All of Rudy's friends were there and they had presents for him. Jacob brought Rudy a new ball and Sally brought him a bone. There was one more present for Rudy to open. When he opened the gift from Thomas, Rudy was so exited that he jumped and barked. It was a new red collar with a shiny name tag on it. It was the best gift Rudy had ever been given.


Q: Who was Rudy's best friend?

A: Thomas||Rudy had a best friend. His name was Thomas

Q: How long have they been friends?

A: almost a year||Thomas and Rudy had been friends for almost a year

Q: Where do they like to play?

A: in the back yard||Rudy and Thomas loved to play in the big back yard

Q: Does anyone join them?

A: Jacob||Thomas would ask his friend Jacob to come to the back yard and play with them

Q: What does he bring?

A: his puppy||Jacob would always bring his puppy

Q: What was its name?

A: Sally||Jacob's puppy was named Sally

Q: What did she bring to the party?

A: a bone||Sally brought him a bone

Q: What did Jacob bring?

A: ball|| Jacob brought Rudy a new ball

Q: Whose party was it?

A: Rudy's||It would be Rudy's birthday.

Q: Who was the last go give him a gift?

A: Thomas||one more present for Rudy to open. When he opened the gift from Thomas,

Q: What was it?

A: new red collar||new red collar

Q: Was he excited?

A: yes||Rudy was so exited

Q: What was shiny?

A: yes||shiny name tag

Q: Who planned the celebration?

A: Thomas||Thomas threw a birthday party

Q: Who was his dad?

A: Rick||Thomas had a nice dad named Rick

Q: Was he nice?

A: yes||nice dad named Rick

Q: Whose birthday was it?

A: Rudy's|| Rudy's birthday


Summary: Rudy had a best friend.Thomas had a nice dad named Rick.Thomas and Rudy had been friends for almost a year.Rudy and Thomas loved to play in the big back yard.Sometimes, Thomas would ask his friend Jacob to come to the back yard and play with them.Jacob would always bring his puppy too.Jacob's puppy was named Sally.It would be Rudy's birthday.The next day came and Thomas threw a birthday party for Rudy.Jacob brought Rudy a new ball and Sally brought him a bone.There was one more present for Rudy to open.When he opened the gift from Thomas, Rudy was so exited that he jumped and barked.It was a new red collar with a shiny name tag on it.It was the best gift Rudy had ever been given.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: cnn

(The Frisky) -- By T-minus 18 days until the Oscars and, of course, we are all starting to place bets on who we think will walk away with little golden men this year. Luckily, the Academy has proven itself to be pretty darn predictable over the years. If you're America's Sweetheart, you'll probably win Best Actress. If you sing in a flick, you are almost guaranteed Oscar gold. But there's another trend we've been noticing lately: the winners for Best Actress and Best Actor tend to be the person who's taken on the based-on-a-true-story role. In fact, 10 of the 20 top honors given in the 2000s went to actors who portrayed real people. Let's take a look, shall we? Last year, Sandra Bullock won Best Actress -- just days after taking home a Razzie -- for playing Leigh Anne Tuohy, the Southern mom who took in Michael Oher and helped coach him toward football greatness. The real Leigh Anne was in the theater to see Sandra accept her award. The Frisky: 12 Female Celebs Reveal Their True Size In 2008, Sean Penn won the Academy Award for Best Actor -- again! -- for playing Harvey Milk, the first openly gay man to be elected to public office in California. I still remember the gorgeous mermaid-scale gown that Marion Cotillard won when she accepted the Oscar for Best Actress in 2007 for her role in "La Vie En Rose." In the movie, she played Edith Piaf, an extremely popular singer in France who was also known for her out-of-control social life. In many ways, Marion won for playing the Britney Spears of 1950s France.

Summary: (The Frisky) -- By T-minus 18 days until the Oscars and, of course, we are all starting to place bets on who we think will walk away with little golden men this year.Luckily, the Academy has proven itself to be pretty darn predictable over the years.If you're America's Sweetheart, you'll probably win Best Actress.If you sing in a flick, you are almost guaranteed Oscar gold.But there's another trend we've been noticing lately: the winners for Best Actress and Best Actor tend to be the person who's taken on the based-on-a-true-story role.Last year, Sandra Bullock won Best Actress -- just days after taking home a Razzie -- for playing Leigh Anne Tuohy, the Southern mom who took in Michael Oher and helped coach him toward football greatness.The real Leigh Anne was in the theater to see Sandra accept her award.The Frisky: 12 Female Celebs Reveal Their True Size In 2008, Sean Penn won the Academy Award for Best Actor -- again!-- for playing Harvey Milk, the first openly gay man to be elected to public office in California.I still remember the gorgeous mermaid-scale gown that Marion Cotillard won when she accepted the Oscar for Best Actress in 2007 for her role in "La Vie En Rose."In the movie, she played Edith Piaf, an extremely popular singer in France who was also known for her out-of-control social life.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- Smart, successful, funny and handsome. Robin Williams seemed to have it all. And yet, today he is dead. Apparently, by his own choice. But why? What went wrong? The joy, spontaneity and humor of Robin Williams likely masked the daily torment he endured in his on-again-off-again struggle with depression. He made us laugh out here, but he was in pain in there. Unfortunately, I know that pain. In his death, we have lost one of the most talented and creative spirits on the planet. Still, his death by suicide should be a wake-up call for us all. It is to remind us that many of us are walking a fine line -- smiling on the outside while slowly dying on the inside. I didn't know Robin personally, so I am unable to speak with any certainty as to why he chose to end his life. But I have experienced that kind of torment and pain. For years, I, too, struggled with depression. And many days, I still do. Complete coverage on Robin Williams Those who are suffering will do just about anything not to feel the pain anymore. And in those moments, their brains become their worst enemies. It often takes an outside force to provide light, to make sure those dark thoughts aren't, as in the case of Robin, our last thoughts. According to the Centers for Disease Center, suicide rates increased from 2000 to 2011 from 10.4 deaths per 100,000 to 12.3 deaths per 100,000. The rate of suicide is higher and rising among men. In 2011, 78.5% of suicides were by men, at a rate of 20.2 deaths per 100,000.

A: no, And yet, today he is dead||And yet, today he is dead

Q: What happened to him?

A: suicide||Apparently, by his own choice.

Q: What made him do that?

A: depression|| on-again-off-again struggle with depression.

Q: Did that effect him all the time?

A: no, his on-again-off-again struggle with depression. ||his on-again-off-again struggle with depression.

Q: What hid his struggle from other?

A: his humor||The joy, spontaneity and humor of Robin Williams

A: Heseemed to have it all.||Robin Williams seemed to have it all.

A: 20.2||ate of 20.2 deaths per 100,000.

Q: What happened with suicide between 2000 and 2011?

Q: What was it in 2000?

A: 10.4 deaths per 100,000||0.4 deaths per 100,000

Q: And in 2011?

A: 12.3 deaths per 100,000.||12.3 deaths per 100,000.

A: yes||Smart, successful, funny and handso

source: wikipedia

Yorkshire ( or ; abbreviated Yorks), formally known as the County of York, is a historic county of Northern England and the largest in the United Kingdom. Due to its great size in comparison to other English counties, functions have been undertaken over time by its subdivisions, which have also been subject to periodic reform. Throughout these changes, Yorkshire has continued to be recognised as a geographical territory and cultural region. The name is familiar and well understood across the United Kingdom and is in common use in the media and the military, and also features in the titles of current areas of civil administration such as North Yorkshire, South Yorkshire, West Yorkshire and East Riding of Yorkshire. Within the borders of the historic county of Yorkshire are areas which are widely considered to be among the greenest in England, due to the vast stretches of unspoilt countryside in the Yorkshire Dales and North York Moors and to the open aspect of some of the major cities. Yorkshire has sometimes been nicknamed "God's Own County" or "God's Own Country". The emblem of Yorkshire is the White Rose of the English royal House of York, and the most commonly used flag representative of Yorkshire is the White Rose on a blue background, which after nearly fifty years of use, was recognised by the Flag Institute on 29 July 2008. Yorkshire Day, held annually on 1 August, is a celebration of the general culture of Yorkshire, ranging from its history to its own dialect.


Q: what is the emblem of the country

A: the White Rose of the English royal House of York|| the White Rose of the English royal House of York

Q: what does their flag look like

A: the White Rose on a blue background||the White Rose on a blue background

Q: how many years was it used before it was finally recognized

A: fifty years||y fifty years

Q: what organization recognized it

A: the Flag Institute||the Flag Institute

Q: what holiday is celebrated annually

A: Yorkshire Day|| Yorkshire Day

Q: what day is it celebrated

A: 1 August|| 1 August

Q: What was the country formally known as

A: the County of York,|| the County of York,

Q: does it have a nickname

A: Yes||abbreviated Yorks

Q: what is it

A: Yorks||Yorks

Q: what other nickname/ "phrase"

A: God's Own County||God's Own County

Q: where is the country located

A: Northern England||Northern England

Q: is this a large country

A: yes|| Due to its great size in comparison to other English counties, functions have been undertaken over time by its subdivisions

Q: does it have some of the greenest land

A: yes||Within the borders of the historic county of Yorkshire are areas which are widely considered to be among the greenest in England, due to the vast stretches of unspoilt countryside in the Yorkshire Dales

Q: why is this

A: due to the vast stretches of unspoilt countryside|| due to the vast stretches of unspoilt countryside


Summary: Yorkshire ( or ; abbreviated Yorks), formally known as the County of York, is a historic county of Northern England and the largest in the United Kingdom.Due to its great size in comparison to other English counties, functions have been undertaken over time by its subdivisions, which have also been subject to periodic reform.Within the borders of the historic county of Yorkshire are areas which are widely considered to be among the greenest in England, due to the vast stretches of unspoilt countryside in the Yorkshire Dales and North York Moors and to the open aspect of some of the major cities.Yorkshire has sometimes been nicknamed "God's Own County" or "God's Own Country".The emblem of Yorkshire is the White Rose of the English royal House of York, and the most commonly used flag representative of Yorkshire is the White Rose on a blue background, which after nearly fifty years of use, was recognised by the Flag Institute on 29 July 2008.Yorkshire Day, held annually on 1 August, is a celebration of the general culture of Yorkshire, ranging from its history to its own dialect.

source: mctest

There once was an elephant named Ellie. She really liked to eat peanuts. She lived with a circus and performed with clowns. One day she was really hungry and could not find any peanuts. She asked the lion, "Do you have any peanuts?" The lion said, "Sorry, I don't like peanuts, but the squirrel may have some." Ellie went looking for the squirrel and along the way saw a little girl. The little girl was crying. Ellie asked the little girl, "Why are you crying?" The little girl, Ava, said, "I lost my parents!" The elephant put Ava on her back and said, "I can help you look for them." They looked high and low for Ava's parents. Ellie made a loud sound with her nose and Ava's parents came to see what it was! Her parents were so happy to find Ava and so was Ellie. Ellie's stomach began to growl and Ava heard it. She dug into her parent's bag and brought out a bag of peanuts! Ellie ate the peanuts and everyone lived happily ever after.


Q: What girl did the elephant meet?

A: Ava||The little girl, Ava

Q: What was the elephant's name?

A: Ellie||There once was an elephant named Ellie.

Q: Did she live in a zoo?

A: no, She lived with a circus ||She lived with a circus

Q: Where did she live?

A: a circus||She lived with a circus

Q: What did she want to snack on?

A: peanuts.||She really liked to eat peanuts.

Q: Who did she get them from?

A: Ava, from her parents bag|| She dug into her parent's bag and brought out a bag of peanuts!

Q: Who did she help Ava find?

A: her parents||The little girl, Ava, said, "I lost my parents!"

Q: What did Ellie do to find them?

A: she made a loud noise||Ellie made a loud sound with her nose and Ava's parents came to see what it was!

Q: Where were the peanuts?

A: her parent's bag||She dug into her parent's bag and brought out a bag of peanuts!

Q: How did she carry the girl?

A: put her on her back||The elephant put Ava on her back and said

Q: Did Ellie meet a squirrel?

A: no, Ellie went looking for the squirrel and along the way saw a little girl. || Ellie went looking for the squirrel and along the way saw a little girl.


Summary: There once was an elephant named Ellie.She really liked to eat peanuts.She lived with a circus and performed with clowns.Ellie went looking for the squirrel and along the way saw a little girl.The little girl, Ava, said, "I lost my parents!"The elephant put Ava on her back and said, "I can help you look for them."Ellie made a loud sound with her nose and Ava's parents came to see what it was!She dug into her parent's bag and brought out a bag of peanuts!

source: mctest

The Rover family goes to the park for a wonderful picnic. The Rovers are a family of dogs. Mommy Rover packs a lunch which includes lots of doggie treats like dog bones and chew sticks. Daddy Rover brings the dog toys - an old Frisbee and a shoe that can be used for some fun activities - so their puppies, Paulie and Lucky, have games to play. It is a bright sunny day at the dog park. Lots of other doggie families are also at the park enjoying the nice weather. The Rovers see their friends, the Fidos, and invite them to join them for lunch. The two families eat and play together. Afterwards, it's nap time for the pups. The adult dogs clean up the leftover food. They pack the extra food in doggie bags - and pack their baskets and head home. The day was a lot of fun for all the dogs. Next week they plan to go to the beach and they might invite the Fidos to join them again.

A: the beach||Next week they plan to go to the beach

A: they might||hey might invite the Fidos to join them again.

A: yes||The adult dogs clean up the leftover food

A: Two||The two families eat and play together


Summary: The Rovers are a family of dogs.Mommy Rover packs a lunch which includes lots of doggie treats like dog bones and chew sticks.Daddy Rover brings the dog toys - an old Frisbee and a shoe that can be used for some fun activities - so their puppies, Paulie and Lucky, have games to play.It is a bright sunny day at the dog park.The Rovers see their friends, the Fidos, and invite them to join them for lunch.The two families eat and play together.The adult dogs clean up the leftover food.Next week they plan to go to the beach and they might invite the Fidos to join them again.

source: race

Linda was kind of late. Linda, 25, had a lot to do at work, plus visitors on the way: her parents were coming in for Thanksgiving from her hometown. But as she hurried down the subway stairs, she started to feel uncomfortably warm. By the time she got to the platform, Linda felt weak and tired -- maybe it hadn't been a good idea to give blood the night before, she thought. She rested herself against a post close to the tracks. Several yards away, Frank, 43, and his girlfriend, Jennifer, found a spot close to where the front of the train would stop. They were deep in discussion about a house they were thinking of buying. But when he heard the scream, followed by someone yelling, "Oh, my God, she fell in!"Frank didn't hesitate. He jumped down to the tracks and ran some 40 feet toward the body lying on the rails. "No ! Not you ! "his girlfriend screamed after him. She was right to be alarmed. By the time Frank reached Linda, he could feel the tracks shaking and see the light coming. The train was about 20 seconds from the station. It was hard to lift her. She was just out. But he managed to raise her the four feet to the platform so that bystanders could hold her by the arms and drag her away from the edge. That was where Linda briefly regained consciousness, felt herself being pulled along the ground, and saw someone else holding her purse. Linda thought she'd been robbed. A woman held her hand and a man gave his shirt to help stop the blood pouring from her head. And she tried to talk but she couldn't, and that was when she realized how much pain she was in. Police and fire officials soon arrived, and Frank told the story to an officer. Jennifer said her boyfriend was calm on their 40minute train ride downtown--just as he had been seconds after the rescue, which made her think about her reaction at the time. "I saw the train coming and I was thinking he was going to die, " she explained.


Q: How old is Linda?

A: 25|| Linda, 25

Q: was she early?

A: no, Linda was kind of late||Linda was kind of late

Q: who was coming to visit?

A: her parents||her parents were coming in for Thanksgiving from her hometown

Q: how did she feel walking down?

A: uncomfortably warm||feel uncomfortably warm

Q: and later?

A: weak and tired||felt weak and tired

Q: what did she lean against?

A: a post||She rested herself against a post close to the tracks.

Q: at the back of the platform?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: How old is Frank?

A: 43||Frank, 43

Q: was Frank alone?

A: no, Frank, 43, and his girlfriend||Frank, 43, and his girlfriend

Q: who was he with?

A: his girlfriend||his girlfriend

Q: who is?

A: Jennifer||Jennifer,

Q: what had they been doing?

A: talking||deep in discussion

Q: about?

A: about buying a house||about a house they were thinking of buying

Q: what did someone yell?

A: Oh, my God, she fell in!||Oh, my God, she fell in

Q: how far was he from the body?

A: about 40 feet||an some 40 feet toward

Q: was the train coming?

A: yes||uld feel the tracks shaking and see the light coming. The train was about 20 seconds from the station.

Q: how long before it got to them?

A: about 20 seconds||The train was about 20 seconds from the station

Q: was Linda easy to move?

A: no, It was hard to lift her||It was hard to lift her

Q: What did Linda think had happened?

A: she thought she'd been robbed||Linda thought she'd been robbed

Q: where was the blood coming from?

A: from her head||from her head


Summary: Linda was kind of late.Linda, 25, had a lot to do at work, plus visitors on the way: her parents were coming in for Thanksgiving from her hometown.But as she hurried down the subway stairs, she started to feel uncomfortably warm.By the time she got to the platform, Linda felt weak and tired -- maybe it hadn't been a good idea to give blood the night before, she thought.She rested herself against a post close to the tracks.Several yards away, Frank, 43, and his girlfriend, Jennifer, found a spot close to where the front of the train would stop.They were deep in discussion about a house they were thinking of buying.But when he heard the scream, followed by someone yelling, "Oh, my God, she fell in!He jumped down to the tracks and ran some 40 feet toward the body lying on the rails.By the time Frank reached Linda, he could feel the tracks shaking and see the light coming.The train was about 20 seconds from the station.It was hard to lift her.Linda thought she'd been robbed.And she tried to talk but she couldn't, and that was when she realized how much pain she was in.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: cnn

(CNN) -- The man labeled the most powerful vice president in American history remains resolute in his steadfast defense of his time in the White House in a new documentary that begins airing Friday. "I did what I did. It's all on the public record, and I feel very good about it. If I had to do it over again, I'd do it in a minute," Dick Cheney says in "The World According to Dick Cheney," which debuts at 9 p.m. ET on Showtime. The two-hour documentary tells the story of Cheney's life through his own comments, supplemented by a narrator and interviews with journalists, biographers, former aides and his longtime friend and mentor Donald Rumsfeld, the former secretary of Defense. While the film covers Cheney's unprecedented and controversial role as vice president, the first half of the film explores the surprising tale of his rise from a two-time Yale dropout with two drunk-driving arrests to the man who once stood behind the leader of the free world. In "The World According to Dick Cheney," produced by R.J. Cutler — also known for "The War Room" and "The September Issue" -- the former Washington powerhouse gets personal, but he still maintains his ever-steady, matter-of-fact tone. "When you came in at night after work, you'd go to the bar and down large quantities of Coors beer," he stated coolly, referring to the two times he was arrested for drinking and driving in his home state of Wyoming. Noticeably absent from the documentary are details about Cheney's post-White House life. The 72-year-old gives little to no insight about his heart transplant last year or his decision to support same-sex marriage. His younger daughter Mary wed her longtime partner Heather Poe in June.

A: Dick Cheney||Dick Cheney,

Q: What position did he hold?

A: vice president||vice president

Q: What did he have on his criminal record?

A: drunk-driving arrests||drunk-driving arrests

Q: What had he been drinking?

A: Coors beer||Coors beer,

Q: Where was he?

A: Wyoming||Wyoming

Q: How old is he at the time of the documentary?

A: 72||72-year-old

Q: What's the name of his daughter-in-law?

A: Heather Poe||Heather Poe

A: two-hours||two-hour

A: no, supplemented by a narrator||supplemented by a narrator

Q: What will the title of it be?

A: "The World According to Dick Cheney"||"The World According to Dick Cheney,"

A: heart transplant||heart transplant

A: Yale||Yale dropout

A: two||two-time Yale dropout

A: Donald Rumsfeld||mentor Donald Rumsfeld

A: secretary of Defense||secretary of Defense

A: yes|| interviews with journalists, biographers, former aides and his longtime friend and mentor Donald Rumsfeld,

Q: Does Cheney regret his past?

A: no, I feel very good about it.||I feel very good about it.

Q: What network aired the documentary?

A: Showtime||Showtime


Summary: (CNN) -- The man labeled the most powerful vice president in American history remains resolute in his steadfast defense of his time in the White House in a new documentary that begins airing Friday.It's all on the public record, and I feel very good about it.If I had to do it over again, I'd do it in a minute," Dick Cheney says in "The World According to Dick Cheney," which debuts at 9 p.m.ET on Showtime.The two-hour documentary tells the story of Cheney's life through his own comments, supplemented by a narrator and interviews with journalists, biographers, former aides and his longtime friend and mentor Donald Rumsfeld, the former secretary of Defense.While the film covers Cheney's unprecedented and controversial role as vice president, the first half of the film explores the surprising tale of his rise from a two-time Yale dropout with two drunk-driving arrests to the man who once stood behind the leader of the free world.In "The World According to Dick Cheney," produced by R.J. Cutler — also known for "The War Room" and "The September Issue" -- the former Washington powerhouse gets personal, but he still maintains his ever-steady, matter-of-fact tone."When you came in at night after work, you'd go to the bar and down large quantities of Coors beer," he stated coolly, referring to the two times he was arrested for drinking and driving in his home state of Wyoming.Noticeably absent from the documentary are details about Cheney's post-White House life.The 72-year-old gives little to no insight about his heart transplant last year or his decision to support same-sex marriage.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Plymouth (i/ˈplɪməθ/) is a city on the south coast of Devon, England, about 37 miles (60 km) south-west of Exeter and 190 miles (310 km) west-south-west of London, between the mouths of the rivers Plym to the east and Tamar to the west where they join Plymouth Sound to form the boundary with Cornwall. Plymouth's early history extends to the Bronze Age, when a first settlement emerged at Mount Batten. This settlement continued as a trading post for the Roman Empire, until it was surpassed by the more prosperous village of Sutton, now called Plymouth. In 1620, the Pilgrim Fathers departed Plymouth for the New World and established Plymouth Colony – the second English settlement in what is now the United States of America. During the English Civil War the town was held by the Parliamentarians and was besieged between 1642 and 1646. Throughout the Industrial Revolution, Plymouth grew as a commercial shipping port, handling imports and passengers from the Americas, and exporting local minerals (tin, copper, lime, china clay and arsenic) while the neighbouring town of Devonport became a strategic Royal Naval shipbuilding and dockyard town. In 1914 three neighbouring independent towns, viz., the county borough of Plymouth, the county borough of Devonport, and the urban district of East Stonehouse were merged to form a single County Borough. The combined town took the name of Plymouth which, in 1928, achieved city status. The city's naval importance later led to its targeting and partial destruction during World War II, an act known as the Plymouth Blitz. After the war the city centre was completely rebuilt and subsequent expansion led to the incorporation of Plympton and Plymstock along with other outlying suburbs in 1967.


Q: What grew as a commercial port during the Industrial Revolution?

A: Plymouth||Plymouth

Q: What is it located on the south coast of?

A: Devon||Devon

Q: In what country?

A: England||England

Q: What does Plymouth's early history extend to?

A: the Bronze Age||the Bronze Age

Q: Where was a first settlement?

A: at Mount Batten|| at Mount Batten

Q: What happened in 1620?

A: the Pilgrim Fathers departed Plymouth for the New World and established Plymouth Colony|| the Pilgrim Fathers departed Plymouth for the New World and established Plymouth Colony

Q: Was it the first English settlement?

A: no, second ||second

Q: Which number was it?

A: the second||the second

Q: Who held it during the English Civil War?

A: the Parliamentarians||the Parliamentarians

Q: When was it besieged?

A: between 1642 and 1646|| between 1642 and 1646

Q: What did the city's naval importance lead to?

A: its targeting and partial destruction during World War II||its targeting and partial destruction during World War II

Q: What happened to the city centre after the war?

A: it was completely rebuilt||was completely rebuilt

Q: What kind of a trading post was the early Plymouth?

A: it was a trading post for the Roman Empire||a trading post for the Roman Empire

Q: What village did it get surpassed by?

A: Sutton||Sutton

Q: What is Sutton called today?

A: Plymouth||Plymouth

Q: Is Plymouth in England, 38 miles south-west of Exeter?

A: no, 37 miles|| 37 miles

Q: Which river mouths is it in between?

A: Plym and Tamar||Plym to the east and Tamar

Q: Which boundary do the form?

A: Cornwall||Cornwall

Q: How many miles is it west-south-west of London?

A: 190||190

Q: What kind of exports came from Plymouth?

A: local minerals|| local minerals


Summary: Plymouth (i/ˈplɪməθ/) is a city on the south coast of Devon, England, about 37 miles (60 km) south-west of Exeter and 190 miles (310 km) west-south-west of London, between the mouths of the rivers Plym to the east and Tamar to the west where they join Plymouth Sound to form the boundary with Cornwall.Plymouth's early history extends to the Bronze Age, when a first settlement emerged at Mount Batten.This settlement continued as a trading post for the Roman Empire, until it was surpassed by the more prosperous village of Sutton, now called Plymouth.In 1620, the Pilgrim Fathers departed Plymouth for the New World and established Plymouth Colony – the second English settlement in what is now the United States of America.During the English Civil War the town was held by the Parliamentarians and was besieged between 1642 and 1646.Throughout the Industrial Revolution, Plymouth grew as a commercial shipping port, handling imports and passengers from the Americas, and exporting local minerals (tin, copper, lime, china clay and arsenic) while the neighbouring town of Devonport became a strategic Royal Naval shipbuilding and dockyard town.The city's naval importance later led to its targeting and partial destruction during World War II, an act known as the Plymouth Blitz.After the war the city centre was completely rebuilt and subsequent expansion led to the incorporation of Plympton and Plymstock along with other outlying suburbs in 1967.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: cnn

(CNN) -- For the first time since the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Christine Wilford plans do something remarkable on Thursday that once was routine: drop her child off at school. The last time her 7-year-old son, Richie, was in class was on December 14, when a gunman smashed his way into his school in Newtown, Connecticut, and killed 26 children and adults. As shots rang out, Richie's teacher locked the door and huddled her students into the corner as the shooter roamed the hallways, wielding an AR-15 assault rifle and firing. When it appeared safe, the children were then hurried away to a nearby fire station, where teary parents either reunited with their sons and daughters or learned that they had been killed. Nearly a month later, Wilford said her son still has trouble sleeping and is often scared by loud noises. Newtown chooses faith, charity, hope But on Thursday, he will join hundreds of other Newtown students returning to class for the first time since the tragedy. "We think it's good he's going back," Wilford said. "If I leave my child anywhere, I'm leaving a piece of my heart, so it's difficult to leave him." 'I think I'll be OK,' Sandy Hook student says after first day But Richie apparently isn't afraid and says he's looking forward to seeing his friends, she said. They won't be attending Sandy Hook Elementary, which police say remains part of an ongoing investigation into Adam Lanza, the gunman who also killed his mother before opening fire at the school.


Q: How old is Christine's son?

A: 7-years-old|| 7-year-old son, Richie

Q: What is his name?

A: Richie||he last time her 7-year-old son, Richie,

Q: Who is his mother?

A: Christine Wilford||Christine Wilford plans do something remarkable on Thursday that once was routine: drop her child off at school.

Q: What does she plan to resume doing with Richie?

A: drop her child off at school.|| drop her child off at school.

Q: When?

A: on Thursday||on Thursday

Q: True or False: That day will be the first time the school has opened since the tragedy.

A: true||or the first time since the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Christine Wilford plans do something remarkable on Thursday

Q: What does Richie have difficulty doing?

A: sleeping||Wilford said her son still has trouble sleeping and is often scared by loud noises.

Q: Does anything startle him?

A: yes||Nearly a month later, Wilford said her son still has trouble sleeping and is often scared by loud noises.

Q: What?

A: loud noises||Wilford said her son still has trouble sleeping and is often scared by loud noises.

A: Adam Lanza|| which police say remains part of an ongoing investigation into Adam Lanza, the gunman

A: to leave him|| to leave him

A: to see his friends||seeing his friends

A: No, But Richie apparently isn't afraid||But Richie apparently isn't afraid


Summary: (CNN) -- For the first time since the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Christine Wilford plans do something remarkable on Thursday that once was routine: drop her child off at school.The last time her 7-year-old son, Richie, was in class was on December 14, when a gunman smashed his way into his school in Newtown, Connecticut, and killed 26 children and adults.As shots rang out, Richie's teacher locked the door and huddled her students into the corner as the shooter roamed the hallways, wielding an AR-15 assault rifle and firing.When it appeared safe, the children were then hurried away to a nearby fire station, where teary parents either reunited with their sons and daughters or learned that they had been killed.Nearly a month later, Wilford said her son still has trouble sleeping and is often scared by loud noises.Newtown chooses faith, charity, hope But on Thursday, he will join hundreds of other Newtown students returning to class for the first time since the tragedy."If I leave my child anywhere, I'm leaving a piece of my heart, so it's difficult to leave him."'I think I'll be OK,' Sandy Hook student says after first day But Richie apparently isn't afraid and says he's looking forward to seeing his friends, she said.They won't be attending Sandy Hook Elementary, which police say remains part of an ongoing investigation into Adam Lanza, the gunman who also killed his mother before opening fire at the school.

source: mctest

A boy named Pedro was walking down the street one day, and he met a pretty girl in a pink dress who handed him a bell. It was made of metal, and looked worn and old. The girl said, this bell gave me my wish for a pink dress, but in order to keep my wish, I have to give the bell to someone else. Ring the bell three times to get your wish. Not two, not four, but three. When your wish arrives, give the bell to someone else. Pedro thanked the girl for the bell, and when she had gone, he rang the bell three times and wished for a puppy. Soon after, he saw a puppy on a street corner. It was black with brown and white spots. He picked the puppy up and hugged it. Then he saw his friend Alice. He gave the bell to Alice, who rang the bell and wished for a pretty bird. Soon a pretty bird landed on her shoulder. Alice thought the bell was a wonderful thing, and chose to keep it, rather than give it away. The next day when she woke up, her bird had flown away.


Q: How many times do you have to ring the bell?

A: three times||Ring the bell three times

Q: What was the name of the boy walking down the street?

A: Pedro||A boy named Pedro was walking down the street

Q: Who did he meet?

A: a pretty girl||met a pretty girl

Q: Was she dressed in blue?

A: no, met a pretty girl in a pink dress||met a pretty girl in a pink dress

Q: What did she give him?

A: a bell.||who handed him a bell.

Q: What did the bell give her?

A: a wish||this bell gave me my wish for a pink dress,

Q: What do you have to do to keep your wish?

A: give the bell to someone else.||in order to keep my wish, I have to give the bell to someone else.

Q: Did Pedro wish for a bike?

A: no, he rang the bell three times and wished for a puppy. ||he rang the bell three times and wished for a puppy.

Q: What did he ask for?

A: a puppy.||he rang the bell three times and wished for a puppy.

Q: What color was it?

A: It was black with brown and white spots.||It was black with brown and white spots.

Q: Who did he pass the bell to?

A: Alice||He gave the bell to Alice

Q: Did she ask for a cat?

A: no, who rang the bell and wished for a pretty bird. ||who rang the bell and wished for a pretty bird.

Q: What did she ask for?

A: a pretty bird||who rang the bell and wished for a pretty bird

Q: Did she pass on the bell?

A: no, Alice thought the bell was a wonderful thing, and chose to keep it,||Alice thought the bell was a wonderful thing, and chose to keep it,

Q: Why?

A: she kept it.|| Alice thought the bell was a wonderful thing, and chose to keep it

Q: What happened to her bird?

A: it flew away.||her bird had flown away.

Q: When did it fly away?

A: The next day.||The next day when she woke up, her bird had flown away.

Q: Where did the bird land before it flew away?

A: on her shoulder.|| Soon a pretty bird landed on her shoulder.


Summary: A boy named Pedro was walking down the street one day, and he met a pretty girl in a pink dress who handed him a bell.The girl said, this bell gave me my wish for a pink dress, but in order to keep my wish, I have to give the bell to someone else.Ring the bell three times to get your wish.Pedro thanked the girl for the bell, and when she had gone, he rang the bell three times and wished for a puppy.It was black with brown and white spots.He gave the bell to Alice, who rang the bell and wished for a pretty bird.Soon a pretty bird landed on her shoulder.Alice thought the bell was a wonderful thing, and chose to keep it, rather than give it away.The next day when she woke up, her bird had flown away.

source: mctest

Jack and Mackenzie wanted to do something fun during their day off from school. They knew that the library had story time on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Their mother told them they could go to the library every Tuesday for their story time. They packed up the car and drove to the library, ready for a fun morning. When they arrived to the story room, there were lots of other children their age, all sitting cross-legged and ready for the story of the day. The teacher told them they would be reading "The Wild Horse". She began to tell the story of Majestic, the wild horse who could not be calmed. His people had tried and tried to break him, but he was wild at heart. Every time they took him to the river to drink, he would run straight into the water and get soaking wet! He would splash and play until he was ready to go back home, where he would sleep for hours, having worn himself out playing.


Q: Did the library have story time?

A: yes||Their mother told them they could go to the library every Tuesday for their story time

Q: what days

A: Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday||They knew that the library had story time on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday.

Q: did Jack and Mackenzie want to go?

A: yes||Jack and Mackenzie wanted to do something fun during their day off from school.

Q: when did they have time free?

A: Tuesday||Their mother told them they could go to the library every Tuesday for their story time.

Q: did their mom say it was ok to go?

A: yes||Their mother told them they could go to the library every Tuesday for their story time.

Q: what vehicle did they use to get there?

A: car||the car

Q: what was the name of the story?

A: "The Wild Horse"||they would be reading "The Wild Horse"

Q: were there other children there?

A: yes||there were lots of other children their age

Q: how were they sitting?

A: cross-legged||all sitting cross-legged

Q: were there many of them?

A: yes|| lots of other children

Q: what was the name of the horse in the story?

A: Majestic||Majestic, the wild horse

Q: was he wild or calm?

A: wild||the wild horse

Q: what did he run into?

A: water||he would run straight into the water

Q: did he get wet?

A: yes||get soaking wet

Q: how wet?

A: soaking||soaking wet

Q: was he calm or did he splash?

A: splash|| He would splash

Q: where did he go when he was done?

A: home||go back home

Q: what did he do once there?

A: sleep||sleep for hours

Q: for how long?

A: hours||sleep for hours

Q: was he tired?

A: yes||having worn himself out playing.


Summary: Jack and Mackenzie wanted to do something fun during their day off from school.They knew that the library had story time on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday.Their mother told them they could go to the library every Tuesday for their story time.They packed up the car and drove to the library, ready for a fun morning.When they arrived to the story room, there were lots of other children their age, all sitting cross-legged and ready for the story of the day.The teacher told them they would be reading "The Wild Horse".She began to tell the story of Majestic, the wild horse who could not be calmed.Every time they took him to the river to drink, he would run straight into the water and get soaking wet!He would splash and play until he was ready to go back home, where he would sleep for hours, having worn himself out playing.

source: mctest

Once there was a white horse named Bob, who lived in a house with his best friend. His friend was a cat named Shelly who loved to play baseball. The two of them would go to the park and play baseball with Lucy a lamb who lived next door. It was Friday morning and Bob and Shelly were in the park waiting for Lucy. She was late and when she finally showed up she had forgotten the ball. "What can we use for a ball?" Bob asked. They looked around. There were rocks but they were too hard. There could get mud out of the pond but that would be too soft and splat when they hit it with the wooden bat. Finally Bob, being the tallest, saw that in a pile of plants that there were melons growing. "Let's use a melon," Bob said. "That's stupid," said Shelly, the practical one. "No hear him out," said Lucy. "It might work. "It'll work," said Bob, and he picked a melon and handed it to Shelly. "You pitch." "This is going to end badly, I'm afraid," Shelly said, throwing the melon at Bob who stood over home plate. "I know what I'm doing," Bob said, swinging the bat as hard as he could. When the bat hit the melon it splatted into a million pieces, raining sticky pieces down on Bob and Shelly and Lucy and a wedding party that had been setting up nearby. "Oops," said Bob.


Q: Did the horse have a name?

A: yes||Once there was a white horse named Bob,

Q: what was it?

A: Bob||Once there was a white horse named Bob,

Q: who was his friend?

A: a cat|| His friend was a cat named Shelly

Q: does it have a name?

A: yes||His friend was a cat named Shelly

Q: what is it?

A: Shelly|| His friend was a cat named Shelly

Q: where'd they go?

A: the park||The two of them would go to the park and play baseball with Lucy a lamb who lived next door.

Q: to do what?

A: play baseball||The two of them would go to the park and play baseball

Q: what'd they forget?

A: the ball||She was late and when she finally showed up she had forgotten the ball.

Q: What'd they use?

A: a melon||"Let's use a melon," Bob said.

Q: what happened?

A: it splattered into a million pieces||When the bat hit the melon it splatted into a million pieces,


Summary: Once there was a white horse named Bob, who lived in a house with his best friend.His friend was a cat named Shelly who loved to play baseball.The two of them would go to the park and play baseball with Lucy a lamb who lived next door.She was late and when she finally showed up she had forgotten the ball."Let's use a melon," Bob said.When the bat hit the melon it splatted into a million pieces, raining sticky pieces down on Bob and Shelly and Lucy and a wedding party that had been setting up nearby.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XII THE MEETING OF THE GEE EYES When Link Merwell went down again Dave looked at Nat Poole, thinking that lad might possibly attack him. But the dudish fellow was too scared to do anything but back away to a safe distance. "Don--don't you dare to hit me, Porter!" he cried, in a trembling voice. "Don't you dare! If you do I'll tell Doctor Clay!" "If you behave yourself I'll not lay my fingers on you, Nat Poole," was the reply. "Merwell brought this on himself--you know that as well as I do." "He's pretty badly hurt, I fear." "Oh, he'll come around all right," answered Dave. "You had better see to it that he gets to the Hall safely." "Are you going to leave me?" "Yes, I want to find Henshaw and the others." Nat Poole wanted to argue, but he did not dare. Dave waited until Link Merwell sat up and opened his eyes. Then he leaped on the ice-boat and flung off the three skates he found there. "Going away?" mumbled Merwell, when he could speak. "Yes, and after this, Link Merwell, see that you keep a civil tongue in your head," answered Dave, and then he trimmed the sail of the ice-boat, shoved the craft around, and started for the river. Dave was a good deal "worked up," but he had not deemed it wise to let his enemies see it. To be called a "poorhouse rat" had stung him to the quick, and once again when touched on that subject he had found his temper as ungovernable as ever.


Q: What is the title of the chapter?

A: The meeting of the gee eyes||CHAPTER XII THE MEETING OF THE GEE EYES

Q: Who is badly injured?

A: Merwell||Merwell brought this on himself--you know that as well as I do." "He's pretty badly hurt, I fear."

Q: Does Dave think he will recover?

A: yes||"Oh, he'll come around all right," answered Dave

Q: What does he tell Merwell to do?

A: keep a civil tongue in your head||"Yes, and after this, Link Merwell, see that you keep a civil tongue in your head

Q: How did Dave leave?

A: he left on an ice-boat|| Dave, and then he trimmed the sail of the ice-boat, shoved the craft around

Q: What did he throw off the boat?

A: three skates|| he leaped on the ice-boat and flung off the three skates he found there

Q: What insult had Dave been called?

A: "poorhouse rat"|| To be called a "poorhouse rat"

Q: True or False: This made Dave very angry.

A: true||he had found his temper as ungovernable as ever

Q: Was he able to keep his temper?

A: no, he had found his temper as ungovernable as ever||he had found his temper as ungovernable as ever

Q: Had he ever been able to?

A: no, his temper as ungovernable as ever||his temper as ungovernable as ever

Q: Who does Dave say he wants to find?

A: Henshaw and the others.|| I want to find Henshaw and the others.

Q: Did Poole want him to leave?

A: no, Nat Poole wanted to argue||Nat Poole wanted to argue

Q: What was Poole afraid Dave would do to him?

A: hit him||Don--don't you dare to hit me, Porter!" he cried

Q: Who did he threaten to tell if Dave did?

A: Doctor Clay|| If you do I'll tell Doctor Clay

Q: Did Dave hit him?

A: no, "If you behave yourself I'll not lay my fingers on you, Nat Poole,"||"If you behave yourself I'll not lay my fingers on you, Nat Poole,"

Q: Where does Dave say Poole needs to bring Merwell?

A: the Hall||You had better see to it that he gets to the Hall safely

Q: What is Poole's first name?

A: Nat||Nat Poole

Q: And Merwell's?

A: Link||Link Merwell

Q: What is Dave's last name?

A: Porter||Don--don't you dare to hit me, Porter!

Q: Did Poole shout at him in a strong voice?

A: no, he cried, in a trembling voice||he cried, in a trembling voice


Summary: CHAPTER XII THE MEETING OF THE GEE EYES When Link Merwell went down again Dave looked at Nat Poole, thinking that lad might possibly attack him."Don--don't you dare to hit me, Porter!"he cried, in a trembling voice.If you do I'll tell Doctor Clay!""If you behave yourself I'll not lay my fingers on you, Nat Poole," was the reply."Merwell brought this on himself--you know that as well as I do.""Oh, he'll come around all right," answered Dave."You had better see to it that he gets to the Hall safely.""Yes, I want to find Henshaw and the others."Nat Poole wanted to argue, but he did not dare.Then he leaped on the ice-boat and flung off the three skates he found there."Yes, and after this, Link Merwell, see that you keep a civil tongue in your head," answered Dave, and then he trimmed the sail of the ice-boat, shoved the craft around, and started for the river.To be called a "poorhouse rat" had stung him to the quick, and once again when touched on that subject he had found his temper as ungovernable as ever.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXVII TATO IS ADOPTED They canvassed the subject of their future travels with considerable earnestness. Uncle John was bent upon getting to Rome and Venice, and from there to Paris, and the nieces were willing to go anywhere he preferred, as they were sure to enjoy every day of their trip in the old world. But Mr. Watson urged them strongly to visit Syracuse, since they were not likely to return to Sicily again and the most famous of all the ancient historic capitals was only a few hours' journey from Taormina. So it was finally decided to pass a week in Syracuse before returning to the continent, and preparations were at once begun for their departure. Kenneth pleaded for one more day in which to finish his picture of Etna, and this was allowed him. Uncle John nevertheless confessed to being uneasy as long as they remained on the scene of his recent exciting experiences. Mr. Watson advised them all not to stray far from the hotel, as there was no certainty that Il Duca would not make another attempt to entrap them, or at least to be revenged for their escape from his clutches. On the afternoon of the next day, however, they were startled by a call from the Duke in person. He was dressed in his usual faded velvet costume and came to them leading by the hand a beautiful little girl. The nieces gazed at the child in astonishment. Tato wore a gray cloth gown, ill-fitting and of coarse material; but no costume could destroy the fairy-like perfection of her form or the daintiness of her exquisite features. With downcast eyes and a troubled expression she stood modestly before them until Patsy caught her rapturously in her arms and covered her face with kisses.


Q: Who was wanted to get somewhere?

A: . Uncle John||. Uncle John was bent upon getting to Rome and Venice, and from there to Paris, and the nieces were willing to go anywhere he

Q: Where did he want to go?

A: Rome and Venice,||ncle John was bent upon getting to Rome and Venice,

Q: What did Mr. Watson do?

A: urged them to visit Syracus||ut Mr. Watson urged them strongly to visit Syracus

Q: Why?

A: since they were not likely to return to Sicily again|| since they were not likely to return to Sicily again

Q: What did they canvas?

A: their future travels||They canvassed the subject of their future travels with considerable earnestnes

Q: How?

A: considerable earnestness.||They canvassed the subject of their future travels with considerable earnestness.

Q: What was a few hours away from Taormina?

A: most famous of all the ancient historic capitals w||e most famous of all the ancient historic capitals was only a few hours' journey from Taormina

Q: How long did they decide to stay in Syracuse?

A: a week||So it was finally decided to pass a week in Syracuse

Q: Who pleaded?

A: Kenneth||Kenneth pleaded for one more

Q: What did he want?

A: one more day||Kenneth pleaded for one more day in which to finish his picture of Etn

Q: To do what?

A: to finish his picture of Etna||Kenneth pleaded for one more day in which to finish his picture of Etna

Q: Did Uncle John confess?

A: yes||Uncle John nevertheless confessed to being uneasy as long as they remained on the scene

Q: What was he feeling?

A: Uneasy||Uncle John nevertheless confessed to being uneasy as long as they remained on the scene of his recent e

Q: Did Mr. Watson advise them?

A: yes||Mr. Watson advised them all not to stray far from the hotel,

A: the duke||On the afternoon of the next day, however, they were startled by a call from the Duke in person. He was dressed in his usual faded velvet costume and came to them leading by the hand a beautiful little girl.

Summary: CHAPTER XXVII TATO IS ADOPTED They canvassed the subject of their future travels with considerable earnestness.Uncle John was bent upon getting to Rome and Venice, and from there to Paris, and the nieces were willing to go anywhere he preferred, as they were sure to enjoy every day of their trip in the old world.But Mr. Watson urged them strongly to visit Syracuse, since they were not likely to return to Sicily again and the most famous of all the ancient historic capitals was only a few hours' journey from Taormina.So it was finally decided to pass a week in Syracuse before returning to the continent, and preparations were at once begun for their departure.Kenneth pleaded for one more day in which to finish his picture of Etna, and this was allowed him.Uncle John nevertheless confessed to being uneasy as long as they remained on the scene of his recent exciting experiences.Mr. Watson advised them all not to stray far from the hotel, as there was no certainty that Il Duca would not make another attempt to entrap them, or at least to be revenged for their escape from his clutches.On the afternoon of the next day, however, they were startled by a call from the Duke in person.He was dressed in his usual faded velvet costume and came to them leading by the hand a beautiful little girl.Tato wore a gray cloth gown, ill-fitting and of coarse material; but no costume could destroy the fairy-like perfection of her form or the daintiness of her exquisite features.With downcast eyes and a troubled expression she stood modestly before them until Patsy caught her rapturously in her arms and covered her face with kisses.

source: cnn

(CNN)Sen. Marco Rubio said he'll make a decision on running for president in the next few weeks and feels confident that he could obtain the resources to "credibly run a campaign and win," despite an increasingly crowded GOP field taking shape. In a wide-ranging interview with CNN's Wolf Blitzer, the Florida Republican also gave his thoughts on Republican efforts to defund the president's executive action on immigration, and further explained why he won't support the administration's new Cuba policy. 2016 Rubio, who released a new book "American Dreams" on Tuesday, said he's still deciding whether he thinks he can be more effective as president or as a senator under the new majority. He has already said he won't run for both offices in 2016. Marco Rubio: Radicalized individuals 'very real threat' to the West With power players Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush now considered likely contenders, Rubio said "they're both credible and well-funded" candidates but argued there would still be room for his campaign if he decides to plow forward. "I'm confident that if we decide to run for president ... we will have the funding and the resources necessary to credibly run a campaign and win," he said. "But I understand that the longer you wait, the harder it becomes to do that," he added. Romney tells donors he's considering 2016 bid Bush and Romney have already been in active in talking with big-money supporters and securing financial resources, making it strategically more difficult for other potential contenders like Rubio to lock down support from the GOP's donor class.


Q: What's Rubio going to decide in the next few weeks?

A: running for president||on running for president

Q: Does he feel confident about it?

A: yes||Marco Rubio said he'll make a decision on running for president in the next few weeks and feels confident that he could

Q: What policy is he not in favor of?

A: immigration||defund the president's executive action on immigration

Q: What type of people does he think are dangerous to the West?

A: Radicalized individuals||Radicalized individuals 'very real threat' to the West

Q: Who are some likely competition to him?

A: Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush||With power players Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush now considered likely contenders

Q: Does he think they have a lot of money and credibility?

A: yes||they're both credible and well-funded

Q: What was the title of his book?

A: American Dreams||Rubio, who released a new book "American Dreams

Q: When was it released?

A: Tuesday||Rubio, who released a new book "American Dreams" on Tuesday

Q: Has he decided if he'd be a better president or senator?

A: not yet||said he's still deciding whether he thinks he can be more effective as president or as a senator under the new majority.

Q: What happens the longer you wait?

A: the harder it becomes||But I understand that the longer you wait, the harder it becomes to do that

Q: When's Romney considering making his own bid?

A: 2016||Romney tells donors he's considering 2016 bid

Q: What type of resources are Bush and Romney trying to get?

A: big-money supporters||Bush and Romney have already been in active in talking with big-money supporters


Summary: (CNN)Sen. Marco Rubio said he'll make a decision on running for president in the next few weeks and feels confident that he could obtain the resources to "credibly run a campaign and win," despite an increasingly crowded GOP field taking shape.In a wide-ranging interview with CNN's Wolf Blitzer, the Florida Republican also gave his thoughts on Republican efforts to defund the president's executive action on immigration, and further explained why he won't support the administration's new Cuba policy.2016 Rubio, who released a new book "American Dreams" on Tuesday, said he's still deciding whether he thinks he can be more effective as president or as a senator under the new majority.Marco Rubio: Radicalized individuals 'very real threat' to the West With power players Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush now considered likely contenders, Rubio said "they're both credible and well-funded" candidates but argued there would still be room for his campaign if he decides to plow forward."But I understand that the longer you wait, the harder it becomes to do that," he added.Romney tells donors he's considering 2016 bid Bush and Romney have already been in active in talking with big-money supporters and securing financial resources, making it strategically more difficult for other potential contenders like Rubio to lock down support from the GOP's donor class.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: cnn

(CNN) -- The Japanese coast guard has rescued a British woman on a solo round-the-world trip whose boat was damaged when it rolled several times during a tropical storm, her team said Friday. Sarah Outen was rescued by the coast guard in rough seas Friday afternoon, the London2London team wrote on its website. "Sarah is now making her way to back to Japan," the team wrote. "We are awaiting final confirmation of details of Sarah's arrival in Japan and will let you know more once we have further information." A nearby merchant vessel and a coast guard plane kept watch on Outen until the rescue ship arrived. Sarah Outen: Around the world on two boats and a bike A small amount of water had gotten into the cabin of Outen's boat, Gulliver, but she was "bearing up well and demonstrating the strength and resolve that has brought her the huge distance on the journey so far," the team said before her rescue. She asked for pancakes, cold orange juice and grapes for her first meal after arriving in Japan. Planning a round-the-world trip Coincidentally, a second solo British rower is about 280 miles northeast of Outen's position and is also awaiting rescue, Outen's team said. Charlie Martell departed Japan last month on a quest to row 6,000 miles across the Pacific, his website says. Outen managed to send updates on Twitter while waiting for rescue, writing, "Trying hard2 smile and breathe calm keep getting interuptd by waves throwing us over." (sic)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Toronto is the most populous city in Canada and the provincial capital of Ontario. With a population in 2016 of 2,731,571, it is the fourth most populous city in North America after Mexico City, New York City, and Los Angeles. Toronto is the centre of the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), the most populous metropolitan area in Canada, and anchors the Golden Horseshoe, an urbanized region that is home to 9.2 million people, or over 26% of the population of Canada. A global city, Toronto is an international centre of business, finance, arts, and culture. Toronto is located in Southern Ontario on the northwestern shore of Lake Ontario on a broad sloping plateau interspersed with rivers, deep ravines, and urban forest. Indigenous peoples have travelled through and inhabited the area for more than 10,000 years. After the broadly disputed Toronto Purchase, when the Mississaugas surrendered the area to the British Crown, the British established the town of York in 1793, and later designated it as the capital of Upper Canada. During the War of 1812, the town was the site of the Battle of York and suffered heavy damage by U.S. troops. York was renamed and incorporated as the city of Toronto in 1834, and became the capital of the province of Ontario during Canadian Confederation in 1867. The city proper has since expanded past its original borders through both annexation and amalgamation to its current area of .


Q: where is Toronto located?

A: Canada||Toronto is the most populous city in Canada

Q: what part?

A: Ontario||Toronto is the most populous city in Canada and the provincial capital of Ontario

Q: how long have people been in the area?

A: More than 10,000 years||Indigenous peoples have travelled through and inhabited the area for more than 10,000 years

Q: what is the former name of Toronto?

A: York|| the British established the town of York in 1793,

Q: is Toronto a capital?

A: Yes||Toronto is the most populous city in Canada and the provincial capital of Ontario.

A: Ontario||Toronto is the most populous city in Canada and the provincial capital of Ontario

A: 1867|| and became the capital of the province of Ontario during Canadian Confederation in 1867.

A: Fourth most populous city in North America|| it is the fourth most populous city in North America

A: Lake Ontario||Toronto is located in Southern Ontario on the northwestern shore of Lake Ontario
