A: The Mississaugas surrendered the area to the British Crown.||After the broadly disputed Toronto Purchase, when the Mississaugas surrendered the area to the British Crown

Q: how has Toronto expanded past its original borders?

A: annexation and amalgamation||The city proper has since expanded past its original borders through both annexation and amalgamation

A: an urbanized region|| the Golden Horseshoe, an urbanized region

A: Business, finance, arts, and culture.|| Toronto is an international centre of business, finance, arts, and culture.


Summary: Toronto is the most populous city in Canada and the provincial capital of Ontario.With a population in 2016 of 2,731,571, it is the fourth most populous city in North America after Mexico City, New York City, and Los Angeles.Toronto is the centre of the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), the most populous metropolitan area in Canada, and anchors the Golden Horseshoe, an urbanized region that is home to 9.2 million people, or over 26% of the population of Canada.A global city, Toronto is an international centre of business, finance, arts, and culture.Toronto is located in Southern Ontario on the northwestern shore of Lake Ontario on a broad sloping plateau interspersed with rivers, deep ravines, and urban forest.Indigenous peoples have travelled through and inhabited the area for more than 10,000 years.After the broadly disputed Toronto Purchase, when the Mississaugas surrendered the area to the British Crown, the British established the town of York in 1793, and later designated it as the capital of Upper Canada.York was renamed and incorporated as the city of Toronto in 1834, and became the capital of the province of Ontario during Canadian Confederation in 1867.The city proper has since expanded past its original borders through both annexation and amalgamation to its current area of .

source: wikipedia

The Italian National Institute of Statistics (Italian: Istituto Nazionale di Statistica; Istat) is the main producer of official statistics in Italy. Its activities include the census of population, economic censuses and a number of social, economic and environmental surveys and analyses. Istat is by far the largest producer of statistical information in Italy, and is an active member of the European Statistical System, coordinated by Eurostat. Its publications are released under creative commons "Attribution" (CC BY) license. Istat was created in 1926 as "Central Institute of Statistics" (Istituto Centrale di Statistica), to collect and organize essential data about the nation. It took its current denomination with the reform of 1989. This also gave Istat statutory responsibility for the coordination and standardization of official statistics collected or published under the aegis of the national statistical system SISTAN, whose membership includes the statistical offices of ministries, national agencies, regions, provinces, communes, chambers of commerce, and similar bodies. Since 4 August 2009, Enrico Giovannini, former Chief statistician of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), has been the President of the institute. "Istituto Centrale di Statistica": "Istituto Nazionale di Statistica": Istat has 18 regional offices which host public access points named "Centri di informazione statistica", Statistical information centers. The center in Rome also offers data from Eurostat.


Q: What does Istat stand for in English?

A: Italian National Institute of Statistics||Italian National Institute of Statistics

Q: What does Istat stand for in Italian?

A: Istituto Nazionale di Statistica||Istituto Nazionale di Statistica

Q: What country does it operate for?

A: Italy||Italy

Q: Is it a member of the European Statistical System?

A: Yes||nd is an active member of the European Statistical System, coordinated by Eurostat.

Q: Who coordinates the European Statistical System?

A: Eurostat|| coordinated by Eurostat

Q: When was the first version of Istat created?

A: 1926||1926

Q: What was it called then?

A: "Central Institute of Statistics"||Istat was created in 1926 as "Central Institute of Statistics"

Q: When did it have a name change?

A: 1989|| It took its current denomination with the reform of 1989. T

Q: Who is the person who is in charge of it now?

A: Enrico Giovannini||Enrico Giovannini

Q: What is his official title?

A: the President of the institute||the President of the institute

Q: When did he begin this role?

A: 4 August 2009||4 August 2009

Q: How many regional offices does it have?

A: 18||18

Q: Does this agency deal with the population census?

A: Yes|| the census of population,

Q: Does this agency deal with the economic census?

A: Yes||economic censuses


Summary: The Italian National Institute of Statistics (Italian: Istituto Nazionale di Statistica; Istat) is the main producer of official statistics in Italy.Its activities include the census of population, economic censuses and a number of social, economic and environmental surveys and analyses.Istat is by far the largest producer of statistical information in Italy, and is an active member of the European Statistical System, coordinated by Eurostat.Istat was created in 1926 as "Central Institute of Statistics" (Istituto Centrale di Statistica), to collect and organize essential data about the nation.It took its current denomination with the reform of 1989.Since 4 August 2009, Enrico Giovannini, former Chief statistician of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), has been the President of the institute."Istituto Centrale di Statistica": "Istituto Nazionale di Statistica": Istat has 18 regional offices which host public access points named "Centri di informazione statistica", Statistical information centers.

source: mctest

David and Lucy waited in their mom's truck. They all were going to the circus to see the clowns. Their Mom had to take their little brother back into the house to get more diapers and go to the bathroom. David was worried because he did not want to miss the wolf clown. Lucy watched her brother rub his chin. "Why are you looking out the window?" she asked. "Mom needs to hurry. We might miss the clowns." "I am going to get out of the truck and draw triangles in the sand." Lucy said. "No! You might make us miss it." David cried. Before she could get out of the truck Lucy saw her mom and little brother walk out of the house. Her mom got in the truck and asked, "Okay kids are we ready to go?" David and Lucy yelled, "Yes!" When they got to the circus David and Lucy saw all the clowns. Their little brother was too young to go into the tent, so their mom stayed with him. The show ended and they walked to the truck. "What do you have there?" David asked Lucy "It is a bag I found in the tent." Lucy said. "We have to return that Lucy." Their mom said. "Why? It has cool stuff in it. I found it." Lucy said. "It is not ours." Their mom said. Lucy frowned as they walked to the lost and found and gave the bag back. Then they all went home. When they were washing up to go to bed Lucy said, "I fear some of those clowns. The wolf one was scary." "Lucy, I can save you. The wolf clown was a person in make-up." With that they shut off the bathroom light and went to bed. A great day had by all.

A: unknown||unknown

Q: What was in it?

A: cool stuff||"Why? It has cool stuff in it. I found it." Lucy said. "It is not ours." Their mom said. Lucy fro

Q: Who was in the truck?

A: David and Lucy||David and Lucy waited in their mom's truck

Q: why?

A: They were going to the circus|| They all were going to the circus to see the clowns

Q: Who's trruck was it?

A: their mom's||in their mom's truck

Q: was she there?

A: No, Their Mom had to take their little brother back into the house ||Their Mom had to take their little brother back into the house

Q: why not?

A: She had to take their brother to the house||Mom had to take their little brother back into the house to get more diapers and go to the bathroom.

Q: why?

A: to get diapers and go to the bathroom||to get more diapers and go to the bathroom

Q: Did Lucy get out of the truck?

A: No, Before she could get out of the truck Lucy saw her mom and little brother walk out of the house.|| Before she could get out of the truck Lucy saw her mom and little brother walk out of the house.

Q: Did she want to?

A: Yes||"I am going to get out of the truck and draw triangles in the sand." Lucy said.

source: race

Jack and James were good friends .One day,they were walking through the desert .During the journey they had a big fight,and Jack hit james in the face.James felt hurt,but he didn't say anything.Instead( ),he wrote in the sand:Today my best friend hit me in the face. They kept on walking until they found an oasis .They decided to get some water there .Suddenly James had trouble in the water,he fell into the mire and was in danger.Jack saved him at once.When he felt Ok,he wrote on a stone:Today my best friend saved my life. "After I hurt you ,you wrote in the sand, and now you wrote on the stone.Why?"asked Jack."When someone hurts us,we should write it down in the sand so that the wind of forgiveness can blow it away.But when someone does anything good for us,we must write it down on the stone,so no wind can blow it away." Since then ,the two friends have never fought with each other again. Hatred can bring you nothing but unhappiness .If you don't forgive others,you are making trouble for yourself.Keep a peaceful heart all the time and remember to be always thankful to those who ahve helped you!


Q: What type of friends were they?

A: good|| good

Q: Who got hit in the face?

A: james|| james

Q: Will where he wrote about it last a long time?

A: no, sand so that the wind of forgiveness can blow it away|| sand so that the wind of forgiveness can blow it away

Q: Where were they walking?

A: through the desert||through the desert

Q: Who did something heroic?

A: Jack||Jack

Q: Whose life was saved by his best friend?

A: James||James

Q: Where can you write something so the wind won't blow it away?

A: on a stone||on a stone

Q: What have James and Jack never done with each other again?

A: fought||fought

Q: Can hatred bring you something other than unhappiness?

A: no, nothing but unhappiness||nothing but unhappiness

Q: What should you be towards those who've helped you?

A: thankful||thankful

Q: Were the friends walking during the day or the night?

A: day||day

Q: Did James fall into lava?

A: no, into the mire|| into the mire

Q: What did James write in the first time?

A: Today my best friend hit me in the face.||Today my best friend hit me in the face.

Q: How did James feel when he got hit in the face?

A: hurt||hurt

Q: How many people are in this story?

A: two||Jack and James

Q: What do you make for yourself if you don't forgive others?

A: trouble|| trouble

Q: What did they want to get in the oasis?

A: water||water

Q: Were they enemies?

A: no, good friends||good friends

Q: What type of heart should you keep?

A: peaceful||peaceful

Q: Have they ever fought again?

A: no, ave never fought with each other again||ave never fought with each other again


Summary: Jack and James were good friends .One day,they were walking through the desert .During the journey they had a big fight,and Jack hit james in the face.James felt hurt,but he didn't say anything.Instead( ),he wrote in the sand:Today my best friend hit me in the face.They kept on walking until they found an oasis .They decided to get some water there .Suddenly James had trouble in the water,he fell into the mire and was in danger.Jack saved him at once.When he felt Ok,he wrote on a stone:Today my best friend saved my life."When someone hurts us,we should write it down in the sand so that the wind of forgiveness can blow it away.But when someone does anything good for us,we must write it down on the stone,so no wind can blow it away."Since then ,the two friends have never fought with each other again.Hatred can bring you nothing but unhappiness .If you don't forgive others,you are making trouble for yourself.Keep a peaceful heart all the time and remember to be always thankful to those who ahve helped you!

source: mctest

There was once a group of kittens who all liked to play together. Their names were Fluffy, Snowball, Cookie Monster, and Larry. Fluffy was the leader of the group, and whatever he said, the others did. One day he said, "Hey, everybody, let's go chase some mice." Everyone said "Yes!" except Larry. Larry did not want to chase mice. Larry wanted to drink some milk. He told Fluffy, and Fluffy only said "too bad." So everyone went off to chase mice. The next day Fluffy said, "Hey, everybody, let's go annoy the dogs." Everyone said "Yes" except Larry. Larry thought it was a bad idea. He told Fluffy, and Fluffy only said, "Too bad." So everyone went off to annoy the dogs. Except Larry. When the cats annoyed the dogs, the dogs became very angry. They started growling. They caught the kittens in their paws. The kittens yelled, "Help us!" Larry heard, and he ran over and hissed at the dogs. The dogs could not see Larry, only his shadow, which looked very big. The dogs got scared and ran away, and the kittens cheered. "Yay Larry! We'll do anything you want!"


Q: How many kittens were there?

A: Four||heir names were Fluffy, Snowball, Cookie Monster, and Larry.

Q: Who was in charge?

A: Fluffy||Fluffy was the leader of the group

Q: What did Larry desire?

A: milk||to drink some milk

Q: Did he get it?

A: no, and Fluffy only said "too bad."||and Fluffy only said "too bad."

Q: What did the group do?

A: chased mice||So everyone went off to chase mice

Q: Did they do something else?

A: yes||So everyone went off to annoy the dogs

Q: What did they do?

A: annoyed the dogs||So everyone went off to annoy the dogs

Q: Did they get hurt?

A: no, hen the cats annoyed the dogs, the dogs became very angry. They started growling. They caught the kittens in their paws||hen the cats annoyed the dogs, the dogs became very angry. They started growling. They caught the kittens in their paws

Q: How did they survive?

A: Larry hissed at the dogs||Larry heard, and he ran over and hissed at the dogs

Q: Did the dogs stay?

A: no, The dogs got scared and ran away,||The dogs got scared and ran away,


Summary: Their names were Fluffy, Snowball, Cookie Monster, and Larry.Fluffy was the leader of the group, and whatever he said, the others did.Larry wanted to drink some milk.He told Fluffy, and Fluffy only said "too bad."So everyone went off to chase mice.So everyone went off to annoy the dogs.When the cats annoyed the dogs, the dogs became very angry.Larry heard, and he ran over and hissed at the dogs.The dogs got scared and ran away, and the kittens cheered.

source: mctest

There once was a girl named Erin who had a really close friend named Kevin. They really liked being with each other, only it was difficult as Erin lived in England and Kevin lived in the United States. Because they both liked traveling and Erin wanted to see Kevin, she planned a trip to see him in the United States one summer. They had planned to travel around where Kevin lived and then go to see New York City at one point in order to see the sights and have a really nice steak dinner together. Once Erin arrived and met Kevin at the airport, she ran up to him and jumped into his arms, giving him a great big hug. They drove home where Kevin helped Erin organize her things before they changed and watched a movie together. The next day, they went out to have breakfast at the diner. They thought about getting eggs, French toast, or cereal... but couldn't make up their minds. Finally, Kevin asked the worker to bring out pancakes for the two of them to share. They had a really fun time together, visiting the beach, watching movies, and even visiting New York City like they had planned. In the morning, they went to see the Empire State building. In the afternoon, they saw the Statue of Liberty and Central Park. At night, they went to have their dinner and went back to their hotel. As Erin's trip was ending, Erin became really sad about leaving Kevin. They talked and came up with a plan for the months ahead which made Erin feel a lot better. Erin then went home and waited for Kyle to come to see her.


Q: Where did Erin live?

A: England||England

Q: Who was her friend?

A: Kevin|| Kevin

Q: What country did she travel to?

A: United States||United States

Q: Why?

A: to see the sights||to see the sights

Q: What cities?

A: New York City|| New York City

Q: How did they feel to see each other?

A: she ran up to him and jumped into his arms, giving him a great big hug||she ran up to him and jumped into his arms, giving him a great big hug

Q: What did they end up eating in the morning?

A: pancakes||pancakes

Q: Where did they visit in NYC?

A: Empire State building and the Statue of Liberty and Central Park|| Empire State building. In the afternoon, they saw the Statue of Liberty and Central Park

Q: How did she feel towards the end?

A: sad||sad

Q: Did she feel better?

A: Yes||n we

Q: What did they come up with?

A: came up with a plan for the months ahead||came up with a plan for the months ahead


Summary: There once was a girl named Erin who had a really close friend named Kevin.They really liked being with each other, only it was difficult as Erin lived in England and Kevin lived in the United States.Because they both liked traveling and Erin wanted to see Kevin, she planned a trip to see him in the United States one summer.They had planned to travel around where Kevin lived and then go to see New York City at one point in order to see the sights and have a really nice steak dinner together.Once Erin arrived and met Kevin at the airport, she ran up to him and jumped into his arms, giving him a great big hug.Finally, Kevin asked the worker to bring out pancakes for the two of them to share.In the morning, they went to see the Empire State building.As Erin's trip was ending, Erin became really sad about leaving Kevin.They talked and came up with a plan for the months ahead which made Erin feel a lot better.Erin then went home and waited for Kyle to come to see her.

source: mctest

One sunny day, Lisa and Jane went to the park to play. Lisa was eating her sandwich and saw Jane was swinging with Josh. Josh and Jane have been friends for 3 years and love to play together with Lisa. Lisa then made Jane and Josh a sandwich and called them both over to eat. Josh grabbed one and took a bite. Jane didn't eat her sandwich, she only ate the chips. Lisa asked if they wanted to go play on the slide and they all did. Josh went down the slide first. Jane was scared because the slide was too high up. Josh told Jane that if Lisa can go down the slide, she can too. They both watched Lisa go down the slide with no problem. Jane went up the slide and closed her eyes. When she opened them, she was at the bottom of the slide. Jane had done it and Lisa and Josh were cheering for her! Jane was very happy that she went down the slide. Since Jane went down the slide, everyone had a cupcake.


Q: where did Lisa and Jane go?

A: the park||Lisa and Jane went to the park to play

Q: to do what?

A: play||to play

Q: was anyone there besides Lisa and Jane?

A: Josh|| Jane was swinging with Josh

A: swinging|| swinging

A: 3 years||Josh and Jane have been friends for 3 years

A: yes||love to play together with Lisa

A: a sandwich|| Lisa then made Jane and Josh a sandwich

Q: did Jane eat it?

A: no, Jane didn't eat her sandwich, she only ate the chips||Jane didn't eat her sandwich, she only ate the chips

Q: what did she eat instead?

A: chips|| she only ate the chips

Q: after, did they play on the slide?

A: yes||Lisa asked if they wanted to go play on the slide and they all did.

Q: who went down the slide first?

A: Josh||Josh went down the slide first

Q: was Jane scared?

A: yes||Jane was scared because the slide was too high up

Q: did she finally go down the slide?

A: yes||she was at the bottom of the slide

Q: who cheered for her?

A: Lisa and Josh||Lisa and Josh were cheering for her

Q: was Jane happy or sad?

A: happy||Jane was very happy

Q: what did they eat to celebrate?

A: cupcakes||everyone had a cupcake

Q: did they all have one?

A: yes||, everyone had a cupcake.

Q: Did Lisa have a problem going down the slide?

A: no, Lisa go down the slide with no problem||Lisa go down the slide with no problem


Summary: One sunny day, Lisa and Jane went to the park to play.Lisa was eating her sandwich and saw Jane was swinging with Josh.Josh and Jane have been friends for 3 years and love to play together with Lisa.Lisa then made Jane and Josh a sandwich and called them both over to eat.Jane didn't eat her sandwich, she only ate the chips.Lisa asked if they wanted to go play on the slide and they all did.Josh went down the slide first.Jane was scared because the slide was too high up.They both watched Lisa go down the slide with no problem.When she opened them, she was at the bottom of the slide.Jane had done it and Lisa and Josh were cheering for her!Jane was very happy that she went down the slide.Since Jane went down the slide, everyone had a cupcake.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: cnn

(CNN)As art, film stills are often overlooked. The photographers tend to be anonymous; it's easy to imagine their work done by the director or cinematographer. Their images are often lumped in with the promotional machinery: Whether documenting the stars frolicking on set or getting down to business, it's just another form of salesmanship. Which is why the work of Ernst Haas is so striking. Haas, one of the 20th century's great photojournalists and image-makers -- an early member of the great Magnum Photos cooperative who was famous enough in his prime to have been the subject of a Museum of Modern Art exhibit in 1962 -- was also a regular on movie sets. It was a necessity in those early days, said John Jacob, the editor of a new book of Haas' movie photography, "Ernst Haas: On Set." "Working on film sets was really important to Magnum, and all of the photographers working with Magnum in the '50s did films," says Jacob, now the McEvoy Family Curator for Photography at the Smithsonian American Art Museum. Not only did the work pay off financially, but the photographers also established relationships with members of the industry, he said. And the stars and directors knew what they were getting: some of the best in the field. Photographers such as Haas were entrusted to bring their talent and style to the work. The photographers "are definitely producing work for posterity, that very much has their own fingerprint on it," Jacob said. Such distinction is obvious from looking at Haas' work -- some of which is as famous as the movies he worked on.


Q: What art form is usually overlooked?

A: Film stills||film stills are often overlooked.

Q: Do people usually know who created them?

A: No, The photographers tend to be anonymous;||The photographers tend to be anonymous;

Q: Who they actually think created those?

A: Director or cinematographer.||; it's easy to imagine their work done by the director or cinematographer.

Q: Who is Haas?

A: Photojournalist.||Haas, one of the 20th century's great photojournalists and image-makers

Q: Which era he was active?

A: 20th century||Haas, one of the 20th century's great photojournalists

Q: What he was member in?

A: Magnum Photos cooperative.||an early member of the great Magnum Photos cooperative

Q: What was important to them?

A: Working on film sets.||Working on film sets was really important to Magnum,

Q: Did the photographers feel the same way?

A: Yes.|| to Magnum, and all of the photographers working with Magnum in the '50s did films,

Q: Who is Jacob?

A: The editor of a new book.|| the editor of a new book

Q: Where he works?

A: Smithsonian American Art Museum.|| now the McEvoy Family Curator for Photography at the Smithsonian American Art Museum.

Q: Was it a lucrative job for photographers in the 50s?

A: Yes.|| Not only did the work pay off financially,

Q: What other benefits they got from that job?

A: Relationships with members of the industry.||the photographers also established relationships with members of the industry

Q: Were the directors happy about it?

A: Yes.||And the stars and directors knew what they were getting: some of the best in the field.

Q: According to Jacob was the photographers creating art work for the future?

A: Yes||The photographers "are definitely producing work for posterity, that very much has their own fingerprint on it," Jacob said.

Q: Did some of the works become famous?

A: Yes.||Such distinction is obvious from looking at Haas' work -- some of which is as famous as the movies he worked on.


Summary: (CNN)As art, film stills are often overlooked.The photographers tend to be anonymous; it's easy to imagine their work done by the director or cinematographer.Haas, one of the 20th century's great photojournalists and image-makers -- an early member of the great Magnum Photos cooperative who was famous enough in his prime to have been the subject of a Museum of Modern Art exhibit in 1962 -- was also a regular on movie sets.It was a necessity in those early days, said John Jacob, the editor of a new book of Haas' movie photography, "Ernst Haas: On Set.""Working on film sets was really important to Magnum, and all of the photographers working with Magnum in the '50s did films," says Jacob, now the McEvoy Family Curator for Photography at the Smithsonian American Art Museum.Not only did the work pay off financially, but the photographers also established relationships with members of the industry, he said.And the stars and directors knew what they were getting: some of the best in the field.The photographers "are definitely producing work for posterity, that very much has their own fingerprint on it," Jacob said.Such distinction is obvious from looking at Haas' work -- some of which is as famous as the movies he worked on.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXV WINNING THE CONTESTS Powell was again the first to throw the hammer and this time it went two feet beyond his first mark. "Good for you, Songbird!" said Tom. "I wish you had made it a yard." Jackson came up with a scowling face. He did his best, but this time fell behind Powell by four inches. "You ought to have stuck to the other hammer, Jackson," laughed the youth who composed songs. "Don't you throw that up to me!" whispered Jackson fiercely. "If you do I'll hammer you for it." "Is that meant for a pun, Jackson?" "No, it ain't. I won't stand being slurred. I'll pound you good." "With the hammer?" "No, with my fists." "Really? Well, you'll have to spell able first." Tom came next, as before, and now the hammer flew out four feet and nine inches beyond his first mark. "That shows what the other hammer can do," said Major Larry. Larson was as much out of sorts as Jackson, but nevertheless he resolved to do his best to win the contest. Up went the hammer with a mighty swing and circled through the air. But the throw was behind that of Tom by fourteen inches. "Hurrah! Tom Rover wins!" was the cry, and many rushed forward to congratulate him, while Larson and Jackson retired as quickly as they could and in great disgust. The next contest was a dash of two hundred yards and was won by a boy named Bird. "He's a bird!" sang out Tom loudly, and at this the crowd laughed heartily.


Q: Who fell behind Powell by four inches?

A: Jackson||Jackson came up with a scowling face. He did his best, but this time fell behind Powell by four inches.

Q: Who threw the hammer first?

A: Powell||Powell was again the first to throw the hammer

Q: Who came next?

A: Jackson||Jackson came up with a scowling face. He did his best, but this time fell behind Powell by four inches

Q: What is the name of the chapter?

A: WINNING THE CONTESTS||CHAPTER XXV WINNING THE CONTESTS

Q: Whose throw was behind Tom's by 14 inches?

A: Larson|| But the throw was behind that of Tom by fourteen inches.

Q: Was he in a good mood?

A: No, Larson was as much out of sorts as Jackson, bu||Larson was as much out of sorts as Jackson, bu

Q: Who won the 200 yard dash?

A: Bird||The next contest was a dash of two hundred yards and was won by a boy named Bird.

Q: What did the crowd laugh at?

A: Tom singing, "He's a bird!"||"He's a bird!" sang out Tom loudly, and at this the crowd laughed heartily.

Q: How far did Powell's hammer throw go?

A: Two feet beyond his first mark.||Powell was again the first to throw the hammer and this time it went two feet beyond his first mark.

Q: What name did Tom call Powell?

A: Songbird||"Good for you, Songbird!"

Q: Who told Jackson he should've stuck with other hammer?

A: The youth who composed songs.||"You ought to have stuck to the other hammer, Jackson," laughed the youth who composed songs.

Q: What did Jacskson say he wouldn't stand for?

A: Being slurred.||"No, it ain't. I won't stand being slurred.

Q: Who said that shows what the hammer can do?

A: Major Larry||That shows what the other hammer can do," said Major Larry.

Q: And who won the hammer throw?

A: Tom||Tom Rover wins!"

Q: What did Larson and Jackson do then?

A: Retired as quickly as they could and in great disgust.||while Larson and Jackson retired as quickly as they could and in great disgust.

Q: What was the next event?

A: A dash of two hundred yards.||The next contest was a dash of two hundred yards


Summary: CHAPTER XXV WINNING THE CONTESTS Powell was again the first to throw the hammer and this time it went two feet beyond his first mark."Good for you, Songbird!"Jackson came up with a scowling face."You ought to have stuck to the other hammer, Jackson," laughed the youth who composed songs.I won't stand being slurred."That shows what the other hammer can do," said Major Larry.Larson was as much out of sorts as Jackson, but nevertheless he resolved to do his best to win the contest.But the throw was behind that of Tom by fourteen inches.was the cry, and many rushed forward to congratulate him, while Larson and Jackson retired as quickly as they could and in great disgust.The next contest was a dash of two hundred yards and was won by a boy named Bird.sang out Tom loudly, and at this the crowd laughed heartily.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXIX Have you seen but a bright lily grow, Before rude hands have touched it? Have you marked but the fall of the snow, Before the soil hath smutched it?--BEN JONSON At the end of a week Mervyn made his appearance in a vehement hurry. Cecily's next sister, an officer's wife, was coming home with two little children, for a farewell visit before going to the Cape, and Maria and Bertha must make way for her. So he wanted to take Phoebe home that afternoon to get the Underwood ready for them. 'Mervyn, how can I go? I am not nearly ready.' 'What can you have been doing then?' he exclaimed, with something of his old temper. 'This house has been in such a state.' 'Well, you were not wanted to nurse the sick man, were you? I thought you were one that was to be trusted. What more is there to do?' Phoebe looked at her list of commissions, and found herself convicted. Those patterns ought to have been sent back two days since. What had she been about? Listening to Mr. Randolf's explanations of the _Hiawatha_ scenery! Why had she not written a note about that hideous hearth-rug? Because Mr. Randolf was looking over Stowe's _Survey of London_. Methodical Phoebe felt herself in disgrace, and yet, somehow, she could not be sorry enough; she wanted a reprieve from exile at Hiltonbury, alone and away from all that was going on. At least she should hear whether _Macbeth_, at the Princess's Theatre, fulfilled Mr. Randolf's conceptions of it; and if Mr. Currie approved his grand map of the Newcastle district, with the little trees that she had taught him to draw.


Q: What did Phoebe want a reprieve from?

A: exile||she wanted a reprieve from exile

Q: From where?

A: at Hiltonbury|| she wanted a reprieve from exile at Hiltonbury

Q: What did she teach Mr. Currie to draw?

A: little trees||with the little trees that she had taught him to draw.

Q: What did Mervyn do at week's end?

A: made his appearance||At the end of a week Mervyn made his appearance in a vehement hurry

Q: Who is Cecily's sister?

A: an officer's wife||Cecily's next sister, an officer's wife,

Q: Does the officer's wife have children?

A: Yes||an officer's wife, was coming home with two little children

Q: How many?

A: two|| an officer's wife, was coming home with two little children

Q: Are they grown up?

A: No, two little children|| two little children

Q: What was the purpose of the officer's wife's trip?

A: farewell visit||an officer's wife, was coming home with two little children, for a farewell visit

Q: Where was she going next?

A: the Cape||an officer's wife, was coming home with two little children, for a farewell visit before going to the Cape

Q: Who had to make way for her?

A: Maria and Bertha|| Maria and Bertha must make way for her.


Summary: Have you marked but the fall of the snow, Before the soil hath smutched it?--BEN JONSON At the end of a week Mervyn made his appearance in a vehement hurry.Cecily's next sister, an officer's wife, was coming home with two little children, for a farewell visit before going to the Cape, and Maria and Bertha must make way for her.Methodical Phoebe felt herself in disgrace, and yet, somehow, she could not be sorry enough; she wanted a reprieve from exile at Hiltonbury, alone and away from all that was going on.At least she should hear whether _Macbeth_, at the Princess's Theatre, fulfilled Mr. Randolf's conceptions of it; and if Mr. Currie approved his grand map of the Newcastle district, with the little trees that she had taught him to draw.

source: race

The Board Meeting had come to an end. Bob started to stand up and knocked into the table, spilling his coffee over his notes. "How embarrassing! I am getting so clumsy in my old age." Everyone had a good laugh, and soon we were all telling stories of our most embarrassing moments. It came around to Frank, who sat quietly listening to the others. Someone said, "Come on, Frank. Tell us your most embarrassing moment." Frank laughed and began to tell us of his childhood. "I grew up in San Pedro. My Dad was a fisherman, and he loved the sea. He had his own boat, but it was hard making a living on the sea. He worked hard and would stay out until he caught enough to feed the family. Not just enough for our family, but also for his Mom and Dad and the other kids that were still at home." He looked at us and said, "I wish you could have met my Dad. He was a big man, and he was strong from pulling the nets and fighting the seas for his catch. When you got close to him, he smelled like the ocean. He would wear his old canvas, foul-weather coat and his bibbed overalls. His rain hat would be pulled down over his brow. No matter how much my mother washed them, they would still smell of the sea and of fish." Frank's voice dropped a bit. "When the weather was bad he would drive me to school. He had this old truck that he used in his fishing business. That truck was older than he was. It would wheeze and rattle down the road. You could hear it coming for blocks. As he would drive toward the school, I would shrink down into the seat hoping to disappear. Half the time, he would slam to a stop and the old truck would belch a cloud of smoke. He would pull right up in front, and it seemed like everybody would be standing around and watching. Then he would lean over and give me a big kiss on the cheek and tell me to be a good boy. It was so embarrassing for me. Here, I was twelve years old, and my Dad would lean over and kiss me goodbye!" He paused and then went on, "I remember the day I decided I was too old for a goodbye kiss. When we got to the school and came to a stop, he had his usual big smile. He started to lean toward me, but I put my hand up and said, "No, Dad." It was the first time I had ever talked to him that way, and he had this surprised look on his face. I said, "Dad, I'm too old for a goodbye kiss. I'm too old for any kind of kiss." My Dad looked at me for the longest time, and his eyes started to tear up. Then he turned and looked out of the windshield . "You're right," he said. " You are a big boy....a man. I won't kiss you anymore." Frank got a funny look on his face, and the tears began to well up in his eyes, as he spoke. "It wasn't long after that when my Dad went to sea and never came back. It was a day when most of the fleet stayed in, but not Dad. He had a big family to feed. They found his boat adrift with its nets half in and half out. He must have gotten into a strong wind and was trying to save the nets and the floats." I looked at Frank and saw that tears were running down his cheeks. Frank spoke again. "Guys, you don't know what I would give to have my Dad give me just one more kiss on the cheek...to feel his rough old face... to smell the ocean on him... to feel his arm around my neck. _ . If I had been a man, I would never have told my Dad I was too old for a goodbye kiss."


Q: Why is Frank crying?

A: Dad went to sea and never came back.||Dad went to sea and never came back

Q: Where did he grow up?

A: San Pedro.||I grew up in San Pedro.

Q: What did his dad do for a job?

A: fisherman||My Dad was a fisherman

Q: Did he own a boat

A: Yes||He had his own boat

Q: Was this a hard job?

A: yes||but it was hard making a living on the sea

Q: What did he smell like?

A: the ocean||smelled like the ocean

Q: Did he ever transport his kid to school?

A: yes||When the weather was bad he would drive me to school

Q: When?

A: During bad weather.||When the weather was bad

Q: How old was he?

A: 12||I was twelve years old

Q: Was he proud of his dad's vehicle?

A: No, I would shrink down into the seat hoping to disappear|| I would shrink down into the seat hoping to disappear

Q: What was it?

A: Truck||old truck

Q: How old was it?

A: Older than his dad.||That truck was older than he was

Q: Did you know when it was close?

A: Yes||You could hear it coming for blocks

Q: How?

A: It would wheeze.||It would wheeze and rattle down the road

Q: Where did he park to drop of his son?

A: in front||He would pull right up in front

Q: What did the car emit when it came to a sudden stop?

A: A cloud of smoke||belch a cloud of smoke

Q: What was he attempting to do when a strong wind happened?

A: save the nets.||ave the nets and the floats."

Q: Did they find the boat?

A: Yes||They found his boat adrift

Q: Did they find his dad?

A: No, It wasn't long after that when my Dad went to sea and never came back.||It wasn't long after that when my Dad went to sea and never came back.

Q: What would he like now from his dad?

A: A kiss||ne more kiss on the cheek


Summary: "I grew up in San Pedro.My Dad was a fisherman, and he loved the sea.He had his own boat, but it was hard making a living on the sea.When you got close to him, he smelled like the ocean."When the weather was bad he would drive me to school.He had this old truck that he used in his fishing business.That truck was older than he was.It would wheeze and rattle down the road.You could hear it coming for blocks.As he would drive toward the school, I would shrink down into the seat hoping to disappear.He would pull right up in front, and it seemed like everybody would be standing around and watching.Here, I was twelve years old, and my Dad would lean over and kiss me goodbye!""It wasn't long after that when my Dad went to sea and never came back.It was a day when most of the fleet stayed in, but not Dad.They found his boat adrift with its nets half in and half out.I looked at Frank and saw that tears were running down his cheeks."Guys, you don't know what I would give to have my Dad give me just one more kiss on the cheek...to feel his rough old face... to smell the ocean on him... to feel his arm around my neck.

The teacher will cover such areas as kinds of film, light and lenses . Bring your own 35mm camera to class. Course charge: $50.Jan. 10,12,17,19, Tues & Thurs. 6:00-8:00 pm. Marianne Adams is a professional photographer whose photographs appear in many magazines. Understanding Computers This twelve-hour course is for people who do not know much about computers, but need to learn about them. You will learn what computers are, what they can and can't do, and how to use them. Course charge: $75. Equipment charge: $10. Jan.14, 21, 28, Sats. 7:00-10:30pm. Joseph Saimders is Professor of Computer Science at New Urban University. He has over twelve years of experience in the computer field. Stop Smoking Do you want to stop smoking? Jan. 4, 11, 18, 25, Wedns. 4:00-7:00pm. Dr John Goode is a practicing psychologist who has helped hundreds of people stop smoking. Typing This course on week-days is for those who want to learn to type, as well as those who want to improve their typing. You are tested in the first class and practice at one of eight different skill levels. This allows you to learn at your own speed. Each program lasts 20 hours. Bring your own paper. Course charge: $125. Material charge: $25. Two hours each evening for two weeks. New classes begin every two weeks. This course is taught by a number of business education teachers who have successfully taught typing courses before. Oil painting Oil paint is easy to use once you learn the basics. When you enroll at this oil painting course, you will learn to draw and learn to paint using many oil painting techniques under complete guidance and instruction. Together with the teacher's knowledge and your passion-we'll unlock your creativity and develop your potential! Course charge: $35. Jan. 5, 12, 19, 26, Thurs. 2:00-5:00 pm. Ralf Ericssion has taught beginners to masters and he has learned that everything builds on just a few basic concepts that he will show you here. Singing This course shows you how to deliver an accomplished vocal performance on stage and in the studio. Develop your vocal talents with professional warm-up routines and learn vocal techniques to gain confidence in your performance. You'll learn to perform classic songs before exploring your own songwriting ideas with a tutor. And finally you'll get the chance to record in a professional studio. Singing tuition may be in groups or one-to-one. We have Choral singing, Gospel singing, Folk singing and many other styles of song. All styles are welcome and no previous experience is required. Please read on for course contents and reviews from our students. Course charge: $90. Jan. 10, 12, 17, 19, Tues. & Thurs. 5:30-8:30pm. Peter Syrus is a Grammy award winning tutor.

source: cnn

London (CNN) -- Janet Jackson is opening up for the first time about a duet with her brother that she's reviving two years after his death. Jackson took to the stage in London on Thursday and performed their 1995 song Scream as video of Michael Jackson played and his voice filled Royal Albert Hall. The reworked duet follows in the footsteps of jazz pianist and singer Nat King Cole and his daughter, Natalie Cole. In 1991 she turned her father's famous 1961 recording "Unforgettable" into a father-daughter duet. Janet Jackson said she did the original duet at the request of her brother years ago. "I was on the Rhythm Nation tour and Mike actually asked me to do a song with him and I told him no. I didn't want to do it. I felt I hadn't come into my own and I hadn't fully made a name for myself ... and I didn't want to ride anyone's coattails," she said. "And I remember being in the Janet Tour a few good years later and he asked me again if I would do a song with him. And I felt, at that point, I'd carved my own little niche in this world of music and I felt okay, I can do this now and that's how it came about." Jackson said that performing the song alongside her brother again isn't difficult. "It feels great -- just listening to and hearing his voice," she said, adding that on stage she finds herself, "remembering the experience of recording it."


Q: Who is doing a show in London?

A: Janet Jackson||Jackson took to the stage in London

Q: What day?

A: Thursday||Jackson took to the stage in London on Thursday

Q: Who is she doing a duet with?

A: Michael Jackson||Jackson took to the stage in London on Thursday and performed their 1995 song Scream as video of Michael Jackson played and his voice filled Royal Albert Hall.

Q: Is his portion live?

A: no, as video of Michael Jackson played and his voice filled Royal Albert Hall. || as video of Michael Jackson played and his voice filled Royal Albert Hall.

Q: Why not?

A: he died||brother that she's reviving two years after his death.

Q: When?

A: two years ago||two years after his death

Q: How is he being heard?

A: video|| as video of Michael Jackson played and his voice filled Royal Albert Hall.

Q: What song are they singing?

A: 1995||their 1995 song Scream

A: she was on tour||"I was on the Rhythm Nation tour

Q: Who's idea was it?

A: his||"And I remember being in the Janet Tour a few good years later and he asked me again if I would do a song with him

Q: Was it the first time he'd asked?

A: no, "I was on the Rhythm Nation tour and Mike actually asked me to do a song with him and I told him no||"I was on the Rhythm Nation tour and Mike actually asked me to do a song with him and I told him no

Q: When was the first?

A: the Rhythm Nation tour||"I was on the Rhythm Nation tour and Mike actually asked me to do a song with him and I told him no

Summary: London (CNN) -- Janet Jackson is opening up for the first time about a duet with her brother that she's reviving two years after his death.Jackson took to the stage in London on Thursday and performed their 1995 song Scream as video of Michael Jackson played and his voice filled Royal Albert Hall.The reworked duet follows in the footsteps of jazz pianist and singer Nat King Cole and his daughter, Natalie Cole."I was on the Rhythm Nation tour and Mike actually asked me to do a song with him and I told him no.I felt I hadn't come into my own and I hadn't fully made a name for myself ... and I didn't want to ride anyone's coattails," she said."And I remember being in the Janet Tour a few good years later and he asked me again if I would do a song with him.Jackson said that performing the song alongside her brother again isn't difficult.

source: mctest

One day Mary took a walk to the park. The park was very close to her house. One her way to the park she passed her friend Kim's house. Mary stopped by and asked if Kim wanted to play. Kim said yes. Mary and Kim walked together to the park. John's house was three houses down. Mary and Kim stopped by to ask John if he wanted to play at the park. John said no. He was afraid of being chased by a squirrel. Mary worried that John didn't like her, but John thought she was a good friend. So Mary and Kim went to the park to play. They loved the park. They loved the flowers, and the swings! Soon it was dinnertime and the girls went home. What a lovely day at the park.


Q: Who took a walk to the park?

A: Mary||Mary took a walk to the park

Q: Was it close to her house?

A: yes||The park was very close to her house

Q: Whose house did she pass on her way there?

A: Kim's||One her way to the park she passed her friend Kim's hous

Q: Did she stop?

A: yes||Mary stopped

Q: Why?

A: She asked her if she wanted to play||asked if Kim wanted to play.

Q: What did she say?

A: yes||. Kim said yes

Q: Did they walk or ride to the park?

A: walked||Mary and Kim walked together to the park.

Q: Whose house was nearby?

A: John's||John's house was three houses down

Q: How many houses down was it?

A: Three||ohn's house was three houses down.

Q: Did they ask him if he wanted to play?

A: yes|| ask John if he wanted to play at the park

Q: What did he say?

A: no, John said no. H|| John said no. H

Q: Why?

A: He was afraid of being chased by a squirre|| He was afraid of being chased by a squirre

Q: What was Mary worried about?

A: that he didn't like her|| Mary worried that John didn't like her,

Q: Did he?

A: yes||but John thought she was a good friend.

Q: Did the girls continue to the park?

A: Yes||So Mary and Kim went to the park to play

Q: What did they love about the park?

A: the flowers and the swings||They loved the flowers, and the swings!

Q: When did they go home?

A: Dinnertime.|| it was dinnertime and the girls went home

Q: What kind of day did they have?

A: a lovely one|| What a lovely day


Summary: One day Mary took a walk to the park.The park was very close to her house.One her way to the park she passed her friend Kim's house.Mary stopped by and asked if Kim wanted to play.Kim said yes.Mary and Kim walked together to the park.John's house was three houses down.Mary and Kim stopped by to ask John if he wanted to play at the park.John said no.He was afraid of being chased by a squirrel.Mary worried that John didn't like her, but John thought she was a good friend.So Mary and Kim went to the park to play.They loved the flowers, and the swings!Soon it was dinnertime and the girls went home.What a lovely day at the park.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Strabo (; "Strabōn"; 64 or 63 BC) was a Greek geographer, philosopher, and historian who lived in Asia Minor during the transitional period of the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire. Strabo was born to an affluent family from Amaseia in Pontus (modern Amasya, Turkey), a city that he said was situated the approximate equivalent of 75 km from the Black Sea. Pontus had recently fallen to the Roman Republic, and although politically he was a proponent of Roman imperialism, Strabo belonged on his mother's side to a prominent family whose members had held important positions under the previous resisting regime of King Mithridates VI of Pontus. Strabo's life was characterized by extensive travels. He journeyed to Egypt and Kush, as far west as coastal Tuscany and as far south as Ethiopia in addition to his travels in Asia Minor and the time he spent in Rome. Travel throughout the Mediterranean and Near East, especially for scholarly purposes, was popular during this era and was facilitated by the relative peace enjoyed throughout the reign of Augustus (27 BC – AD 14). He moved to Rome in 44 BC, and stayed there, studying and writing, until at least 31 BC. In 29 BC, on his way to Corinth (where Augustus was at the time), he visited the island of Gyaros in the Aegean Sea. Around 25 BC, he sailed up the Nile until reaching Philae, after which point there is little record of his proceedings until AD 17.


Q: Who was born to a rich family?

A: Strabo||Strabo belonged on his mother's side to a prominent family whose members had held important positions under the previous resisting regime of King Mithridates VI of Pontus.

Q: Where were they from?

A: Amaseia||Strabo was born to an affluent family from Amaseia

Q: How far from the Black Sea is it?

A: about 75 km||a city that he said was situated the approximate equivalent of 75 km from the Black Sea

A: King Mithridates VI of Pontus.||Strabo belonged on his mother's side to a prominent family whose members had held important positions under the previous resisting regime of King Mithridates VI of Pontus.

A: the Roman Republic||ontus had recently fallen to the Roman Republic

A: Roman imperialism||politically he was a proponent of Roman imperialism

A: Amasya, Turkey|| Pontus (modern Amasya, Turkey

Summary: Strabo (; "Strabōn"; 64 or 63 BC) was a Greek geographer, philosopher, and historian who lived in Asia Minor during the transitional period of the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire.Strabo was born to an affluent family from Amaseia in Pontus (modern Amasya, Turkey), a city that he said was situated the approximate equivalent of 75 km from the Black Sea.Pontus had recently fallen to the Roman Republic, and although politically he was a proponent of Roman imperialism, Strabo belonged on his mother's side to a prominent family whose members had held important positions under the previous resisting regime of King Mithridates VI of Pontus.Travel throughout the Mediterranean and Near East, especially for scholarly purposes, was popular during this era and was facilitated by the relative peace enjoyed throughout the reign of Augustus (27 BC – AD 14).He moved to Rome in 44 BC, and stayed there, studying and writing, until at least 31 BC.In 29 BC, on his way to Corinth (where Augustus was at the time), he visited the island of Gyaros in the Aegean Sea.Around 25 BC, he sailed up the Nile until reaching Philae, after which point there is little record of his proceedings until AD 17.

source: race

Thelma was such a life-loving and easy-going person that she was always full of energy and never felt sad. When she was at the age of 75, her husband passed away. Her children were afraid she was lonely and suggested that she move to a "Senior living community ". Thelma thought that was a good idea and decided to do so. Shortly after moving in, Thelma became many activities' director. She loved to organize all kinds of things for the people in the community. So quickly she became very popular and made many friends. When Thelma turned 80, her new friends showed their appreciation by throwing a surprise birthday party for her. When Thelma entered the dining room for dinner that night, she was greeted by a standing ovation and one of _ led her to the head table. The night was filled with laughter and entertainment, but throughout the evening, Thelma could not take her eyes off a gentleman sitting at the other end of the table. When the party ended, Thelma quickly rose from her seat and rushed over to the man "Pardon me," Thelma said, "Please forgive me if I made you feel uncomfortable by _ at you all night. I just couldn't help myself from looking your way. You see, you look just like my fifth husband." "Your fifth husband!" replied the gentleman. "Forgive me for asking, but how many times have you been married? " With that, a smile appeared on Thelma's face as she replied, "Four." They were married shortly after that.

A: Senior living community||Senior living community

A: Thelma||Thelma

Fox was hungry. He was very hungry because he had not eaten in 3 days. Bird flew to Fox's home and talked to him. Bird asked Fox why he had not eaten in so long. Fox said it was too cold outside. Bird said "But you have such nice, thick fur!" \tabFox said, "Well I am really too lazy." Bird said he would bring Fox any food he saw when he was flying around and left. \tabBird flew to other side of the forest to visit Tiger, but he did not see any food on the way. Tiger was reading a book about cooking. "Hmm, there are so many delicious foods I have not tried yet." Bird arrived at Tiger's den and said "Hello Tiger, what are you doing?" Tiger said "I am trying to think of what to have for dinner." \tab"How can you choose?" asked Bird. \tab"Why don't we pick a color and eat something that is that color" said Tiger. \tab"How about red?" said Bird. \tab"Yes! Like a fox!" said Tiger. \tab"I know where a fox is!" said Bird, "I'll show you." So Tiger followed Bird all the way across the forest. Finally they arrived outside Fox's home. "Pretend you are asleep and wait right here", said Bird to Tiger. Bird then flew in to Fox's home very happy. "Fox, I have found a big yummy treat for you and you won't ever be hungry again! Follow me outside." Fox followed Bird outside and said "WOW! A whole tiger! Yum!" Then Tiger jumped up and gobbled up Fox in one bite. Fox was now inside Tiger's belly and he yelled out "Bird, you lied to me! Why?!" \tab"Because you ate my sister!" yelled Bird. \tab"That wasn't me, it was Snake!" cried Fox. \tab"Oh. Um, sorry Fox. Well at least you don't have to hunt for food now" said Bird. Tiger laughed so hard that he coughed up Fox. Then they all went and got ice cream.

A: Bird.||Bird flew to Fox's home

A: Said it was too cold outside.||Fox said it was too cold outside

source: cnn

(CNN) -- There are plenty of country songs about how to be a man. One way is to face the music, and two country crooners did that on Thursday. Ty Herndon and Billy Gilman came out as being gay. Herdon went first, in interviews with People Magazine and Entertainment Tonight. His revelation inspired Gilman to do go public as well. Gilman posted a message to YouTube, thanking Herndon for breaking the ice. He preferred telling his fans directly, from the comfort of home, to sitting down with the press, he said. But an encounter with a journalist also prodded him to spill the beans before someone else did. The reporter bumped into Gilman in a public place and snapped a photo of him -- with his partner. "It was in that moment that I knew that I'd rather it be from me than you reading it somewhere else," Gilman told fans. He also feared being ripped over his sexuality in an article. Country and LGBTQ In the genre of country, Thursday's tune was a tough one to sing, Gilman said. "Being a gay, male country artist is not the best thing." At age 26, he's had a long career, having rocketed up the charts at age 11 with his then silky, pre-voice-change alto pipes, according to his biography on AllMusic.com. But currently, he's hitting snags. Rumors about his sexual orientation have been going around, he said, and he thinks major music labels may have thumbed their noses at him over it.


Q: Who came out?

A: Ty Herndon and Billy Gilman||Ty Herndon and Billy Gilman came out as being gay.

Q: What they do?

A: they are country singers||wo country crooners did that on Thursday.

Q: Who went first about it?

A: Herdo||Herdon went first,

Q: Where?

A: in interviews with People Magazine and Entertainment Tonight||Herdon went first, in interviews with People Magazine and Entertainment Tonight.

Q: Did his partner follow suit?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: Where he acknowledged that?

A: YouTube||Gilman posted a message to YouTube

Q: Why?

A: thanking Herndon|| thanking Herndon for breaking the ice

Q: From where he posted that message?

A: home||He preferred telling his fans directly, from the comfort of home,

Q: Were there rumors about their sexual orientation?

A: no, "It was in that moment that I knew that I'd rather it be from me than you reading it somewhere else," Gilman told fans. He also feared being ripped over his sexuality in an article. ||"It was in that moment that I knew that I'd rather it be from me than you reading it somewhere else," Gilman told fans. He also feared being ripped over his sexuality in an article.

Q: Did Gilman meet journalists later?

A: no, "It was in that moment that I knew that I'd rather it be from me than you reading it somewhere else," Gilman told fans. He also feared being ripped over his sexuality in an article. ||"It was in that moment that I knew that I'd rather it be from me than you reading it somewhere else," Gilman told fans. He also feared being ripped over his sexuality in an article.


Summary: (CNN) -- There are plenty of country songs about how to be a man.One way is to face the music, and two country crooners did that on Thursday.Ty Herndon and Billy Gilman came out as being gay.Herdon went first, in interviews with People Magazine and Entertainment Tonight.Gilman posted a message to YouTube, thanking Herndon for breaking the ice.He preferred telling his fans directly, from the comfort of home, to sitting down with the press, he said."It was in that moment that I knew that I'd rather it be from me than you reading it somewhere else," Gilman told fans.

source: wikipedia

Leeds is a city in West Yorkshire, England. Historically in Yorkshire's West Riding, the history of Leeds can be traced to the 5th century, when the name referred to a wooded area of the Kingdom of Elmet. The name has been applied to many administrative entities over the centuries. It changed from being the name of a small manorial borough in the 13th century, through several incarnations, to being the name attached to the present metropolitan borough. In the 17th and 18th centuries Leeds became a major centre for the production and trading of wool. During the Industrial Revolution, Leeds developed into a major mill town; wool was the dominant industry but flax, engineering, iron foundries, printing, and other industries were important. From being a compact market town in the valley of the River Aire in the 16th century Leeds expanded and absorbed the surrounding villages to become a populous urban centre by the mid-20th century. Leeds has a population of around 781,700 (2016) making it the third largest city in the United Kingdom. The city lies within the United Kingdom's fourth-most populous urban area, with a population of 2.3 million. Today, Leeds has the most diverse economy of all the UK's main employment centres and has seen the fastest rate of private-sector jobs growth of any UK city and has the highest ratio of public to private sector jobs of all the UK's Core Cities. Leeds has the third-largest jobs total by local authority area with 480,000 in employment and self-employment at the beginning of 2015. Leeds is also ranked as a gamma world city by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network; and is considered the cultural, financial and commercial heart of the West Yorkshire Urban Area. Leeds is served by four universities, and has the fourth largest student population in the country and has the country's fourth largest urban economy.


Q: What city referred to a wooded area?

A: Leeds||Leeds can be traced to the 5th century, when the name referred to a wooded area

Q: What kingdom was this area in?

A: the Kingdom of Elmet||wooded area of the Kingdom of Elmet

Q: In what country is it?

A: England||Leeds is a city in West Yorkshire, England

Q: What part?

A: West Yorkshire||Leeds is a city in West Yorkshire, England

Q: When did wool trade become popular?

A: In the 17th and 18th centuries||In the 17th and 18th centuries Leeds became a major centre for the production and trading of wool.

Q: Was it the strongest industry?

A: yes||wool was the dominant industry

Q: How many were close behind?

A: four and others||but flax, engineering, iron foundries, printing, and other industries

Q: Name them.

A: flax, engineering, iron foundries and printing|| flax, engineering, iron foundries, printing, and other industries were important

Q: How can the city's economy be described today?

A: the most diverse of all the UK's main employment centres||Leeds has the most diverse economy of all the UK's main employment centres

A: four||Leeds is served by four universities

Summary: Leeds is a city in West Yorkshire, England.Historically in Yorkshire's West Riding, the history of Leeds can be traced to the 5th century, when the name referred to a wooded area of the Kingdom of Elmet.In the 17th and 18th centuries Leeds became a major centre for the production and trading of wool.During the Industrial Revolution, Leeds developed into a major mill town; wool was the dominant industry but flax, engineering, iron foundries, printing, and other industries were important.Leeds has a population of around 781,700 (2016) making it the third largest city in the United Kingdom.Today, Leeds has the most diverse economy of all the UK's main employment centres and has seen the fastest rate of private-sector jobs growth of any UK city and has the highest ratio of public to private sector jobs of all the UK's Core Cities.Leeds has the third-largest jobs total by local authority area with 480,000 in employment and self-employment at the beginning of 2015.Leeds is also ranked as a gamma world city by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network; and is considered the cultural, financial and commercial heart of the West Yorkshire Urban Area.Leeds is served by four universities, and has the fourth largest student population in the country and has the country's fourth largest urban economy.

source: race

Deep into the night, the bus pulled in to a Howard Johnson's restaurant and everybody got off the bus except Vingo. The young people began to wonder about him , trying to imagine his life. One of the girls sat beside him and introduced herself. After a long time, slowly and painfully, he began to tell his story. He had been in prison in prefix = st1 /New Yorkfor the last four years, and now he was going home. "Well, when I was in prison I wrote to my wife. I said, 'Martha, I understand if you can not stay married to me'. I said I was going to be away for a long time, and that if she couldn't stand it , if the kids kept asking questions, if it hurt her too much, well, she could just forget me . Get a new young man---she's a wonderful woman---and forget all about me. I told her she didn't have to write to me and she didn't. Not for the three and a half years." "Last week, when I was sure freedom was coming through, I wrote to her. I told her that if she had a new young man, I would understand. But if she didn't, if she would take me back, she should let me know. We used to live in the town,Brunswick, and there's a great big oak tree just as you come into the town. I told her if she would take me back, she should put a yellow handkerchief on the tree, and if she didn't want me, forgot me, no handkerchief and I'd keep going on through." Soon all the others were in it. When they were 20 miles fromBrunswick, the young men took over window seats on the right side, waiting for the approach of the great oak tree. Vingo stopped looking, tightening his face into the ex-con's mask. Then it was 10 miles, and then 5, and the bus became very quiet. Then suddenly all of the young people were up out of their seats, screaming and shouting and crying, doing small dances. All except Vingo.

A: Howard Johnson's|| Howard Johnson's

Q: What type of vehicle was it?

A: a bus||bus

Q: Was it easy for him to tell his tale?

A: no, slowly and painfully,||slowly and painfully,

Q: Where was he headed?

A: home||home

Q: What was he sure of last week?

A: freedom was coming through|| freedom was coming through

Q: How far from the city were they when they took window seats?

A: 20 miles||20 miles

Q: What city were they headed to?

A: Brunswick,||Brunswick,

Q: Who on the bus didn't get up to celebrate?

A: Vingo||Vingo

Q: Where had he been in prison?

A: New York||New York

Q: How close were they when the bus became quiet?

A: 5 miles||5

Q: Who was his wife?

A: Martha||Martha

Q: What did he do to his wife?

A: he wrote to her||wrote to my wife


Summary: Deep into the night, the bus pulled in to a Howard Johnson's restaurant and everybody got off the bus except Vingo.After a long time, slowly and painfully, he began to tell his story.He had been in prison in prefix = st1 /New Yorkfor the last four years, and now he was going home."Well, when I was in prison I wrote to my wife.I said, 'Martha, I understand if you can not stay married to me'."Last week, when I was sure freedom was coming through, I wrote to her.When they were 20 miles fromBrunswick, the young men took over window seats on the right side, waiting for the approach of the great oak tree.Then it was 10 miles, and then 5, and the bus became very quiet.

source: wikipedia

Dhaka (, ; or ) is the capital and largest city of Bangladesh. The name of the city was spelled as "Dacca", which was an anglicisation name until the current spelling was adopted in 1983 to match with Bengali pronunciation. Located in an eponymous district and division, it lies along the east bank of the Buriganga River in the heart of the Bengal delta. The city is a microcosm of the entire country, with diverse religious and ethnic communities. Dhaka is the economic, cultural and political center of Bangladesh. It is a major financial center of South Asia. It is one of the world's most populated cities and within OIC countries, with a population of 17 million people in the Greater Dhaka Area. It is also the 4th most densely populated city in the world. At the height of its medieval glory, Dhaka was regarded as one of the wealthiest and most prosperous cities in the world. It served as the capital of the Bengal province of the Mughal Empire twice (1608–39 and 1660–1704). The city's name was Jahangir Nagar ("City of Jahangir") in the 17th century. It was central to the economy of Mughal Bengal, which generated 50% of Mughal GDP. It was a cosmopolitan commercial center and the hub of the worldwide muslin and silk trade.


Q: What is the capital of Bangladesh?

A: Dhaka||Dhaka (, ; or ) is the capital and largest city of Bangladesh

Q: Is it also the largest city?

A: yes||Dhaka (, ; or ) is the capital and largest city of Bangladesh. T

A: Dacca||. The name of the city was spelled as "Dacca",

Q: When was it changed?

A: 1983||"Dacca", which was an anglicisation name until the current spelling was adopted in 1983

Q: Why was it changed?

A: to match with Bengali pronunciation||to match with Bengali pronunciation

A: eponymous|| Located in an eponymous district and division,

A: the east|| it lies along the east bank of the Buriganga River in the heart of the Bengal delta.

A: the Bengal delta.||it lies along the east bank of the Buriganga River in the heart of the Bengal delta.

A: major financial center|| It is a major financial center of South Asia

A: 4th||It is also the 4th most densely populated city in the world.

Q: and when was that?

A: . Jahangir Nagar||. The city's name was Jahangir Nagar ("City of Jahangir") in the 17th century.

Q: It was known to be a hub of the worldwide trade in what?

A: muslin and silk||It was a cosmopolitan commercial center and the hub of the worldwide muslin and silk trade.


Summary: Dhaka (, ; or ) is the capital and largest city of Bangladesh.The name of the city was spelled as "Dacca", which was an anglicisation name until the current spelling was adopted in 1983 to match with Bengali pronunciation.Located in an eponymous district and division, it lies along the east bank of the Buriganga River in the heart of the Bengal delta.The city is a microcosm of the entire country, with diverse religious and ethnic communities.It is a major financial center of South Asia.It is one of the world's most populated cities and within OIC countries, with a population of 17 million people in the Greater Dhaka Area.It is also the 4th most densely populated city in the world.At the height of its medieval glory, Dhaka was regarded as one of the wealthiest and most prosperous cities in the world.It served as the capital of the Bengal province of the Mughal Empire twice (1608–39 and 1660–1704).The city's name was Jahangir Nagar ("City of Jahangir") in the 17th century.It was a cosmopolitan commercial center and the hub of the worldwide muslin and silk trade.

source: cnn

Stephen Colbert plays a dangerous game. He walks a tightrope every night, and it's amazing that he doesn't fall on a regular basis. He tells jokes about race, gender, class and people love him or hate him. Does everyone get a joke? No. But of course he does say, in persona, amazingly offensive things sometimes. Last week things went south, and Twitter exploded in calls to #CancelColbert. The offense? A 140-character long foot-in-the-mouth that came from the Twitter feed @ColbertReport. The tweet was a joke that played off of a show segment that mocked an attempt by the owner of the Washington Redskins to make peace with the Native American community without having to change the team's name. "I'm willing to show the #Asian community I care by introducing the Ching-Chong Ding-Dong Foundation for Sensitivity to Orientals or Whatever." Race, meet satire. But it didn't work. The controversial tweet, it turns out, was not written by Colbert himself, or from anyone on his show. But it was a Comedy Central account that presumably had license from the show's producers to publicize and magnify Colbert's voice. But instead of repudiating the tweet, Colbert on Monday night made further jokes about how the incident almost silenced "my message of core conservative principles mixed with youth-friendly product placement." Following the lead of Asian-American activist Suey Park, some have been demanding that "The Colbert Report" be canceled. These words perpetuate hateful stereotypes and bring up a history of very public repression and personal shame. To use them now is to call forth that history. And in calling it forth, these words create more racism.


Q: what hash tag is mentioned?

A: #Asian||"I'm willing to show the #Asian

Q: any others?

A: #CancelColbert.||Last week things went south, and Twitter exploded in calls to #CancelColbert.

Q: who is that one about

A: Stephen Colbert.||Stephen Colbert plays a dangerous game. He walks a tightrope every night, and it's amazing that he doesn't fall on a regular basis. He tells jokes about race, gender, class and people love him or hate him. Does everyone get a joke? No. But of course he does say, in persona, amazingly offensive things sometimes. Last week things went south, and Twitter exploded in calls to #CancelColbert.

Q: does he have a show?

A: "The Colbert Report"||Following the lead of Asian-American activist Suey Park, some have been demanding that "The Colbert Report" be canceled.

Q: was is the social media account named in the story?

A: @ColbertReport.||A 140-character long foot-in-the-mouth that came from the Twitter feed @ColbertReport.

Q: what platform is that on?

A: Twitter|| the Twitter feed @ColbertReport.

Q: did they say something offensive?

A: Yes||The offense? A 140-character long foot-in-the-mouth that came from the Twitter feed @ColbertReport.

Q: what?

A: "I'm willing to show the #Asian community I care by introducing the Ching-Chong Ding-Dong Foundation for Sensitivity to Orientals or Whatever."||"I'm willing to show the #Asian community I care by introducing the Ching-Chong Ding-Dong Foundation for Sensitivity to Orientals or Whatever."

Q: did colbert say that?

A: No, The controversial tweet, it turns out, was not written by Colbert himself,||The controversial tweet, it turns out, was not written by Colbert himself,

Q: who did?

A: Comedy Central employee||But it was a Comedy Central account that presumably had license from the show's producers to publicize and magnify Colbert's voice.


Summary: Stephen Colbert plays a dangerous game.Last week things went south, and Twitter exploded in calls to #CancelColbert.A 140-character long foot-in-the-mouth that came from the Twitter feed @ColbertReport."I'm willing to show the #Asian community I care by introducing the Ching-Chong Ding-Dong Foundation for Sensitivity to Orientals or Whatever."The controversial tweet, it turns out, was not written by Colbert himself, or from anyone on his show.But it was a Comedy Central account that presumably had license from the show's producers to publicize and magnify Colbert's voice.Following the lead of Asian-American activist Suey Park, some have been demanding that "The Colbert Report" be canceled.

source: mctest

A boy was trying to pick out what instrument that he wanted to play. His parents wanted him to pick a good one because playing an instrument was very important to them. So, the boy went to a music store with his parents. When he got there he didn't know where to start, so the boy walked up to the front and asked the man who worked there for help. First the worker brought the boy to a piano. "No way," said the boy, "that looks way too hard!" The worker laughed at this, and then brought out a guitar. The boy thought that guitars were too popular and wanted to play something that not many other people would play. Finally, the worker brought the boy to the drums. "That's it! That is a cool instrument that I could really get into." However, his mom wasn't so happy with this because she thought that he would be too loud. The boy's dad stepped in and talked her into it because he knew that if the boy liked what he did, he would do way better. Twenty years later, and the boy was the drummer in a band. It the most popular rock band in the world.

A: A piano||the worker brought the boy to a piano

Q: did the boy think he could do it?

A: no, "that looks way too hard!"||"that looks way too hard!"

Q: what else did he try?

A: a guitar.||then brought out a guitar.

Q: what else?

A: the drums||the worker brought the boy to the drums

Q: did he want the guitar?

A: no, The boy thought that guitars were too popular||The boy thought that guitars were too popular

Q: what order did he try each of the instruments?

A: piano, guitar, drums||the worker brought the boy to the drums

Q: which did he pick?

A: the drums||the drums. "That's it! That is a cool instrument that I could really get into

Q: did his parents like that choice?

A: his mom didn't||However, his mom wasn't so happy with this

Q: why?

A: she thought that he would be too loud||because she thought that he would be too loud

Q: who talked her into it?

A: The boy's dad||The boy's dad stepped in

Q: did the boy join a band?

A: yes||the boy was the drummer in a band

Q: was he still playing drums?

A: yes||and the boy was the drummer in a band

Q: for who?

A: the most popular rock band in the world||the most popular rock band in the world.

Q: when?

A: Twenty years later||Twenty years later


Summary: First the worker brought the boy to a piano."No way," said the boy, "that looks way too hard!"The worker laughed at this, and then brought out a guitar.The boy thought that guitars were too popular and wanted to play something that not many other people would play.Finally, the worker brought the boy to the drums.However, his mom wasn't so happy with this because she thought that he would be too loud.The boy's dad stepped in and talked her into it because he knew that if the boy liked what he did, he would do way better.Twenty years later, and the boy was the drummer in a band.It the most popular rock band in the world.
