source: wikipedia

New Jersey is a state in the Northeastern and mid-Atlantic regions of the United States. It is a peninsula, bordered on the north and east by the state of New York; on the east, southeast, and south by the Atlantic Ocean; on the west by the Delaware River and Pennsylvania; and on the southwest by the Delaware Bay and Delaware. New Jersey is the fourth-smallest state by area but the 11th-most populous and the most densely populated of the 50 U.S. states. New Jersey lies entirely within the combined statistical areas of New York City and Philadelphia and is the third-wealthiest state by median household income as of 2016. New Jersey was inhabited by Native Americans for more than 2,800 years, with historical tribes such as the Lenape along the coast. In the early 17th century, the Dutch and the Swedes made the first European settlements in the state. The English later seized control of the region, naming it the Province of New Jersey after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey, and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton. New Jersey was the site of several decisive battles during the American Revolutionary War in the 18th century.


Q: Who inhabited NJ first

A: Native Americans.||New Jersey was inhabited by Native Americans for more than 2,800 years,

Q: for how long

A: More than 2,800 years.||inhabited by Native Americans for more than 2,800 years,

Q: What century did others start to come

A: Early 17th.|| In the early 17th century, the Dutch and the Swedes made the first European settlements in the state.

Q: Who came there

A: Dutch and the Swedes.||In the early 17th century, the Dutch and the Swedes made the first European settlements in the state.

Q: What was it named

A: Province of New Jersey.||naming it the Province of New Jersey

Q: who did they grant it to

A: Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley,||, Jersey, and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley,

Q: Were there battles located there

A: Yes.||1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton. New Jersey was the site of several decisive battles during the American Revolutionary War

A: American Revolutionary War.||several decisive battles during the American Revolutionary Wa

A: 18th.||several decisive battles during the American Revolutionary War in the 18th century.

A: New York;|| bordered on the north and east by the state of New York;

Summary: New Jersey is a state in the Northeastern and mid-Atlantic regions of the United States.It is a peninsula, bordered on the north and east by the state of New York; on the east, southeast, and south by the Atlantic Ocean; on the west by the Delaware River and Pennsylvania; and on the southwest by the Delaware Bay and Delaware.New Jersey is the fourth-smallest state by area but the 11th-most populous and the most densely populated of the 50 U.S. states.New Jersey lies entirely within the combined statistical areas of New York City and Philadelphia and is the third-wealthiest state by median household income as of 2016.New Jersey was inhabited by Native Americans for more than 2,800 years, with historical tribes such as the Lenape along the coast.In the early 17th century, the Dutch and the Swedes made the first European settlements in the state.The English later seized control of the region, naming it the Province of New Jersey after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey, and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton.New Jersey was the site of several decisive battles during the American Revolutionary War in the 18th century.

source: mctest

Terry is a normal human boy who enjoys football and playing with his toys. What makes him different is that he really enjoys talking to his magical reindeer Max. One day, Terry is walking around town with Max, and as they pass by the nearby farm, the farmer who owns the land calls out to them - "Hey! You, over there!" They quickly turn around, not sure if they are the ones being called to, but seeing no one nearby, they walk over to the farmer. "What do you need, sir?" Terry asks. "I need help with the plants; they're growing faster than normal. Can you help with the potato plants?" the farmer asks. "Sure! Let's help out, Max!" Terry happily answers. They end up spending the rest of the day helping, and are paid well, both in potatoes, carrots and money, for their work. "That was fun!" Terry says to Max, as they head home. Max simple nods back, as they hurry back to their home.


Q: What is the name of the reindeer?

A: Max||reindeer Max

Q: who calls over to the boy?

A: farmer|| farmer who owns the land calls out to them

Q: What does the farmer want?

A: help with the potato plants|| help with the potato plants

Q: What is the problem with the plants?

A: they're growing faster than normal|| they're growing faster than normal

Q: How long does Terry spend helping?

A: the rest of the day|| the rest of the day helping

Q: How much money do they get paid?

A: paid well||paid well, both in potatoes, carrots and money

Q: what else do they get for their work?

A: potatoes and carrots|| paid well, both in potatoes, carrots

Q: what did Terry say to Max when they were done?

A: That was fun!||"That was fun!" Terry says to Max

Q: Does Max say anything to Terry?

A: no, Max simple nods back|| Max simple nods back

Q: How does Max answer back to Terry?

A: nods||Max simple nods back

Q: Is there anthing special about Terry?

A: no, a normal human boy||a normal human boy


Summary: Terry is a normal human boy who enjoys football and playing with his toys.What makes him different is that he really enjoys talking to his magical reindeer Max.One day, Terry is walking around town with Max, and as they pass by the nearby farm, the farmer who owns the land calls out to them - "Hey!"I need help with the plants; they're growing faster than normal.Can you help with the potato plants?"They end up spending the rest of the day helping, and are paid well, both in potatoes, carrots and money, for their work."That was fun!"Max simple nods back, as they hurry back to their home.

source: race

A fish that lives in America can live out. of water for months at a time, similar to how animals got used to land millions of years ago, a new study shows. The Mangrove Rivulus, a kind of little fish, lives in small pools of water. When their living place dries up, they live. on the land, said Scott Taylor, a researcher in Florida. The fish can grow as large as three inches. They group together and breathe air through their skin before they can find water again. The new scientific discovery came during a trip. "We were travelling for fun. and one day I kicked over a log and the fish came out," Taylor told reporters by telephone. He said he would make his study on the fish known to the public in an American magazine early next year. In lab tests, Taylor said he found the fish can live up to 66 days out of water without eating. Some other fish can live out of water for a short period of time. The walking catfish found in Southeast Asia can stay on land for hours at a time, while lungfish found in Australia, Africa and South America can live out of water, but only in a not active way. But no other known fish can be out of water as long as the Mangrove Rivulus and keep active, according to Patricia Wright, a biologist at a Canadian University. More studies of the fish may tell how animals changed over time. "These animals live in conditions similar to those millions of years ago, when animals began to move from water onto land," Wright said.


Q: What kind of fish can live on land?

A: The Mangrove Rivulus||The Mangrove Rivulus

Q: When does it do that?

A: When their living place dries up||When their living place dries up, they live. on the land

Q: How big are they?

A: three inches.||can grow as large as three inches.

Q: Can any other fish live on land?

A: yes||The walking catfish found in Southeast Asia can stay on land for hours at a time, while lungfish found in Australia, Africa and South America can live out of water

Q: What kinds?

A: The walking catfish||The walking catfish

Q: Who can be on land the longest?

A: the Mangrove Rivulus||the Mangrove Rivulus

Q: How long is that?

A: up to 66 days||the fish can live up to 66 days out of water

Q: How long can the walking catfish be out?

A: hours||walking catfish found in Southeast Asia can stay on land for hours at a time

Q: Where is it found?

A: Southeast Asia||walking catfish found in Southeast Asia

Q: What about the lungfish?

A: Australia, Africa and South America|| lungfish found in Australia, Africa and South America

Q: Does it do a lot on land?

A: no, but only in a not active way.||but only in a not active way.

Q: What does it do?

A: not active||but only in a not active way.

Q: Have they stayed the same over time?

A: yes||More studies of the fish may tell how animals changed over time

Q: What happened on a trip?

A: new scientific discovery||The new scientific discovery came during a trip

Q: How was it made?

A: he kicked over a log and the fish came out||I kicked over a log and the fish came out,

Q: How do they stay out so long?

A: without eating||without eating

Q: Who is Patricia?

A: a biologist|| a biologist

Q: Where?

A: at a Canadian University||at a Canadian University

Q: Where does the Mangrove live normally?

A: in small pools of water||lives in small pools of water

Q: Who is Scott Taylor?

A: a researcher||a researcher


Summary: The Mangrove Rivulus, a kind of little fish, lives in small pools of water.When their living place dries up, they live.on the land, said Scott Taylor, a researcher in Florida.The fish can grow as large as three inches.The new scientific discovery came during a trip.and one day I kicked over a log and the fish came out," Taylor told reporters by telephone.In lab tests, Taylor said he found the fish can live up to 66 days out of water without eating.The walking catfish found in Southeast Asia can stay on land for hours at a time, while lungfish found in Australia, Africa and South America can live out of water, but only in a not active way.But no other known fish can be out of water as long as the Mangrove Rivulus and keep active, according to Patricia Wright, a biologist at a Canadian University.More studies of the fish may tell how animals changed over time.

source: race

A new study suggests that early exposure to germs strengthens the immune system. That means letting children get a little dirty might be good for their health later in life. The study involved laboratory mice. It found that adult mice raised in a germ-free environment were more likely to develop allergies, asthma and other autoimmune disorders. There are more than eighty disorders where cells that normally defend the body instead attack tissues and organs. Richard Blumberg,who led the study,is a professor at Harvard Medical School in Boston,Massachusetts. He says,in 1989,medical researchers who sought to explain these diseases, first discovered that the increasing use of antibacterial soaps and other products, especially early in life, could weaken immune systems. Now, Dr. Blumberg and his team have what is the first biological evidence to link early exposure to germs to stronger adult immune systems. They say this exposure could prevent the development of some autoimmune diseases. In the adult germ-free mice, they found that inflammation in the lungs and colon was caused by so-called killer T cells. These normally fight infection. But they became overactive and targeted healthy tissue--an autoimmune condition seen in asthma and a disease called ulcerative colitis . Dr. Blumberg says the mice raised in a normal environment did not have the same reaction. He says their immune systems had been "educated" by early exposure to germs. Rates of autoimmune disorders are rising worldwide, but mostly in wealthier, industrialized countries. According to Dr. Blumberg, it might be high time that people were warned to be more careful with the early use of antibiotics and the prescription from their doctors. Rob Dunn is a professor of ecology and evolutionary biology at North Carolina State University in Raleigh. He says the new study does not mean people should stop washing. "Wash your hands , but don't do it with antibacterial soap. Let your kids play in a reasonable amount of dirt and get outside and get exposed to a diversity of things", says Rob Dunn.


Q: Are kids getting dirty a good thing?

A: yes||letting children get a little dirty might be good for their health later in life

Q: why?

A: early exposure to germs strengthens the immune system||early exposure to germs strengthens the immune system

Q: Where kids tested in the study?

A: no, laboratory mice||laboratory mice

Q: What was?

A: laboratory mice||laboratory mice

Q: What was found?

A: adult mice raised in a germ-free environment were more likely to develop allergies, asthma and other autoimmune disorders||adult mice raised in a germ-free environment were more likely to develop allergies, asthma and other autoimmune disorders

Q: Who led the study?

A: Richard Blumberg||Richard Blumberg

Q: From where?

A: Boston||Boston

Q: At what school?

A: Harvard Medical School||Harvard Medical School

Q: Early exposure to what makes a stronger adult immune system?

A: germs||germs

Q: What type of enviornment were the mice raised in?

A: germ-free||germ-free

Q: Did they raise others in a germ envirnment?

A: yes||a normal environment

Q: Was there a difference in the two?

A: yes||did not have the same reaction

Q: Was it the same reaction?

A: no, id not have the same reaction||id not have the same reaction

Q: What caused inflammation in the lungs?

A: killer T cells||killer T cells

Q: So, should we stop washing our kids?

A: no, does not mean people should stop washing||does not mean people should stop washing

Q: Who says?

A: Rob Dunn||Rob Dunn

Q: What should we do?

A: Wash your hands , but don't do it with antibacterial soap||Wash your hands , but don't do it with antibacterial soap

Q: and what else?

A: Let kids play in a reasonable amount of dirt||Let your kids play in a reasonable amount of dirt

Q: So they are exposed to what?

A: a diversity of things|| a diversity of things

Q: What could weaken the immune system?

A: increasing use of antibacterial soaps||increasing use of antibacterial soaps


Summary: A new study suggests that early exposure to germs strengthens the immune system.That means letting children get a little dirty might be good for their health later in life.The study involved laboratory mice.It found that adult mice raised in a germ-free environment were more likely to develop allergies, asthma and other autoimmune disorders.Richard Blumberg,who led the study,is a professor at Harvard Medical School in Boston,Massachusetts.He says,in 1989,medical researchers who sought to explain these diseases, first discovered that the increasing use of antibacterial soaps and other products, especially early in life, could weaken immune systems.In the adult germ-free mice, they found that inflammation in the lungs and colon was caused by so-called killer T cells.These normally fight infection.Dr. Blumberg says the mice raised in a normal environment did not have the same reaction.Rob Dunn is a professor of ecology and evolutionary biology at North Carolina State University in Raleigh.He says the new study does not mean people should stop washing."Wash your hands , but don't do it with antibacterial soap.Let your kids play in a reasonable amount of dirt and get outside and get exposed to a diversity of things", says Rob Dunn.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Slate is an online magazine that covers current affairs, politics, and culture in the United States from a liberal perspective. It was created in 1996 by former "New Republic" editor Michael Kinsley, initially under the ownership of Microsoft as part of MSN. On December 21, 2004, it was purchased by The Washington Post Company, later renamed the Graham Holdings Company. Since June 4, 2008, "Slate" has been managed by The Slate Group, an online publishing entity created by the Graham Holdings Company to develop and manage web-only magazines. "Slate" is based in New York City, with an additional office in Washington, D.C. A French version "(slate.fr)" was launched in February 2009 by a group of four journalists, including Jean-Marie Colombani, Eric Leser, and economist Jacques Attali. Among them, the founders hold 50% in the publishing company, while The Slate Group holds 15%. In 2011, "slate.fr" started a separate site covering African news, "Slate Afrique", with a Paris-based editorial staff. In July 2014, Julia Turner replaced David Plotz, who had been editor of "Slate" since 2008. Plotz had been the deputy editor to Jacob Weisberg, "Slate's" editor from 2002 until his designation as the chairman and editor-in-chief of The Slate Group. The Washington Post Company's John Alderman is "Slate"s publisher.


Q: What's the french version's address?

A: (slate.fr)||(slate.fr)

Q: when was it started?

A: February 2009||French version "(slate.fr)" was launched in February 2009

Q: how many people started it

A: four||four journalists

Q: what was their jobs?

A: journalists,|| four journalists,

Q: anything else?

A: Jacques Attali was an economist||economist Jacques Attali

A: three|| current affairs, politics, and culture

A: Since June 4, 2008 so 10||June 4, 2008, "Slate" has been managed by The Slate Group,

Summary: Slate is an online magazine that covers current affairs, politics, and culture in the United States from a liberal perspective.It was created in 1996 by former "New Republic" editor Michael Kinsley, initially under the ownership of Microsoft as part of MSN.On December 21, 2004, it was purchased by The Washington Post Company, later renamed the Graham Holdings Company.Since June 4, 2008, "Slate" has been managed by The Slate Group, an online publishing entity created by the Graham Holdings Company to develop and manage web-only magazines."Slate" is based in New York City, with an additional office in Washington, D.C. A French version "(slate.fr)" was launched in February 2009 by a group of four journalists, including Jean-Marie Colombani, Eric Leser, and economist Jacques Attali.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER IX--GONE OVER TO THE ENEMY "Can I teach thee, my beloved? can I teach thee?" E. B. BROWNING. Agatha came home in due time, and Magdalen sent her sister to meet her at the station, where they found a merry Clipstone party in the waggonette waiting for Gillian, who was to come home at the same time. There was so much discussion of the new golf ground, that Vera had hardly a hand or a glance to bestow on Mr. Delrio, who jumped out of the same train, shook hands with Agatha, and bestirred himself in finding her luggage and calling a cab. "How he is improved! What a pleasing, gentlemanly fellow he looks!" she exclaimed, as she waved her thanks, while driving off in the cab. "Is he not?" said Paula, while Vera bridled and blushed. "You will be delighted with his work. I never saw anything more lovely than little St. Cyriac the martyr." "He is taken from Mrs. Henderson's little boy," added Vera; "such a dear little darling." "And his mother is to be done; indeed, he has sketched her for St. Juliet." "Flapsy! St. Romeo, too, I suppose?" "Nonsense, Nag! There really was a St. Juliet or Julitta, and she was his mother, and they both were martyrs. I will tell you all the history," began Paula; but Agatha interposed. "You must like having him down here. Sister must be much pleased with him. She used to like old Mr. Delrio." "Well, we have not said much about him," owned Paula. "He does not seem to wish it, or expect to be in with swells."


Q: Who's the top quote by?

A: E. B. BROWNING.||"Can I teach thee, my beloved? can I teach thee?" E. B. BROWNING.

Q: Who arrived just in time?

A: Agatha||Agatha came home in due time

Q: Who picked her up?

A: Magdalen's sister||Agatha came home in due time, and Magdalen sent her sister to meet her at the station

Q: Where did they pick her up at?

A: the station||and Magdalen sent her sister to meet her at the station

Q: Who was waiting in the wagon?

A: Clipstone|| where they found a merry Clipstone party in the waggonette waiting for Gillian

Q: What did the discussions circle around?

A: the new golf ground,||There was so much discussion of the new golf ground,

Q: Who did this keep Vera from giving attention?

A: Mr. Delrio|| Vera had hardly a hand or a glance to bestow on Mr. Delrio

Q: What did he do after getting off the train?

A: bestirred himself in finding her luggage and calling a cab||who jumped out of the same train, shook hands with Agatha, and bestirred himself in finding her luggage and calling a cab.

Q: What did she do after waving thanks?

A: Drove off in the cab.||as she waved her thanks, while driving off in the cab.

Q: What was the loveliest thing Paula had seen?

A: little St. Cyriac the martyr|| I never saw anything more lovely than little St. Cyriac the martyr."

Q: Does Mrs. Henderson have a son or daughter?

A: A son||"He is taken from Mrs. Henderson's little boy,"

Q: Who was the mother sketched for?

A: St. Juliet||he has sketched her for St. Juliet

Q: Who knew the history of the martyrs?

A: Paula|| I will tell you all the history," began Paula


Summary: CHAPTER IX--GONE OVER TO THE ENEMY "Can I teach thee, my beloved?Agatha came home in due time, and Magdalen sent her sister to meet her at the station, where they found a merry Clipstone party in the waggonette waiting for Gillian, who was to come home at the same time.There was so much discussion of the new golf ground, that Vera had hardly a hand or a glance to bestow on Mr. Delrio, who jumped out of the same train, shook hands with Agatha, and bestirred himself in finding her luggage and calling a cab.she exclaimed, as she waved her thanks, while driving off in the cab.I never saw anything more lovely than little St. Cyriac the martyr.""He is taken from Mrs. Henderson's little boy," added Vera; "such a dear little darling.""And his mother is to be done; indeed, he has sketched her for St.I will tell you all the history," began Paula; but Agatha interposed.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- A man who lost both legs in the Boston Marathon attack is engaged to the woman he was waiting for at the finish line. Jeff Bauman, 28, is also expected a child this summer with fiancee Erin Hurley, 27, according to an announcement on his foundation's Facebook page: "We are so happy to share with you exciting news that has happened over the last few months...Jeff and Erin became engaged and are expecting their first child in the summer!!! Congratulations Jeff and Erin!!" The posting did not reveal a due date for the child or a wedding date. Bauman is credited with helping investigators identify the suspects in the April 15, 2013, double bombing. The image of the maimed Bauman being led to safety by a man in a cowboy hat became one of the most memorable images of the Boston Marathon terrorist attack that killed three and injured more than 260 people. A day after he woke up from two life-saving surgeries with no legs, he mustered the strength to describe bombing suspect Tamerlan Tsarnaev to law enforcement. Tsarnaev's younger brother, Dzhokhar, has pleaded not guilty to 30 federal charges related the bombings, including murder. Tamerlan Tsarnaev was killed when his brother ran over him as police were trying to handcuff him in a chase a few days later, authorities said. Bauman announced in September that he will publish a memoir -- titled "Stronger" -- about his experiences at and since the marathon. "The past months have often been difficult, but the support I've received from around the world, and especially from the people of Boston, has inspired me to set and achieve high goals," he said in a statement released by Grand Central Publishing last year.


Q: How old is Jeff?

A: 28||Jeff Bauman, 28

Q: Who he is marrying?

A: Erin Hurley|| fiancee Erin Hurley

Q: How old is she?

A: 27||Erin Hurley, 27

Q: Did Jeff help authority with something?

A: yes||Bauman is credited with helping investigators identify the suspects in the April 15, 2013, double bombing

Q: In what?

A: the Boston Marathon attack||A man who lost both legs in the Boston Marathon attack

Q: When?

A: April 15, 2013||Bauman is credited with helping investigators identify the suspects in the April 15, 2013, double bombing

Q: Was he injured?

A: yes||The image of the maimed Bauman

A: he lost both legs|| A man who lost both legs in the Boston Marathon attack

Summary: (CNN) -- A man who lost both legs in the Boston Marathon attack is engaged to the woman he was waiting for at the finish line.Jeff Bauman, 28, is also expected a child this summer with fiancee Erin Hurley, 27, according to an announcement on his foundation's Facebook page: "We are so happy to share with you exciting news that has happened over the last few months...Jeff and Erin became engaged and are expecting their first child in the summer!!!Bauman is credited with helping investigators identify the suspects in the April 15, 2013, double bombing.The image of the maimed Bauman being led to safety by a man in a cowboy hat became one of the most memorable images of the Boston Marathon terrorist attack that killed three and injured more than 260 people.A day after he woke up from two life-saving surgeries with no legs, he mustered the strength to describe bombing suspect Tamerlan Tsarnaev to law enforcement.Tsarnaev's younger brother, Dzhokhar, has pleaded not guilty to 30 federal charges related the bombings, including murder.Tamerlan Tsarnaev was killed when his brother ran over him as police were trying to handcuff him in a chase a few days later, authorities said.Bauman announced in September that he will publish a memoir -- titled "Stronger" -- about his experiences at and since the marathon.

source: mctest

Princess Ellen wanted nothing more than to be a singer when she grew up. She had a beautiful voice and everyone who heard it said she was the best singer in the land. But her uncle believed singing would keep her from her job as princess, so he found a witch and paid her to steal Princess Ellen's voice. The witch made a spell which gave Ellen the witch's voice. The spell also gave Ellen's voice to the witch. The witch went on to become famous as a singer, and Ellen grew up to be Queen. One day Queen Ellen heard of a singer who was the best in the land. She went to hear this singer, and was surprised to hear her own voice coming from the woman on stage. When the show was over, Ellen found the singer and gave her a penny. Ellen told the singer, "You have a magical voice". The witch was so touched by Ellen's kindness, that she gave Ellen her voice back.


Q: Who is the main character in the story?

A: Princess Ellen||Princess Ellen

Q: Who is the villain?

A: a witch||a witch

Q: What was special about Ellen?

A: She had a beautiful voice||She had a beautiful voice

Q: How did she compare to other singers?

A: she was the best||she was the best singer in the land

Q: What happened to her voice?

A: a witch stole her voice||so he found a witch and paid her to steal Princess Ellen's voice.

Q: Why?

A: he thought singing would prevent her from her princess job||But her uncle believed singing would keep her from her job as princess,

Q: How did the witch take it away?

A: a spell||The witch made a spell which gave Ellen the witch's voice

Q: Where did her voice go

A: to the witch.||The spell also gave Ellen's voice to the witch.

Q: What did Ellen do when she grew up?

A: she became Queen||and Ellen grew up to be Queen.

Q: What happened to the withc?

A: she became famous as a singer||he witch went on to become famous as a singer

Q: Did their paths ever cross again?

A: yes|| She went to hear this singer,

Q: Where did they run into each other?

A: at a performance||She went to hear this singer, and was surprised to hear her own voice coming from the woman on stage.

Q: What did the Queen bestow upon the singer?

A: a penny.||a penny.

Q: What was the result of her doing that?

A: the witch gave Ellen her voice back||The witch was so touched by Ellen's kindness, that she gave Ellen her voice back.


Summary: Princess Ellen wanted nothing more than to be a singer when she grew up.She had a beautiful voice and everyone who heard it said she was the best singer in the land.But her uncle believed singing would keep her from her job as princess, so he found a witch and paid her to steal Princess Ellen's voice.The witch made a spell which gave Ellen the witch's voice.The spell also gave Ellen's voice to the witch.The witch went on to become famous as a singer, and Ellen grew up to be Queen.She went to hear this singer, and was surprised to hear her own voice coming from the woman on stage.Ellen told the singer, "You have a magical voice".The witch was so touched by Ellen's kindness, that she gave Ellen her voice back.

source: mctest

Once upon a time, there was a squirrel named Joey. Joey loved to go outside and play with his cousin Jimmy. Joey and Jimmy played silly games together, and were always laughing. One day, Joey and Jimmy went swimming together at their Aunt Julie's pond. Joey woke up early in the morning to eat some food before they left. He couldn't find anything to eat except for pie! Usually, Joey would eat cereal, fruit (a pear), or oatmeal for breakfast. After he ate, he and Jimmy went to the pond. On their way there they saw their friend Jack Rabbit. They dove into the water and swam for several hours. The sun was out, but the breeze was cold. Joey and Jimmy got out of the water and started walking home. Their fur was wet, and the breeze chilled them. When they got home, they dried off, and Jimmy put on his favorite purple shirt. Joey put on a blue shirt with red and green dots. The two squirrels ate some food that Joey's mom, Jasmine, made and went off to bed.


Q: what kind of animal was joey

A: a squirrel||a squirrel

Q: what was his cousin's name

A: Jimmy||Jimmy

Q: Were they happy?

A: yes||always laughing

Q: Where did they go?

A: outside||outside

Q: Then where?

A: at their Aunt Julie's pond||at their Aunt Julie's pond

Q: what did he eat before he left

A: pie||pie

Q: Who was at the pond?

A: Jack Rabbit||Jack Rabbit

Q: Who is Joey's mom?

A: Jasmine||Jasmine

Q: What did they do at the pond?

A: swam||swam

Q: What was the weather?

A: Sunny||The sun was out


Summary: Once upon a time, there was a squirrel named Joey.Joey loved to go outside and play with his cousin Jimmy.Joey and Jimmy played silly games together, and were always laughing.One day, Joey and Jimmy went swimming together at their Aunt Julie's pond.Usually, Joey would eat cereal, fruit (a pear), or oatmeal for breakfast.On their way there they saw their friend Jack Rabbit.They dove into the water and swam for several hours.The sun was out, but the breeze was cold.The two squirrels ate some food that Joey's mom, Jasmine, made and went off to bed.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: race

George Washington Carver showed that plant life was more than just food for animals and humans. Carver's first step was to analyze plant parts to find out what they were made of. He then combined these simpler isolated substances with other substances to create new products. The branch of chemistry that studies and finds ways to use raw materials from farm products to make industrial products is called chemurgy. Carver was one of the first and greatest chemurgists of all time. Today the science of chemurgy is better known as the science of synthetics . Each day people depend on and use synthetics made from raw materials. All his life Carver battled against the disposal of waste materials, and warned of the growing need to develop substitutes for the natural substances being used up by humans. Carver never cared about getting credit for the new products he created. He never tried to patent his discoveries or get wealthy from them. He turned down many offers to leave Tuskegee Institute to become a scientist in private industry. Thomas Edison, inventor of the electric light, offered him a laboratory in Detroit to carry out food research. When the United States government made him a collaborator in the Mycology and Plant Disease Survey of the Department of Agriculture, he accepted the position with the understanding that he wouldn't leave Tuskegee. An authority on plant disease--especially of the fungus variety--Carver sent hundreds of specimens to the United States Department of Agriculture. At the peak of his career, Carver's fame and influence were known on every continent.


Q: What branch of Chemistry seeks ways to use raw materials to make industrial products?

A: chemurgy.||The branch of chemistry that studies and finds ways to use raw materials from farm products to make industrial products is called chemurgy.

Q: Where do these raw materials originate from?

A: farm products||The branch of chemistry that studies and finds ways to use raw materials from farm products to make industrial products is called chemurgy.

Q: What is chemurgy called today?

A: the science of synthetics||oday the science of chemurgy is better known as the science of synthetics

Q: What was Carver's full name?

A: George Washington Carver||George Washington Carver

Q: Was his initial step in his process to analyze parts of plants?

A: Yes||Carver's first step was to analyze plant parts to find out what they were made of

Q: To determine what?

A: what they were made of.||Carver's first step was to analyze plant parts to find out what they were made of.

Q: Did he combine substances to make new things?

A: Yes||He then combined these simpler isolated substances with other substances to create new products.

Q: What did he not care about in regards to the products he made?

A: getting credit||Carver never cared about getting credit for the new products he created.

Q: Where was he a scientist?

A: Tuskegee Institute||He turned down many offers to leave Tuskegee Institute

Q: Did he get offers to work elsewhere?

A: Yes||Thomas Edison, inventor of the electric light, offered him a laboratory in Detroit to carry out food research.

Q: Where did the U.S. government make him a collaborator?

A: the Mycology and Plant Disease Survey of the Department of Agriculture||the United States government made him a collaborator in the Mycology and Plant Disease Survey of the Department of Agriculture

Q: What was his condition for accepting this position?

A: that he wouldn't leave Tuskegee||he accepted the position with the understanding that he wouldn't leave Tuskegee

Q: On what kind of disease was he an expert?

A: plant disease||An authority on plant disease--especially of the fungus variety--Carver sent hundreds of specimens to the United States Department of Agriculture

Q: Did he have superior knowledge on one type especially?

A: Yes||An authority on plant disease--especially of the fungus variety--Carver sent hundreds of specimens to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Q: Which one?

A: the fungus variety||An authority on plant disease--especially of the fungus variety--Carver sent hundreds of specimens to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Q: Where did he send his specimens?

A: the United States Department of Agriculture.||Carver sent hundreds of specimens to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Q: What was the last name of the man who invented the electric light?

A: Edison||Thomas Edison, inventor of the electric light

Q: And his first name?

A: Thomas||Thomas Edison, inventor of the electric light

Q: What did he offer Carver?

A: a laboratory in Detroit to carry out food research.||Thomas Edison, inventor of the electric light, offered him a laboratory in Detroit to carry out food research.


Summary: George Washington Carver showed that plant life was more than just food for animals and humans.Carver's first step was to analyze plant parts to find out what they were made of.He then combined these simpler isolated substances with other substances to create new products.The branch of chemistry that studies and finds ways to use raw materials from farm products to make industrial products is called chemurgy.Today the science of chemurgy is better known as the science of synthetics .Carver never cared about getting credit for the new products he created.He turned down many offers to leave Tuskegee Institute to become a scientist in private industry.Thomas Edison, inventor of the electric light, offered him a laboratory in Detroit to carry out food research.When the United States government made him a collaborator in the Mycology and Plant Disease Survey of the Department of Agriculture, he accepted the position with the understanding that he wouldn't leave Tuskegee.An authority on plant disease--especially of the fungus variety--Carver sent hundreds of specimens to the United States Department of Agriculture.

source: race

When I was young, I went looking for gold in California. I never found enough to make a rich strike. But I did discover a beautiful part of the country called Stanislau. Like Heaven on Earth, it had bright green hills and deep forests where soft winds touched the trees. By the time I arrived, the charming paradise had been deserted because miners' good luck didn't last. Then, I realized I was not alone after all. A man was smiling at me as he stood in front of his little house. Its front yard was full of blue and yellow flowers. White curtains hung from the windows and floated in the soft summer wind. Still smiling, the man invited me inside. My spirit seemed to come to life again. I saw a bright rug on the shining wooden floor. And on little tables there were seashells, books and china vases full of flowers. A woman had made this house into a home. The joy in my heart showed on my face. The man read my thoughts. "All her work." He said affectionately, "Nothing here hasn't felt the touch of her hand." One picture on the wall was not hanging straight. He went to fix it. He stepped back several times to make sure the picture was straight. Then he gave it a gentle touch. "She always does that," he explained, "It is like the finishing pat a mother gives her child's hair after she has brushed it. I don't know why I do it. I just do it." As he talked, I went to a little black-walnut shelf that held a small picture of the most beautiful creature I had ever seen. There was a sweetness and softness in the woman's expression. The man stared at the picture. "Nineteen her last birthday. That was the day we married. When you see her...ah, just wait until you meet her!" "Where is she now?" I asked. "Oh, she is away visiting her parents. This is Wednesday," he said slowly. "She will be back on Saturday, in the evening." That night, I stayed. The man told me his name was Henry. Thursday evening we had two visitors, Tom and Joe. "We just drop over to ask when little madam is coming home. Any news from her?" "Oh yes," the man replied. "A letter." He took a yellowed letter out of his wallet and read it. It was full of loving messages. While reading, he glimpsed his friends and cried out, "Oh no, you are doing it again, Tom! Take your hands away and let me see your eyes. I'm going to tell her this time!" "No, you mustn't do that, Henry," the grey-haired miner said. "I am getting old. And any little sorrow makes me cry. Lord, we miss her so." Saturday finally came. I was glad to see his two friends, Tom and Joe, with guitars, coming down the road as the sun began to set. They put the flowers they brought in vases and began to play some fast and lively songs. Henry's friends kept giving him glasses of whiskey. When I reached for one of the two remaining glasses, Tom stopped my arm. "Drop that! Take the other." he whispered. I did so. Henry was served last. He had hardly swallowed his drink when the clock struck midnight. His face grew paler and paler. "Boys," he said, "I am sick with fear. Help! I want to lie down." Henry was asleep almost before the words were out of his mouth. In a moment, those handy men had his clothes off and tucked him into his bed. They seemed to be getting ready to leave. So I said, "Please don't go, gentlemen. She won't know me. I am a stranger." They glanced at each other. Then Joe said, "She? Poor thing, she's been dead nineteen years!" "Dead?" I whispered. "That or worse." he said. "She went to see her folks half a year after she got married. On her way back, on a Saturday evening in June, when she was almost here, the Indians captured her. She's never been heard of since. Henry _ . He thinks she is still alive. When June comes, he thinks she has gone on her trip to see her parents. Then he begins to wait for her to come back. We drop in here, three days before she's due, to encourage him up and listen to him read the letter. On Saturday we all come and get everything ready for a dance. We've done it for nineteen years. The first Saturday there were twenty-seven of us, but only two now. We drug him to sleep through the night. Then he's all right for another year." The two old men opened the door and disappeared into the darkness of Stanislau.


Q: Where was the man standing?

A: in front of his house||A man was smiling at me as he stood in front of his little house

Q: What was his name?

A: Henry.|| The man told me his name was Henry.

Q: Did he have any friends?

A: yes|| was glad to see his two friends, Tom and Joe

Q: How many?

A: two||I was glad to see his two friends,

Q: What are their names?

A: Tom and Joe||I was glad to see his two friends, Tom and Joe

Q: Did the narrator go into the man's house?

A: yes||I saw a bright rug on the shining wooden floor

Q: What covered the floor?

A: a rug|| I saw a bright rug on the shining wooden floor.

Q: What was the floor made of?

A: wood||I saw a bright rug on the shining wooden floor

Q: What was hanging on the wall?

A: a picture||One picture on the wall was not hanging straight.

Q: What did Henry do to it?

A: He went to fix it.||He went to fix it.

Q: Why?

A: it was not hanging straight||One picture on the wall was not hanging straight

Q: Were there any other pictures?

A: yes||I went to a little black-walnut shelf that held a small picture

Q: Where?

A: a shelf||I went to a little black-walnut shelf that held a small picture

Q: What was the shelf made of?

A: black-walnut|| I went to a little black-walnut shelf

Q: What was that photo of?

A: a woman||little black-walnut shelf that held a small picture of the most beautiful creature I had ever seen. There was a sweetness and softness in the woman's expression.

Q: Who was she to Henry?

A: his wife||That was the day we married

Q: Was she in the home?

A: no, just wait until you meet her!"|| just wait until you meet her!"

Q: Where was she?

A: visiting her parents||she is away visiting her parents

Q: When had she left?

A: half a year after she got married.||She went to see her folks half a year after she got married.

Q: When would she be returning?

A: Saturday||She will be back on Saturday, in the evening."

Q: In the morning?

A: no, "She will be back on Saturday, in the evening." ||"She will be back on Saturday, in the evening."


Summary: A man was smiling at me as he stood in front of his little house.I saw a bright rug on the shining wooden floor.One picture on the wall was not hanging straight.He stepped back several times to make sure the picture was straight.As he talked, I went to a little black-walnut shelf that held a small picture of the most beautiful creature I had ever seen.When you see her...ah, just wait until you meet her!""Where is she now?"This is Wednesday," he said slowly."She will be back on Saturday, in the evening."Thursday evening we had two visitors, Tom and Joe.I was glad to see his two friends, Tom and Joe, with guitars, coming down the road as the sun began to set.On her way back, on a Saturday evening in June, when she was almost here, the Indians captured her.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXXVI THE CHARLATAN UNMASKED There seemed for the next few minutes to be a somewhat singular abstention from any desire to interfere with the two people who stood in the centre of the little group, hand-in-hand. Saton, after his first speech, and after Lois had given him her hands, had turned a little defiantly toward Rochester, who remained, however, unmoved, his elbow resting upon the broad mantelpiece, his face almost expressionless. Vandermere, too, stood on one side and held his peace, though the effort with which he did so was a visible one. Lady Mary looked anxiously towards them. Pauline had shrunk back, as though something in the situation terrified her. Even Saton himself felt that it was the silence before the storm. The courage which he had summoned up to meet a storm of disapproval, began to ebb slowly away in the face of this unnatural silence. It was clear that the onus of further speech was to rest with him. Still retaining Lois' hand, he turned toward Rochester. "You have forbidden me to enter your house, or to hold any communication with your ward until she was of age, Mr. Rochester," he said. "One of your conditions I have obeyed. With regard to the other, I have done as I thought fit. However, to-day she is her own mistress. She has consented to be my wife. I do not need to ask for your consent or approval. If you are not willing that she should be married from your roof, I can take her at once to the Comtesse, who is prepared to receive her."


Q: Who felt there was a silence before the storm?

A: Even Saton||Even Saton

Q: Who stood in the centre of the little group?

A: Saton and Lois|| centre of the little group, hand-in-hand. Saton, after his first speech, and after Lois

Q: Whose elbow was on the mantelpiece?

A: Rochester||Rochester, who remained, however, unmoved, his elbow resting upon the broad mantelpiece

Q: Who looked anxiously at them?

A: Mary||Mary looked anxiously towards them

Q: And who stood on the side and held his peace?

A: Vandermere|| Vandermere, too, stood on one side

Q: What was beginning to slowly ebb away from Saton?

A: courage||courage which he had summoned up to meet a storm of disapproval, began to ebb slowly away

Q: Whose hand was he holding?

A: Lois|| Saton, after his first speech, and after Lois had given him her hands

Q: Had she consented to be his wife?

A: yes|| She has consented to be my wife

Q: Who had shrunk back, terrified?

A: Pauline||Pauline had shrunk back

Q: Where did Saton say he could take Lois if she couldn't be married there?

A: the Comtesse|| I can take her at once to the Comtesse

Q: What is the title of the chapter?

A: THE CHARLATAN UNMASKED||THE CHARLATAN UNMASKED

Q: When Saton turned toward Rochester was he defiant or scared?

A: defiant|| defiantly toward Rochester

Q: Who was forbidden to enter the house (Rochester's)?

A: Saton||Saton

Q: What else was he not supposed to do?

A: hold any communication with Rochester's ward||hold any communication with your ward

Q: What is Lois today?

A: she is her own mistress||she is her own mistress

Q: Do they still have to have Rochestere's approval?

A: no, I do not need to ask for your consent or approval.|| I do not need to ask for your consent or approval.

Q: Was Saton still holding Lois' hand when he turned to Rochester again?

A: yes||Still retaining Lois' hand, he turned toward Rochester.

Q: What number chapter is this?

A: XXXVI||XXXVI

Q: Did Saton obey 2 conditions set?

A: no, One of your conditions I have obeyed. With regard to the other, I have done as I thought fit||One of your conditions I have obeyed. With regard to the other, I have done as I thought fit


Summary: CHAPTER XXXVI THE CHARLATAN UNMASKED There seemed for the next few minutes to be a somewhat singular abstention from any desire to interfere with the two people who stood in the centre of the little group, hand-in-hand.Saton, after his first speech, and after Lois had given him her hands, had turned a little defiantly toward Rochester, who remained, however, unmoved, his elbow resting upon the broad mantelpiece, his face almost expressionless.Vandermere, too, stood on one side and held his peace, though the effort with which he did so was a visible one.Lady Mary looked anxiously towards them.Pauline had shrunk back, as though something in the situation terrified her.Even Saton himself felt that it was the silence before the storm.The courage which he had summoned up to meet a storm of disapproval, began to ebb slowly away in the face of this unnatural silence.Still retaining Lois' hand, he turned toward Rochester."You have forbidden me to enter your house, or to hold any communication with your ward until she was of age, Mr. Rochester," he said."One of your conditions I have obeyed.However, to-day she is her own mistress.She has consented to be my wife.I do not need to ask for your consent or approval.If you are not willing that she should be married from your roof, I can take her at once to the Comtesse, who is prepared to receive her."

source: mctest

Andrew waited for his granddaddy to show up. They were going fishing. His mom had packed them a lunch. She had made Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwiches. She also packed a bottle of nice cool water to drink. Andrew had wanted something else for lunch. He wanted chicken or cold cuts or left over meat loaf, but his mom sent Peanut Butter and Jelly sandwiches. The best way to get to the river was along the path. When the path ended, they needed to go through the bushes to the river. On some days they would think about going another way. They could go over the bridge, or through the back of the house or through Uncle Tom's yard. Today they took the path to the river. Andrew found some animal poop along the path. He asked his Grandpa what kind of animal poop he had found. He wanted to know if it was a lion, a tiger or a bear that had made the poop. Grandpa pointed in the bushes. Andrew saw a small black and white animal looking at him with big eyes. Andrew knew that he had was looking at a raccoon. He was sure that the raccoon had made the poop. When Andrew and Grandpa got to the river they put their fishing poles into the water. Andrew caught his first fish right away. He caught a second fish before lunch. He got hungry and had his Peanut Butter and Jelly sandwich and cool water. He saw that Grandpa had fallen asleep. After eating his lunch, Andrew caught three more fish before he woke up his grandpa. When Andrew and Grandpa got back home they gave all the fish they had caught to Andrew's mother, so she could make a good dinner.


Q: What was Andrew waiting for?

A: His granddaddy.||Andrew waited for his granddaddy to show up

Q: Why?

A: Because they were going fishing.||They were going fishing

Q: What did his mom do?

A: Packed them a lunch|| His mom had packed them a lunch

Q: of what?

A: Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwiches and a bottle of nice cool water.||She had made Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwiches. She also packed a bottle of nice cool water to drink

Q: Did he like it?

A: No.||Andrew had wanted something else for lunch

Q: What did he want?

A: Chicken or cold cuts or left over meat loaf.||He wanted chicken or cold cuts or left over meat loaf

Q: How did they get to the river?

A: Along the path.||The best way to get to the river was along the path

Q: where there other ways?

A: Yes.||On some days they would think about going another way. They could go over the bridge, or through the back of the house or through Uncle Tom's yard

Q: What did he find on the path?

A: Animal poop.||Andrew found some animal poop along the path.

Q: what kind?

A: Raccoon.||He was sure that the raccoon had made the poop


Summary: Andrew waited for his granddaddy to show up.They were going fishing.His mom had packed them a lunch.She had made Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwiches.Andrew had wanted something else for lunch.He wanted chicken or cold cuts or left over meat loaf, but his mom sent Peanut Butter and Jelly sandwiches.The best way to get to the river was along the path.On some days they would think about going another way.Andrew found some animal poop along the path.He was sure that the raccoon had made the poop.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXIII A SLIDE DOWN THE MOUNTAIN SIDE "My gracious, Dick! It sure is snowing some now!" "Yes, and it is getting colder every minute." "If we don't get out of the mountains putty quick we'll be snowed in," came from Jack Wumble. "Did you calkerlate to git back to Dawson afore winter sot in?" inquired Ike Furner, curiously. "Why of course!" cried Sam. "I don't see how you are goin' to make it." "Oh, we must get back," said Dick. "If only we could find Tom," he added, with a sigh. It was fully an hour after they had left the campfire at the entrance to the cave of the mountain. They had walked to the chasm where they thought Tom might have had a tumble and crossed and recrossed it several times. But they had found no traces of the missing Rover boy. "If only we knew whether he went down in that opening!" said Sam, for at least the tenth time. "Dick, do you suppose we can climb down into it?" "Not without a rope, Sam. The sides are too steep and slippery." Time and again they called down. But no answer came back. If Tom was down there he was either unconscious or dead. And now it had begun to snow harder than ever. The air was so full of the white flakes that they could not see ten feet in any direction. It was a typical Alaskan snowstorm. There was a sweep to the wind that found the very marrow of their bones.


Q: Who says it's getting cold?

A: Dick||My gracious, Dick

Q: Is it snowing?

A: yes||mountains putty quick we'll be snowed in

Q: What will happen if they stay?

A: they will be snowed in||et out of the mountains putty quick we'll be snowed in

Q: Who says this?

A: Wumble||came from Jack Wumble

Q: What is his first name?

A: Jack||came from Jack Wumble

Q: How long did it take them to get to their destination?

A: an hour||It was fully an hour

Q: Where had they come from?

A: entrance to the cave of the mountain||they had left the campfire at the entrance to the cave of the mountain

Q: What was there?

A: campfire||the campfire at the entrance to the cave of the mountain

Q: Did they find what they were looking for?

A: no, they had found no traces of the missing Rover boy||they had found no traces of the missing Rover boy

Q: What was it?

A: Tom||Tom might have had a tumble

Q: What would have been helpful to know?

A: whether he went down in the opening||we knew whether he went down in that opening

Q: Who says this?

A: Sam||said Sam

Q: Did he say it once?

A: no, said Sam, for at least the tenth time||said Sam, for at least the tenth time

Q: After how many times?

A: at least ten||at least the tenth time

Q: What does he suggest?

A: climb into the opening||suppose we can climb down into it

Q: Can they?

A: no, Not without a rope, Sam||Not without a rope, Sam

Q: Says who?

A: Dick||Dick, do you suppose

Q: Why not?

A: they don't have a rope||Not without a rope, Sam

Q: What do they do then?

A: they called down||Time and again they called down

Q: Does anyone respond?

A: no, But no answer came back||But no answer came back


Summary: CHAPTER XXIII A SLIDE DOWN THE MOUNTAIN SIDE "My gracious, Dick!"If we don't get out of the mountains putty quick we'll be snowed in," came from Jack Wumble.It was fully an hour after they had left the campfire at the entrance to the cave of the mountain.They had walked to the chasm where they thought Tom might have had a tumble and crossed and recrossed it several times.But they had found no traces of the missing Rover boy."If only we knew whether he went down in that opening!"said Sam, for at least the tenth time."Dick, do you suppose we can climb down into it?"The sides are too steep and slippery."But no answer came back.If Tom was down there he was either unconscious or dead.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER X After nearly a year's captivity, the King engaged to pay a ransom, and, until the terms could be arranged, his two sons were to be placed as hostages in the hands of the Normans, whilst he returned to his own domains. The Princes were to be sent to Bayeux; whither Richard had returned, under the charge of the Centevilles, and was now allowed to ride and walk abroad freely, provided he was accompanied by a guard. "I shall rejoice to have Carloman, and make him happy," said Richard; "but I wish Lothaire were not coming." "Perhaps," said good Father Lucas, "he comes that you may have a first trial in your father's last lesson, and Abbot Martin's, and return good for evil." The Duke's cheek flushed, and he made no answer. He and Alberic betook themselves to the watch-tower, and, by and by, saw a cavalcade approaching, with a curtained vehicle in the midst, slung between two horses. "That cannot be the Princes," said Alberic; "that must surely be some sick lady." "I only hope it is not the Queen," exclaimed Richard, in dismay. "But no; Lothaire is such a coward, no doubt he was afraid to ride, and she would not trust her darling without shutting him up like a demoiselle. But come down, Alberic; I will say nothing unkind of Lothaire, if I can help it." Richard met the Princes in the court, his sunny hair uncovered, and bowing with such becoming courtesy, that Fru Astrida pressed her son's arm, and bade him say if their little Duke was not the fairest and noblest child in Christendom.


Q: What was the King to pay?

A: a ransom||a ransom

Q: What would happen to his sons?

A: they would be hostages||be placed as hostages

Q: In whose hands?

A: the Normans||the Normans

Q: Where were they to go?

A: Bayeux||Bayeux

Q: Who would Richard be under the charge of?

A: Centevilles||Centevilles

Q: Was he free?

A: kind of||and was now allowed to ride and walk abroad freely, provided he was accompanied by a guard

Q: Could he ride alone?

A: no, provided he was accompanied by a guard||provided he was accompanied by a guard

Q: Who was at the wattchtower?

A: The Duke and Alberic||He and Alberic

Q: What did they see?

A: a cavalcade||a cavalcade

Q: Who was in it?

A: the Princes||the Princes

Q: Did he wear a hat?

A: no, his sunny hair uncovered||his sunny hair uncovered

Q: What chapter is this?

A: X||X

Q: What are the princes' names?

A: unknown||unknown


Summary: CHAPTER X After nearly a year's captivity, the King engaged to pay a ransom, and, until the terms could be arranged, his two sons were to be placed as hostages in the hands of the Normans, whilst he returned to his own domains.The Princes were to be sent to Bayeux; whither Richard had returned, under the charge of the Centevilles, and was now allowed to ride and walk abroad freely, provided he was accompanied by a guard.He and Alberic betook themselves to the watch-tower, and, by and by, saw a cavalcade approaching, with a curtained vehicle in the midst, slung between two horses.Richard met the Princes in the court, his sunny hair uncovered, and bowing with such becoming courtesy, that Fru Astrida pressed her son's arm, and bade him say if their little Duke was not the fairest and noblest child in Christendom.

My name is James Brown. I have an 8-year-old daughter. Her name is Ann. Her favorite activity is watching movies. She watches movies once a week . Movie World is in my neighborhood . And it is the biggest movie theater in the city . It has the most comfortable seats and the best sound . She likes watching movies there. Last Sunday, I took her to Movie World to watch the movie Epic . Epic is a movie about a father Bomba and his 17-year-old daughter Mary. Bomba was interested in looking for Leaf Men. He said they lived in a forest, but no one believed him. One day , Mary was swept into the world of the Leaf Men, and she found her father was right. At this early-afternoon showing, the theater was almost full. 60% of the _ were kids aged three to ten and their fathers. I didn't think it was because of the movie itself. In fact, a study showed that dads were 50% more likely than moms to take young kids to the movies in the United States. ,.


Q: who is the author ?

A: James||James

Q: last name ?

A: Brown||Brown

Q: who went to movie world ?

A: Ann||Ann

Q: who is ann ?

A: daughter||daughter

Q: how old is she ?

A: Eight||8

Q: what does she loves to do most ?

A: watching movies||watching movies

Q: how often does she do this ?

A: once a week||once a week

Q: what did they go see ?

A: Epic||Epic

Q: are fathers more likly to go to the show with the kids ?

A: yes||dads were 50% more likely

Q: by what percentage ?

A: 50%||50%

Q: the movie they saw stared how many charaters ?

A: Two||Bomba and his 17-year-old daughter

Q: the dads name was mary ?

A: no, Bomba ||Bomba

Q: what is the little girls name ?

A: Mary||Mary

Q: and her dads ?

A: Bomba||Bomba

Q: how old is the girl ?

A: 17||17

Q: what were they searching for ?

A: Leaf Men||Leaf Men

Q: where ?

A: in a forest|| in a forest

Q: did they go at night ?

A: no, early-afternoon ||early-afternoon

Q: what time of day was it ?

A: afternoon||afternoon

Q: what percentage were children ?

A: 60||60


Summary: My name is James Brown.I have an 8-year-old daughter.Her name is Ann.Her favorite activity is watching movies.She watches movies once a week .Epic is a movie about a father Bomba and his 17-year-old daughter Mary.Bomba was interested in looking for Leaf Men.He said they lived in a forest, but no one believed him.At this early-afternoon showing, the theater was almost full.60% of the _ were kids aged three to ten and their fathers.In fact, a study showed that dads were 50% more likely than moms to take young kids to the movies in the United States.

source: mctest

Mrs. Smith liked to deliver her pies with her big hot air balloon. Mrs. Smith like baking pies of all shapes and sizes. She baked for her neighbors of all ages. She would bake them up all on Sunday and pile them high in her balloon. Then she would take off into the sky! Mr. Jones down the street loved strawberry pie. He would stand on his roof and catch the pie as the balloon flew by. Mrs. Kenner liked apple pie. She would run after the balloon and catch her pie in a big basket. Bobby and Sue were brother and sister. They loved chocolate pie. They would ride their bicycles to the top of a hill. Mrs. Smith would hand them their pies as she floated by. Mrs. Smith would throw peach pies down Mr. Tevo's chimney, where they would all land in a big box. Josh had his dog Rex chase after the pies for him. Rex would jump high in the air and catch the pie like frisbee! Everyone would clap as Mrs. Smith rode by and delivered her pies. Then they would eat and be happy. Mrs. Smith loved riding her balloon and making her neighbors so happy!


Q: What did Mrs. Smith deliver?

A: pies||Mrs. Smith liked to deliver her pies

Q: how did she travel to do it?

A: in a hot air balloon||with her big hot air balloon.

Q: who made them?

A: Mrs. Smith||Mrs. Smith like baking pies of all shapes and sizes.

Q: who did she make them for?

A: her neighbors|| She baked for her neighbors of all ages.

Q: how old were they?

A: all ages|| her neighbors of all ages.

Q: on what day did she do this?

A: Sunday||She would bake them up all on Sunday

Q: where did Mr.s Jones live?

A: down the street||Mr. Jones down the street

Q: what did he like?

A: strawberry pie.||Mr. Jones down the street loved strawberry pie.

Q: what would she gather hers in?

A: a big basket||Mrs. Kenner liked apple pie. She would run after the balloon and catch her pie in a big basket.

A: Bobby and Sue||Bobby and Sue were brother and sister. They loved chocolate pie.

Q: were they siblings?

A: yes||Bobby and Sue were brother and sister.

Q: where were they when they received theirs?

A: the top of a hill||They would ride their bicycles to the top of a hill. Mrs. Smith would hand them their pies as she floated by.

Q: how did they get there?

A: on their bicycles||They would ride their bicycles to the top of a hill.

Q: Who wanted the peach kind?

A: Mr. Tevo||Mrs. Smith would throw peach pies down Mr. Tevo's chimney,

A: in a big box||Mrs. Smith would throw peach pies down Mr. Tevo's chimney, where they would all land in a big box.

A: his dog chased after them||Josh had his dog Rex chase after the pies for him.

A: Rex||Josh had his dog Rex chase after the pies

A: clap||Everyone would clap as Mrs. Smith rode by and delivered her pies.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XVII THE MAN AT THE ASTOR Refraining from discussing with Master Maloney the alleged bone-headedness of girls, Smith went through into the inner room, and found John sitting in the editorial chair, glancing through the latest number of _Peaceful Moments_. "Why, John, friend of my youth," he said, "where have you been hiding all this time? I called you up at your office weeks ago, and an acid voice informed me that you were no longer there. Have you been fired?" "Yes," said John. "Why aren't you on the _News_ any more? Nobody seemed to know where you were, till I met Faraday this morning, who told me you were here." Smith was conscious of an impression that in some subtle way John had changed since their last meeting. For a moment he could not have said what had given him this impression. Then it flashed upon him. Before, John had always been, like Mrs. Fezziwig in "The Christmas Carol," one vast substantial smile. He had beamed cheerfully on what to him was evidently the best of all possible worlds. Now, however, it would seem that doubts had occurred to him as to the universal perfection of things. His face was graver. His eyes and his mouth alike gave evidence of disturbing happenings. In the matter of confidences, Smith was not a believer in spade-work. If they were offered to him, he was invariably sympathetic, but he never dug for them. That John had something on his mind was obvious, but he intended to allow him, if he wished to reveal it, to select his own time for the revelation.


Q: Did John used to be something of an optimist?

A: Yes||. Before, John had always been, like Mrs. Fezziwig in "The Christmas Carol," one vast substantial smile.

Q: Who had he been like?

A: Mrs. Fezziwig in "The Christmas Carol"||John had always been, like Mrs. Fezziwig in "The Christmas Carol," one vast substantial smile.

Q: Is that a novel?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: Did John smile a lot?

A: Yes|| He had beamed cheerfully on what to him was evidently the best of all possible worlds.

Q: Does he still believe in the universal perfection of things?

A: No, Now, however, it would seem that doubts had occurred to him as to the universal perfection of things. ||Now, however, it would seem that doubts had occurred to him as to the universal perfection of things.

Q: What had now occurred to him?

A: Doubts||Now, however, it would seem that doubts had occurred to him as to the universal perfection of things.

Q: And his face is now what?

A: Graver||His face was graver.

Q: What tidings does he likely bring news of?

A: Disturbing happenings.||His eyes and his mouth alike gave evidence of disturbing happenings.

Q: Is Smith someone who likes to try to gossip?

A: No, In the matter of confidences, Smith was not a believer in spade-work. If they were offered to him, he was invariably sympathetic, but he never dug for them. ||In the matter of confidences, Smith was not a believer in spade-work. If they were offered to him, he was invariably sympathetic, but he never dug for them.

Q: Was Smith going to press John to reveal anything before he was ready?

A: No, That John had something on his mind was obvious, but he intended to allow him, if he wished to reveal it, to select his own time for the revelation. ||That John had something on his mind was obvious, but he intended to allow him, if he wished to reveal it, to select his own time for the revelation.

Q: Who had John met that morning?

A: Faraday||Nobody seemed to know where you were, till I met Faraday this morning, who told me you were here."

Q: Where had he missed seeing Smith?

A: At the News||"Yes," said John. "Why aren't you on the _News_ any more? Nobody seemed to know where you were, till I met Faraday this morning, who told me you were here."

A: No, Nobody seemed to know where you were, till I met Faraday this morning, who told me you were here." ||Nobody seemed to know where you were, till I met Faraday this morning, who told me you were here."

A: Since Smith's youth||"Why, John, friend of my youth,"

Q: Did John do an outside job, like construction?

A: No, found John sitting in the editorial chair, glancing through the latest number of _Peaceful Moments_. || found John sitting in the editorial chair, glancing through the latest number of _Peaceful Moments_.

Q: What did he work in, then?

A: As an editor|| John sitting in the editorial chair, glancing through the latest number of _Peaceful Moments_.

Q: Was the person who informed Smith of John's firing very friendly?

A: No, I called you up at your office weeks ago, and an acid voice informed me that you were no longer there.|| I called you up at your office weeks ago, and an acid voice informed me that you were no longer there.

Q: What was John reading when Smith found him?

A: Peaceful Moments||John sitting in the editorial chair, glancing through the latest number of _Peaceful Moments_.

Q: Who was allegedly bone-headed?

A: Girls|| Refraining from discussing with Master Maloney the alleged bone-headedness of girls


Summary: CHAPTER XVII THE MAN AT THE ASTOR Refraining from discussing with Master Maloney the alleged bone-headedness of girls, Smith went through into the inner room, and found John sitting in the editorial chair, glancing through the latest number of _Peaceful Moments_."Why, John, friend of my youth," he said, "where have you been hiding all this time?I called you up at your office weeks ago, and an acid voice informed me that you were no longer there.Have you been fired?""Yes," said John.Nobody seemed to know where you were, till I met Faraday this morning, who told me you were here."Before, John had always been, like Mrs. Fezziwig in "The Christmas Carol," one vast substantial smile.He had beamed cheerfully on what to him was evidently the best of all possible worlds.Now, however, it would seem that doubts had occurred to him as to the universal perfection of things.His face was graver.His eyes and his mouth alike gave evidence of disturbing happenings.In the matter of confidences, Smith was not a believer in spade-work.That John had something on his mind was obvious, but he intended to allow him, if he wished to reveal it, to select his own time for the revelation.
