Q: How many metropolitan areas in the UK are larger?

A: Four.||With its surrounding areas, it is the fifth-largest metropolitan area in the UK,


Summary: Liverpool () is a city in North West England, with an estimated population of 478,580 in 2015.With its surrounding areas, it is the fifth-largest metropolitan area in the UK, with over 2.24 million people in 2011.Liverpool is located on the eastern side of the Mersey Estuary, and historically lay within the ancient hundred of West Derby in the south west of the county of Lancashire.It became a borough in 1207 and a city in 1880.Its growth as a major port was paralleled by the expansion of the city throughout the Industrial Revolution.Along with handling general cargo, freight, raw materials such as coal and cotton, the city merchants were involved in the Atlantic slave trade.In the 19th century, it was a major port of departure for Irish and English emigrants to the United States.Liverpool was home to both the Cunard and White Star Line, and was the port of registry of the ocean liner RMS "Titanic", the RMS "Lusitania", "Queen Mary" and "Olympic".

source: race

Weather has a strong effect on people. It influences health, intelligence and feelings. In August, it is very hot and wet in the southern part of the United States. People there easily have heart trouble and other kinds of health problems during this month. In the Northeast and the Middle West, it is hot at some times and very cold at other times. People in those states will have heart trouble after the weather changes in February or March. The weather can also influence intelligence. For example, in a 1983 study by scientists, the IQ scores of some college students were very high during storm, but after the storm, their scores were low. Storms can increase intelligence. Very hot weather, on the other hand, can decrease it. Students in many schools of the United States often do badly in exams in the hot months of the year(July and August). Weather also has a strong effect on people's feeling. Winter may be a bad time for thin people. They usually feel cold during these months. They might feel depressed during cold weather. In hot summer weather, on the other hand, fat people may feel unhappy. At about 65F, people become stronger. Low air pressure makes people feel free, but it also increases forgetful- ness. People leave more bags and umbrellas on buses and in stores on low pressure days. There is a"perfect weather"for work and health. People feel best at a tempera- ture of about 64F with 65 percent humidity . Are you feeling sick, sad, tired, forgetful, or very intelligent today? The weather may be the reason.


Q: Does weather have an impact on human attributes?

A: Yes||Weather has a strong effect on people

Q: Which ones?

A: Health, intelligence and feelings|| It influences health, intelligence and feelings

Q: What problems do people in the southern US typically have when it is hot and clammy?

A: Heart trouble and other kinds||People there easily have heart trouble and other kinds of health problems during this month

Q: Do storms impact cognitive ability?

A: Yes||Storms can increase intelligence

Q: When did the study that showed this happen?

A: 1983||in a 1983 study

Q: What were the names of the scientists involved?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: What group was tested?

A: College students|| some college students

Q: What months tend to have the highest temperatures?

A: July and August||July and August

Q: Name two effects cold temperatures can have

A: Cold and depressed||They usually feel cold during these months. They might feel depressed during cold weather

Q: What about two effects of low air pressure?

A: makes people feel free, but it also increases forgetful-ness||makes people feel free, but it also increases forgetful- ness

Q: What tends to be the most beneficial temperature?

A: 64F with 65 percent humidity||People feel best at a tempera- ture of about 64F with 65 percent humidity

Q: What climate tends to make overweight people feel irritable?

A: hot summer weather||hot summer weather

Q: What weather tends to negatively impact test scores?

A: Very hot weather||Very hot weather, on the other hand, can decrease it


Summary: Weather has a strong effect on people.It influences health, intelligence and feelings.People there easily have heart trouble and other kinds of health problems during this month.For example, in a 1983 study by scientists, the IQ scores of some college students were very high during storm, but after the storm, their scores were low.Storms can increase intelligence.Very hot weather, on the other hand, can decrease it.Students in many schools of the United States often do badly in exams in the hot months of the year(July and August).They usually feel cold during these months.In hot summer weather, on the other hand, fat people may feel unhappy.Low air pressure makes people feel free, but it also increases forgetful- ness.People feel best at a tempera- ture of about 64F with 65 percent humidity .

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER VIII. STEAD IN POSSESSION. "At night returning, every labour sped, He sits him down, the monarch of a shed." GOLDSMITH. Another day made it certain that the garrison of Bristol had surrendered to the besiegers. A few shots were heard, but they were only fired in rejoicing by the Royalists, and while Steadfast was studying his barley field, already silvered over by its long beards, and wondering how soon it would be ripe, and how he should get it cut and stacked, his name was shouted out, and he saw Tom Oates and all the rest of the boys scampering down the lane. "Come along, Stead Kenton, come on and see, the Parliament soldiers come out and go by." Poor Steadfast had not much heart for watching soldiers, but it struck him that he might see or hear something of Jephthah, so he came with the other boys to the bank, where from behind a hedge they could look down at the ranks of soldiers as they marched along, five abreast, the road was not wide enough to hold more. They had been allowed to keep their weapons, so the officers had their swords, and the men carried their musquets. Most of them looked dull and dispirited, and the officers had very gloomy, displeased faces. In fact, they were very angry with their commander, Colonel Fiennes, for having surrendered so easily, and he was afterwards brought to a court-martial for having done so. Stead did not understand this, he thought only of looking under each steel cap or tall, slouching hat for Jephthah. Several times a youthful, slender figure raised his hopes, and disappointed him, and he began to wonder whether Jeph could have after all stayed behind in the town, or if he could have been hurt and was ill there.


Q: Who surrendered?

A: the garrison of Bristol||garrison of Bristol had surrendered

Q: Why were there gunshots?

A: they were rejoicing||they were only fired in rejoicing by the Royalists

Q: Who was?

A: the Royalists||rejoicing by the Royalists

Q: What was Steadfast doing?

A: studying his barley field||Steadfast was studying his barley field

Q: What did he not want to watch?

A: soldiers||Poor Steadfast had not much heart for watching soldiers

Q: Who was he hoping to learn something about?

A: Jephthah||hear something of Jephthah

Q: Where did they watch the soldiers?

A: behind a hedge||where from behind a hedge

Q: What weapons did the officers have?

A: swords||so the officers had their swords

Q: And the men?

A: musquets||the men carried their musquets

Q: Did they look happy?

A: no, Most of them looked dull and dispirited||Most of them looked dull and dispirited

Q: Who were they mad at?

A: their commander|| they were very angry with their commander

Q: Wht?

A: for surrendering|| Colonel Fiennes, for having surrendered so easily

Q: What was the consequence for him?

A: a court-martial|| he was afterwards brought to a court-martial for having done so.


Summary: Another day made it certain that the garrison of Bristol had surrendered to the besiegers.A few shots were heard, but they were only fired in rejoicing by the Royalists, and while Steadfast was studying his barley field, already silvered over by its long beards, and wondering how soon it would be ripe, and how he should get it cut and stacked, his name was shouted out, and he saw Tom Oates and all the rest of the boys scampering down the lane.Poor Steadfast had not much heart for watching soldiers, but it struck him that he might see or hear something of Jephthah, so he came with the other boys to the bank, where from behind a hedge they could look down at the ranks of soldiers as they marched along, five abreast, the road was not wide enough to hold more.They had been allowed to keep their weapons, so the officers had their swords, and the men carried their musquets.Most of them looked dull and dispirited, and the officers had very gloomy, displeased faces.In fact, they were very angry with their commander, Colonel Fiennes, for having surrendered so easily, and he was afterwards brought to a court-martial for having done so.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- A Russian bookmaking company is offering to pay 100,000 euros for Paul, the prognosticating octopus who correctly predicted Spain's win in the World Cup. "100,000 euros (about $129,800) was our starting price," Oleg Zhuravsky, co-owner of Liga Stavok -- "Bet League" in Russian -- told CNN. He said the offer could be increased if need be -- "We are bookmakers, after all." Paul currently lives at the Sea Life Center in Oberhausen, Germany. Zhuravsky said a representative of the center's public relations firm has told him the offer has been received and "they are studying it." However, the firm, Dederichs Reinecke and Parner, said it declined the Russian offer and that Paul will not be sold to anyone. "Seriously speaking, we want the octopus for a number of purposes," Zhuravsky said. "First, to see whether he can indeed effectively forecast the results of the football games. Secondly, Paul could become a good mascot, a good symbol for my bookmaking companies. And thirdly, he has an international fame like perhaps no other animal across the world does these days, and I'd love to be able to move him to Russia. "Both kids and adults, I'm sure, would love to see him here," he said. "We are even prepared to put him in the Moscow City Aquarium if that were the condition." He said Paul would be given "the best food" and officials would let him forecast the results of the Russian domestic football tournament, "which, I think, is a more difficult task than predicting the World Cup," he said. "This would also boost the profile of the Moscow Aquarium."


Q: What did the firm do with the offer?

A: declined it||However, the firm, Dederichs Reinecke and Parner, said it declined the Russian offer and that Paul will not be sold to anyone.

Q: What is Paul going to be given?

A: tyhe best food||He said Paul would be given "the best food"

Q: What will he forecast?

A: the Russioan domestic football tournament||forecast the results of the Russian domestic football tournament,

Summary: (CNN) -- A Russian bookmaking company is offering to pay 100,000 euros for Paul, the prognosticating octopus who correctly predicted Spain's win in the World Cup."100,000 euros (about $129,800) was our starting price," Oleg Zhuravsky, co-owner of Liga Stavok -- "Bet League" in Russian -- told CNN.Paul currently lives at the Sea Life Center in Oberhausen, Germany.However, the firm, Dederichs Reinecke and Parner, said it declined the Russian offer and that Paul will not be sold to anyone."Seriously speaking, we want the octopus for a number of purposes," Zhuravsky said.And thirdly, he has an international fame like perhaps no other animal across the world does these days, and I'd love to be able to move him to Russia."Both kids and adults, I'm sure, would love to see him here," he said."We are even prepared to put him in the Moscow City Aquarium if that were the condition."He said Paul would be given "the best food" and officials would let him forecast the results of the Russian domestic football tournament, "which, I think, is a more difficult task than predicting the World Cup," he said."This would also boost the profile of the Moscow Aquarium."


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Szczecin (; ; German and , known also by other alternative names) is the capital and largest city of the West Pomeranian Voivodeship in Poland. Located near the Baltic Sea and the German border, it is a major seaport and Poland's seventh-largest city. As of June 2011, the population was 407,811. Szczecin is located on the Oder, south of the Szczecin Lagoon and the Bay of Pomerania. The city is situated along the southwestern shore of Dąbie Lake, on both sides of the Oder and on several large islands between the western and eastern branches of the river. Szczecin is adjacent to the town of Police and is the urban centre of the Szczecin agglomeration, an extended metropolitan area that includes communities in the German states of Brandenburg and Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. The city's recorded history began in the 8th century as a Slavic Pomeranian stronghold, built at the site of the Ducal castle. In the 12th century, when Szczecin had become one of Pomerania's main urban centres, it lost its independence to Piast Poland, the Duchy of Saxony, the Holy Roman Empire and Denmark. At the same time, the House of Griffins established themselves as local rulers, the population was Christianized, and German settlers arrived from Western European states. The native Slavic population was subjected to discrimination and Germanization in the following centuries. Between 1237 and 1243, the town was rebuilt, granted extensive autonomy rights and eventually joined the Hanseatic League.


Q: Where is Szczecin?

A: Poland.||Szczecin (; ; German and , known also by other alternative names) is the capital and largest city of the West Pomeranian Voivodeship in Poland.

Q: When did it's history begin?

A: 8th century||The city's recorded history began in the 8th century

Q: When did it lose independence?

A: 12th century||In the 12th century, when Szczecin had become one of Pomerania's main urban centres, it lost its independence to Piast Poland,

A: House of Griffins||At the same time, the House of Griffins established themselves as local rulers, t

A: yes|| it lost its independence to Piast Poland, the Duchy of Saxony, the Holy Roman Empire and Denmark.

Summary: Szczecin (; ; German and , known also by other alternative names) is the capital and largest city of the West Pomeranian Voivodeship in Poland.Located near the Baltic Sea and the German border, it is a major seaport and Poland's seventh-largest city.As of June 2011, the population was 407,811.The city's recorded history began in the 8th century as a Slavic Pomeranian stronghold, built at the site of the Ducal castle.In the 12th century, when Szczecin had become one of Pomerania's main urban centres, it lost its independence to Piast Poland, the Duchy of Saxony, the Holy Roman Empire and Denmark.At the same time, the House of Griffins established themselves as local rulers, the population was Christianized, and German settlers arrived from Western European states.Between 1237 and 1243, the town was rebuilt, granted extensive autonomy rights and eventually joined the Hanseatic League.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Greece is a developed country with an economy based on the service (82.8%) and industrial sectors (13.3%). The agricultural sector contributed 3.9% of national economic output in 2015. Important Greek industries include tourism and shipping. With 18 million international tourists in 2013, Greece was the 7th most visited country in the European Union and 16th in the world. The Greek Merchant Navy is the largest in the world, with Greek-owned vessels accounting for 15% of global deadweight tonnage as of 2013. The increased demand for international maritime transportation between Greece and Asia has resulted in unprecedented investment in the shipping industry. The country is a significant agricultural producer within the EU. Greece has the largest economy in the Balkans and is as an important regional investor. Greece was the largest foreign investor in Albania in 2013, the third in Bulgaria, in the top-three in Romania and Serbia and the most important trading partner and largest foreign investor in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The Greek telecommunications company OTE has become a strong investor in former Yugoslavia and in other Balkan countries.


Q: Is Greece a developing country?

A: no, Greece is a developed country||Greece is a developed country

Q: what is their economy based on?

A: service and industrial sectors||Greece is a developed country with an economy based on the service (82.8%) and industrial sectors (13.3%).

Q: how much of it is service?

A: 82.8%|| the service (82.8%)

Q: how much is industrial?

A: 13.3%||industrial sectors (13.3%).

Q: is tourism important there?

A: yes||Important Greek industries include tourism and shipping.

Q: how many people visited in 2013?

A: 18 million||With 18 million international tourists in 2013,

Q: how does that compare to the rest of the EU?

A: 7th most visited||Greece was the 7th most visited country in the European Union

Q: what about the world?

A: 16th in the world||Greece was the 7th most visited country in the European Union and 16th in the world.

Q: Do they produce much agriculture?

A: no, The agricultural sector contributed 3.9% of national economic output in 2015||The agricultural sector contributed 3.9% of national economic output in 2015

A: Greece||The country is a significant agricultural producer within the EU.

A: 1st||Greece was the largest foreign investor in Albania in 2013

A: third||the third in Bulgaria

A: Romania and Serbia||in the top-three in Romania and Serbia

A: telecommunications company OTE||The Greek telecommunications company OTE has become a strong investor in former Yugoslavia

A: increased demand for international maritime transportation||The increased demand for international maritime transportation between Greece and Asia has resulted in unprecedented investment in the shipping industry.

Q: between who?

A: Greece and Asia||The increased demand for international maritime transportation between Greece and Asia


Summary: Greece is a developed country with an economy based on the service (82.8%) and industrial sectors (13.3%).The agricultural sector contributed 3.9% of national economic output in 2015.Important Greek industries include tourism and shipping.With 18 million international tourists in 2013, Greece was the 7th most visited country in the European Union and 16th in the world.The increased demand for international maritime transportation between Greece and Asia has resulted in unprecedented investment in the shipping industry.The country is a significant agricultural producer within the EU.Greece was the largest foreign investor in Albania in 2013, the third in Bulgaria, in the top-three in Romania and Serbia and the most important trading partner and largest foreign investor in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.The Greek telecommunications company OTE has become a strong investor in former Yugoslavia and in other Balkan countries.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XIV THE CURE It was noon when Harding returned to camp, ragged and exhausted, with Clarke limping after him in an even more pitiable state. The latter had suffered badly from the hurried march, but his conductor would brook no delay and the grim hints he had been given encouraged him to the utmost exertion he was capable of. Blake was alive, but when Harding bent over him he feared that help had come too late. His skin looked harsh and dry, his face had grown hollow, and his thick strong hair had turned lank and was falling out. His eyes were vacant and unrecognizing when he turned them upon Harding. "Here's your patient," the American said to Clarke. "We expect you to cure him, and you had better get to work at once." Then his face grew troubled as he asked Benson: "How long has he been like that?" "The last two days," said Benson. "I'm afraid he's very bad." Harding sat down with a smothered groan. Every muscle seemed to ache, he could scarcely hold himself upright, and his heart was heavy. He would miss Blake terribly; it was hard to think of going on without him, but he feared that this was inevitable. He was filled with a deep pity for the helpless man, but after a few moments his weary face grew stern. He had done all that he was able, and now Clarke, whom he believed to be a man of high medical skill, must do his part. If he were unsuccessful, it would be the worse for him.


Q: Which chapter?

A: XIV||CHAPTER XIV

Q: Is it about a disease?

A: Yes||"We expect you to cure him, and you had better get to work at once."

Q: What time did Harding return to camp?

A: Noon||It was noon when Harding returned to camp

Q: How long has Blake looked ill?

A: The last two days||"The last two days," said Benson. "I'm afraid he's very bad."

Q: What state did Clarke limp into camp in?

A: An even more pitiable one.||Clarke limping after him in an even more pitiable state

Q: Did he have high medical skill?

A: Yes|| whom he believed to be a man of high medical skill

Q: Would things be worse if he was unsuccessful?

A: Yes|| If he were unsuccessful, it would be the worse for him.

Q: Had Harding done all he was able?

A: Yes||He had done all that he was able

Q: What had he smothered?

A: Groan||Harding sat down with a smothered groan

Q: What did every one one of his muscles do?

A: Ache||Every muscle seemed to ache,

A: Clarke||The latter had suffered badly from the hurried march

Q: What level of exertion was he encouraged to give?

A: The utmost that he was capable of.||he had been given encouraged him to the utmost exertion he was capable o

Q: Who feared he had come to late?

A: Harding|| Blake was alive, but when Harding bent over him he feared that help had come too late

Q: Was Blake still alive?

A: Yes|| Blake was alive

Q: What had his thick strong hair turned to?

A: Lank||and his thick strong hair had turned lank and was falling out.

Q: Was Blake's hair growing fitfully and fully?

A: No, and his thick strong hair had turned lank and was falling out.||and his thick strong hair had turned lank and was falling out.

Q: Was there a lot of life in Blake's eyes?

A: No, His eyes were vacant and unrecognizing when he turned them upon Harding. ||His eyes were vacant and unrecognizing when he turned them upon Harding.

A: No, "Here's your patient," the American said to Clarke||"Here's your patient," the American said to Clarke

Summary: CHAPTER XIV THE CURE It was noon when Harding returned to camp, ragged and exhausted, with Clarke limping after him in an even more pitiable state.The latter had suffered badly from the hurried march, but his conductor would brook no delay and the grim hints he had been given encouraged him to the utmost exertion he was capable of.Blake was alive, but when Harding bent over him he feared that help had come too late.His skin looked harsh and dry, his face had grown hollow, and his thick strong hair had turned lank and was falling out.His eyes were vacant and unrecognizing when he turned them upon Harding."Here's your patient," the American said to Clarke."We expect you to cure him, and you had better get to work at once.""The last two days," said Benson.Harding sat down with a smothered groan.Every muscle seemed to ache, he could scarcely hold himself upright, and his heart was heavy.He was filled with a deep pity for the helpless man, but after a few moments his weary face grew stern.He had done all that he was able, and now Clarke, whom he believed to be a man of high medical skill, must do his part.If he were unsuccessful, it would be the worse for him.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER I. "Nerei repandirostrum incurvicervicum pecus." A dingy, swashy, splashy afternoon in October; a school-yard filled with a mob of riotous boys. A lot of us standing outside. Suddenly came a dull, crashing sound from the school-room. At the ominous interruption I shuddered involuntarily, and called to Smithsye:-- "What's up, Smithums?" "Guy's cleaning out the fourth form," he replied. At the same moment George de Coverly passed me, holding his nose, from whence the bright Norman blood streamed redly. To him the plebeian Smithsye laughingly:-- "Cully! how's his nibs?" I pushed the door of the school-room open. There are some spectacles which a man never forgets. The burning of Troy probably seemed a large-sized conflagration to the pious Aeneas, and made an impression on him which he carried away with the feeble Anchises. In the centre of the room, lightly brandishing the piston-rod of a steam-engine, stood Guy Heavystone alone. I say alone, for the pile of small boys on the floor in the corner could hardly be called company. I will try and sketch him for the reader. Guy Heavystone was then only fifteen. His broad, deep chest, his sinewy and quivering flank, his straight pastern, showed him to be a thoroughbred. Perhaps he was a trifle heavy in the fetlock, but he held his head haughtily erect. His eyes were glittering but pitiless. There was a sternness about the lower part of his face,--the old Heavystone look,--a sternness, heightened, perhaps, by the snaffle-bit which, in one of his strange freaks, he wore in his mouth to curb his occasional ferocity. His dress was well adapted to his square-set and herculean frame. A striped knit undershirt, close-fitting striped tights, and a few spangles set off his figure; a neat Glengarry cap adorned his head. On it was displayed the Heavystone crest, a cock regardant on a dunghill or, and the motto, "Devil a better!"


Q: What sound came from the school room?

A: A dull, crashing sound.|| came a dull, crashing sound from the school-room.

Q: Did the author react to it?

A: Yes.||I shuddered involuntarily,

Q: What did he do?

A: Shuddered involuntarily.|| I shuddered involuntarily

Q: Did he ask anyone about the ruckus?

A: Yes.||"What's up, Smithums?"

Q: Who?

A: Smithums.||"What's up, Smithums?"

Q: How old was Guy Heavystone at the time?

A: Fifteen.|| Guy Heavystone was then only fifteen

Q: Did he have a small, shallow chest?

A: No.||. His broad, deep chest

Q: How was it described?

A: Broad, deep chest.|| His broad, deep chest,

Q: What about his flank?

A: Sinewy and quivering.|| his sinewy and quivering flank,

Q: And pastern?

A: Straight.||his straight pastern,

Q: Did Smithums reply to the author?

A: Yes.||Guy's cleaning out the fourth form," he replied.

Q: How did he explain the noise?

A: Guy's cleaning out the fourth form.||"Guy's cleaning out the fourth form,

Q: Did someone come by during this?

A: Yes.||At the same moment George de Coverly passed me,

Q: Who

A: George de Coverly.||At the same moment George de Coverly passed me,

Q: Was he holding something?

A: Yes.||George de Coverly passed me, holding his nose,

Q: What?

A: His nose,||George de Coverly passed me, holding his nose,

Q: Was there anything in the middle of the school room?

A: Yes.||In the centre of the room, lightly brandishing the piston-rod of a steam-engine, stood Guy Heavystone alone.

Q: Who?

A: Guy Heavystone.||In the centre of the room, lightly brandishing the piston-rod of a steam-engine, stood Guy Heavystone alone.

Q: What about in the corner?

A: A pile of small boys.||I say alone, for the pile of small boys on the floor in the corner could hardly be called company.

Q: What was Guy wearing on his head?

A: A neat Glengarry cap.|| a neat Glengarry cap


Summary: Suddenly came a dull, crashing sound from the school-room.At the ominous interruption I shuddered involuntarily, and called to Smithsye:-- "What's up, Smithums?""Guy's cleaning out the fourth form," he replied.At the same moment George de Coverly passed me, holding his nose, from whence the bright Norman blood streamed redly.In the centre of the room, lightly brandishing the piston-rod of a steam-engine, stood Guy Heavystone alone.I say alone, for the pile of small boys on the floor in the corner could hardly be called company.Guy Heavystone was then only fifteen.His broad, deep chest, his sinewy and quivering flank, his straight pastern, showed him to be a thoroughbred.A striped knit undershirt, close-fitting striped tights, and a few spangles set off his figure; a neat Glengarry cap adorned his head.

source: mctest

One day there was a six year old little girl named Megan who lived in a big house with her family. She had two dogs, a brother, a sister, and a mom and dad. Every day she woke up and went to kindergarten, played outside, and watched movies. Sometimes her family would go to a rollercoaster park. Her mom would always try to get her to ride the big rides but she was afraid and wanted to stay in Snoopyland. For two years she stayed in the little kid section of the park. Her big brother who had to babysit her was getting mad because she would not try new rides. She cried more and more until one day she got brave. She went on a little bigger musical ride that went around in circles pretty fast. She got off the ride and loved it! Her mom said to her, "Okay, let's go on the big kid rides now!" Megan was afraid again and cried and cried. For the rest of that summer she stayed in the little kid section and went on little rides. The next summer her brother brought his girlfriend home. His girlfriend's name was Sara and she was older, and loved big rides. Megan liked Sara a lot and wanted to make her like her. When Sara asked Megan if she would ride on bigger rides she said yes, and she went on her first real rollercoaster, Thunderhawk. She was frightened at first but when she stepped off the ride she loved it like she had loved the other ride last year! Now was the real test. Sara asked Megan if she wanted to go on the biggest ride in the park. She was afraid but wanted to show Sara how big she was. At the beginning of the ride Megan was afraid and was about to start crying when they went down the first big hill. Her stomach was tickled and she began laughing really loud. She stepped off the ride with a huge smile on her face and was very proud. Megan was no longer afraid of the big rides and enjoyed riding them for the rest of her life.


Q: who was the little girl?

A: Megan||One day there was a six year old little girl named Megan

Q: how old was she?

A: six||One day there was a six year old little girl named Megan

Q: where did she live?

A: in a big house||lived in a big house

Q: with who?

A: her family||lived in a big house with her family

Q: who was in it?

A: two dogs, a brother, a sister, and a mom and dad||She had two dogs, a brother, a sister, and a mom and dad

Q: what grade was she in?

A: kindergarten,||Every day she woke up and went to kindergarten,

Q: when did she go?

A: Every day|| Every day she woke up and went to kindergarten,

Q: where did they all go?

A: a rollercoaster park.||Sometimes her family would go to a rollercoaster park.

Q: what did her mom want her to do?

A: ride the big rides|| Her mom would always try to get her to ride the big rides

Q: how did she feel about that?

A: afraid||but she was afraid

Q: how long did she not do it?

A: two years||For two years she stayed in the little kid section of the park.

Q: who became angry?

A: Her big brother||Her big brother who had to babysit her was getting mad

Q: what did she do after she was done crying?

A: got brave||She cried more and more until one day she got brave

Q: what did she ride after that?

A: a little bigger musical ride||She went on a little bigger musical ride that went around in circles pretty fast.

Q: what was its speed?

A: pretty fast.||went around in circles pretty fast.

Q: did she like it?

A: loved it||She got off the ride and loved it

Q: what did she do all summer?

A: stayed in the little kid section||For the rest of that summer she stayed in the little kid section

A: his girlfriend||The next summer her brother brought his girlfriend home

A: yes|| Megan liked Sara a lot

A: Sara||When Sara asked Megan if she would ride on bigger rides she said yes, and she went on her first real rollercoaster

A: Thunderhawk||first real rollercoaster, Thunderhawk


Summary: One day there was a six year old little girl named Megan who lived in a big house with her family.She had two dogs, a brother, a sister, and a mom and dad.Every day she woke up and went to kindergarten, played outside, and watched movies.Sometimes her family would go to a rollercoaster park.Her mom would always try to get her to ride the big rides but she was afraid and wanted to stay in Snoopyland.For two years she stayed in the little kid section of the park.Her big brother who had to babysit her was getting mad because she would not try new rides.She cried more and more until one day she got brave.She went on a little bigger musical ride that went around in circles pretty fast.She got off the ride and loved it!For the rest of that summer she stayed in the little kid section and went on little rides.The next summer her brother brought his girlfriend home.His girlfriend's name was Sara and she was older, and loved big rides.Megan liked Sara a lot and wanted to make her like her.When Sara asked Megan if she would ride on bigger rides she said yes, and she went on her first real rollercoaster, Thunderhawk.

source: gutenberg

Chapter VIII The House in Onslow Crescent Harry, as he walked away from the house in Bolton street, hardly knew whether he was on his heels or his head. Burton had told him not to dress--"We don't give dress dinner parties, you know. It's all in the family way with us"--and Harry, therefore, went direct from Bolton street to Onslow Crescent. But, though he managed to keep the proper course down Piccadilly, he was in such confusion of mind that he hardly knew whither he was going. It seemed as though a new form of life had been opened to him, and that it had been opened in such a way as almost necessarily to engulf him. It was not only that Lady Ongar's history was so terrible, and her life so strange, but that he himself was called upon to form a part of that history, and to join himself in some sort with that life. This countess, with her wealth, her rank, her beauty, and her bright intellect, had called him to her, and told him that he was her only friend. Of course he had promised his friendship. How could he have failed to give such a promise to one whom he had loved so well? But to what must such a promise lead, or rather to what must it not have led had it not been for Florence Burton? She was young, free, and rich. She made no pretence of regret for the husband she had lost, speaking of him as though in truth she hardly regarded herself as his wife. And she was the same Julia whom he had loved, who had loved him, who had jilted him, and in regret for whom he had once resolved to lead a wretched, lonely life! Of course she must expect that he would renew it all--unless, indeed, she knew of his engagement. But if she knew it, why had she not spoken of it?


Q: Who lost her husband?

A: Lady Ongar|| Lady Ongar

Q: Who was walking somewhere?

A: Harry,||Harry,

Q: From where?

A: the house||the house

Q: Where?

A: in Bolton street||in Bolton street

Q: Did he have a clear head?

A: No, confusion of mind||confusion of mind

Q: Where was he going next?

A: Onslow Crescent||Onslow Crescent

Q: Who was engaged?

A: Harry||Harry

Q: Who had a bad past?

A: Lady Ongar||Lady Ongar

Q: What was another of her titles?

A: countess||countess

Q: Did she have a lot of money?

A: yes||her wealth

Q: Who had he loved earlier?

A: Julia||Julia

Q: Did she break up with him?

A: Yes||who had jilted him


Summary: Chapter VIII The House in Onslow Crescent Harry, as he walked away from the house in Bolton street, hardly knew whether he was on his heels or his head.It's all in the family way with us"--and Harry, therefore, went direct from Bolton street to Onslow Crescent.But, though he managed to keep the proper course down Piccadilly, he was in such confusion of mind that he hardly knew whither he was going.It was not only that Lady Ongar's history was so terrible, and her life so strange, but that he himself was called upon to form a part of that history, and to join himself in some sort with that life.This countess, with her wealth, her rank, her beauty, and her bright intellect, had called him to her, and told him that he was her only friend.And she was the same Julia whom he had loved, who had loved him, who had jilted him, and in regret for whom he had once resolved to lead a wretched, lonely life!

source: race

When Jackie Robinson walked onto Ebbets Field in Brooklyn, New York, on April 15, 1947, he changed baseball forever. As the first African American to play in the Major League in modern times, many believe he changed the country forever. Robinson was born in 1919. He lived in a time when rules controlled what African Americans could do. He was a top athlete, playing football, basketball and baseball. But playing for a major League team was off limits to Robinson because of his race. Branch Rickey, president and manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, signed (......) Robinson in 1947. He believed that Robinson not only had the skills, but the courage to face the challenge of becoming modern baseball's first black player. It wasn't easy. Robinson sometimes faced boos from fans. But he became a star, anyway. In 1962, he became the first African-American player chosen to enter the Baseball Hall of Fame. In 2005, he was awarded a Congressional Gold Medal, the highest award Congress can give to an American. By breaking baseball's color barrier , Robinson opened the door for many to follow his footsteps, not only in baseball, but in other areas of life as well. After he stopped playing the game, Robinson worked as a manager for a coffee company. He wrote a newspaper column . He also started a bank.


Q: Who was said to have changed baseball forever?

A: Jackie Robinson||Jackie Robinson

Q: What barrier did he break?

A: Race barrier||r. As the first African American to

Q: What sport did he play?

A: baseball|| baseball

Q: What did he need in addition to skill to play baseball?

A: courage||e courage

Q: When did he play for the first time?

A: April 15, 1947,||April 15, 1947,

Q: Who brought him on to the team?

A: Branch Rickey|| Branch Rickey

Q: How did people in the stadium react?

A: boos||boos

Q: Where was his first game?

A: Ebbets Field|| Ebbets Field

Q: What did he do in 1962?

A: he became the first African-American player chosen to enter the Baseball Hall of Fame||he became the first African-American player chosen to enter the Baseball Hall of Fame

Q: What other award was he given?

A: Congressional Gold Medal|| Congressional Gold Meda

Q: When?

A: 2005|| 2005

Q: What was the significance?

A: it's the highest award Congress can give to an American||the highest award Congress can give to an American

Q: What did he do after his baseball career ended?

A: he worked as a manager for a coffee company||worked as a manager for a coffee company

Q: When was he born?

A: 1919|| 1919

Q: What other sports did he participate in?

A: football and basketball||football, basketball

Q: What were his other career options after baseball ended?

A: He wrote a newspaper column|| He wrote a newspaper column

Q: DId he own a car wash?

A: No, He also started a bank||He also started a bank


Summary: When Jackie Robinson walked onto Ebbets Field in Brooklyn, New York, on April 15, 1947, he changed baseball forever.Robinson was born in 1919.He was a top athlete, playing football, basketball and baseball.Branch Rickey, president and manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, signed (......) Robinson in 1947.He believed that Robinson not only had the skills, but the courage to face the challenge of becoming modern baseball's first black player.Robinson sometimes faced boos from fans.In 1962, he became the first African-American player chosen to enter the Baseball Hall of Fame.In 2005, he was awarded a Congressional Gold Medal, the highest award Congress can give to an American.After he stopped playing the game, Robinson worked as a manager for a coffee company.He wrote a newspaper column .He also started a bank.

source: race

Claude Monet is surely one of the most famous French artists of all. Monet was particularly interested in the effect of light and would paint the same scene in different lighting conditions or times of the day. For example, he painted around 20 versions of the Rouen Cathedral from dawn to dusk. His most famous paintings include his Water lilies series. The paintings of Paul Cezanne had a lot of influence in the development of 20th century art, including Cubism and Fauvism . Cezanne is one of the most famous French artists and is known as a "post-impressionist", which was similar in some ways to impressionism but also broke away from some of its limitations. Famous French paintings include his Bathers and Mont St Victoire series. Henri Matisse was one of the most important famous French artists of the 20th century. He was considered one of the leaders of the Fauvist movement. He had a long and varied artistic career, painting in different styles ranging from Impressionism to Abstract. In 1941, Matisse was diagnosed with cancer and was forced into a wheelchair. But this didn't stop him completing the amazing Chapel of the Rosary in Vence. Degas is probably one of the most fascinating of all the famous French artists. He is known as one of the founders of Impressionism, but his paintings were also influenced by classicism, romanticism, and realism. His style is definitely very unique. He was a prolific artist, producing over one thousand works. He is best known for his paintings of ballet dancers.


Q: Degas is known as what?

A: founder of Impressionism||He is known as one of the founders of Impressionism

Q: How many categories was his paintings influenced by?

A: three||his paintings were also influenced by classicism, romanticism, and realism

Q: What was the first category?

A: classicism|| his paintings were also influenced by classicism, romanticism, and realism

Q: And the second?

A: romanticism||his paintings were also influenced by classicism, romanticism, and realism

Q: The third?

A: realism||his paintings were also influenced by classicism, romanticism, and realism.

Q: What kind of style does he have?

A: unique||His style is definitely very unique

Q: What kind of artist was he?

A: French||Degas is probably one of the most fascinating of all the famous French artists

Q: How many items did he produce?

A: over one thousand|| producing over one thousand works

Q: What is he best known for?

A: paintings of ballet dancers||He is best known for his paintings of ballet dancers

Q: What did the paintings of Paul Cezanne influence?

A: Cubism and Fauvism||The paintings of Paul Cezanne had a lot of influence in the development of 20th century art, including Cubism and Fauvism

Q: What is he known as?

A: a post-impressionist||Cezanne is one of the most famous French artists and is known as a "post-impressionist

Q: What is that?

A: similar to impressionism||a "post-impressionist", which was similar in some ways to impressionism but also broke away from some of its limitations.

Q: What is his most famous pieces?

A: Bathers||Famous French paintings include his Bathers and Mont St Victoire series

Q: Who was a leader of the Fauvist movement?

A: Henri Matisse||Henri Matisse was one of the most important famous French artists of the 20th century. He was considered one of the leaders of the Fauvist movement.

Q: What kind of paintings did he specialize in?

A: Impressionism to Abstract.|| He had a long and varied artistic career, painting in different styles ranging from Impressionism to Abstract.

Q: What was he diagnosed with?

A: cancer||Matisse was diagnosed with cancer

Q: Did this stop him from working?

A: no, But this didn't stop him completing the amazing Chapel of the Rosary in Vence. || But this didn't stop him completing the amazing Chapel of the Rosary in Vence.

Q: Who is one of the most famous french artists of all?

A: Claude Monet||Claude Monet is surely one of the most famous French artists of all.

Q: What kind of conditions did he prefer to work in?

A: different lighting conditions|| paint the same scene in different lighting conditions or times of the day.

Q: How many times did he paint the Rouen Cathedral?

A: 20||he painted around 20 versions of the Rouen Cathedral


Summary: Claude Monet is surely one of the most famous French artists of all.Monet was particularly interested in the effect of light and would paint the same scene in different lighting conditions or times of the day.For example, he painted around 20 versions of the Rouen Cathedral from dawn to dusk.The paintings of Paul Cezanne had a lot of influence in the development of 20th century art, including Cubism and Fauvism .Cezanne is one of the most famous French artists and is known as a "post-impressionist", which was similar in some ways to impressionism but also broke away from some of its limitations.Famous French paintings include his Bathers and Mont St Victoire series.Henri Matisse was one of the most important famous French artists of the 20th century.He had a long and varied artistic career, painting in different styles ranging from Impressionism to Abstract.In 1941, Matisse was diagnosed with cancer and was forced into a wheelchair.But this didn't stop him completing the amazing Chapel of the Rosary in Vence.Degas is probably one of the most fascinating of all the famous French artists.He is known as one of the founders of Impressionism, but his paintings were also influenced by classicism, romanticism, and realism.His style is definitely very unique.He was a prolific artist, producing over one thousand works.He is best known for his paintings of ballet dancers.

source: race

You are going to high school, aren't you? Maybe you don't know what to do. Well, here's a list of the top six things to do when you are in high school. These things will give you ideas of what your high school life could be like. Here you go! 1 Find your passion and what kind of person you are: Whether it's dance, basketball, or drawing, the important thing is that you have found something you are interested in. 2 Talk to people you wouldn't usually talk to: meet new people, find new friends and even talk to people you don't like. It will show what a great person you are. You never know what will happen after high school. 3 Take part in at least one contest : This will give you tears of laughter, happiness and memories. 4 Get a job: This will help you see what it's like to have responsibility . It can also help you make a little money to spend on yourself. 5 Take a trip with your friends: It doesn't matter where you go or what you do, the memories will happen on the way and go on till the final place. 6 Do your best at school: Don't ever get lazy; working hard now will help you in the future.


Q: What is this a list of?

A: things to do in high school||a list of the top six things to do when you are in high school

Q: Why do you need it?

A: Because you don't know what to do.||you don't know what to do

Q: Where?

A: high school||are in high school

Q: How many contests should you participate in?

A: one contest||one contest

Q: Why?

A: to get laughter, happiness and memories||This will give you tears of laughter, happiness and memories

Q: What kind of tears will you get?

A: tears of laughter|| tears of laughter

Q: Should you get a job?

A: yes||Get a job

Q: What will that show you?

A: what it's like to have responsibility|| what it's like to have responsibility

Q: What can you use the money for?

A: to spend on yourself|| money to spend on yourself

Q: What should you find out about yourself?

A: your passion||Find your passion

A: dance, basketball, or drawing||dance, basketball, or drawing

Q: Who should you talk to?

A: to people you wouldn't usually talk to||Talk to people you wouldn't usually talk to

Q: What about ones you don't like?

A: talk to people you don't like too||even talk to people you don't like

Q: Why?

A: It will show what a great person you are.||It will show what a great person you are

Q: What kind of people should you meet?

A: new friends and people you don't like||new friends and even talk to people you don't like

Q: Is it a good idea to take a trip?

A: yes||Take a trip

Q: With who?

A: with friends||with your friends

Q: Any particular destination?

A: no, It doesn't matter||It doesn't matter

Q: What about a certain agenda?

A: no, doesn't matter where you go or what you do||doesn't matter where you go or what you do

Q: What's the trip for?

A: memories||memories


Summary: Maybe you don't know what to do.Well, here's a list of the top six things to do when you are in high school.1 Find your passion and what kind of person you are: Whether it's dance, basketball, or drawing, the important thing is that you have found something you are interested in.2 Talk to people you wouldn't usually talk to: meet new people, find new friends and even talk to people you don't like.It will show what a great person you are.3 Take part in at least one contest : This will give you tears of laughter, happiness and memories.4 Get a job: This will help you see what it's like to have responsibility .It can also help you make a little money to spend on yourself.5 Take a trip with your friends: It doesn't matter where you go or what you do, the memories will happen on the way and go on till the final place.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- Evangelist Tony Alamo was arrested Thursday in Flagstaff, Arizona, on charges related to a child porn investigation, an FBI spokesman said. The 74-year-old founder and leader of Tony Alamo Christian Ministries was arrested without incident at 2:45 p.m. (4:45 p.m. ET) as he was departing the Little America Hotel with his wife, said Manuel Johnson, spokesman for the FBI in Phoenix, Arizona. The FBI, the Flagstaff Police Department and the Arizona Department of Public Safety were involved in the arrest, he said. Alamo was charged under a federal statute with having knowingly transported a minor across state lines with the intent to engage in sexual activity, Johnson said. Alamo, whose real name is Bernie Hoffman, was taken to Coconino County Jail in Flagstaff, where he is to have an initial appearance Friday in federal magistrate court, Johnson said. Over the weekend, about 100 federal and state agents authorities raided Alamo's 15-acre compound near Texarkana, Arkansas, and took six children into temporary custody. The children were interviewed as part of a two-year investigation into Tony Alamo Christian Ministries to determine whether they were physically or sexually abused, said Bill Sadler of the Arkansas State Police. Alamo, reached by phone Saturday in Los Angeles, California, denied any wrongdoing. "It's a hoax," Alamo said. "They're just trying to make our church look evil ... by saying I'm a pornographer. Saying that I rape little children. ... I love children. I don't abuse them. Never have. Never will." Asked why authorities were searching the property, Alamo compared himself to Christ.


Q: Who thinks he's Jesus?

A: Alamo||Alamo compared himself to Christ

Q: Does he admit to doing evil acts?

A: no, "It's a hoax," Alamo said.||"It's a hoax," Alamo said.

Q: What is his real name?

A: Bernie Hoffma||whose real name is Bernie Hoffma

Q: How old is he?

A: 74||The 74-year-old

Summary: The 74-year-old founder and leader of Tony Alamo Christian Ministries was arrested without incident at 2:45 p.m. (4:45 p.m.ET) as he was departing the Little America Hotel with his wife, said Manuel Johnson, spokesman for the FBI in Phoenix, Arizona.Alamo, whose real name is Bernie Hoffman, was taken to Coconino County Jail in Flagstaff, where he is to have an initial appearance Friday in federal magistrate court, Johnson said.Over the weekend, about 100 federal and state agents authorities raided Alamo's 15-acre compound near Texarkana, Arkansas, and took six children into temporary custody.The children were interviewed as part of a two-year investigation into Tony Alamo Christian Ministries to determine whether they were physically or sexually abused, said Bill Sadler of the Arkansas State Police."It's a hoax," Alamo said.

source: mctest

The best afternoon I ever had with my grandfather was when we went down to the river and fished. It was a hot July day, and I was bored. My grandfather was sitting in the backyard, reading. "Hey, you look like you need some fun," he said. "Want to go fishing?" I said sure, and he went to the garage. He came out with two poles, some hooks, and some fishing line. Everything was in pieces, but he showed me how to put it all together. I asked if we needed worms, and he said no. Then, we set off to the river. It was only about ten blocks to the river, but walking along past the library and the store, he told me about how he used to go fishing with his friend Steve. They used to catch catfish, then take them home so that their mothers could cook them for dinner. When we got to the park at the river, my grandfather went right to the bank, then turned and walked up along the side of the river until we were off in the shade under the trees right at the edge of the park. There, he taught me how to throw my line in the water. Then we sat down to wait. While we were fishing, my grandfather told me lots of stories about what he and Steve did as kids. We didn't have any worms, so we never caught any fish, but sitting there as he told me stories made it a great afternoon.


Q: how far was it to the river?

A: ten blocks||It was only about ten blocks to the river

Q: what month was it?

A: July||It was a hot July day,

Q: were you bored?

A: yes||I was bored.

Q: what did grandpa suggest?

A: fishing||he said. "Want to go fishing?"

Q: did you think it was a good idea?

A: yes||I said sure

Q: was the gear intact?

A: no, Everything was in pieces||Everything was in pieces

Q: what did they used to catch at the river?

A: catfish||They used to catch catfish,

Q: did you need bait?

A: no, I asked if we needed worms, and he said no.|| I asked if we needed worms, and he said no.

Q: what was on the way to the river?

A: library and store||walking along past the library and the store

Q: where did grandpa go once you reached the park?

A: right to the bank||my grandfather went right to the bank


Summary: It was a hot July day, and I was bored."Hey, you look like you need some fun," he said.I said sure, and he went to the garage.Everything was in pieces, but he showed me how to put it all together.I asked if we needed worms, and he said no.It was only about ten blocks to the river, but walking along past the library and the store, he told me about how he used to go fishing with his friend Steve.They used to catch catfish, then take them home so that their mothers could cook them for dinner.When we got to the park at the river, my grandfather went right to the bank, then turned and walked up along the side of the river until we were off in the shade under the trees right at the edge of the park.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXXVIII. MAKING them pens was a distressid tough job, and so was the saw; and Jim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all. That's the one which the prisoner has to scrabble on the wall. But he had to have it; Tom said he'd GOT to; there warn't no case of a state prisoner not scrabbling his inscription to leave behind, and his coat of arms. "Look at Lady Jane Grey," he says; "look at Gilford Dudley; look at old Northumberland! Why, Huck, s'pose it IS considerble trouble?--what you going to do?--how you going to get around it? Jim's GOT to do his inscription and coat of arms. They all do." Jim says: "Why, Mars Tom, I hain't got no coat o' arm; I hain't got nuffn but dish yer ole shirt, en you knows I got to keep de journal on dat." "Oh, you don't understand, Jim; a coat of arms is very different." "Well," I says, "Jim's right, anyway, when he says he ain't got no coat of arms, because he hain't." "I reckon I knowed that," Tom says, "but you bet he'll have one before he goes out of this--because he's going out RIGHT, and there ain't going to be no flaws in his record." So whilst me and Jim filed away at the pens on a brickbat apiece, Jim a-making his'n out of the brass and I making mine out of the spoon, Tom set to work to think out the coat of arms. By and by he said he'd struck so many good ones he didn't hardly know which to take, but there was one which he reckoned he'd decide on. He says:


Q: what job was hard?

A: Making pens||MAKING them pens was a distressid tough job

Q: what was harder?

A: The inscription|| and Jim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all.

Q: who got to scrabble the wall

A: The prisoner|| That's the one which the prisoner has to scrabble on the wall.

Q: who has to do his coat of arms?

A: Tom||Tom said he'd GOT to; there warn't no case of a state prisoner not scrabbling his inscription to leave behind, and his coat of arms.

Q: does he think he has one?

A: No, "Why, Mars Tom, I hain't got no coat o' arm;||"Why, Mars Tom, I hain't got no coat o' arm;

Q: do they all have one?

A: No, Oh, you don't understand, Jim; a coat of arms is very different." "Well," I says, "Jim's right, anyway, when he says he ain't got no coat of arms, because he hain't."||Oh, you don't understand, Jim; a coat of arms is very different." "Well," I says, "Jim's right, anyway, when he says he ain't got no coat of arms, because he hain't."

Q: who is right?

A: Jim||"Well," I says, "Jim's right

Q: who filed way?

A: Jim||So whilst me and Jim filed away

Q: at what?

A: At the pens||So whilst me and Jim filed away at the pens on a brickbat apiece

Q: on what?

A: on a brickbat||So whilst me and Jim filed away at the pens on a brickbat apiece,


Summary: MAKING them pens was a distressid tough job, and so was the saw; and Jim allowed the inscription was going to be the toughest of all.That's the one which the prisoner has to scrabble on the wall.But he had to have it; Tom said he'd GOT to; there warn't no case of a state prisoner not scrabbling his inscription to leave behind, and his coat of arms.Jim says: "Why, Mars Tom, I hain't got no coat o' arm; I hain't got nuffn but dish yer ole shirt, en you knows I got to keep de journal on dat.""Oh, you don't understand, Jim; a coat of arms is very different.""Well," I says, "Jim's right, anyway, when he says he ain't got no coat of arms, because he hain't."So whilst me and Jim filed away at the pens on a brickbat apiece, Jim a-making his'n out of the brass and I making mine out of the spoon, Tom set to work to think out the coat of arms.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER IX THE BATTLE IN THE PLAIN The distance from the bottom of the funnel to the floor of the chamber beneath it could not have been great, for all three of the victims of Tario's wrath alighted unscathed. Carthoris, still clasping Thuvia tightly to his breast, came to the ground catlike, upon his feet, breaking the shock for the girl. Scarce had his feet touched the rough stone flagging of this new chamber than his sword flashed out ready for instant use. But though the room was lighted, there was no sign of enemy about. Carthoris looked toward Jav. The man was pasty white with fear. "What is to be our fate?" asked the Heliumite. "Tell me, man! Shake off your terror long enough to tell me, so I may be prepared to sell my life and that of the Princess of Ptarth as dearly as possible." "Komal!" whispered Jav. "We are to be devoured by Komal!" "Your deity?" asked Carthoris. The Lotharian nodded his head. Then he pointed toward a low doorway at one end of the chamber. "From thence will he come upon us. Lay aside your puny sword, fool. It will but enrage him the more and make our sufferings the worse." Carthoris smiled, gripping his long-sword the more firmly. Presently Jav gave a horrified moan, at the same time pointing toward the door. "He has come," he whimpered. Carthoris and Thuvia looked in the direction the Lotharian had indicated, expecting to see some strange and fearful creature in human form; but to their astonishment they saw the broad head and great-maned shoulders of a huge banth, the largest that either ever had seen.


Q: Who fell from one floor to the one under it?

A: all three of the victims|| for all three of the victims of Tario's wrath alighted unscathed.

Q: Who was mad at them?

A: Tario||the victims of Tario's wrath

Q: What or who was Carthoris holding?

A: Thuvia||Carthoris, still clasping Thuvia tightly to his breast

Q: Was that a girl?

A: yes||breaking the shock for the girl

Q: How did Carthoris land?

A: catlike||came to the ground catlike

Q: Had it been a long drop?

A: no, it could not have been great||it could not have been great

Q: What did Carthoris do as soon as he touched down?

A: drew his sword||his sword flashed out

Q: Did he see anybody to use it on?

A: no, there was no sign of enemy about. || there was no sign of enemy about.

Q: Well was there enough light to see?

A: yes||But though the room was lighted

Q: Did he then ask a question?

A: yes||What is to be our fate?" asked the Heliumite

Q: Of whom?

A: Jav||Carthoris looked toward Jav

Q: Was Jav afraid?

A: yes||Jav. The man was pasty white with fear.

Q: How afraid?

A: he was pasty white with fear|| The man was pasty white with fear

Q: What did Jav think was going to happen to them?

A: they would be devoured by Komal||whispered Jav. "We are to be devoured by Komal!

Q: Did Jav think it was a good idea forn Carthoris to use his sword?

A: no, Lay aside your puny sword, fool||Lay aside your puny sword, fool

Q: Why not?

A: it would just enrage him more||Lay aside your puny sword, fool. It will but enrage him the more

Q: So did Carthoris take his advice?

A: no, Carthoris smiled, gripping his long-sword the more firmly. ||Carthoris smiled, gripping his long-sword the more firmly.

Q: What did he do instead?

A: he gripped his long-sword more firmly||Carthoris smiled, gripping his long-sword the more firmly

Q: What was the expression on his face?

A: he smiled||Carthoris smiled, gripping his long-sword the more firmly.

Q: Did the Komal come?

A: yes||He has come," he whimpered.


Summary: CHAPTER IX THE BATTLE IN THE PLAIN The distance from the bottom of the funnel to the floor of the chamber beneath it could not have been great, for all three of the victims of Tario's wrath alighted unscathed.Carthoris, still clasping Thuvia tightly to his breast, came to the ground catlike, upon his feet, breaking the shock for the girl.Scarce had his feet touched the rough stone flagging of this new chamber than his sword flashed out ready for instant use.But though the room was lighted, there was no sign of enemy about.Carthoris looked toward Jav.The man was pasty white with fear."What is to be our fate?""We are to be devoured by Komal!"It will but enrage him the more and make our sufferings the worse."Carthoris smiled, gripping his long-sword the more firmly.Carthoris and Thuvia looked in the direction the Lotharian had indicated, expecting to see some strange and fearful creature in human form; but to their astonishment they saw the broad head and great-maned shoulders of a huge banth, the largest that either ever had seen.

source: gutenberg

CHAPTER XXXI. NELLIE ARDELL'S TROUBLES. On the following morning Jerry went to work at the bindery as if nothing had happened. When he went in, Dick Lanning glared at our hero and stopped as if to speak, but changed his mind and walked off without saying a word. During the day the young oarsman became much better acquainted with his work and began to like it. That night, on leaving the bindery by the side entrance, which opened on a narrow lane, our hero saw Dick Lanning and several of his friends waiting for him. He attempted to pass but Lenning put out his foot, and had Jerry not stopped he would have been tripped up. "Let me pass," said he, sharply, but instead of complying, Lenning took a stand in front of him and hit the youth on the shoulder. "I said I'd git square," he hissed, savagely. "If yer ain't afraid, stand up and fight." "I'm not afraid," replied Jerry, and pushed him up against the wall. Without delay a rough-and-tumble fight ensued. "Give it to him, Dick!" "Do the hayseed up!" "Knock him into the middle of next week!" These and a dozen other cries arose on the air, and the crowd kept increasing until fully a hundred spectators surrounded the pair. Dick Lanning had caught Jerry unfairly, but the youth soon managed to shake him off, and, hauling back, gave him a clean blow on the end of his unusually long nose, which caused the blood to spurt from that organ in a stream.


Q: Are the two men in this passage friends?

A: no, "I said I'd git square," he hissed, savagely. ||"I said I'd git square," he hissed, savagely.

Q: Who is the 'villain' in this scenario?

A: Dick Lanning||our hero saw Dick Lanning

Q: And the hero?

A: Jerry||Jerry went to work at the bindery as if nothing had happened.

Q: Where do they work at?

A: the bindery||n leaving the bindery

Q: Did the two men go dancing after work?

A: no, Dick Lanning and several of his friends waiting for him. || Dick Lanning and several of his friends waiting for him.

Q: What happened then?

A: they fight||Without delay a rough-and-tumble fight ensued

Q: Is Dick Lanning alone?

A: no, Dick Lanning and several of his friends waiting for him. ||Dick Lanning and several of his friends waiting for him.

Q: Who is with him?

A: several of his friends||ick Lanning and several of his friends waiting for him.

Q: Where were they waiting at?

A: outside work||hat night, on leaving the bindery by the side entrance, which opened on a narrow lane

Q: Was the conflict witnessed by anyone?

A: yes||These and a dozen other cries arose on the air,

Q: How many people saw this?

A: a hundred||a hundred spectators surrounded

Q: Was Dick a fair fighter?

A: no, Dick Lanning had caught Jerry unfairly||Dick Lanning had caught Jerry unfairly

Q: Did the hero hold his own ground though?

A: yes||ut the youth soon managed to shake him off


Summary: On the following morning Jerry went to work at the bindery as if nothing had happened.That night, on leaving the bindery by the side entrance, which opened on a narrow lane, our hero saw Dick Lanning and several of his friends waiting for him."I said I'd git square," he hissed, savagely.Without delay a rough-and-tumble fight ensued.These and a dozen other cries arose on the air, and the crowd kept increasing until fully a hundred spectators surrounded the pair.Dick Lanning had caught Jerry unfairly, but the youth soon managed to shake him off, and, hauling back, gave him a clean blow on the end of his unusually long nose, which caused the blood to spurt from that organ in a stream.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- He armors himself, keeps other people guessing and likes to wear a mask. Christian Bale is known as a hard worker who immerses himself in his characters. Batman? Try Christian Bale. Though in his case the armor and mask are metaphorical, the 34-year-old "Dark Knight" star likes to keep his personal life as shadowy as a superhero's back story. He's been known to keep a low profile -- "You will never see me at a party," he told the Times of London -- and delights in concocting stories about his life. "I make up [things]," he told Details magazine earlier this year. "Absolutely. I'm an actor -- I'm not a politician. I always kick myself when I talk too much about family, or personal things. I'll enjoy chatting now and then later I'll regret it." But with the explosive impact of "The Dark Knight" -- the film has set box office records in the 10 days since its release, becoming the fastest film to reach the $300 million mark in history -- and the forthcoming release of the fourth "Terminator," which will star Bale, he may find his privacy limited. ("The Dark Knight" is a Warner Bros. film. The studio, like CNN, is a unit of Time Warner.) "Can he stand the glare of the spotlight?" a rival studio executive asked Entertainment Weekly. "Being put in major roles and major films?" Already there are signs that Bale has made the jump from actor to movie star. Last week, news of an alleged hotel-room tussle between the actor, his mother and his sister made headlines around the world. Bale, who has denied the allegations, described the incident as "a deeply personal matter" and asked the media to "respect my privacy in the matter" at a press conference. Watch the latest on the incident »


Q: Which film reached $300 mil the fastest?

A: The Dark Knight||The Dark Knight

Q: Who is the star?

A: Christian Bale||Christian Bale

Q: is another movie he is in mentioned?

A: YEs.||Terminator,

Q: what is it?

A: Terminator||Terminator

Q: is he a person who talks about himself a lot?

A: No.|| He's been known to keep a low profile

Q: does he tell the truth about himself?

A: Not all of the time.||I make up [things]

Q: what does he do instead?

A: I make up [things]||I make up [things]

Q: is he a sloth or a hard worker?

A: hard worker|| hard worker

Q: is he a partier?

A: No.||You will never see me at a party,

Q: who did he tell that he never goes to them?

A: Times of London||Times of London

Q: is he happy when he tells family stories?

A: Yes, then regretful||I'll enjoy chatting now and then later I'll regret it."

Q: who is the studio behind The Dark Knight?

A: Warner Bros. film||Warner Bros. film

Q: is that a part of a larger company?

A: Yes.||unit of Time Warner.

Q: which one?

A: Time Warner||Time Warner

Q: does anyone doubt his ability to cope with being in the spotlight?

A: Yes.||Can he stand the glare of the spotlight?

Q: who?

A: a rival studio executive||a rival studio executive

Q: from which studio?

A: unknown||unknown

Q: which agency did the exec say that to?

A: Entertainment Weekly||Entertainment Weekly

Q: what scandal hit the news last week?

A: hotel-room tussle between the actor, his mother and his sister||hotel-room tussle between the actor, his mother and his sister

Q: did he affirm the reports?

A: No.|| Bale, who has denied the allegations


Summary: (CNN) -- He armors himself, keeps other people guessing and likes to wear a mask.Christian Bale is known as a hard worker who immerses himself in his characters.He's been known to keep a low profile -- "You will never see me at a party," he told the Times of London -- and delights in concocting stories about his life."I make up [things]," he told Details magazine earlier this year.I'll enjoy chatting now and then later I'll regret it."But with the explosive impact of "The Dark Knight" -- the film has set box office records in the 10 days since its release, becoming the fastest film to reach the $300 million mark in history -- and the forthcoming release of the fourth "Terminator," which will star Bale, he may find his privacy limited.The studio, like CNN, is a unit of Time Warner.)"Can he stand the glare of the spotlight?"a rival studio executive asked Entertainment Weekly."Being put in major roles and major films?"Last week, news of an alleged hotel-room tussle between the actor, his mother and his sister made headlines around the world.Bale, who has denied the allegations, described the incident as "a deeply personal matter" and asked the media to "respect my privacy in the matter" at a press conference.

source: cnn

(CNN) -- The United States is deeply concerned about the well-being of Eman al-Obeidy, according to a State Department source, and worked closely with officials in Europe and Libya to get her safely out of the country. The same source said the U.S. is "prepared to provide whatever help and support Eman may need." Al-Obeidy grabbed the world's attention this spring when she accused Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi's security forces of gang-raping her. She is now on the way to Malta with her father, according to another high-level U.S. State Department source. She will eventually head to a processing center in Europe before leaving for a final destination. She has told CNN on repeated occasions that she wants to go to the United States. One of the State Department sources told CNN that Secretary of State Hillary Clinton "has been deeply interested in the case and has followed it throughout." Al-Obeidy was in Qatar awaiting resettlement as a refugee when she was deported Thursday and sent back to Libya. She was reportedly beaten before being deported. Najah Dawaji, a U.S.-based Libyan pro-freedom activist, said she was with three key members of Libya's Transitional National Council when they first learned that al-Obeidy was forced from Doha and arrived in Benghazi, Libya, on Thursday. She said al-Obeidy had a black eye, bruises on her legs and scratches on her arms. Al-Obeidy told a journalist that officials in the Transitional National Council had pressured the Qataris to expel her. But, according to Dawaji, she did not blame the rebel group for the beating itself.


Q: Who was reportedly beaten before being deported?

A: Al-Obeidy||Al-Obeidy was in Qatar awaiting resettlement as a refugee when she was deported Thursday and sent back to Libya. She was reportedly beaten before being deported.

Q: Why was she in Qatar?

A: Awaiting resettlement as a refugee||Al-Obeidy was in Qatar awaiting resettlement as a refugee

Q: On what day?

A: Thursday||Al-Obeidy was in Qatar awaiting resettlement as a refugee when she was deported Thursday

Q: Where was she sent back to?

A: Libya||Al-Obeidy was in Qatar awaiting resettlement as a refugee when she was deported Thursday and sent back to Libya

Q: When did Al-Obeidy grab the world's attention?

Summary: (CNN) -- The United States is deeply concerned about the well-being of Eman al-Obeidy, according to a State Department source, and worked closely with officials in Europe and Libya to get her safely out of the country.Al-Obeidy grabbed the world's attention this spring when she accused Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi's security forces of gang-raping her.She is now on the way to Malta with her father, according to another high-level U.S. State Department source.Al-Obeidy was in Qatar awaiting resettlement as a refugee when she was deported Thursday and sent back to Libya.Najah Dawaji, a U.S.-based Libyan pro-freedom activist, said she was with three key members of Libya's Transitional National Council when they first learned that al-Obeidy was forced from Doha and arrived in Benghazi, Libya, on Thursday.Al-Obeidy told a journalist that officials in the Transitional National Council had pressured the Qataris to expel her.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


source: wikipedia

Hanoi ( or ; , ) is the capital of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and the country's second largest city by population. Its population in 2009 was estimated at 2.6 million for urban districts and 7 million for the metropolitan jurisdiction. The population in 2015 was estimated at 7.7 million people. From 1010 until 1802, it was the most important political centre of Vietnam. It was eclipsed by Huế, the imperial capital of Vietnam during the Nguyễn Dynasty (1802–1945), but Hanoi served as the capital of French Indochina from 1902 to 1954. From 1954 to 1976, it was the capital of North Vietnam, and it became the capital of a reunified Vietnam in 1976, after the North's victory in the Vietnam War. The city lies on the right bank of the Red River. Hanoi is north of Ho Chi Minh City and west of Hai Phong city. October 2010 officially marked 1000 years since the establishment of the city. The Hanoi Ceramic Mosaic Mural is a 4 km ceramic mosaic mural created to mark the occasion. Hanoi (, "inside (the) river") has had many official and unofficial names throughout history. Hanoi has been inhabited since at least 3000 BC. The Cổ Loa Citadel in Dong Anh district served as the capital of the Âu Lạc kingdom founded by the Shu emigrant Thục Phán after his 258 BC conquest of the native Văn Lang.


Q: When was Hanoi first inhabited?

A: 3000 BC|| Hanoi has been inhabited since at least 3000 BC

Q: What did October 2010 mark?

A: 1000 years since the establishment of the city||October 2010 officially marked 1000 years since the establishment of the city

Q: What was made to honor the occasion?

A: The Hanoi Ceramic Mosaic Mural||The Hanoi Ceramic Mosaic Mural is a 4 km ceramic mosaic mural created to mark the occasion.

Q: How large is it?

A: 4 km||The Hanoi Ceramic Mosaic Mural is a 4 km ceramic mosaic mural created to mark the occasion.

Q: What is it the capital of?

A: Socialist Republic of Vietnam||Hanoi ( or ; , ) is the capital of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam

Q: Does it have a large population?

A: 7.7 million people||The population in 2015 was estimated at 7.7 million people

Q: What does it rank for the country's population?

A: second largest city||country's second largest city by population

Q: What was significant from the years 1010 to 1802?

A: it was the most important political centre of Vietnam||From 1010 until 1802, it was the most important political centre of Vietnam

Q: What was Hue?

A: the imperial capital of Vietnam during the Nguyễn Dynasty|| the imperial capital of Vietnam during the Nguyễn Dynasty

Q: What years were the Nguyen Dynasty?

A: 1802–1945||Nguyễn Dynasty (1802–1945),

Q: What was Hanoi the capitol of from 1902 to 1954?

A: French Indochina||Hanoi served as the capital of French Indochina from 1902 to 1954

Q: What about 1954 to 1976?

A: it was the capital of North Vietnam||, it was the capital of North Vietnam,

Q: What does the city lie to the right of?

A: right bank of the Red River||The city lies on the right bank of the Red Rive

Q: What is it north of?

A: Ho Chi Minh City||Hanoi is north of Ho Chi Minh City and west of Hai Phong city

Q: And west of?

A: Hai Phong city||west of Hai Phong city.


Summary: Hanoi ( or ; , ) is the capital of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and the country's second largest city by population.The population in 2015 was estimated at 7.7 million people.From 1010 until 1802, it was the most important political centre of Vietnam.It was eclipsed by Huế, the imperial capital of Vietnam during the Nguyễn Dynasty (1802–1945), but Hanoi served as the capital of French Indochina from 1902 to 1954.From 1954 to 1976, it was the capital of North Vietnam, and it became the capital of a reunified Vietnam in 1976, after the North's victory in the Vietnam War.The city lies on the right bank of the Red River.Hanoi is north of Ho Chi Minh City and west of Hai Phong city.October 2010 officially marked 1000 years since the establishment of the city.The Hanoi Ceramic Mosaic Mural is a 4 km ceramic mosaic mural created to mark the occasion.Hanoi has been inhabited since at least 3000 BC.
